Title: Now, it is a total lockdown at Bengaluru’s apartment complexes
Content: For many Bengalureans, living in a big apartment society also translates to easy access to lifestyle amenities, such as multi-sport facilities, swimming pools, childrens’ parks and more. A day off from work or school offered plenty of options to stay engaged and active without having to step out of the complex. This week, however, in their effort to follow the government order on partial shutdown of day-to-day activities, there has been a clamp on most of these privileges. Several housing societies in the city are working round-the-clock to ensure that the health and safety of residents is paramount and are taking extra measures to maintain status quo.When early news of the Coronavirus in Karnataka began doing the rounds, the first thing that the residents association at SNN Raj Serenity in Yelenahalli did was to close access to the swimming pool — a move that was later part of the government directive as well. Crucial safety measures taken at most of the apartment complexes too, have been on similar lines.“There is no access to the gym or the sports courts, or even the clubhouse. We have stopped entry for personal trainers and sports coaching staff as well,” Pretheesh Unni, a member of the managing committee at the complex.Apart from sanitation measures, apartment complexes are looking at screening residents and visitors for potential symptoms of the virus at the entrance of the building. Complex management has also invested in infrared thermometers that are being used to check the temperatures of everyone entering the building.“Our apartment management sent us all declaration forms that we had to enter and sign up — anyone with a recent foreign travel history had to declare the same and also observe self-quarantine for 28 days — irrespective of whether they show symptoms of carrying the virus or not,” says a resident of a complex located in south Bengaluru.Yet another resident of Elita Promenade, in JP Nagar, says, “All the elevators in all the 17 blocks in the complex are being sanitised twice every day. Access to any of the ‘social’ areas that is otherwise open to all residents have been shut. Frequent sanitising and social distancing the norm.”At Bhartiya City, on Thanisandra Main Road, visitors, vendors, delivery agents, maids and cooks are being allowed into the premises only after being debriefed about their health status. “Disinfectants are sprayed frequently in common areas, with major focus on places like doorknobs, stairs banisters, lift buttons, common washrooms, etc., to mitigate spread of COVID-19. Staff has been sensitised, briefed and instructed to avoid shaking hands, hugs, high-fives or any physical contact with others, especially those who are sick,” reads a statement issued by the agency handling affairs at the Bhartiya City.With restrictions in place for a mandatory period of at least 10 days, which began over the weekend, this sense of panic that is currently prevalent among most Bengalureans, is more than evident.(With inputs by Sunayana.Suresh@timesgroup.com)

Title: Ever considered a voluntary career as Bengaluru's bicycle councillor?
Content: It looks like Bengaluru is ready to up its game, as far as bicycling is concerned. Plans are afoot to introduce the concept of bicycle councillors who will help make our city more cycle friendly.So far, the authorities have done their bit to spread awareness about the advantages of cycling. But just awareness on the matter does not seem to be doing the trick.“Over the last six years, there have been rallies, awareness programmes and even as many as 500 cycle days that have been organised in the city. But we realise we need macro-level programmes to get everyone’s attention. This concept of introducing cycle councillors is the first of its kind in the country, and probably the first in the world too,” explains Sathya Sankaran, the Bicycle Mayor of Bengaluru, of the programme that was recently announced by Deputy Chief Minister CN Ashwath Narayan.“With bicycle councillors, we hope to be able to move beyond the concept of awareness and into a more solutions and action-oriented system. There are 198 wards in the city and each councillor will be required to analyse what it would take to make their wards cycling friendly. They will then engage with BBMP and other civic authorities and come up with solutions. They will also be required to adhere to a set of goals — the main one being to increase the number of cyclists on our roads by 20% by the year 2030. Councillors need to come up with innovative and achievable plans to help achieve this goal,” he explains.

Title: Kerala campuses give saris a dhoti makeover
Content:
Campuses have always been on the lookout for cool new ways to drape saris. Guess what’s the latest style that has won over Kerala colleges? The dhoti style! Be it in reunions, college fests, dance programmes or random events, girls can be seen pulling off this look with ease, pairing it up with shirts, jackets, long tops, what not. And the girls tell us why they love the style so much.

‘Gives traditional sari look an unconventional twist’

Ramzana Sulfikar

B Com third year student

National College of Arts and Science, Thiruvananthapuram

As a hijabi, I love the dhoti style in sari as I always get the compliment, ‘You look like Aladdin’s princess in this look.’ I try it with belts, trendy shirts, bell-bottomed blouse (the ones with huge sleeves) and more. I also love to complete the look with a good pair of shades, which gives the traditional sari look a totally unconventional twist.

‘Keeps the sari in place’

Kripa Anna Cherian

Architecture third year student

Marian College of Architecture and Planning, Thiruvananthapuram

All you need is a comfy pants or leggings to try this sari style! It keeps the sari in place, and can even style it with chunky boots, large chain statement necklaces and more. I had worn in on our college day and the look helped me win our fashion show too!

‘Its vibe changes with the material you pick’

Rukmini Shafi

BHM second year student

Lourdes Matha Institute of Hotel Management and Catering Technology, Thiruvananthapuram

The dhoti style gives saris a different kind of elegance and vibe, as per the material one picks. In traditional functions, it looks best in crop tops or those with embroidery. For a modern look, one can pick offbeat colours or accessorize saris with hoop earrings, bangles and the like. I like to wear polka dot saris in dhoti style with a good hair band or bow, which gives a classy vintage look.

‘I learnt the style from Youtube in five minutes’

Thazneem.L

Second year diploma student

Government Commerce Institute, Thiruvananthapuram

The dhoti style might look complicated, but infact, I learnt to drape it like this in five minutes! Personally, I like to exude a gypsy attitude and love it when my clothes reflect it. While the usual sari look doesn’t give it, dhoti style nails it. And what’s more, you can grab any sari and get into the look. I would say it’s the coolest look in 2020.

Story by Nyshma R

Third year B A Journalism student

Mar Ivanios College, Thiruvananthapuram

Title: Have fond memories of Chennai; can’t wait to be back in the city
Content: For Aditya Dhar and Madhu C Narayanan , 2019 had been a great year. Their directorial debuts — the Hindi film Uri: The Surgical Strike and the Malayalam movie Kumbalangi Nights respectively — went on to impress both the critics and the audiences alike, and also set the cash registers ringing. This year, the films continue their winning streak by landing the filmmakers the Gollapudi Srinivas National Award 2019. Reportedly, this is the first time that two directors have jointly won the Best Debut Director honour.“It’s one of highest honours for any debutant director. I feel truly honoured to receive the award. Considering that I’m sharing it with Madhu is amazing because he is a brilliant talent. I feel honoured and humbled,” says Aditya, who recently won the National Award for the Best Director for the Vicky Kaushal-starrer Uri.Madhu adds, “This is a national-level award, and a prestigious one. When I was told I’d won it this year, I was quite excited and even watched videos of the previous editions.”Both of them have fond memories of Chennai, and tell us that they can’t wait to be back here again. “One of my gurus, Priyan sir (director Priyadarshan) is based out of Chennai. Of course, it’s been really long since I came down there, but it’s my most favourite city in the country. I’m looking forward to being there again,” Aditya says.“I used to frequent Chennai as an assistant director because most of our film-related work used to happen here. In fact, I watched the final cut of Kumbalangi Nights in Chennai,” Madhu tells us with a smile.

Title: Ajmal attends workshop with Netrikann’s team
Content: After Devi 2, Ajmal Ameer will be seen next in Milind Rau ’s Netrikann , which has Nayanthara in the lead. Tipped to be a thriller, with Nayan playing a visually-impaired girl, Ajmal, too, will be seen essaying an important role in the film. “The story revolves around these two characters. It is a thriller and there will be a lot of twists and turns in the story, and yet, we will have a beautiful story woven around it,” he begins.On bagging this role, Ajmal says, “I had seen Milind’s Aval. I loved the film and congratulated him on making such a technically brilliant movie. I even expressed my desire to work with him on his next. Luckily, he called me when he was working on this script. I confirmed it even before I listened to the narration. Once I heard the script, I was even more kicked about this film.”Ajmal started shooting last week. “I started shooting with Nayanthara on the first day itself. Right now, we have stopped the shooting owing to Coronascare. But whatever little I worked with the team, I can say that they are a hardworking bunch, who didn’t waste even a single minute. Right now, we are doing workshops,” he says.

Title: Actor-filmmaker Imtiaz Khan passes away
Content: Senior actor-filmmaker Imtiaz Khan passed away in Mumbai on Monday. He was 77. Imtiaz was the brother of late actor Amjad Khan and son of yesteryear actor Jayant. He is survived by his wife Krutika Desai , a popular film and television actress, and daughter Ayesha Khan BT spoke to Krutika, who said, “It all happened so suddenly that I don’t even know what I am feeling. Imtiaz complained of breathlessness on Monday, following which our family doctor visited him. He was given some medicines and soon after, he complained of severe shoulder pain. The doctor then gave him an injection. When I came back to the bedroom after seeing off the doctor, he looked at me and said, ‘Kuka, I am going’. And that was it, he passed away peacefully.”

Title: Salons in the state mask up to combat deadly #COVID19
Content:
As we try to combat the deadly virus that’s spreading fast, unprecedented lifestyle changes all around us seem... Read More

As we try to combat the deadly virus that’s spreading fast, unprecedented lifestyle changes all around us seem to be the norm. In a span of a few weeks, everyone has learnt new hashtags that are going to stay with us for lives —- #COVID19, #CoronaVirus, and #SocialDistancing. The last hashtag has emerged as the best bet to beat the virus, as people withdraw into their homes, and mass congregation places like malls, theatres, parks, etc have been locked down upon government order.

But what happens to those things that we all, till now, used to do without a second thought? Like going to the salon for a haircut or facial? These are close contact places and hotbeds for spreading the virus. But salon owners in the state aver they’re ready and all prepped to deal with this, though some moan the dip in business.

SANITISING IS PRIORITY

“I have made it mandatory to disinfect all our salons either after every use, or on an hourly basis,” says Sam Paul of the Toni and Guy chain of salons. “We wipe down chairs, countertops and the entrance door after every hour/every use with disinfectants. Every person in the salon has to wear a mask and gloves when servicing customers and we’ve also begun handing out free masks and sanitisers to our customers.”

“All the implements used are electronically sanitised — this is a standard procedure at our place, but now, we have intensified monitoring this process. We are trying to get temperature screens installed across all our salons at the earliest,” adds Sam.

Muthu Kumar, hairstylist from B Blunt Nungambakkam, adds, “We’re much more cautious when we work with clients now. We anyway use hand sanitiser when men and women come for haircuts, but now, we’ve made it mandatory for the clients to wash their hands, and use sanitiser. Scissors, combs and other hair cutting instruments are usually washed and sterilised after every service, but now, we are ultra-careful about not leaving them lying outside.”

Celebrity makeup artiste, Ibrahim, says that working with gloves on gets uncomfortable. “But I will wear a mask. We generally wash our hands before and after every service and carry a hand sanitiser. We do a shampoo of the brushes immediately after every use, and sponges, powder pads, lashes, etc., are use and throw.”

Veena Kumaravel of Naturals tells us how her chain of parlours are being cleaned thoroughly and the equipment, chairs, and floors are being disinfected periodically. “We’ve been sterilising the instruments right in front of the customers for the last one week. We’ve stopped threading service since there is a risk of the beautician breathing into the face of the customer. We’re ensuring that our staff is not put at risk, too. We’ve been screening them for the last one week for symptoms. We have advised our staff to be extra cautious with customers who have returned from abroad. The staff are asked to wear gloves and masks for pedicures and manicures,” she adds.

Manoj Samuel from Vurve Signature Salon, says, “We’re taking every step to ensure staff and customers stay safe. We’ve told the staff to take a day off and consult a doctor if they aren’t feeling okay. We’ve asked them to avoid eating outside/ ordering food from outside. Salon kits are cleaned with alcohol swabs after each use and put in a UV box. We’ve moved from fragrance-based solutions to disinfectants for cleaning the floors and we’ve told our valets to wear gloves and masks since they handle cars of different customers.”

Travel Woes of Celebrity makeup artistes

For Ibrahim, travelling is a big worry. “I have a wedding makeup booked for March 21 & 22 in Tirupur and Erode, respectively. This was booked some time ago, and I can’t cancel; the client, too, checked with me as to whether I would be able to make it. So, I will be driving down. Actually, for makeup artistes, travelling via flight is anyway an exhausting procedure. The number of products and implements we carry usually requires multiple security checks. Since both the weddings are in Tamil Nadu, I will be taking my car and I don’t risk catching the virus,” he adds. Manoj Samuel, who owns salons, tells us they’ve been making discreet inquiries about whether the customer has travelled abroad. “When they call to fix appointments, we tell them in a friendly way that they can reschedule if they are feeling unwell. It’s a bit sensitive but important to let them know,” says Manoj.

Beauty Business is down

Freelancer Abhirami, who does salon services at clients’ homes, says that she wants to do a self-quarantine of sorts and reduce the number of clients she takes on till this COVID-19 threat is over. “Since I do all services, including threading and waxing, I come in close contact with the customer. I use gloves and masks to be on the safe side now, but I try not to take too many clients at the moment, as it’s not safe,” she says. “Not as much as I had predicted, but there has been a 25-30% dip in business,” says Sam. Muthu, however, says “Clients keep coming in as usual,” while Veena says, “The parlours at the malls are closed, and the footfall at the standalone ones has come down.” Manoj says that there’s certainly a dip in the number of clients walking in for the last one week. “Even as the best hygienic practices are followed, between the two cities — Bangalore and Chennai — where we have our salons, we’ve seen a steep dip in Bangalore so far. We presume it's because people have been working from home since last week there. We’ve to see how things turn out in Chennai, now,” he adds.

It’s better to do beauty treatments at home

I’m letting my hair grow; the rest of the things can be easily taken care of at home for us, men. I told my wife to get her beauty things from the cosmetics shop and do them at home — anyway both of us are grounded as the MNCs we have been working for has asked us to work from home. So time pass ke liye achcha hai — she can put on a face mask and still do Tally

—Rupesh Shah, an IT professional from OMR

I’m going for a clean-shaven look

Maintaining a beard is a task and frequent salon visits are a must. I now think a clean-shaven look is the best to avoid going to a salon for a while. I know I am going to look a bit unrecognisable once I shave off the beard – I’ve kept one for a long while, now. But I’ll blame it on #Coronascare. No matter how careful you are, you never know how hygienic the salon equipment are when customers keep walking in.

- Ashish Kumar, a youngster from Kotturpuram

Try homemade remedies

I went to a parlour on Harrington Road yesterday, and the lady refused to thread my eyebrows and upper lips. They’ve begun to use an epilator, now. The parlour girls usually hold one end of the thread in their mouth, and I immediately cursed myself for not figuring this out myself. So, spreading the word for other women — do not go for threading to the parlours, even if they haven’t stopped it by themselves. Try tweezing at home — ditto for other beauty treatments. Try homemade remedies

- Ramya Sivamani, a housewife from Chetpet

Title: Abin Abraham: I wish to be an international sportsman and a teacher, in the future
Content:
Abin loved playing cricket and sports since childhood. Following a surgery in 2011 when he was 14, the Kochi boy was paralysed down the right side, and even lost his memory and ability to speak for a few months.

But the braveheart has since slowly started regaining his abilities, though the right wrist and foot remain paralysed. The youngster, has not given up and tries to be as active as he can.

In the recently concluded State Para Athletics Championship that was held in Kochi, Abin, who is a first-time participant, came first in 1500 m, 100 m and long jump. The final year MCom student of Sacred Heart College , Thevara, tells us how he turned his disabilities into strengths.

“I couldn’t speak much after the surgery and have faced many issues because of it, but I used to be involved with social service activities. That’s where I met renowned para badminton player Neeraj George Baby,” says Abin, who is called ‘Abin Chill’ by friends, for his positive attitude. He explains, “He motivated me to practice para badminton and as took part in a badminton tournament selection. That’s where I met Fr Mathew Kiriyantha, who is the State Para Sports president. Following his encouragement I took part in the State Athletic Championship.” The athlete is now gearing up for his first national championship as well, which is scheduled to be held in Mysore in April. As he is a first-time participant, Abin does not have much-needed sponsorship to go for the event. “As my final year exam coincides with the preparations, I couldn’t try hard to get sponsorship,” says the sportsman.

While his prizes in the championship are for track events, Abin says, “Para badminton is my first love and that’s what I regularly practice. I am an SL3 category player. I am also a fan of players like Neeraj and P V Sindhu, and wish to be an international player someday. I also want a career and be independent, and love teaching profession the best.”

Title: Uncertainty looms as COVID-19 impacts placement drives at Bengaluru colleges
Content: Students and faculty members are a confused lot these day, thanks to the COVID-19 outbreak. With campuses being shut, it’s not just exams and other events that have been affected. Placement and internship drives have also taken a beating, after strict precautionary mandates were issued by the state government.For now, companies have been requested to push the dates for placement drives by a week “Ahead of these drives on campus, students take the psychometric test, which helps them understand their strengths and weaknesses. Currently, students have been asked to take the test from home,” says Kiran Jeevan, public relations officer at St Joseph’s College (Autonomous). Since some of the companies are not in a position to delay the recruit process for too long, they have agreed to conduct online and telephonic interviews, Kiran adds.With internships also in limbo, students say that things are a little chaotic at this moment. “Although we have been asked to study at home until the situation gets better, there are uncertainties over this year’s internship opportunities. Ideally, we should have started applying for those by now, as in most companies internships begin in May. We are not sure how to go about it now,” says Nanvi, a student of Srishti School of Design and Technology.Adding to this, Namrata (name changed), a student of Christ (deemed-to-be) University, says, “I had made elaborate plans for this summer, both for my holidays and internship. Now, all that has slipped out of gear.”

Title: Sruthi Hariharan to play a dancer in her comeback film
Content: In a twist of sorts, actress Sruthi Hariharan , who began her showbiz journey as a background dancer and inched her way up to lead roles, makes her filmi comeback playing a dancer. The as-yet-untitled thriller is being directed by actor Surya Vasishtha , who she has known since her Lucia days.Talking about the film, Surya says, “This is a film that I had written a while ago. I had, in fact, pitched it to Sruthi way back in 2016, and she had agreed to be a part of it. Unfortunately, the film did not take off then. And then Sruthi got busy with other commitments, marriage and motherhood. Now that she is set to return to films, I am glad that we are also ready to roll and Sruthi gets to play the protagonist in it. She plays a dancer named Maya, who is also a realist. The film has an ensemble cast that includes Deepak Subramanya , Shweta Gupta, Ravi Bhat, Ram Manjjonath , Pruthvi Banwasi and me. The story follows the emotional journeys, turmoils and the path to closure for these characters.”The film, adds Surya, will go on floors once it is safe to shoot again, given the current Coronavirus pandemic. “Ravi Kashyap, who backed Lucia, Sulle Sathya and Badmaash, is part of the project. We have Aparajith composing music for the film. We are looking at finishing the film in one extended schedule by May end if all goes as per our plans,” reveals Surya, adding that this will be an indie film made with a minimal crew.

Title: Juice Kudithiya singer ViRaj Kannadiga is set to release a party track
Content: Techie-singer ViRaj Kannadiga — who is best-known for his 2019 viral track, Juice Kudithiya — is all set to release a party number this year. Called Psych, the track’s got groovy beats, says the artiste, adding, “The song is about love at first sight — Avanu Psych Aaghogthaane, which roughly translates to ‘he becomes crazy in love’.”Last year, he had also released a motivational song, titled Fighter, and a Ganesha habba dance number, called Dhool. ViRaj was initially planning to release Psych as a New Year’s Eve party track, but it didn’t work out. Then, it was pushed to Valentine’s Day, plans for which also got stalled eventually. Now, finally, the team has zeroed in on an April release. The video will be shot by the end of this month, followed by post-production work. “Apart from this party number, I am hoping to be able to launch a few more new projects in 2020,” ViRaj signs off.

Title: FDA seizes sanitisers worth Rs 50 lakh in Aurangabad
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

AURANGABAD: The food and drug administration (FDA) sleuths raided a godown in the Waluj area on Sunday, where people were found removing stickers from expired hand sanitiser bottles and pasting new ones with higher MRP and new expiry dates.

The FDA joint commissioner informed the staff of Eurolife Healthcare situated in MIDC Waluj industrial area of Aurangabad was caught while they were replacing existing stickers with new stickers reading 2021 as their expiry date.

Citing preliminary probe carried out by FDA, an official said the seized sanitisers were found manufactured in Gujarat and the company where the raid was carried out markets the product. The total valuation of the seized articles was estimated at Rs 50 lakh. The raid that started on late Sunday evening, went on for hours, before an offence against the suspects was registered in the wee hours of Monday.

Title: Inter-school dance competition at SNBP
Content:
PUNE: SNBP School and College , Yerawada , organised an inter-school competition, titled, "Dance 2 Advance- Dancing Feet of SNBP", for SNBP institutes recently at the Morwadi branch.

The chief guests for the event were D K Bhosale, chairman, and Vrishali Bhosale, president of SNBP Educational Institutes .

The preliminary rounds had students from the five branches - Pimpri, Rahatani, Moshi, Wagholi, Chikhli, and Yerawada. Bollywood choreographers Akash Shetty, Subhash Dang and Sanjay Sawant were judges for the event.

The competition was held in group and solo categories. The first prize between Standard V to VII was bagged by SNBP International School, Chikhli, followed by SNBP International School, Rahatani, at the second position. Among Std VIII to XI, SNBP, Morwadi (state), Chikhli and Yerawada branches bagged the first, second and third prizes respectively.

In the solo dance competition, the winners were SNBP, Morwadi (Std I to IV), SNBP International School, Rahatani (Std V to VII) and SNBP School and Junior College, Yerawada (Std VIII to XI).

The school also organised an intra-school singing competition, titled, "Rising Star Voice of SNBP" recently. Students from all the five branches had participated in the competition. The judges were playback singers, Yogita Godbole and Mangesh Borgaonkar. The competitions were held in group and solo singing categories. The first and second prize in the group singing competition was bagged by SNBP International School, Rahatani (CBSE branch).

CM school cultivates miniature gardens

CM International School chose the theme "window gardening" for National Science Day celebrations recently.

The students sowed the seeds of different plants and observed the germination period, plant size, number of leaves grown among others.

Title: Laal Bindi singer Akull’s latest single releases today
Content:
Akull burst in on the music scene with his hit single, ‘Lal Bindi’, in 2018. The composer, singer-songwriter and producer’s second outing, ‘I Love You’, won him further appreciation and popularity from the audience. A VYRL Originals’ talent, he dons multiple hats with ease. He has been involved with every aspect of his latest single, ‘Laal Chunariya’, and also features as the protagonist in the video.

An upbeat song, ‘Laal Chunariya’ promises Akull’s distinctive swag, infused with a soundscape that highlights the shehnai. He says, “I am super excited to share ‘Laal Chunariya’ with my fans. I have also used guitars, drums andon piano to lend the track a youthful appeal. As someone born and brought up in Delhi, most of my works have a desi Punjabi touch. My songs can’t be bracketed in any particular genre and my fans say that I have a distinct lazy Pop swag.”

The video of ‘Laal Chunariya’ releases today at 11 am, on VYRL Originals’channel on a video-streaming platform and is out on all streaming platforms.

Meanwhile, Akull’s unique sound appeals to young audiences and has also caught the industry’s attention. He has worked with various artistes and also made his Bollywood debut as the music programmer for the title track of Malang. He says that 2020 will be a power-packed year for him, with multiple releases, Bollywood singing debut and also his maiden international collaboration.

Title: COVID-19 outbreak: Disney postpones the release date of Scarlett Johansson's 'Black Widow'
Content: Scarlett Johansson's 'Black Widow' is one of the anticipated films of the year. The film was supposed to hit the theatres in May. However now, Disney has postponed the release of the film.Due to COVID-19 pandemic, Disney had shifted the release dates of 'Mulan', 'The New Mutunts' and 'Antlers' but not 'Black Widow' hoping to release it on the scheduled date. But now, theatres have been shut down for the coming weeks due to Coronavirus outbreak, the makers of 'Black Widow' left with no option but to postpone the release.Well, multiple studios have made changes in the release dates in the wake of Coronavirus outbreak. 'Fast 9', James Bond flick 'No Time to Die' and 'A Quiet Place 2' are a few of them.Meanwhile, the virus has brought the whole world to a standstill. From countries shutting down their borders and flights to home quarantine, nations are taking all the necessary steps to contain the virus.The virus is massively impacting the world economy including the film industry. Film & TV production, shoots and more have been shut for a month at least. Celebs like Tom Hanks , his wife Rita Wilson, Idris Elba, Kristofer Hivju and Olga Kurylenko have been tested positive for COVID-19.

Title: #CoronaFear: The one time when being 'foreign-returned' isn't cool
Content: Have you recently returned from an exotic holiday? Before you spam your friends' timeline with your vacay pictures, think twice. With people in over 160 countries being infected with the coronavirus , those who have recently returned from a vacation are not only making sure they aren’t infected, but are also minimising their travel updates on social media. Families, relatives and friends, too, are ensuring a distance from them, and they’re being advised to stay away from offices.People are not just socially distancing themselves, but are ensuring that their friends or acquaintances are not bombarded with their vacation pictures. Ishan Bhattacharya, a CR Park resident who works with an IT service company in Noida, got married last month and for his honeymoon, the couple went to Italy. "We left for Italy on February 23 and were back in India on March 3. Even though it was a few weeks back, the situation was different. There wasn’t much awareness then. There were positive cases of the coronavirus, but people hadn’t realised the gravity of the situation yet," says Ishan.In the beginning, Ishan was sharing a lot of pictures with his wife on social media, but as the situation turned graver, he decided to limit his posts. "I realised it won't look good, and some may even find it insensitive." He added that while some of his relatives and friends have told him not meet them for at least two weeks, his office has asked him to work from home, at least till March 31.Prateek Bagga, a Rohini resident who works as a management consultant, shares that his friends decided to not meet him after he returned from his honeymoon in New Zealand. "We came back on March 7, but our stopovers were in Singapore and Thailand. Though we shared our honeymoon pictures online, I intentionally didn’t post any pictures from the Singapore or Thailand airports. My friends have been asking me whether I got myself checked or not. My family was concerned for us, and we made sure that we did not eat anything at these airports," he shared.Usually, when someone returns from a vacation, their friends can’t wait to hear all about it. However, in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak, the situation is different. Rajat Chopra, a South Extension – II resident and a businessman, says he has not only stopped going out after the coronavirus outbreak, but is also avoiding those who recently returned from abroad. "Two of my friends returned from Austria and Italy last month, and I haven’t met them yet. I will not meet them at least this month as well. I'm keeping a check on them through calls, but not meeting them to avoid any risk."Offices, too, are taking precautions while dealing with their employees who have travelled abroad. "For her honeymoon, my colleague had gone to Singapore. When she returned last week, we asked our HR to extend her leave period by two more weeks because she had a minor cold. Though she is fine, it is better that she gets herself checked, and she can join office later this month," shares Himanshi Manchanda*, who works at a software company in Gurgaon.People are not only not meeting those who came back from a vacation, but are avoiding tourist spots, too. "I am avoiding any place where I can find tourists, including malls and markets. I maintain a distance from people in public places, if at all I step out. If someone stands close to me, I make sure that I am wearing a mask or covering my face because no one really knows someone else's travel history," says Sujata Kumar, a Tagore Garden resident who studies at Delhi University.*Name changed on request

Title: Coronavirus death in Mumbai: 63-year-old man is India’s 3rd death, first in Maharashtra; another critical
Content: MUMBAI: Maharashtra on Tuesday recorded its first Covid-19 casualty — India’s third — with the death of a 63-year-old man who was undergoing treatment at Kasturba Hospital, Chinchpokli . Another patient undergoing treatment at Kasturba is said to be critical.Two more persons in the state — one from Mumbai and the other from Pune — also tested positive on Tuesday, taking the state’s count to 41.Of the 40 people now in public hospitals in the state, one is critical, seven have mild symptoms, and the rest are showing no symptoms. Twenty-six of the patients are men and 14 women.Civic officials said the new case in Mumbai is of a 49-year-old man from Ghatkopar who came back from the US on March 7. The latest case in Pune is of a 26-year-old man who also returned from the US on March 14.Civic officials said the senior citizen from Mumbai who died on Tuesday had high blood pressure, which, combined with inflammation of the heart muscles and an increased heart rate, contributed to his death. His wife and son, who too have tested positive, are currently under treatment at Kasturba and couldn’t attend his cremation.All ward-level officers and staffers at the Shivaji Park crematorium were provided masks, gloves and a gown. Complete with protective gear, the staffers completed all the formalities as the family members were asked to witness it from a distance. Sanitizers and disinfectants were also kept ready.The senior citizen had returned to the city from a business trip in Dubai on March 5. Three days later, he got admitted to Mahim’s P D Hinduja Hospital after developing symptoms. The doctors admitted him before suspecting coronavirus . They subsequently sent his samples to Kasturba Hospital, which came positive on March 12.The state’s 41st patient, and Mumbai’s eighth, who tested positive on Tuesday, had returned to the city on March 7 and reported to Kasturba Hospital after feeling unwell. Four of his close contacts have been admitted to Kasturba, while seven low-risk contacts have been home-quarantined. The latest Pune patient has been admitted to Bhosari hospital in Pimpri-Chinchwad There are currently 10 coronavirus patients in Pimpri-Chinchwad, eight in Pune, four in Yavatmal, three each in New Mumbai and Kalyan, and one each in Raigad, Thane, Ahmednagar and Aurangabad.

Title: Sensex sheds 811 pts, Nifty closes below 9k 1st time in 3 years
Content:
MUMBAI: The markets see-sawed on Tuesday as fears of a pandemic-led global recession kept investors jittery. Local institutions tried to support the sensex at lower levels but eventually failed. The index opened about 200 points higher, lost 800 points within the first hour, then rallied nearly 500 points but finally, due to a fag-end selloff, settled with a loss of 811 points, or 2.6%, at 30,579 — a three-year closing low. On the NSE, the Nifty lost 230 points, or 2.5%, to 8,967, its first closing below the 9K mark in the last three years.

The day’s selling was again led by foreign funds with a net outflow figure of Rs 4,045 crore, BSE data showed. Banking and financial services stocks were again at the forefront of the sell-off with ICICI Bank (down 9%), IndusInd Bank (8.9%) and Bajaj Finance (6.3%) among the top sensex laggards. Of the 30 sensex stocks, nine closed higher with HUL (up 3.5%) and Hero MotoCorp (3.1%) leading. The day’s selling also left investors poorer by Rs 2.1 lakh crore with BSE’s market capitalisation now almost at Rs 119 lakh crore.

With each passing the day, as the epidemic spreads across the world and market after market enters bear territory, the chances of a recession are growing. A report by global financial services major Morgan Stanley on Tuesday said the fallout was likely to trigger a global recession.

“With Covid-19 spreading in Europe and the US after hitting Asia, the disruptions and dislocations in the economy and markets will trigger a year-on-year contraction in global growth in the first half of 2020. However, the strong monetary and fiscal policy response under way will help to revive global growth from the third quarter of 2020,” the report said.

On Monday night, the Dow Jones index in the US had lost nearly 13%, its biggest rout in more than 30 years. In early trades on Tuesday, the UK and German markets were also deep in the red but recovered in late trades as the US markets rallied over 3% after opening. In India, too, the VIX, a gauge of volatility, reached a current peak of 63.4, NSE data showed.

Market players feel the volatility will continue for a while. According to Pankaj Bobade , head (fundamental research), Axis Securities, “Markets are expected to be volatile in the near term given the rise in new reported cases is outside mainland China than inside, marking a new milestone in the evolution of the global pandemic. As cases blow up in Europe and North America, fear is growing in Asia of the possibility of a second wave of infections from imported cases, which is driving risk aversion in markets globally.”

Title: Watch Video: Anushka Sharma takes up the #SafeHands challenge!
Content: The world is in a state of panic and going towards a complete shutdown due to the outbreak of Coronavirus . As of now, there is no cure for the same and the only way to be safe is by taking precautionary measures to avoid infection. World Health Organization has declared it as the pandemic and to spread the awareness, the even started a 'Safe Hands' challenge where they asked several celebs took share videos of how to wash hands properly.And now, Bollywood beauty Anushka Sharma took to her Instagram story to share the video. The actress looked pretty in casual attire while she explained the importance of washing hands. Check out the video here:Meanwhile, on the work front, the actress was last seen in Aanand L Rai 's 'Zero' co-starring Shah Rukh Khan and Katrina Kaif . The film was released in December 2018. The actress is yet to announce her next project.On the other hand, the pandemic has caused over 6,000 deaths worldwide.

Title: PM snubs MPs: House can’t be adjourned during crisis
Content: NEW DELHI: Prime Minister Narendra Modi on Tuesday took a dim view of the suggestion to adjourn Parliament because of the coronavirus outbreak and said MPs should not be seen as abdicating their responsibility as people’s representatives when so many others were attending to the call of duty at great risk to themselves.Addressing BJP MPs, Modi referred to the growing suggestion that Parliament should go into recess to help MPs dodge the virus. “What I have been hearing is not right. MPs should be seen to be in the front of the fight against the pandemic. We should think of the crew members of IAF and Air India who are evacuating Indians from countries hit by the epidemic, of the doctors and nurses who are treating patients, of the loaders who are handling the baggage of the evacuated... police. What if they also decide to take a break at this time?” the PM was quoted as saying by BJP MPs.Modi, whose address was applauded, made it clear that the ongoing Budget session scheduled till April 3 will not be curtailed. “We are representatives of the 130 crore people of the country,” he said.The PM also appreciated the role of electronic and print media in spreading awareness about Covid-19, parliamentary affairs minister Pralhad Joshi said.Modi expressed disappointment over missives by some MPs asking for curtailment of the session, Joshi said. The PM, who greeted all members with folded hands and “namaste”, also asked party MPs to visit their constituencies to spread awareness about coronavirus and ways to prevent it. Party MPs were allowed into the meeting venue at the Parliament library building after undergoing thermal screening.

Title: Trains Cancelled: Indian Railways stops, cuts frequency of 76 long-distance trains
Content:
NEW DELHI: At least 76 long-distance trains have been cancelled or their frequencies reduced from Wednesday till March-end due to low occupancy because of the coronavirus outbreak. Railways also advised all divisional railway managers on Tuesday to hike the price of platform tickets from Rs 10 to Rs 50 at important stations to prevent crowding.

Ministry officials said they were assessing the extent of cancellations even as they appealed to passengers “to avoid non-essential train journeys”. The ministry urged passengers to ensure they are not running a fever before commencing their journeys. An internal assessment done last week had found that the share of cancellation of confirmed tickets had increased from 17% to 30%.

Central Railway announced cancellation or reduced the frequency of 23 long-distance trains followed by South Central Railway (17 trains). Some of the trains that won’t operate from Wednesday include Mumbai-Pune Deccan Express , Howrah-Mumbai Duranto Express and Rajdhani Express from Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Terminus to New Delhi’s Hazrat Nizamuddin .

Content: Actor Arjun Kapoor, who is quite active on social media, has taken to his Instagram handle to share a happy video post recovering from COVID-19. He was tested positive for the deadly virus earlier and he was quarantined at his home.

Title: Coronavirus in Sri Lanka: Sri Lanka suspends all incoming international flights amid coronavirus fears
Content: COLOMBO: In view of the rising number of the novel coronavirus cases globally, Sri Lanka on Tuesday suspended all international flights arriving in the country.The deadly virus, which originated in China in December last year, has spread to 155 countries, infected 182,406 people and claimed 7,154 lives, according to the Johns Hopkins Coronavirus tracker.Sri Lanka so far has 29 confirmed coronavirus cases.President Gotabaya Rajapaksa 's office said a decision has been made to suspend all international flights arriving in the country with effect from 1500 hours on Tuesday due growing threat of the spread of the coronavirus.The government on Tuesday also extended the public holiday till March 19 to prevent the spread of the virus across the country. Earlier, it was declared for March 16.Although the state offices will remain closed, essential services such as food supplies and banks will continue to function, the information department said.The doctors' trade union has urged the president to order a complete lockdown of the country in order to facilitate the prevention operations.The government also announced the appointment of Lieutenant General Shavendra Silva , who is the chief of the Army, to head the National Operations Center for Prevention of Covid-19.The Army is already in charge of the quarantine Centers where the suspected cases are kept under observation.

Title: ‘Encouraging to see India’s efforts being led by highest political leadership’
Content:
As COVID-19 cases increase across the globe, WHO south-east Asia regional director

says the risk is very high even in India and a shift in testing strategy will be needed. Asserting that testing and isolating is critical, Singh tells Sushmi Dey that it is encouraging to see India’s efforts being led by the highest political leadership. Excerpts:

Positive cases of COVID-19 are increasing rapidly. How serious is the situation in your view?

Do you think India is on the right track as far as its strategy is concerned?

Do you think there is a need for India to move towards

testing now?

What are the measures required to tackle community transmission?

What is the possibility of community transmission in India, especially now that cases are increasing fast?

Do you think there is a need for lockdown in India?

Is India adequately equipped to handle the situation in case of an epidemic here?

How effective are the two anti-HIV drugs in treatment? Do you recommend their use?

How is the

related situation evolving in the region? Which are the countries doing better and do you expect cases to increase in near term?

What is the update on vaccine against coronavirus?

The risk of COVID-19 globally, including India, is very high. WHO is deeply concerned both by the alarming levels of global spread and severity of the disease. As of this morning, well over 1,60,000 cases have been reported from over 150 countries . These numbers have increased manifold in recent weeks, prompting WHO to characterise COVID-19 as a pandemic.It is very encouraging to see India’s efforts being led by the highest political leadership who continue to review the situation, preparedness and response. The country has been responding to the evolving situation. WHO has recommendations for countries preparing for the first case, the first cluster and community transmission and India’s containment plan is in line with it.India has been testing suspected cases and contacts of confirmed cases. We are aware that laboratory capacities have been augmented with many more laboratories now collecting samples. As the situation evolves a shift in the testing strategy will be needed. Now that countries report more cases as well as clusters, WHO recommends scaling up measures to detect, test, treat, isolate and trace contacts. Testing and isolating is critical to break the virus transmission.A: Community transmission means the source of infection is from the community as opposed to households or health facilities. As such the source is unclear. It requires a whole of society approach, where everyone has a role to play if transmission is to be slowed. To slow down transmission, everyone needs to practice hand hygiene, respiratory etiquette, and physical distancing from other people. Surveillance needs to be ramped up...For the sick, care needs to be prioritsed, with triage procedures activated.The situation is evolving rapidly. From the onset, WHO has been recommending all countries to prepare for the first cases of importation, first cluster as well as community transmission – with the risk of all three being real in all countries.Every country makes its own decision in terms of evolution of the outbreak and should decide to implement the most appropriate measures adapted to the local contexts. In particular, we encourage citizens to follow guidance from health authorities and reach out to support others. Practicing social distancing has been found to be effective to slow down transmission. Policies such as working from home can alleviate crowding in offices and public transport, and cut down risk of virus spread.WHO has been recommending all countries to scale-up emergency response mechanism. India has been taking measures which are effective in the current context. As the situation evolves, the country would need to scale up accordingly.So far, we have no evidence that any drug is effective. There are no specific treatments for this Covid-19 and treatment is based on clinical presentation. WHO recommends enrolling into a randomised controlled trial to test efficacy and safety of interventions. A master global clinical trial protocol for research and prioritisation of therapeutics is ongoing at WHO.Countries in the region are at various stages of response. While Thailand, Indonesia and India are dealing with clusters of transmission, there are also countries like Bhutan and Nepal with one case of importation and countries who are yet to get any case.So far WHO has received applications for review and approval of 40 diagnostic tests, 20 vaccines are in development and many clinical trials of therapeutics are underway. We expect the first results in a few weeks.Vaccines usually take several years. We were able to shorten that in the development to the vaccine for Ebola by harnessing global efforts. We are already working to do the same for COVID-19.

Title: Sunday market, night food courts closed
Content:
Guntur: Guntur Municipal Corporation ( GMC ) has decided to close down Sunday market to prevent the spread of coronavirus. The civic body also decided to close all night food markets in the city.

GMC commissioner C Anuradha directed the municipal health officer to take immediate measures to restrict street markets on Sunday.

Reviewing the situation with senior officials, the commissioner said that there should not be any let up in imposing curbs on crowded market places in the city.

Manny visit Sunday bazar in Arundelpet to buy a range of items-clothes to shoes to fancy articles. Almost half the main road in Arundelpet would be occupied by merchants to sell their wares.

The GMC commissioner directed the officials to close the night food bazar near Hindu College with immediate effect. She asked the officials to visit the malls and big shopping areas and advise them to take measures to screen visitors for coronavirus symptoms.

The commissioner also asked managements of hotels and lodges not to give accommodation to foreigners without consulting senior health department officials. She asked the hoteliers to screen even local visitors with thermal scanners before allowing them to occupy the rooms. “Although there is nothing to panic about the situation, we are taking precautionary measures to avoid troubles in the future,” said Anuradha.

Title: Bihar: Irate mob blocks NH-22 to protest girl’s murder
Content:
PATNA: An irate mob on Tuesday blocked NH-22 connecting Hajipur to Muzaffarpur and disrupted vehicular traffic for over three hours to protest the killing of a 16-year-old girl at Akhtiarpur Patedha village under the Sarai police station area in Vaishali district on Monday.

The victim, a Class IX student of a local government school, was attacked by her tormentor, Sudhanshu Kumar and his accomplices in her house around 8 am on Monday. She later succumbed to injuries. The deceased’s mother, younger brother and sister were also assaulted by the attackers when they tried to rescue her.

The deceased’s mother told police that Sudhanshu often used to harass her teenage daughter whenever she used to go to her coaching institute. On Monday also, Sudhanshu accosted and passed lewd comments. When she returned home from her coaching classes, Sudhanshu reached her house and started harassing her again. He also attacked her with a sharp substance when she resisted the molestation bid.

The victim’s family alleged that the Sarai police did not initiate action against the culprits and provided enough time to them to escape after committing the crime. “A sub-inspector of police from the Sarai police station spent almost half-an-hour inside the house of the accused and left the spot without making any arrest,” the deceased’s uncle Ajay Mishra said.

On getting information, DSP (Sadar) Raghav Dalay along with the SHO of Sarai police station Dharmajeet Mahto reached the site and removed the road blockade. The DSP said that two accused—Gudia Devi and Chhoti Kumari—have been arrested in connection with the incident. Other accused are absconding after the incident, the SHO said.

Altogether 11 persons have been made named accused in the FIR lodged with the Sarai police station. The SHO said the victim had not lodged any complaint against the tormentor earlier. “Raids are on to nab the culprits,” he said. The incident has sparked off tension in the village.

Title: Music composers rake in moolah as Bhojpuri songs top charts
Content: PATNA: The Covid-19 pandemic may have hit many small and big businesses all over, but the Bhojpuri music industry is raking in money with catchy songs and jingles based on the virus.The composers are trying to create awareness about the importance of washing hands and the use of soaps and masks. They have, therefore, gained immense popularity on social media sites.Ramu Singh, a local singer from Raxual, had recorded and uploaded a song — ‘Bihari zindabad, coronavirus murdabad…’ — on YouTube, which received 18,862 views in a few days. “The song is not just entertaining, but informative as well,” he told this newspaper.Another singer, Chotu Bihari, garnered 1,815 views and 14 comments on his song ‘Coronavirus bahal ba Bihar me…’. He said, “Uploaded on March 15, my song talks about Covid-19, which originated in China and spread across the world.”Other songs like ‘Coronavirus le ke te aiyl Bihar’, ‘Dhoka demi ashwa dharto coronavirus’, ‘Chhori ke jawani’ and ‘Aiyle coronavirus ke mahamari’ are also trending on the internet. While some have termed coronavirus ‘unfaithful’ and ‘villain’, others have made fun of the scenario only for entertaining the listeners and viewers.Lucky Raja’s song ‘Coronavirus ghus gayil lehenga ma…’ has topped the charts with 3.09 lakh views and more than 200 comments in just five days. The city-based artist said, “The man tells his girlfriend that if she ever leaves him, she will be infected by coronavirus. He also talks about maintaining hygiene to combat Covid-19.”He added, “I am glad that people like my song and appreciate it. I am now writing another song, which I will record and release by this week.”Due to the rising popularity of coronavirus songs in Bhojpuri, music studios have increased their recording charges from Rs 1,000 to to Rs 1,600. Manish Kumar, the owner of a studio in Bakerganj locality, said, “Singers have to pay Rs 5,400 for recording a whole album. We had to increase the rates because this is our only source of income.”Another studio owner, Ashutosh Verma, claimed that eight songs were recorded on Tuesday. “Some local singers recorded jingles and poems as well,” he said.

Title: Patna: Undeterred by coronavirus threat, devotees visit temples for puja
Content: PATNA: Devotees of Lord Hanuman in the state capital seemed undeterred by the outbreak of Covid-19 as they were seen in significant numbers at the temples here on Tuesday. Though their numbers were less compared to other Tuesdays.This was in sharp contrast with many famous shrines in the country, including Mumbai's Siddhivinayak Temple and Ujjain’s Baba Mahakal temple, which have been closed. Shirdi Saibaba Temple in Maharashtra was also shut for devotees on Tuesday.However, in Patna, the famous Mahavir temple near Patna Junction and Durga temple near Patna museum witnessed huge gatherings on Tuesday despite government advisory not to gather at one place in large numbers.Though many people were seen wearing masks, but the advisory related to social distancing was hardly being followed as people stood very close to each other, ignoring other precautions.Temple authorities, on the other hand, claimed they have taken several precautionary measures in order to stop the spread of the virus. “The temple premises is being cleaned with water and disinfectants and people as well as shrine management staff are being asked to wash their hands at regular intervals,” said Harikant Prasad, who looks after bookings for rituals at Mahavir Mandir.Prasad, however, said the number of devotees had reduced substantially over the last few days, but it increased on Tuesday. “Though more devotees came on Tuesday but their number was still less as compared to other Tuesdays in the past,” he said.Arvind Pandey, a priest at Khajpura Shiva temple also made similar claims with regard to devotee footfalls. “The number of people coming to the temple has definitely reduced over the past few days. In fact, very few people came to the temple even last Sunday, despite it being a holiday. Though the footfall increased on Tuesday, it was still comparatively lower than Tuesdays in the past,” he said.Hari Gopal, the priest at Durga Temple near Golghar, said liquid soaps for handwash has been introduced in the shrine and the devotees are asked to wash their hands with it before entering the temple premises. “We have started providing handwash to the devotees as preventive measure to curb the spread of Covid-19. The number of people coming to the temple has plunged but it surged slightly on Tuesday,” he said.Devotees, on the other hand, claimed that they exercised caution in visiting the temples. Tarun Kumar of Boring Road said: “I used to visit Mahavir Mandir early morning on every Tuesday and Saturday, but this time I went around 10am, so that the number of people could be less. Besides, I avoided touching the steel and wooden surfaces.”

Title: Covid-19 in Bihar: IMA, IDA ask members to check crowding of patients
Content: PATNA: The Bihar chapters of Indian Medical Association (IMA) and Indian Dental Association (IDA) have asked their members running clinics and nursing homes in the state to take self precautions and not allow patients’ gathering at one time.“The outpatients department (OPD) timings of different departments of medical colleges and institutes should be separated. Instructions were also issued to display informative posters at OPDs and private clinics to make patients and their attendants aware of the precautionary measures necessary to check spread of the coronavirus ,” said senior vice-president of IMA (Bihar) Dr Ajay Kumar on Tuesday. There are about 11,000 IMA members.The IDA Bihar unit has appealed to its members to avoid non-urgent and non-essential dental care services till March 31, said its president Dr Mohit Kumar. He said the receptors which attach coronavirus are maximum in the oral cavity and as such dentists and oral surgeons are highly vulnerable to contract the infection.“There is nothing to panic, at least in Bihar. However, we are looking at the trends of spread of this virus and it is worsening. So, we will appeal for closure of all private dental clinics in the state,” he said.The IDA (Bihar) has about 8,000 members of which only 550 were working in government hospitals. The remaining practise in private clinics. Mohit said all those running private clinics have been advised to take patient’s history, especially whether he or she recently visited any foreign country affected by the Covid-19 or had other symptomatic problems like cough, fever or breathlessness.

Title: Trustees to HC: 20% of Yes Bank AT-1 bonds can be made equity
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: Debenture trustees on Tuesday argued before the Bombay high court that at least 20% of the additional tier-1 ( AT-1 ) bonds issued by Yes Bank may be converted into equity. They also said that any decision on a write-off can only be taken by the Reserve Bank of India ( RBI ) and not by the Yes Bank administrator.

Janak Dwarkadas, counsel for Axis Trustee Services, submitted that the final restructuring scheme as notified by the RBI, in fact, did not provide for any write-off. More significantly, the court was informed that the write-off would adversely impact many senior citizens. Many bonds were held by senior citizens who had put their entire life’s savings in it. One of them — a cancer patient — put in savings on the promise of good returns which were to be used for treatment, said Dwarkadas and lawyer Zal Andhyarujina.

Provident funds and pension funds also have invested in the AT-1 bonds. Individual bond holders had also come to court, some wearing masks, some too preoccupied with the worry of losing all their savings. One is a nonagenarian, represented by her children in court. Another couple, both senior citizens, had invested Rs 70 lakh in the bonds.

Others had broken their fixed deposits and invested in the bonds on the promise of earning 9.5% returns. “Many of us are senior citizens who have invested a substantial part of lifetime savings, which are now on the verge of getting lost,” said one retired engineer who was in court.

As a preventive measure in the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic, the HC from Tuesday restricted working hours from noon till 2 pm. As a result, time ran out for the hearing and the HC will continue it on Wednesday. It continued its interim order passed on Monday, which subjects any decision in the controversy to court orders.

Dwarkadas said it was the trustees’ Rs 8,400-odd crore that helped the bank too. While the trustees understand the issue of “capital adequacy” for the new investees when SBI steps in, he wondered why should the bank’s promoters get the benefit of equity when it goes up as “existing investors” like Axis Trustee are made to suffer. He said, “AT-1 should have equity to the extent of 20%...we are willing to sail along with fortunes of other equity holders and willing to go with the lock-in period of three years.”

Along with Axis Trustee, Indiabulls Housing Finance also has filed a separate writ petition before the HC to challenge the March 14 notification issued by the Yes Bank administrator, where AT-1 capital bonds have been permanently written down in full.

The notification by the administrator was despite ongoing discussions between the debenture holders and the RBI, and the removal of the clause writing down of the bonds in the final reconstruction scheme, they said.

Title: To stop overcrowding, TTD introduces time-slot darshan system in Tirumala
Content:
Devotees can present any government-approved photo identity card to avail the darshan tokens

TIRUPATI: The dip in the number of devotees visiting Tirumala due to the coronavirus outbreak has forced the TTD to make time-slot darshan mandatory from this week. The temple body, which has already initiated measures to avoid overcrowding of devotees in queues and inside the temple, has now made time slots mandatory for devotees under the free darshan system. Sanitation exercises at various pilgrim congregation points in Tirumala have also been intensified.

TTD EO Anil Kumar Singhal said devotees can avail their time-slot based free darshan tokens at special counters set up at Srinivasam complex, TTD choultries, Galigopuram at Alipiri pedestrian route and Srivari mettu trekking routes leading to Tirumala. Two more counters have been set up at central reservation complex and at the RTC bus stand in Tirumala.

Devotees can present any government-approved photo identity card to avail the darshan tokens. Starting Tuesday, free darshan devotees will no longer have to wait in compartments at the Vaikuntam Q complex, but can join the queues at the temple as per the time slot allotted to them.

Meanwhile, pressure has been mounting on the TTD to impose further curbs on movement of devotees due to the spike in the number of positive cases across the country. The Shirdi Sai Sansthan has already announced the closure of the shrine at Shirdi in Maharashtra from Tuesday. Many other religious bodies across the country are also mulling similar moves.

Though no positive cases have been reported in the district so far, the spread of the virus from migrant devotees looms large. The TTD administers the affairs of nearly 29 temples in Chittoor district alone, including the Venkateswara temple in Tirumala, which continues to register a footfall of nearly 50,000 devotees per day despite the coronavirus fears.

Rayalaseema Porata Samithi convener P Naveen Kumar Reddy said while a few weekly sevas at the Tirumala temple have been cancelled, the temple continues to allow devotees to take part in daily arjitha sevas and some weekly sevas, where they sit in close proximity. “Though TTD has set up screening centres at Alipiri and Srivari mettu, it’s not possible to screen every single devotee . Only those with symptoms of cough or cold are being screened. The TTD should impose curbs on entry of devotees for all arjitha sevas held inside the temple till the corona scare settles down. Till then, the sevas can be performed by the priests in ekantham,” he advised.

Title: Tamil Nadu Chamber flays govt for hiking fuel price
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Tamil Nadu Chamber of Commerce and Industry has condemned the union government for increasing excise duty and taxes on fuel instead of passing on the benefits of drop in crude oil price in the international market. “No wonder suspicion spawns among all whether the problems and predicaments faced by the people in succession are self-generated or forced by the Central government,” the statement said.

Chamber president N Jegatheesan and secretary J Selvam stated that the special excise duty hike on petrol and diesel has added to the woes for the industry and the people such as stagnation of the economy, Covid-19, rising unemployment, stock market crash and weakening Indian rupee. The ongoing tussle between Russia and Saudi Arabia has multiplied production of crude oil and reflected in a steep fall in crude oil price in the international markets. “Under these circumstances, everyone expected the price of diesel and petrol to be reduced by at least by Rs 10 per litre in India,” Jegatheesan said.

Title: Coronavirus in Bihar: Curtains & blankets banned in AC buses
Content: PATNA: With a view to preventing the spread of coronavirus (Covid-19), the state transport department has banned the use of curtains and distribution of blankets in air-conditioned (AC) buses till March 31.A decision in this regard was taken by transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal at a meeting with bus operators, autorickshaw associations and private taxi operators on Tuesday.“Curtains and blankets have to be removed from AC buses to prevent the spread of Covid-19. Passengers can, however, bring their own blankets and use masks,” Agarwal said.He added, “All city, inter-city and inter-state buses, which arrive at and depart from Bankipore depot and Mithapur stand, have to be fumigated. The bus terminus will also be sanitised. Auto drivers and private taxi aggregators, on the other hand, have to clean their vehicles with bleaching powder twice a day.”Agarwal, who is also Patna’s divisional commissioner, laid emphasis on maintenance of personal hygiene as well. He asked cab and bus operators to provide hand sanitizers to all passengers and told private motorbike aggregators to give plastic headgears to pillion riders.“We have constituted different teams in all districts to ensure that preventive measures are being taken. They will conduct awareness campaigns across Bihar to tell people about ways to maintain hygiene to stop the spread of Covid-19. Each team comprises district transport officers, motor vehicle inspectors and enforcement sub-inspectors,” the transport secretary said, adding, “If any bus operator fails to follow the instructions, his permit will be cancelled.”

Title: Coronavirus scare: PMC launches disinfection drive
Content: PATNA: The Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) has launched a disinfection drive in different localities of the state capital as a preventive measure against coronavirus (Covid-19). Sanitation workers wearing full body cover are spraying disinfectants on roads, drains and garbage dumping points.PMC officials claimed that emphasis under the disinfection drive is being laid on public places, including bus stand, government offices and court premises. The executive officers and sanitation inspectors have also been asked to identify crowded places in their respective circles and get the disinfection done.The disinfection drive was carried out on the premises of Patna civil court on Monday and continued in Kakarbagh circle on Tuesday. A statement issued by the PMC on Tuesday evening stated that cleanliness drive was conducted at Mithapur bus stand in Kankerbagh circle. All buses parked there were disinfected using insecticides and other chemicals. Besides, anti-viral chemicals were sprayed in waiting rooms and all carts on the bus stand premises.The PMC officials claimed that disinfection drive was conducted at various places under Patliputra circle as well, including at the collectorate office, public grievance redressal office and the guest office inside the residence of Chief Justice of Patna high court.Disinfectants were also sprayed in the office of sub-divisional office, DSP office, Gaighat roundabout and Alamganj police station among several other places in Bankipore circle.PMC’s public relations officer Harshita said the drive will be conducted regularly at all places of people’s gathering.“Alcohol and other anti-viral chemicals are being sprayed in public places and government offices under the ongoing drive. All 75 sanitary inspectors have been asked to regularly conduct the drive in their respective areas. Besides, the workers involved in disinfection drive are being given boots, gloves and raincoats to ensure that they are not exposed to bacteria or viruses. They are also being given towel, soaps and asked to clean their hands frequently as preventive measures,” she said.Patna civil surgeon Raj Kishore Chaudhary said the municipal corporation has been asked to ensure utmost hygiene and frequent disinfection across the city to prevent any scope of the spread of Covid-19.“The PMC has been asked to conduct disinfection, cleanliness as well as fogging in all areas in the city to prevent the spread of the virus. The civic body apart, residents should also ensure highest level of personal hygiene, including frequent handwash and cleanliness in homes,” Dr Chaudhary said.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Patna: Ordered to vacate hostels, students leave for homes
Content: PATNA: Students staying in hostels across the city are leaving for their homes after the district administration asked all hostels in Patna, including private ones, to be vacated till March 31 as a precautionary measure against the coronavirus (Covid-19).Several hostels in the state capital, including at NIT and IIT campuses, on Tuesday issued notices to their boarders to vacate within two days following the directive from Patna DM Kumar Ravi.However, the NIT and IIT administrations have kept the hostels open for students from far off places. “If anyone wants to stay in the hostel, they can stay on as the mess will remain open,” an NIT official said.Niranjan, an electrical engineering student of NIT, said, “Many students returned to their homes whereas roughly 50 students are still staying who belong to other states.” Since he is from the city, Niranjan returned home after the classes were dismissed.Rukmini Devi, who runs a girls’ hostel in Makhaniya Kuan, said, “Students have been asked to lock their rooms properly and fill the entry/exit register. They have also been asked to take the print of leave slip, which is required to be filled up by their parents.”Several boarders living in hostels on Govind Mitra Road, Makhaniya Kuan, Naya Tola, Dariyapur and Boring Road were seen leaving for their home with their baggage.Manju Singh, a post-graduate student of Patna University , said, “My home is in Vaishali but I would be able to reach only by March 18 as all buses are going full. We have decided to hire a vehicle. My cousin is coming from Delhi and we would go together after she reaches here by evening,” she said.Another woman boarder of a private hostel, Roshni Agarwal, said, “We will leave in the morning, I got confirmed train tickets to Siwan. I also bought a simple mask as medically recommended masks are out of stock. We will carry boiled water and sanitizer on train.”Smriti Kumari, a Boring Canal Road hostel boarder who is preparing for medical entrance tests, is leaving for Nalanda with her friends after they were asked to vacate by Thursday. “The coaching classes were already suspended, so there is no need to stay in the hostel. My parents are asking me to return home, so I’m going back,” she said.Mohan Bhardwaj, an UPSC aspirant who lives in a private hostel in Naya Tola plans to stay with his local guardian. “My parents live in Palamu and it is not safe to go for such a long journey. I have moved to my local guardian’s place till the situation gets better, then I will move back to my hostel,” he said.

Title: Coronavirus: Bihar government yet to decide on use of breathalysers
Content: PATNA: While Maharashtra police on Tuesday temporarily stopped the use of breathalyser on roads as a precautionary measure against coronavirus , the state government is yet to take a clear decision on its use in Bihar. The equipment detects alcohol when someone blows into it after taking its nozzle inside the mouth.Same equipment is used on several people for detecting if he or she had consumed alcohol or not. That has a higher probability of coming into direct contact with the pathogen if any infected person had blown into it.Since there is prohibition on the use of liquor in Bihar, the equipment is also used to arrest those who are found in an inebriated state. Besides, the stern prohibition law has provision of arresting someone just on positive reading of a breathalyser.When contacted, ADG (headquarters) Jitendra Kumar told TOI over phone that no such specific direction, in terms of yes or no, has been issued to officers regarding the use of breathalysers. “But instructions have been issued to respond according to the present situation,” he said. Kumar said the final call on breathalysers would be taken by the transport department.When asked on the issue, transport minister Santosh Kumar Nirala also avoided a reply and said transport secretary would take a call.When contacted, transport secretary Sanjay Kumar Agarwal said the equipment is mainly used by the police department and not by the transport department. “There is IG (prohibition) in police department to take a call on such issues. Besides, excise commissioner is also there,” he said.However, Agarwal later said he would speak to the excise department secretary on the issue and check the scenario after which he would be able to tell how the matter would be dealt with.

Title: Covid-19 scare: A Revanth Reddy not produced in court
Content: HYDERABAD: With the coronavirus fear spreading to courts, Congress MP A Revanth Reddy was not produced before the principal special judge of ACB court in Hyderabad on Tuesday in connection with the vote-for-note scam.The judge posted the case to April 20. Revanth, one of the prime accused, was caught by ACB sleuths in May 2015. He was arrested in another case and sent to judicial remand.The same was informed to the ACB court which did not insist on his production because the Telangana high court had already instructed all the trial courts to not insist on production of the accused and also to not pass any adverse orders for failing to produce the accused.The high court itself has directed the district judiciary to ensure that there are no crowds in the trial courts in order to prevent the spread of the virus.ACB filed a chargesheet in the case charging Revanth with trying to bribe an independent legislator with Rs 50 lakh to make him vote for a TDP nominee in the 2015 MLC elections. ACB raided the premises where the alleged transaction took place, arrested Revanth and seized the cash.ACB is supposed to get this voice sample tested at FSL and get to the source of the seized cash. Whether ACB could do these things in the last five years would be known in the forthcoming hearings of the case.

Title: Hyderabad: 4-year-old raped, college hostel chef arrested
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: A family of a four-year-old girl, who was allegedly raped by a chef of a private college, accused the educational institute of offering them money to leave the city. The college has denied the claim.

On March 10, the 32-year-old chef allegedly sexually assaulted the four-year-old. He was subsequently arrested and charged for rape and relevant sections of the POCSO Act.

Shankar (name changed) from West Bengal migrated to Hyderabad with his wife and four-year-old daughter a month ago.

“One of our known people asked us to work at Sri Chaitanya IIT Academy, Madhapur, a residential institution. My wife and I do odd jobs there, including sweeping the floor or help the cook in the kitchen,” Shankar added.

“On March 10, my wife asked the daughter to go out of our tenement but she did not come back for a while. Later, she found her scared and noticed she was bleeding,” the father added.

They approached the college management. “We supported the family. Handed over the accused to police. He was a chef here, both the accused and the family were staying at the servants’ quarters. A case was registered,” a representative of Sri Chaitanya Junior College, Madhapur, said.

According to the family, the college intervened in the case. “They did not even let us speak to police. They feared their reputation will be damaged. Now, they have offered us Rs 10,000 and asked us to leave the city. How can I forget what happened? My daughter still wakes up at night saying ‘uncle will come again!,” the man said.

However, the college denied the allegation. “We intervened because both the parties were our employees, it was our responsibility. Though we had asked the family to come and talk to us, they were missing from their quarters since Sunday. We have not offered them any money,” an official of the junior college said.

Deputy commissioner of police (DCP), Madhapur, A Venkateshwar Rao said the 32-year-old accused was arrested on March 10.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Hyderabad: FIR against man claiming to be actor Lavanya Tripathi’s husband
Content:
Lavanya Tripathi (Photo credit: Insta)

HYDERABAD: Actress Lavanya Tripathi has lodged a complaint with the cyber crime police of Hyderabad commissionerate alleging that a man, who claims to be an actor , has defamed her by saying that they were married.

Assistant commissioner of police (ACP), cyber crime, KVM Prasad said, “Lavanya Tripathi alleged that S Sunisith, who claims to be an actor, has been claiming on YouTube interviews that he married the actress. They went to restaurants and other places. The actress alleged that Sunisith’s false statements have been defamatory,”

Based on the complaint, police started an inquiry and dispatched notices to managers of certain Telugu YouTube channels to appear before the investigating officer for questioning. “We will gather footage of the interviews and other evidence from them. A case will be registered under relevant sections of the IT Act,” the ACP said.

In the interviews, Sunisith said he had affair with another actress too.

Lavanya Tripathi, who won ‘Miss Uttarakhand’ title in 2006, made her Tollywood debut in 2012 with ‘Andala Rakshasi’.

Title: Yes Bank limit ends today, SBI vows funding support
Content: MUMBAI: State Bank of India chairman Rajnish Kumar has said that the country’s largest lender was solidly behind Yes Bank with a 49% stake and liquidity support.
