He added that SBI would not sell a single share of the private lender for three years.Rajnish’s assurance comes a day before the bank lifts restrictions on depositors for withdrawal. The Reserve Bank of India-imposed moratorium will be lifted on Wednesday at 6pm. “Our ATMs are filled with cash and our branches have an adequate supply of cash. There is no need to depend on any external sources for liquidity requirement. But if that is the case, liquidity lines are adequately available,” said Prashant Kumar , the RBI-appointed administrator of the bank.According to Prashant, there are good signs of customer confidence in the bank. “Only a third of our customers withdrew deposits up to the Rs 50,000 limit available under the moratorium. Also, in the last few days, we were having higher inflows than outflows,” he said.Yes Bank, which raised Rs 10,000 crore from SBI and others this week, said it would raise more funds in the next quarter. Rajnish said that while SBI had applied for shares worth Rs 7,250 crore, it was issued only Rs 6,050 crore worth because of the ceiling of 49% under the reconstruction scheme. The SBI chief said that the fund-raising was limited to seven banks other than SBI with an objective of lifting the moratorium early. He said that getting the requisite permissions for foreign investors would have taken longer.While Yes Bank would engage in a second round of capital-raising, this will happen at market rates according to a Sebi formula. Yes Bank’s shares closed at Rs 59 on Tuesday against the Rs 10-per-share investment by the SBI-led lenders.SBI has nominated its two deputy MDs — chief creditor officer Partha Pratim Sengupta, and strategy & chief digital officer Swaminathan Janakiraman — to the board of the bank. SBI’s former chief finance officer Prashant, who is currently the RBI-appointed administrator, will take charge as CEO after a week when the new board is in place.The private-sector bank plans to shift focus to retail, both in terms of deposits and loans, and is looking at increasing the share of retail loans to 60% from the present level of 40%. The SBI chairman said that there were no plans to rebrand the private lender, which is now an associate of SBI. He pointed out that all of SBI’s arms have done very well financially.Under the reconstruction scheme, the employees, barring senior management, are assured continuity for a year. On the issue of the AT-1 bonds, Prashant said that he would not comment as the matter was sub-judice but added that whatever was done was in terms of the contract with investors.

Title: ICICI e-platform to aid virus-hit business
Content: MUMBAI: ICICI Bank has hastened the launch of digital platform ICICIStack , which will allow businesses to access 500 services from home. The bank said with the new platform, business customers can improve productivity even when they are away from office amid social distancing due to the Covid-19 pandemic.The platform comprises both banking services and application programme interfaces (APIs). The platforms consist of the accounts stack, loans stack, investment stack and insurance stack. The account stack enables instant opening of various accounts in the bank including instantly available salary account, current account, travel card, bill pay solutions. The bank will allow customers to directly plug-in with their ERP software for account management and digital on-boarding of partners“In the recent tie-ups with payment fintechs too, it was the wide array of services, APIs and volume handling capability available within the ‘ICICI Stack’ that enabled quick integrations overnight. We believe that in these challenging times, ‘ICICIStack’ is well poised and committed to supporting customers for all their banking requirements,” said Anup Bagchi, ED, ICICI Bank.Bagchi said the digital platform was already on the works, however the bank decided to hasten the launch given the current environment requiring businesses to facilitate work from home.

Title: Paytm moves to Visa from RuPay
Content:
Mumbai: Paytm Payments Bank , the largest issuer of RuPay debit cards, said that it will now issue Visa cards and is targeting one crore of these next year.

The move comes in the wake of the government barring banks from recovering any fees from merchants accepting RuPay cards.

According to bankers, the government’s decision to have zero merchant discount rate ( MDR , or merchant fees) on RuPay cards has caused loss to issuers. The card issuers were providing several benefits like cashback and lounge access to promote usage, which were funded by the merchant fees.

“For the first time, the bank’s customers will also be able to make international transactions using their Visa debit cards. Soon, the customers will also have an option to request for a physical card. This will enable customers to make contactless payment through their chip-inserted cards,” Paytm said in a statement.

“This partnership will allow millions of our customers to avail the benefits of Visa debit cards along with the power to make international transactions,” said Paytm Payments Bank MD & CEO Satish Kumar Gupta. Paytm has issued over 57 million digital debit cards through its mobile banking app.

Commenting on the partnership, Visa’s India chief T R Ramachandran said that debit cards, because of their ease of use, were the first choice of customers who are new to banking. “Debit cards play a critical role to migrate these customers to the digital economy and help them make non-cash transactions,” he said.

Title: Some job interviews go online, others put off
Content: Namrata Singh | TNNMumbai: A global toy manufacturer based in Pune sent out the company’s own sanitised car and a known driver to ferry a candidate from Mumbai for an interview for the senior VP’s role.In the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak, the company’s gesture to ensure the safety of the candidate has gone down well, said a hiring agency expert. The company in question couldn’t postpone the interview for the critical role, but hiring firms are witnessing postponements in assignments across other levels. CIEL HR Services CEO Aditya Narayan Mishra said last week there was a significant 20% drop in normal hiring activities. “This week, the decline could be slightly more and, over the next three weeks, it would be crucial to see whether hiring activities could slow down. It all depends on the extent of the Covid-19 spread,” said Mishra.“The challenge is that a lot of our clients are working from home and decisions on hiring are taken jointly with multiple rounds of interviews. They usually sit across the table and decide on which candidate to choose. Since this cannot be done, hiring is taking a beating. Video interviews are usually done for senior-level hiring only,” he said.Sectors like logistics, travel & tourism and hospitality, which are deeply impacted by the spread of coronavirus, account for around 15% to overall hiring in India. “These sectors are in a panic mode right now, with hiring plans postponed or put on hold,” said Mishra.According to Antal International India MD Joseph Devasia, 80% of the interviews for the firm stand cancelled or postponed, with some moving to video calls. “Wherever the interviews are moving to ‘non-personal’ or digital mode, it’s only for the first couple of rounds. In the final round, companies prefer to meet candidates personally,” said Devasia. Not all hiring firms are facing the heat. Randstad India MD & CEO Paul Dupuis said the firm is not seeing hiring going into a freeze. “Hiring is either going virtual or being rescheduled to another day,” said Dupuis. He added that the company’s move to invest in leveraging technology has enabled the firm to provide services to clients and even on-board virtually.“On any normal day, our offices are filled with candidates registering and interviewing with us for both temporary and permanent staffing. Today, we are doing this virtually in some centres and the conversion rates have been higher than usual,” said Dupuis.TeamLease Services executive VP & co-founder Rituparna Chakraborty said, “With over 2 lakh associates of TeamLease Services in outbound jobs, life moves on for us even in these times of coronavirus pandemic.” Three out of 10 firms have postponed hiring assignments for TeamLease for now and they are expected to issue fresh dates, perhaps once things become more clear.“We only see a handful of firms saying that they want to schedule interviews digitally. For the larger section of mass hiring drives that we conduct, digital interviews are unproductive. There’s a question of affordability that kicks in here,” said Chakraborty.

Title: Leaders must unlearn, reskill to keep pace with change
Content:
By Shailja Dutt

It would be fair to call our slow economic growth a cyclical as well as structural slowdown. The nation is performing well below its growth potential, and lagging. The short-term decline in the economic sentiment could be balanced out by the compounding of small but far reaching changes for the simplification and modernisation of Indian economic systems and market practices. However, the long-term effects of hyper-capitalisation are challenging organisations to be bigger, better and faster.

The 2020 Budget has us all strapped in for fast executions, disguised as pre-planned and board-approved successes. Indian businesses are in critical need of leaders that are able to adapt and survive in an adverse economic environment. Top executives must be ready to unlearn and relearn skills, while simultaneously embracing the volatility of new functions and new roles that are being created to keep pace with the digital wave.

In 2019, India witnessed severe job cuts in the automobile sector and this was attributed to the disadvantages of automation by many. However, the fact of the matter is that existing skillsets of thousands of mid- and top-tier professionals in India are not letting them participate in the digital revolution.

The explosive demand that technology has created in the last few decades is constantly countered by the minimal supply of competent technologists against the creation of such posts as chief transformation officers, chief sustainability officers and many previously unheard of yet important roles. Almost all industries have already been exponentially disrupted by technology.

Fintech is transacting in milliseconds, e-commerce is slowly replacing traditional retailers, and medtech is monitoring our pulse by the minute. Industries are growing at a rate not seen before, and customers are demanding more and more each day.

Despite the slowdown, India is expediting its cybersecurity measures, and the government as well as private organisations are aggressively hiring entire ecosystems to address these needs. Companies like IBM India, Amazon India and Infosys are hiring cybersecurity personnel and first responders, with chief security information officers as leads. India needs a million cybersecurity personnel in 2020 for a market estimated by Nasscom at $35 billion by 2025.

These industries are creating the next big wave of ‘new jobs’. Analytics and Big Data, along with renewable energy, are not new industries. Yet, they are reporting some of the largest funding and recruitment strategies of the decade, according to IRENA (2018). EY, PwC and Deloitte, with other banking, financial services and insurance giants, have reported a collective need of over 1.5 lakh analysts and leaders during 2020 (‘Great Learning’). The Global Wind Energy Council reports that the Indian renewable energy sector is looking at 2.5 million recruitments in 2020 under initiatives like ‘Make-in-India’, led by such companies as Tata, Suzlon and ReNew.

Drone Shipping and E-Retail are hiring executives with legislature and policy-making experience as these industries are just as vulnerable as they are powerful. With the rise of mobile internet, Nykaa, Flipkart and Reliance are engaging workforces to target the predicted $200-billion market by 2026.

Organisations are investing heavily in reskilling programmes to increase the value of their existing contributors, while creating new jobs in the process and retaining existing ones. Hence, leadership must consistently upskill to become a source of constant innovation, or be ready to be replaced by those with more relevant and recent skills.

Unless they have trained technologists and innovators in pole positions, it is a blind passage for organisations to accept and implement changes and be successful in the ever-shifting new digital economy.

The writer is founder and chairperson, Stellar Search

Title: Bird flu scare: Samples of dead crows test positive
Content: PATNA: It may be a double whammy for residents, who are trying their best to keep coronavirus at bay till now, as the samples of crows found dead in Patna city and Lohia Nagar areas in February tested positive for avian influenza or H5N1 virus, commonly known as bird flu. Also, one more person was tested positive for swine flu on Tuesday.The animal husbandry department on Tuesday confirmed that the samples sent to the National Institute of High Security Animal Diseases (NIHSAD) at Bhopal were tested positive for the H5N1. The samples of dead crows were collected by the Institute of Animal Health and Production (IAHP) from two different locations in Patna. Some samples of dead birds were also collected from Bhagalpur.The IAHP officials said the first sample was sent to Bhopal lab as well as Regional Diseases Diagnostic Laboratory (RDDL) at Belgachia for the test, which confirmed H5N1 on February 15. “The second sample was collected from Patna City area in the third week of February and the test result was received only a couple of days back,” the officials said.Dr Umesh Kumar, director of IAHP, also confirmed that the death of crows in Patna were due to avian flu. “The veterinary doctors are on alert and the samples of bird’s drooping, feathers and other body parts have been collected from chicken shops as well as domesticated birds from the affected areas where the dead birds were found. There is no need of panic as the nearby areas are being disinfected by the officials,” he said.“The expert committee of animal husbandry department has started serum surveillance in Lohia Nagar and Patna City areas,” he said.As a precautionary measure, surveillance has been extended throughout the state in view of the possibility of some disease due to the constantly changing weather, said the official.Meanwhile, carcasses of dead pigs were also found in the state capital and the veterinary doctors of Bihar Veterinary College confirmed their deaths due to swine flu.One more positive case of swine flu has been detected on Tuesday at Rajendra Memorial Research Institute of Medical Sciences (RMRI), Patna. Altogether seven persons including two women were infected with swine flu (H1N1) in the last couple of days.Patna civil surgeon Dr Raj Kishore Choudhary said a 42-year-old person from Muzaffarpur was detected with swine flu. “He is presently undergoing treatment at RMRI. Earlier, the five cases had been detected from Patna City where the dead pigs had been found,” he said.“The condition of one patient admitted to a private hospital in Patna was critical. He has been put on ventilator,” Dr Choudhary said.

Title: Uncertainty index can help frame policy, says RBI study
Content:
Mumbai: An RBI-published study has called for the setting up of an uncertainty index to help frame policy responses. The study finds that both investment activity and real GDP growth fall in the face of heightened uncertainty in the economy.

The study uses a novel dataset — consisting of newspaper articles and internet search intensity data — to construct three alternative indices for measuring uncertainty in the Indian context.

Plotting the values for uncertainty against various economic activities, the study concludes that uncertainty correlates negatively with economic activity in India. “Therefore, on an average, the higher the uncertainty, the lower is the private consumption, bank credit, private investment and output. This underlines the strong procyclical nature of uncertainty,” said the report authored by Nalin Priyaranjan and Bhanu Pratap .

Like investment, overall economic activity (real GDP) also witnesses a sharp fall in response to an uncertainty shock triggering almost a 0.8% loss in growth in the model published in the report. Another conclusion is that the financial markets appear to factor-in uncertainty in advance, while uncertainty seems to ‘lead’ the changes in investments and consumption. The report has constructed three uncertainty indices based on newspaper articles, sentiment analysis of news articles and internet search intensity. “From a policy perspective, our results suggest that policymakers can use the information on uncertainty for devising policy framework and institutional arrangements that foster sound and predictable policies, the report said.

Title: Bihar: Minor battles for life after rape in Muzaffarpur village
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PATNA: A 12-year-old girl is struggling for her life at the Sri Krishna Medical College and Hospital (SKMCH) after being raped by a 15-year-old boy at a village under Kanti police station area in Muzaffarpur district on Tuesday. Police said the accused, who is also a minor, is absconding after the incident.

The incident took place when the victim had gone to an agricultural field outside her native village for grazing her goats. The accused, stated to be her neighbour, was already there for grazing his goats. Taking advantage of the girl being alone, the boy raped her. As she fell unconscious after the crime, the accused escaped from the spot.

Some local residents, however, spotted the girl bleeding profusely. They immediately admitted her to the primary health centre at Kanti from where she was later referred to the SKMCH for treatment. The doctors attending to the survivor said that her condition deteriorated due to excess bleeding and rupture in private parts.

Muzaffarpur DSP (West) Krishna Murari Prasad said that the swab of the survivor has been collected and sent for medical test. Women’s police station SHO Abha Rani along with another woman police officer recorded the survivor’s statement in the hospital and subsequently lodged an FIR against the accused. The DSP said that the accused, who is also stated to be a minor, escaped soon after the news about the incident spread in the area. Police have detained some close relatives of the accused to exert pressure on him to surrender before the police.

A para-medical staff, who first attended to the girl at the Kanti PMC, said the girl had received grievous injuries and signs of protest were evident on her body. She was referred to SKMCH as her condition was critical.

An investigating officer said that the girl was operated upon at the SKMCH late in the evening. “She is under observation by a team of doctors,” a senior official of the SKMCH said..

In another incident, Saran police on Tuesday arrested one Shiv Sharan Mahto for his involvement in the gang-rape of a Class VIII student under the Bheldi police station area in neighbouring Saran district. Bheldi police station SHO Vikas Kumar said the girl was gang-raped when she had gone to Raipura Bazar on March 5.

Another accused, Ajay Mahto, a resident of Fatehpur village under the Majhi police station of the district, is still at large. “Raids are on to nab him,” the SHO added.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Bihar: Nirbhaya case convict’s wife seeks divorce
Content:
Akshay Thakur

PATNA/AURANGABAD: With barely three days left for the execution of death warrant against Akshay Kumar Singh alias Akshay Thakur and other Nirbhaya case convicts, his 29-year-old wife Punita Devi has filed a divorce petition in a family court at Aurangabad in Bihar. Akshay and three other convicts are to be hanged on March 20 in connection with the Nirbhaya gang rape and murder case.

Punita, the mother of a nine-year-old male child, filed a divorce petition before the principal judge of Aurangabad family court, Ram Lal Sharma, on Monday. In her petition, Punita said she doesn’t want to live as a widow for the rest of her life after the hanging of her 36-year-old husband.

Akshay, a native of Karma Lahang village under Tandwa police station in Aurangabad district , is currently lodged in Delhi’s Tihar Jail. Punita’s legal counsel Mukesh Kumar Singh said the court has fixed March 19 as the next date of hearing on the divorce petition. Quoting Section 13 (2) (II) of Hindu Marriage Act 1955, the advocate said, “A woman has the legal right to seek divorce from her husband after the latter’s conviction on rape charges.”

According to the divorce petition, Akshay got married to Punita from Gango village under Pipratand police station in Palamu district of neighbouring Jharkhand on May 29, 2010. The couple was blessed with a son, Priyanshu, on July 4, 2011. Akshay, who worked in a private firm in New Delhi at the time of marriage, used to visit his native village from time to time.

Punita said the idea to seek divorce struck her mind after Akshay was held guilty in the Nirbhaya gang rape and murder case and subsequently death warrants were issued against him. Even the last ray of hope ended after the rejection of mercy petition by the President of India. “Now I don’t want to live as the widow of a rapist for the rest of my life. So, I have moved the divorce petition,” she said.

Though the petition was submitted on March 12, the court took up the matter on March 16 and listed the case for next hearing on March 19. When asked whether it was another ploy to stay the execution of hanging scheduled for March 20, the advocate said it’s not like that. “My client has moved the court for natural justice,” he said.

The court is likely to issue notice to Akshay on March 19 when the case would be taken up for hearing. Apart from Akshay, Mukesh Singh, Pawan Gupta and Vinay Sharma have been awarded capital punishment in the case.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: CUSB to introduce seven new courses in new academic session
Content:
Central University of South Bihar (Image credit: https://www.cusb.ac.in/)

GAYA: Central University of South Bihar (CUSB) would be introducing seven new courses in the academic session 2020-21.

The new courses are in addition to the 45 ongoing courses at the undergraduate, postgraduate and PhD level. The PG-level new courses are MPEd (Master of physical education), geography, geology, M Pharma (pharmaceuticals) and M Pharma (pharmacology). PhD courses are being introduced in commerce and history. According to the University PRO, Mudassir Alam, the university was earlier conducting 45 courses (3 UG courses, 22 PG courses and 20 PhD programmes).

From the academic session 2020-21, CUSB will be conducting 52 programmes including 22 PhD-level programmes.

As per the information provided by Alam, the university has invited application for admission to altogether 1,777 seats at the UG, PG and PhD level. Whereas 276 seats are available at the UG-level, the number of seats at the PG and PhD levels have been put at 1,171 and 330 respectively. The PhD programmes for which applications have been invited include biotechnology, Life Sciences, environmental sciences, physics, education, clinical psychology, economics and sociology.

The admission notice issued by Rashmi Tripathi, the university’s controller of exams states that the candidates for admission will be selected through the test conducted by the Central University combined admission exam body. Besides, 14 Central Universities, four state universities too are participating in the combined admission test. For UG and PG admissions, computer readable OMR-based entrance test will be conducted. Test for PhD course admission will be conducted online.

Established in 2009, the university, a couple of years back shifted to its own campus located in Panchanpur village, about 15 km from the divisional headquarters. Prior to that, the university functioned from rented buildings located in Gaya and Patna . The faculty strength of the University is 151, including 21 professors and 24 associate professors.

As per available information, hostel facility is available only for 800 students including 300 women students. Others have to arrange their own accommodation.

Title: Coronavirus: Patna high court introduces alternate day work for judges
Content: PATNA: The Patna high court on Tuesday introduced roster system for its judges, who will function on alternate days in order to avoid lawyers’ congregation in the backdrop of coronavirus threat. Orders were also issued to keep gate number four of the high court closed from 11am to 2pm to check public gathering.Chief Justice Sanjay Karol himself inspected the premises and the hospital located there to assess the preparedness.The Tuesday cause list had the names of only 15 judges, including the Chief Justice. Only bail and urgent matters were listed for hearing, which were completed in less than three hours. Only few advocates, whose matters were listed for hearing, had reached the high court. Advocate clerks or munshis also did not come to the court.A notification was issue on Sunday only that only bail and urgent matters would be taken up for hearing from Monday till March 31.In addition, another notification was issued by the high court administration on Tuesday, announcing commencement of summer schedule in subordinate courts across the state from Wednesday. Their working hours would be from 7am to 1pm. The step is also taken to avoid gathering at the lower courts. Normally, the summer schedule starts from first Monday of April.Public prosecutor Vijay Kumar Sinha of Patna civil court told TOI over phone that no regular hearing in trial of cases was being taken up in the subordinate courts. “Only urgent criminal and civil matters were being taken up for hearing. Only the court handling excise cases is witnessing gathering,” he said, adding such conditions in court would prevail till March 31.Meanwhile, the high court has also emphasized recording of evidence of undertrial prisoners through videoconferencing from jail, instead of their physical production in courts. The district and sessions judges across the state have been asked to consult prisons department to ensure that there is no crowding of prisoners in lockups.

Title: Stress in tourism, aviation on SBI radar
Content: MUMBAI: State Bank if India ( SBI ) chairman Rajnish Kumar has said the country’s largest bank is keeping a watch on exposures to aviation hospitality and tourism sectors in the wake of the Covid-19 pandemic. “We are studying the impact on these sectors,” Kumar said, in response to a query on business.Aviation consultancy Centre for Asia-Pacific Aviation (CAPA) on Monday said the Covid-19 pandemic will push most global airlines into bankruptcy by the end of May 2020. While aviation, tourism and hospitality were the first casualty on account of travel restrictions during precautions taken in the first stage, retail businesses are also taking a hit as cities go into lockdown.On Monday, RBI governor Shaktikanta Das had said the pandemic would clip off up to 1.5 percentage points from global growth and the impact on India was still being studied.Many economists are forecasting a recession. “We expect 2020 global growth to dip to 0.9%, the lowest since the global financial crisis, when global growth bottomed at -0.5% in 2009. This will be worse than the global recession of 2001,” Morgan Stanley had said in a recent report.“We are monitoring two key risk factors: The duration of Covid-19-related economic disruption, and the duration of dislocations in financial markets, especially credit. If disruption from Covid-19 persists into 3Q20 (July-September), we could see an even deeper recession, with 2020 global growth averaging -0.6%,” it said.“On the demand side, inoperability analysis for three sectors, namely transport, tourism and hotels show significant impact on demand and hence output,” said SBI chief economic adviser Soumya Kanti Ghosh.“On an aggregate basis, we estimate that the impact of a 5% inoperability shock could be 90 basis points (100bps = 1 percentage point) on GDP from trade, hotel & transport and transport, storage & communication segment, that could be spread over FY20 and FY21, with a larger impact in FY21,” Ghosh further added.

Title: Covid-19: Restaurants cut jobs, seek rent, tax sops
Content: BENGALURU: The restaurant industry faces an existential crisis as consumer footfall and revenue is down 60% on an average even as online food delivery orders have reduced about 20%, according to half a dozen industry executives that TOI spoke to. The development is a direct result of more people staying at home with the onset of Covid-19 Leading restaurant owners have initiated talks with their landlords for a change in rental arrangements. They are considering a revenue-sharing agreement, based on monthly sales, with the landlords since overall revenue is going to tank further in coming weeks.National Restaurant Association of India ( NRAI ) president Anurag Katriar, who also runs multiple restaurants like Indigo, has sent a letter to the Mumbai excise commissioner, saying it should extend existing liquor licence validity and its renewals by three months. The reason cited is that the outlets are incurring losses and won’t have capital to pay for renewal fees, which is also 15% higher than last year.Restaurant owners are considering salary cuts across the board to stay afloat, while a few smaller outlets have already let go of some of their staff, according to NRAI executives. The association has around 10,000 members, many of whom run large national chains. If things keep becoming worse, the industry — which employs 7 million people — could see job losses of 1 million, according to Katriar.The regional arms of NRAI are in the process of issuing an ‘advisory’ to partner members to shut their restaurants over the next two weeks in order to contain any possible risk of community spread of the coronavirus. “We realise it will be a big financial burden on us (issuing advisory to voluntary shut restaurants). But there is a huge risk to the public and our staff. We are requesting power utilities for discounts, seeking moratorium from loans taken from banks and an interest-waiver,” added Katriar.Some of the restaurant owners are asking their staff to utilise their paid leaves while restaurants remain shut or with very little operations to service online orders. Leading restaurateur Manu Chandra , who runs Toast & Tonic and Monkey Bar, among other brands, said it’s a “recession on steroids”.He added that the effects of coronavirus outbreak are hugely tangible — with a 50-80% drop in revenue and footfalls. “So, we will have to implore our landlords to be considerate in these very, very difficult times. Nobody wants to lay off people. But if there is no way to pay them, then how does one continue to employ them,” he added.While the situation looks grim, industry executives said the next two weeks are crucial in terms of the fate of the sector, which may take longer to recover if the virus spreads faster in India. They are hoping for a government stimulus to come through to survive what is being seen as the biggest crisis they have ever seen.At the same time, orders on both major platforms Swiggy and Zomato have fallen by 20% over the weekend, according to one of the sources briefed on the matter. While both players clocked close to 1.5 million orders each in the previous Sunday, the number fell to around 1.2 million last Sunday as customers limit contact with strangers.“The delay of IPL will also have a significant impact on online food delivery growth as it is equivalent to Diwali sales for e-tailers, which helps set a new benchmark,” said one of the sources briefed on the matter. Swiggy and Zomato spokespersons did not reply to emailed queries from TOI.

Title: No ‘work from home’ for brokerages, MFs
Content: MUMBAI: Even as several new-age companies as well as manufacturing players have asked employees to work remotely to limit the spread of coronavirus , regulatory, infrastructure and compliance constraints are holding back brokerages mutual funds and other stock market participants to recommend work-from-home to traders and dealers. Some, however, have worked out ways to keep their operations running with a minimal in-office staff.For brokerages, among the main hurdles is the imposition of the no-cellphones rule during market hours for traders if they work from a remote location. This is done to stop leakage in trading data and client positions, which could be used for insider trading or front-running, both illegal acts under Sebi rules.According to Ashish Pyasi, associate partner of law firm Dhir and Dhir Associates, “It will be challenging to maintain the record of transactions and recordings if employees work from home . Unless a system, which will cover these situations, is put in place immediately, it will be hard for regulators and stock exchanges to keep a check.”Also, financial intermediaries depend on trading terminals for price updates and feeds in order to place bets, and to have similar infrastructure at home is difficult.Pradeep Gupta, co-founder & VC, Anand Rathi Group , said that it had looked at a work-from-home solution and bifurcated work basis on what is possible and what it may face in terms of regulatory or compliance challenges. “Trading cannot happen from home as it requires terminals and has to be done from office, from the designated desk and by the designated person according to compliance.”At Centrum Capital, dealers and traders, who punch orders on BOLT, have not been allowed to work from home, while its sales and research analysts have been advised to work remotely. However, Motilal Oswal Group has put up secondary facilities so that business critical employees could work either from office or from another place so that they could avoid public transport, Sudhir Dhar, its ED & head of HR, said.Sebi regulations for mutual funds and market intermediaries do not expressly prohibit remote connectivity for employees. “The stipulations mandate data localisation while ensuring data security and integrity,” said Arka Mookerjee, partner, J Sagar Associates. “Given the nature of cloud-based connectivity that the world has been moving towards, this is a good opportunity to test preparedness, especially for smaller players. However information management, including unpublished price-sensitive information, have to be carefully managed by the employee concerned to avoid leakage of information.”Interestingly, insider-trading violations were one of the most investigated cases by Sebi in fiscal 2019. The markets regulator probed 70 cases in 2018-19, a fourfold jump in cases it investigated in fiscal 2018.Neil Parikh, chairman, PPFAS Mutual Fund, said “We have asked staff to work from home for at least two weeks as a precautionary measure to prevent the spread of the coronavirus. However, for critical functions like fund management, NAV calculations, we will have some staff coming to office for the next two-three days until we are comfortable that these can be managed from home without any delay.”

Title: Shabana Azmi reveals her family was upset over her accident photos being circulated online!
Content: Veteran actress Shabana Azmi had met with an accident in January after which she was rushed to the nearby hospital. Later, the actress was shifted Kokilaben hospital in Mumbai for further care.Soon, in February, the actress took to her Twitter to share that she has recovered and thanked everyone for the prayers.The pictures from the accident took over the internet in no time and in a recent interview when she was asked about the same, the actress replied that her family didn't like it. She revealed that she had no idea about the accident the pictures as she didn't use her phone for a long time during the recovery. However, she stated that her family was upset about it. Shabana went on to add that when she saw the pictures, she was nothing but grateful towards who helped and rushed her to the hospital and the staff.On the work front, the latest, she has featured in 'Sheer Qorma', a film which deals with same-sex marriage. The love story between two queer women, played by Swara Bhasker and Divya Dutta is helmed by Faraz Arif Ansari She is currently in Budapest shooting for Steven Spielberg 's 'Halo'.

Title: SEC defers Bengal civic polls, parties back move
Content:
Kolkata: The West Bengal State Election Commission has postponed the civic polls over the emerging coronavirus threat. The panel will take stock of the situation after 15 days and decide on the poll schedule amid indications that civic polls in Kolkata and Howrah may be held by April-end.

“We are delaying the elections due to the situation over coronavirus. We were fully prepared but the present situation is not conducive for conducting polls. We will review the situation after 15 days and decide on the election schedule thereafter,” said state election commissioner Saurabh Das. At the all-party meeting called by Das on Monday, party representatives endorsed the decision.

Chief minister Mamata Banerjee, at a high-level meeting at Nabanna, said: “Covid-19 is a danger to humanity. Our first priority is to avert the virus and save lives. Elections can be held later.” Taking the cue, TMC leader Subrata Bakshi said: “We support the SEC proposal to defer the civic polls. Let the SEC decide on the poll schedule later in consultation with the state government.”

Congress Rajya Sabha member Pradip Bhattacharya said: “We have no problem if SEC defers the civic polls due to the virus threat.” BJP state vice-president Jayprakash Majumdar said: “We are concerned over the new virus and also over the people’s urge for civic polls.” CPM leader Sujan Chakrabarty, while endorsing the decision, said: “There was confusion over holding of the civic polls. The virus now has come as a plea to defer the polls.”

The SEC will take stock of the situation by March-end but is unlikely to issue the election notification because the state government has extended the reasonable restrictions on public gatherings up to April 15. If the notification is issued after April 15, civic polls in Kolkata and Howrah will be pushed to last week of May.

Title: Hyderabad: Three held for cloning debit cards, cops recover Rs 10 lakh
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Three people were arrested by Cyberabad cyber crime police on Tuesday for cloning debit cards of customers at bars and pubs in Hyderabad. According to police, the trio had collected card data of over 150 customers while working at different restaurants and pubs in Hyderabad and Cyberabadby using a skimmer.

The accused were identified as Praful Kumar Nayak (25), Hemanth Kumar Nayak (28) and Sujit Kumar Nayak (31), all from Ganajam District of Odisha and were residing at Madhapur. Praful had learnt about skimming and cloning machines and started collecting the customer card data while working as a in December 2017.

He took assistance from Hemanth for cloning the cars and Sujith Kumar Nayak assisted him with withdrawal of money. “He never used to work at one place for more than 10 days to avoid suspicion,” said a police officer.

The case came to light on March 5 when the manager of HDFC bank, Gachibowli, approached the cyber crime police regarding two complaints received by them in connection with the fraudulent withdrawal of Rs 76,000.

Police nabbed the accused and recovered Rs 10 lakh net cash, one skimmer, one cloning machine, 44 cloned cards and other material from their possession.

Following this, police have requested citizens to not hand over the debit or credit card to the staff at restaurants.

Title: Curbs amid coronavirus scare cause 10% dip in devotees
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: At a time when efforts are taken in temples to prevent people with symptoms resembling those of Covid-19 from entering the premises, the number of people visiting Meenakshi Amman Temple has come down marginally. A decrease of at least 10% devotees has been witnessed in the temple in the last few days, say officials.

Joint commissioner of Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowment (HR and CE) department N Natarajan said that the number of devotees visiting the temple has come down by around 10 to 15%. They are in the process of procuring thermal scanners. Meanwhile, devotees have been asked to maintain distance between themselves while standing in queues. HR and CE department officials ensured thorough check of devotees before letting them inside famous temples in southern district. Devotees were checked using thermal scanner before being let inside the temple premises at Dhandayuthapani Swamy temple in Palani. Health teams sanitized places frequently touched by devotees using chemicals. Officials in Meenakshi Amman Temple said that devotees found coughing and sneezing were asked to visit a doctor and not allowed inside.

Devotees were provided with hand sanitizer procured from Government Rajaji Hospital , where it is prepared by hospital employees themselves, before being let inside. He added that thermal scanner will be installed soon and devotees screened before being allowed in. Officials at Palani temple started using thermal scanner from Monday. At Ramanathaswamy temple in Rameswaram, devotees were checked by health employees at all the towers.

Title: TRS whip slams BJP for playing ‘divisive’ politics
Content:
Hyderabad: Condemning remarks against chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao for passing a resolution against CAA and NRC by BJP state unit, TRS whip and spokesperson Karne Prabhakar said the BJP at the Centre was resorting to divisive politics and the state government had proved that it was secular nature once again by passing the resolution. He also demanded the BJP president to withdraw his remarks against the chief minister.

He said BJP state president Bandi Sanjay lacks maturity and condemned him for commenting against KCR as anti-national. “Some states like Bihar also passed a resolution against NPR, are they also anti-national? Bihar’s CM is also an ally of BJP,” Prabhakar said.

He said KCR would undertake a national level campaign and movement against the CAA if required.

Title: West Bengal: Schools go online to teach students of classes X, XII
Content: KOLKATA: State government’s decision to extend the break in educational institutions up to April 15 has prompted several schools to draw up a contingency plan to combat the loss of time for Class X and Class XII students, who will be appearing for the Board examinations in 2021.Delhi Public School Ruby Park has extended the session break and decided to keep the classes suspended till April 15.“Initially, we planned to start the new academic session from March 19, but now it will be delayed. However, the students, who will appear in CBSE Class X and XII exams next year, cannot remain absent for so long. For, it will take a toll on their studies and teachers will not be able to complete the syllabus. Hence, we have decided to hold online classes from March 20,” said an official. On Wednesday, teachers of the school will hold a planning session to decide the contents for online teaching.The Future Foundation School has been sharing online resources with students in the past decade or more. “We shall offer online classes for the students of Classes I to XII. It is important for Class X and Class XII students to complete the syllabus on time,” said the principal Ranjan Mitter.“We have to transact the curriculum meaningfully. Hence, we have advised parents that from April 1, every child will have to put a study routine in place. Slipped classroom concept will be introduced. The child will be expected to follow the lessons provided online and then complete the assignments, which will again be submitted online,” added Mitter. The interaction and doubt sharing can be done online at pre-scheduled time between teachers and the students. Sujoy Biswas, principal of Ram Mohan Mission School, is also planning to introduce online tutorials where teachers from home can connect with the students over Skype for teaching. “Technology will allow teachers to provide lectures to as many as 50 students online, who can be added to their Skype accounts. Even homework can be submitted through portals,” said Biswas.The Heritage School principal Seema Sapru has already planned the progress mechanism for Class X and XII. “We have already started taking additional classes for the students who will appear for their boards next year between March 11 and March 14. Thereafter, we have planned to take extra classes again from March 23 to March 31. The students have been given the time table. Now with the new directive from the government to shut schools, teachers will hold the classes online,” said Sapru. Teachers will share study materials and conduct tests for students over the virtual platform.

Title: Varsity land can’t be used for housing scheme: HC
Content:
Vijayawada: The high court on Tuesday directed the government against utilising land belonging to Acharya N G Ranga Agriculture University in Amaravati for the housing scheme. The government recently took a decision to use the unused land of various institutions for the scheme.

One Ponnekanti Koteswara Rao from Guntur filed a PIL seeking directions to the government to refrain from taking over land allotted to the university. The land, which originally belonged to Sri Venkateswara Veternary University, was transferred to the Agriculture University to set up seven different institutions like state seed farms, DNA and fingerprint analysis laboratory, quality control and testing laboratory, model farm and seed processing and storage godown.

Arguing on behalf of the petitioner, senior counsel K Manikanteswara Rao said the state government had allotted 110 acres of lands to the university. Out of which about 37.5 acres have been allotted to various institutions and the remaining land is being taken over by the government for the ousing scheme.

Considering the arguments, the high court issued interim orders directing the government not allot the university land for house sites and issued notices to the chief secretary, principal secretaries of revenue, agriculture departments and other officials from Guntur district whom the petitioner made respondents in the case.

Later, the high court heard a petition challenging the reservation applied in the ensuing local body elections and posted the hearing to six weeks later. One Anand from Prakasam district had moved the high court contending that the new reservation adopted by the government was faulty as the quota remained unchanged at several places.

Arguing on behalf of the petitioner, advocate Pranati said with the new method adopted by the state government instead of the earlier rotations system to decide reservation in local bodies, many sections of the society did not get reservation in the present elections.

Title: BJP MLA Raja Singh slams KCR govt
Content: Hyderabad: BJP MLA Raja Singh on Tuesday alleged that chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao is behaving like a chameleon who cannot be trusted. He said that the CM, under the pretext of coronavirus, has shied away from answering difficult questions. He sought to know from the CM what service he has done to the state in past six years. Raja Singh alleged that opposition voice was suppressed and less time was allotted to speak on issues. TNN

Title: Covid-19 scare in Kolkata: Clubs take preventive steps but put responsibility onus on members
Content: KOLKATA: The Covid-19 pandemic has left the top brass of several city clubs battling a dilemma on how to approach fellow members and ask them to refrain from visiting the club if they have recently travelled abroad. Though clubs have taken a slew of measures announced by the government, including closure of swimming pool and gymnasium and putting in place deep cleaning protocol, senior committee members admitted the virus could only be blocked through responsible behaviour of members and not extensive sterilization efforts.Following the advisories from the Centre and state govenrment, Tollygunge Club has suspended reciprocal affiliation with clubs across India and rest of the world that allows members of other affiliate clubs to walk into Tolly and enjoy the facilities here. But it has been unable to bluntly ask members who have travelled recently to stay out for at least a fortnight. A large section of the club’s members are senior corporate executives and businessmen and many travel overseas frequently.“All our members are educated and established individuals. Naturally, one expects them to be responsible citizens. We have through a mailer made the concern of Covid-19 infection known to the members and expect those who have travelled abroad in recent times to stay away for the time being,” said Tolly Club chief executive and managing director Anil Mukerji.Celebrating its 125th year, The Tolly has bad to cancel a jazz fest organised by Alliance Francaise and a cultural and heritage festival to mark 400 years of Bengal, shut down the swimming pool and gym. The kitchen has been fumigated and a rigorous housekeeping regimen put in place to keep the virus at bay.At Calcutta Rowing Club , secretary Chandan Roychowdhury listed out a slew of measures that had been taken including cancellation of DJ nights and weekly programmes. But he conceded there was no way to ensure a member who had travelled abroad didn’t visit the club unless the member acted responsibly. “We can only request members to keep the club safe; not monitor their travel itinerary. On our part, we are doing everything to secure the premises,” said Roychowdhury.CRC and Lake Club have decided to suspend rowing activities. Sources said that while rowing was a non-contact sport and allowed enough social distancing to keep the virus from spreading, the change rooms used by rowers were a matter of concern.At CCFC, committee member Saugata Nandi, too, admitted the high profile of members made it difficult to employ screening activities that corporates could employ in offices. “A club is a place to socialise. We cannot police them. We have requested those who have travelled abroad to stay away for 15 days and hope they do so,” said Nandi, adding that the club has advanced the final match of the merchants’ cup cricket by three days to Wednesday to finish off sporting engagements at the earliest.Calcutta Club, too, has cancelled a tennis tournament, drama and other programmes scheduled to be held later this month. “The club’s revenues are taking a hit but there is little one can do in these hard times,” said A Basu, former president of the club.

Title: Kannur MCH likely to get virology laboratory soon
Content:
Kannur: In the backdrop of the Covid-19 threat, and the increased instances of viral infections, the demand to set up a Virology laboratory at Kannur Govt Medical College in Pariyaram in the district has gained momentum, and the discussions in this regard are going on, giving rise to the hope that it might become a reality soon, according to the officials.

Though places like Kozhikode, Thrissur, Alappuzha and Thiruvananthapuram have such facilities, there is no such facility in north Malabar and in the present health scenario it would be beneficial to have a virology laboratory here, said medical college principal N Roy.

“We have already mooted such a proposal and held discussions with the directorate of medical education, and if the laboratory comes up here , it would be beneficial for the residents of the north Malabar region, because it would bring down the time to get the results in case of infections like the present one,” he said.

Now, even when the swab is tested in Kozhikode laboratory, it takes a day to get the result.

But if there is a laboratory here, the result would be made available within hours and this would help the treatment and isolation of the patients, in case they test positive.

According to the authorities of the medical college, which was taken over from the cooperative sector by the state government, they have the floor space and manpower to handle such a facility and the total expense to set up a moderate laboratory would be less than Rs 25 lakh.

“We can set up the laboratory in a 1,500-1,800sq ft space with a separate entry, which is available here and it additionally requires a RT-polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR) facility to test for the Covid-19 virus,” said Rajan Joseph Payyappilli, head of the department of microbiology.

All other facilities are there, including the dedicated manpower, as they have already got a microbiology laboratory with basic facilities.

Once the lab is set up and it gets the sanction from the National Virology Institute in Pune, which has to provide the probe to identify the virus, it will be of great use even if it is a moderate facility, according to the authorities of the medical College.

Moreover, since the institution offers post-graduation in microbiology, such a laboratory would be beneficial for the researches of the students as well, they said, adding that they are hopeful the government would consider the proposal favourably.

Title: Semester exams likely to be delayed
Content:
Kolkata: The decision to close colleges and universities may have an adverse impact on the holding of the semester examinations, said members of West Bengal Higher Education Council on Tuesday. The meeting of the council, attended by all the state university vice-chancellors , was chaired by education minister Partha Chatterjee.

“Though no decision could be taken, there is a possibility of delay in holding the next semester, which is scheduled in June. However, a decision will be taken later in the next review meeting of the council,” said a VC.

Late on Tuesday night, the higher education department issued a circular, clarifying the decision of the government. “All classes suspended. Administrative departments of universities like the office of vice chancellor, registrar, finance/examination department, head of the institute, emergency services e.g. electricity, cleanliness, water supply, security may remain open as per local need. It will be decided by the head of respective departments,” it said.

Hostels will also remain closed till April l5, though adequate arrangements as per protocol will be made by the institutes for foreign students who are not being able to leave the campus.

Title: Uttarakhand: Task force formed to monitor Covid-19 situation
Content: DEHRADUN: The Uttarakhand government has constituted a task force headed by the chief secretary to monitor the coronavirus situation in the state. Taking into account the scenario, the task force will recommend the required action to be taken.Meanwhile, Dehradun district magistrate Ashish Srivastava on Tuesday debunked rumours that were circulated in social media about vegetable markets being closed in wake of coronavirus scare.A total of 51 samples have been collected for Covid-19 testing. Out of the 29 results available, 28 are negative and one is positive. The report of 22 other samples is still awaited.Through a written note, the DM has specified that there is no plan to close any vegetable market, grocery store, ration shop or mandi. He has assured that these shops would remain open for the people.The DM has ordered the district police to catch people spreading rumours and false information on social media and take strict action against them.

Title: Now, Indian can coach ISL team
Content:
Panaji: Derrick Pereira and Clifford Miranda , both of whom took charge of FC Goa on an interim basis, can take permanent charge of the team, according to rules being framed for next season of the Indian Super League ( ISL ).

Since inception of the ISL in 2014, Indian coaches have not been allowed to take charge. If there were marquee managers at the start, foreign coaches, even if they had valid coaching licenses, needed approval of the organisers till last season.

Now, all that is set to change with the organisers allowing any coach with a Pro Coaching Licence to take charge from next season.

“The decision to appoint a coach has been left entirely to the respective clubs. The only requirement, whether it’s for a foreign or Indian, is a Pro-License,” said one official who has been tracking the development.

Last season, the organisers had said that an assistant coach can be appointed the head coach, if he has a Pro License, has been with the club for at least two years, on the bench for 16 matches, and has experience of managing a team in the top division. No such rules will now be in force as anyone with a licence can take charge.

“The league has in the past refused quite a few coaches, despite having valid licenses,” said the source.

Except probably at FC Goa, the new guidelines are unlikely to tempt clubs to put an Indian at the helm of affairs. Clubs like Bengaluru FC, Chennaiyin FC, NorthEast United FC and Odisha FC all have Indian coaches with Pro licence on their rolls, but it’s unlikely that any of them would be considered for the top post.

The only possibility remains at FC Goa where Derrick Pereira has his own set of admirers and is understood to have made club president Akshay Tandon think. FC Goa will compete in the AFC Champions League next season and a decision on the coach – with 90 applicants jostling for the job – expected next month.

When FC Goa decided to part ways with Sergio Lobera at a crucial stage, Derrick was the first choice to steady the ship. He held the first team meeting, had discussions with players, but had to take a backseat – at least for official purposes – as the organisers said he couldn’t be appointed as interim coach, since he wasn’t part of the first team coaching staff. Clifford was then handed the responsibility and the duo ensured there were no hurdles, winning the next three games and finishing on top at the end of the league stage. Goa bowed out in the semifinals after a 5-6 aggregate loss against Chennaiyin FC.

Title: Oppn objects to two RS nominations, EC order today
Content:
Kolkata: Two Rajya Sabha nominations from Bengal have come under question during scrutiny of papers submitted for the polls slated for March 26. The Election Commission will decide on the two nominations on Tuesday.

One of them is by Dinesh Bajaj, former Trinamool MLA from Jorasanko who has submitted his nomination as an Independent candidate, and the other is former MP and TMC candidate Mausam Noor. Cancellation of either of the two, or both, nominations won’t require voting on March 26 as the remaining five or four with valid nominations will be elected unopposed.

Bajaj has submitted a self-signed affidavit. Left candidate and senior lawyer Bikash Bhattacharya pointed this out to the presiding officer. An affidavit becomes notarized after it is presented to a notary public and the affiant (the individual requesting notarization) swears under oath that the facts contained therein are true. A notarized affidavit, thus, bears the signature of the notary public. Bajaj’s affidavit doesn’t bear any such signature.

Noor, in her notarized affidavit, hasn’t mentioned the criminal cases slapped on her during TMC regime while she was a Congress MP. According to a Supreme Court ruling, a party giving nomination to a candidate having criminal cases has to upload it on social websites and publish it in at least one newspaper justifying its choice. TMC has uploaded it on the party’s official website only.

Noor hasn’t declared one of her properties. Left MLAs pointed out that she has filled the nomination form as Mausam Noor when her name in the passport is Mausam Benazir Noor. “My name in EPIC is Mausam Noor. I have put my signature following my name in the EPIC,” the candidate said.

Title: ‘300 transformers added to improve power supply’
Content:
Q. Has there been an increase in Hyderabad’s power consumption? What are the plans to meet this demand during summer? – Rajeshwari Vasireddy

A. There has been a rise in the power demand every year during summer. In last May, the maximum power demand was 3,300 MW and is expected to touch 3,500 MW this summer. Presently, Greater Hyderabad is getting about 2,600 MW and has been supplying power without any hurdles. TSSPDCL is fully ready to meet power demand during the upcoming summer. Tree cutting and line maintenance works have already taken up and will be completed in the next 10 days. If there is any overloading on the existing transformers, additional distribution transformers will be added. We have already provided 300 transformers in the city and 200 more will be added in April. TSSDPCL will provide 22 numbers 12.5 MVA transformers in the substation for better power supply.

Q. I am a resident of S R C Naik Nagar, IDA Jeedimetla. My locality is facing an issue of power outages caused due to obstruction by tree branches. Can you replace old lines with cables so that we don’t have to choose between the green cover and uninterrupted power supply? -- Vamsi Tadepalli

A. Yes, I will personally look into the issue to ensure that such power interruptions do not occur in the future and the concerned officer will be instructed to take all preventive measures.

Q. I live in old Alwal and our electricity bill amount, over the past few months has been increasing by Rs 100 – Rs 150. What should I do? -- Jai Prakash Sharma

A. Please contact local Assistant Engineer/Operation or ADE/Operation/ Lalbazar to check the meter. Though I think that the bill being generated is correct, if necessary, they will arrange for the meter to be tested in the laboratory.

Q. There are close to 1000 flats in our colony situated in Hydernagar near Miyapur Metro Terminus.

We have a problem of high voltage that’s leading to high power consumption and frequent fusing of bulbs. -- G Harihara IIyer

A. Assistant Divisional Engineer/Operation/ Miyapur will be instructed to reduce the taps of power transformers in the sub-stations to maintain rated voltage.

Q. Residents of east Marrepally are regularly faced with voltage fluctuations due to overgrown tree branches on the HT lines opposite Addaguta Substation. When we complained, we were told cutting tree branches is GHMC’s job. This tussle has resulted in consumers suffering. -- N Ramanathan

A. There is no dispute between the GHMC and the electricity department. The ADE/Operation/Marredpally will be instructed to trim all tree branches near LT and 11KV lines, in coordination with the GHMC. Steps will be taken to arrest power theft.

Q. The TSSPDCL has not kept pace with paperless payment (digital) in spite of the PM's announcement four years ago. Your department does not accept debit cards for payment. Why do you not use POS instruments? -- Dr Y S Prabhakar Rao

A. Yes, the debit card facility is available for those using the TSSPDCL App for online payment of current bills. At present there is no facility to make such payments at banks or at department counters. The matter will be resolved shortly.

Q. We have been experiencing voltage problems in Rajapet 33KV area in Yadadri district for the last two months, specially post 5 pm. On enquiry we were told that it was because of some problem with rural feeders and instructions from top. – Rajender Reddy

A. Instructions have already been given to local officials to operate taps in 33/11KV sub-station to maintain rated voltage. Even Transco officials have been requested to look into.

Q. Just to check the power supply one has to call the assistant engineer’s office and the lineman comes after repeated reminders. When he does, he doesn’t do the work unless bribed/paid. This is harassment. -- Ram Thakur

A. We haven’t received many such complaints. But if we do, serious action will be taken against those involved after SE/Vigilance inquiry.

Q. The call centre for power issues, 1912, isn’t effective at all. Even during long power outages, they seem unaware of any such issue. My humble suggestion would be to wind-up this centre. – Chandra Shekhar

A. Instructions are being issued for effective handling of phone calls at 1912 (ECR) and to propose more operators.

Q. For the last few months our apartments i.e. Patel's BrightView Hislop Road Kowkoor has been facing frequent outages from Kowkoor Substation, sometimes for hours together. Also, we have observed voltage fluctuation. -- Ayyagari Srinivas

A. The instructions have been issued to not take up any long shutdowns and to avoid voltage fluctuations in future. However, this will be under observation.

Q. While buying a second-hand house or flat, one has to not only submit all documents for verification to the registering authority but also the GHMC for changing name in their registers. If that’s not all, the same set of documents have to be submitted yet again to TSSPDCL. Here also all the documents have to be signed by a notary signature etc etc. My question is, since all the documents are verified at two different government offices, why a third verification? The certificate from GHMC should suffice, shouldn't it? For an octogenarian like me, this is also an expensive affair because I have to engage a middleman to do the running around, who’ll also fleece me. Can this not be simplified? – A H Menon

A. The ownership and others are essential and signature of transferor and transferee are needed to avoid legal complications.

Q. We belong to Symphony Park Homes - a GHMC community. Due to non-completion by the builder despite paying full amount we constructed on our own and approached High Court for the delay in providing electricity connections to our villas. The High Court ordered Patancheru ADE to provide electricity to 150 villas within a time frame of six weeks. This time frame lapsed on February 20, but the builder is still choosy in providing electricity and not heeding to High court order. We request you to look into the matter and help us get our electricity connections without any further delay. --

Sudheer P

A. The concerned DE/Operation/Patancheru is instructed to solve the issue as per the advice of SLA.

Q. The TSSPDCL staff have not been coming on time to issue our electricity bills on time at Lokayuktha colony in Udgyognagar (Badangpet). Can you please look into it? – V Dharma Raj

A. Instructions will be issued to the concerned officials to take meter readings on time.

Title: Kodai hotels searched, tourist spots shut
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: A team of officials conducted an inspection in hotels and illegal stays in Kodaikanal on Tuesday to check whether any new accommodations were provided in the wake of the Covid-19 scare. The move comes after hoteliers were instructed not to provide accommodation to visitors any further and start vacating those already staying.

Based on orders from the state government all sightseeing places in the hill station were closed from Tuesday until further orders. At present, only those who are awaiting tickets and making arrangements for alternate travel plans are allowed to stay in hill stations.

The team consisting of officials from the revenue, municipality, tourism, police and health departments conducted searches. “While the checks were conducted in various parts of the tourist town, importance was given to Vattakanal area, which is preferred by foreigners. It is also the place where a large number of illegal stays had mushroomed in the recent past,” said an official, who took part in the inspection.

The team came across a hotel, which had violated the orders and provided accommodation to six German tourists. They did not inform the police or health officials. The hotelier was let off with a severe warning. The hotel will be shut down if he is found violating the rules next time, officials said.

Secretary of Kodaikanal hoteliers association, Abdul Kani Raja said they have been fully cooperating with the officials.

He said that those,who are already staying in hotels have been asked to vacate. However, they are given a day or two to arrange for travel.

Raja admitted that illegal stays pose a threat during this time. Based on a court order a year back, around 300 hotels were sealed for violating masterplan rules. With just around 100 hotels available, illegal stays have sprung up to cash in on the demand, Raja said.

Similarly, tourist places in Madurai and other southern districts were closed from Tuesday onwards.

A tourism official from Madurai said, “As far as Madurai is concerned there is no restriction in providing accommodation to visitors, but hotels have been asked to provide all the information regarding their guests and their travel history.”

Title: Drug to treat inflammation may worsen Covid-19
Content: New Delhi: People showing symptoms of the novel coronavirus should refrain from taking anti-inflammatory drug Ibuprofen and use paracetamol instead. This claim by France’s health minister has received support from World Health Organization ( WHO ). The UN health agency’s experts on Tuesday said they were ‘looking into this to give further guidance.’“In the meantime, we recommend using paracetamol, and not Ibuprofen as a self-medication. That’s important,” said an expert. He added that if Ibuprofen had been “prescribed by a professional, then, of course, that’s up to them.”A recent study published in medical journal, The Lancet, hypothesised that an enzyme boosted by anti-inflammatory drugs such as Ibuprofen could facilitate and worsen Covid-19 infection. This was followed by a warning from French health minister Veran who advised Covid-19 suspects to refrain from using the drug, commonly prescribed and consumed over-the-counter for fever, pain and inflammation.“In case of fever, take paracetamol,” the minister wrote and stressed that patients already being treated with anti-inflammatory drugs should take advice from their doctors.Paracetamol must be taken strictly according to the recommended dose, because too much of it can damage the liver.The Covid-19 pandemic has infected around two lakh people globally and killed over 7,800. It is known to cause fever, dry cough and shortness of breath in most patients, but in some cases, involving elderly and those with co-morbidities such as diabetes, hypertension and heart disease, among others, it can result in pneumonia and multi-organ failure leading to death.There is no cure for the disease and treatment involves symptomatic relief mostly. Recently, Indian Council of Medical Research (ICMR) suggested that Lopinavir and Ritonavir, anti-HIV drugs, could be used in adults who are confirmed positive for Covid-19 and have complications such as: severe respiratory distress, very low blood pressure and new-onset organ dysfunction. It has fixed parameters to decide how severe the respiratory distress should be for the fixed dose combination to be used on a patient.Similar parameters have been fixed for other possible complications as well, upon which the drug can be used to save the patients.According to ICMR experts, the inclusion of the anti-HIV drugs for treating Covid-19 was based on earlier evidence about their effectiveness against SARS and MERS coronaviruses that led to outbreaks in different parts of the world in 2002-03 and 2012, respectively, as well as the docking studies conducted by National Institute of Virology, Pune.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Indore: No weekend treats at Sarafa & 56 for now
Content: INDORE: In view of Covid-19, major public gardens including, Meghdoot and Regional Park have been shut, while food zones - Chhappan Dukaan and Sarafa - will remain closed on weekends to avoid large gathering of people.Collector Lokesh Kumar Jatav said, “All educational institutions, library, gymnasiums, water parks, entertainment parks, marriage halls, discotheques, auditoriums along with major public gardens will remain shut till the next order. They are being closed as preventive move to contain spread of Covid-19. We are also contemplating to close down big malls but no decision has been taken as of now,” he said.On Tuesday, divisional commissioner Akash Tripathi held a meeting of senior officials of departments concerned in view of Covid-19. The officials were instructed to pay attention on sensitizing people about Covid-19. “This fact has come to fore that some countries had taken coronavirus for granted and now they are facing it as epidemic. Additional precautions can help us to control it easily,” he said.During the meeting, Indore airport director Aryama Sanyal told the senior officials that screening of passengers arriving from Dubai was being carried out in coordination with health department. Railways officials said that steps were being taken to spread awareness among people.The officials said that over 900 trains arrive at Indore station and proper preventive measures were being taken in cleaning and sanitisation of their coaches.Tripathi instructed the officials to keep a watch on passengers arriving in Indore through inter-state buses. He also directed the officials to cancel permission for fairs, which are to be held in near future, to avoid any public gathering.

Title: Covid-19 scare in Telangana: Special rooms in exams for those with cold symptoms
Content: HYDERABAD: To limit the spread of coronavirus, the state has decided to make students showing symptoms like cold and cough sit for exams in a special room. The state education minister, Sabitha Indra Reddy, who reviewed arrangements for the Secondary School Certificate (SSC) examination on Tuesday, said hand sanitizers or liquid soap will be available in all centers.“Students can wear protective masks and even carry their water bottles into the examination hall. Further, to ensure that they keep their hands sanitized, liquid soap or hand sanitizer will be made available,” said Reddy, adding that a total of 5,34,903 students will be appearing for the SSC examinations that will be held between March 19 and April 6. She assured students that all necessary arrangements are in place for smooth conduct of examinations and they should not panic.The minister said that reserved invigilators will be kept at all 2,530 centers so that unwell invigilators can be relieved immediately.To make sure that students don’t gather in large numbers near the center, the education minister said that they will be allowed into the centre from 8.30 am to 9.30 am and added that they will be given grace time of 5 minutes. She said that students can download their hall tickets from the board’s website.“There is no need to take principal’s signature on the downloaded hall tickets. Students will be allowed to appear for the exam even without the signature,” said Reddy.Keeping the rising temperatures in mind, the education department has decided to have two medical professionals, stock basic medicines and ORS packets at each center. A special control room – 040 23230942, will be available for students and parents round the clock to resolve exam issues. The TSRTC will be plying special buses to make sure students reach the centres on time.

Title: Reusable prison-manufactured face masks to address scarcity in market
Content:
Vijayawada: With parts of Andhra Pradesh facing an acute shortage of face masks in the wake of coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak, tailoring units of three of four central prisons in Andhra Pradesh has begun producing quality face masks (reusable) and supplying to people and local markets at a low price.

The inmates of the central prisons in Nellore, Visakhapatnam and Kadapa are manufacturing two types of face masks and are ready to manufacture them in bulk.

Meanwhile, district medical and health officer of Nellore, S Rajya Lakshmi, on Tuesday approved the quality of the face masks manufactured by the inmates of central prison and informed that they will place the order after assessment of the required numbers.

Speaking to TOI, superintendent of the Central Prison of Nellore, MR Ravi Kiran said it is the first prison to have come forward to manufacture face masks to address the scarcity of face masks in the market. Prisoners in the tailoring unit designed the face masks as per the recommendations of the government doctors and district administration, he added.

At present, the inmates are manufacturing two types of three-layered reusable masks — with elastic band and thread model . Based on the orders received from government and private organisations, our prison has manufactured over 5,000 masks so far and we have managed to manufacture over 2,000 masks per day, he added. The mask manufactured at Nellore prison is cheaper than other masks as each mask costs Rs 15 for government institutions and Rs 16 for private individuals, Ravi Kiran added.

With the demand for face masks rising due to COVID-19 scare, there has have been instances where medical stores were found selling them at a higher rate than the marked price.

“We have asked for the trained inmates to manufacture face masks for prisoners, jail staff and visitors to the prison. The inmates of the tailoring units used to manufacture at least 700 masks per day with the available resources. If there is a shortage of raw material, we will arrange for more and are ready to supply the face masks to institutions and individuals. Each mask costs around Rs 15,” said superintendent of Visakhapatnam Central Prison, S Rahul.

IG of Prisons, G Jayavardhan said they have directed wardens and others officials at prisons to organise sensitisation drives to spread awareness about COVID-19 and send daily updates to the headquarters. Apart from that, steps have been taken to prevent the possible spread of the virus in the prisons. Arrangements have been made to identify the prisoners if they were to fall ill and shift them to hospitals, he added.

Title: Sewage overflow plugged after report on TOI app
Content:
Hyderabad: A complaint on overflowing sewage at Jagruthi Nagar that was published in TOI’s Citizen Reporter column on March 11, was resolved on the very same day by the Hyderabad Metropolitan Water Supply and Sewerage Board (HMWS&SB).

The photo that displayed sewage overflow on the streets of Jagruthi Nagar was reported by Ballari Sai, a resident of the area. “The sewage water was overflowing on the streets for nearly five to six days. The place had turned into a stinky mess, making it difficult for the commuters to cross the lane and use the road,” said Sai, adding that the sewage overflow emanated foul smell, leaving commuters and passers-by inconvenienced. The leakage also posed potential health hazards and was a serious cause for concern for the residents of the area.

Soon after the issue was highlighted on the Times Citizen My Space page, HMWS&SB officials swung into action and resolved the issue immediately. Although the HMWS&SB swiftly resolved the issue, residents claim that the issue of sewage overflow is one that resurfaces every couple of weeks. They urged authorities to find a permanent solution.

“Before the onset of monsoon, the HMWS&SB and the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation should work together to find a permanent solution for the sewage overflow issue in the area,” said a resident.
