Residents claimed that other issues such as open manholes and frequent power cuts also plague the area and requested the authorities concerned to address the issues.

Title: Maharashtra: Fever watch on five Covid-19 clusters to check spread
Content: PUNE: Five clusters of novel coronavirus which causes Covid-19 have been identified in the state in Pune, Navi Mumbai, Mumbai, Nagpur and Kalyan wherein more than one case of the contagion has been seen in a residential pocket or zone (cluster).“There are certain areas or demographics in which more than one case of the Covid-19 infected is seen. These areas are called clusters. The list of clusters could evolve every day depending on the spread of the virus,” state surveillance officer Pradip Awate told TOI on Tuesday.Awate said,“We have identified five clusters, one each in five different cities in Maharashtra. Strict measures are being taken in the form of fever surveillance within a three-km radius of such areas to rule out active transmission of the Covid-19 virus in the community. So far, there has been no community spread identified anywhere in the six clusters.”Agra was the first city in India to implement the strategy after six residents contracted the infection from their relative who had returned from Italy.The four positive cases of Covid-19 in Pune, all residents of Sinhagad Road area, have led to implementing the strategy in three to five km radius of Sinhagad Road area to curb the spread of the virus in the community in the city as well.Union health minister Harsh Vardhan also called upon states to adopt the cluster containment strategy making district collectors more accountable and laid emphasis on contact tracing and strengthening district surveillance teams to avoid widespread community transmission.“In the cluster containment approach, we immediately start checking and sensitising every household within a 3km radius of the house of an infected person and those who have come in contact with the affected to prevent the community spread of the virus,” public health expert Vaishali Jadhav of Pune Municipal Corporation said.The cluster containment strategy is aimed at containing the virus within a defined geographic area by early detection, breaking the chain of transmission and thus preventing its spread to newer areas, senior public health expert Subhash Salunke, former director general of the state health department, said.

Title: Six held for killing man, throwing body in Ganga
Content:
HARIDWAR: Six people were arrested on Tuesday by city police in connection with the alleged murder of a local history-sheeter Rohit (40).

Police suspects that the body was thrown into Ganga by the accused, although the body hasn’t been found as yet.

Reportedly, Rohit, a resident of Rajiv Nagar Colony under Jwalapur police station jurisdiction, was harassing a woman .

When the matter came to light, people from the woman’s colony asked Rohit to not trouble the woman but he didn’t listen to them.

“Rohit got into a verbal spat with some men from the woman’s colony. The spat turned ugly and those men killed him and threw his body into Ganga. We have booked eight people in the matter under section 302 (murder), 147 (punishment of rioting), 201 (causing disappearance of evidence) of the Indian Penal Code. Six people have already been held and efforts are ongoing to trace the body,” said SHO city police station Praveen Singh Koshyari.

Title: DK, Kasaragod admins work in tandem at contact tracing
Content:
Mangaluru/Kasaragod: Surveillance teams in Dakshina Kannada and Kasaragod districts have initiated the process of contact tracing of all those who met a passenger flying down from Dubai on March 14. The passenger who reported to Kasaragod health authorities on his return from Mangaluru International Airport, tested positive for Covid-19, said minister for health and family welfare B R Sreeramulu on Tuesday.

He said surveillance teams in the two districts are coordinating with each other in contact tracing. “The passenger, as per reports, boarded a taxi from MIA and went straight to Kasaragod. Standard health protocols as per ministry guidelines have been initiated, and all those who met the passenger are being monitored,” the health minister said.

A Facebook post by the Kasaragod information department, quoting district medical officer M V Ramadas, said the passenger who had symptoms of Covid-19 after reporting to the general hospital, was initially placed under house quarantine. Since his swab reports from the National Institute of Virology, Alappuzha, confirmed that he had Covid-19, he was shifted to the isolation ward at the Kasaragod general hospital, Dr Ramadas said.

The information department added that as on March 16, 325 people were under observation for Covid-19 and 321 are under home quarantine in Kasaragod district.

On the same day, two passengers who arrived from Brazil and Dubai, respectively, were shifted to the isolation ward at the general hospital and their swab samples have been sent for testing, Dr Ramadas said, adding the administration is working as per protocols laid down by the government.

Sreeramulu said the Dakshina Kannada district administration has kept a vigil on people from Kasaragod coming to Dakshina Kannada by using the main roads, and will cover all 24 entry points into the district, shortly. Screening and vigil will also be stepped up at the bus station and airport for domestic passengers as well as at Mangaluru Central and junction railway stations.

These transit points see a large number of passengers come to this coastal city from Kasaragod, the minister said.

Title: Alp municipality demands closure of Bevco outlets
Content:
Alappuzha: In the wake of positive Covid-19 cases in the state , Alappuzha municipal council has passed a resolution demanding to close all the outlets of Kerala State Beverage Corporation (Bevco) in the municipal area to keep the people safe.

The resolution has been submitted to Alappuzha district collector M Anjana seeking her immediate intervention in this issue.

Municipal chairman Illikkal Kunjumon said though all the public gatherings have been banned, there is no control or ban on the long queues in front of Bevco outlets.

“Many strangers keep coming to the outlets of Bevco daily. We don’t know who they are and where they come from. So as per the present situation, it is not safe. The health department directed that each people should keep a distance of one metre. In these outlets, people are not keeping such distance and people were seen in close physical proximity to each other. It is very dangerous considering the present situation. So, we have decided to pass a resolution drawing the attention of the district administration and authorities concerned to this issue,” the municipal chairman said.

According to the municipal councillors, the place for standing in the queue in front of Bevco is a narrow and congested place. “Some are also drinking alcohol near the outlets using same glass. These are creating risk for the spread of Covid-19,” they said

“Majority of the council members supported our resolution and we are expecting a positive step in this regard,” said the municipal chairman.

Title: Youth assaulted with rods and glass bottles, dies
Content:
Kolkata: A 25-year-old youth lost his life after being assaulted with rods, wickets and glass bottles by a group of men. The incident took place in Nabadiganta area in Panchasayar, close to south suburban Kolkata. Two of the accused have been arrested while search is on for others.

Cops said the youth, Biswasrup Das, was beaten up after he and his father protested when the accused attacked a street dog. Local police sources claimed an old enmity over promoting and syndicate raj — in which a local criminal from Ajoynagar is involved — is also being probed.

“Two persons — Pradip Dhar (38) and Jayanta Chakraborty (22) — have been arrested till now,” said Gaurav Lal DC (east). The vehicle used to escape after committing the crime has also been seized.

According to joint CP (crime) Murlidhar Sharma, Biswarup — a driver by profession — had returned home around 11.45pm on Monday. “When Biswarup returned, his father, Debu, was preparing to have dinner with him. Soon, the duo heard some dogs barking. Debu came out and found two persons, Tarak and Dhalu, beating up a couple of street dogs. When Debu protested, they started abusing him,” said an officer.

Later, the victim heard the commotion and came out to protest. He was then surrounded and assaulted by the accused with wine bottles, bricks and wickets. The 25-year-old sustained severe injuries and lost consciousness,” said Sharma.

The family members rushed both Das and his father to a private hospital nearby. Biswarup was soon declared dead. “We received the news of the incident from the hospital around 12.20am on Tuesday. We have recorded Debu’s statement. While two people have been arrested, we have detained a few for questioning. A case has been registered at Panchasayar police station,” said an investigating officer from east division police. Besides local cops, the detective department, too, is probing the case.

Title: Baby dies, Gandhi hosp staff booked
Content:
Hyderabad: A negligence case was registered against Gandhi Hospital staff after an infant delivered through a C-section procedure a few days back died on Monday.

Samatha E (25) from Mahbubabad district was admitted to a hospital in Warangal on March 11. However, due to complications, she was shifted to Gandhi Hospital in Hyderabad. She was seven months pregnant at the time and underwent a surgery the next day. She gave birth to a baby boy.

“In one of the first documents, the baby’s gender was assigned female while the rest of the documents mentioned male. The discrepancy was suspicious. We traced the files and think it is a clerical error. We have taken up the investigation to check negligence from the hospital’s side,” said Chilkaguda police.

“Samatha delivered the baby on 12 March. She was shifted to NICU ward under paediatric care after one and half days due to prematurity. I have personally gone through her case sheets and seen her,” said Gandhi Hospital Superintendent P Sharavan Kumar.

The hospital has also ordered an enquiry about the incident.

Title: Man sentenced to life for murdering wife
Content:
Hyderabad: A 33-year-old man on Tuesday was given life sentence and a fine of Rs 1,000 for murdering his wife in 2016.

The accused, Syed Basha, was an alcohol addict. He was staying in a rented house along with his wife and her sister. The couple had frequest fights due to his addiction, said the police.

In October 2016, he throttled and killed the victim after an altercation.TNN

Title: Anti-CAA protesters turn down police’s appeal to suspend stir
Content:
The protesters said they had taken safety steps against Covid-19

PUNE: The anti-CAA protesters staging an agitation since January 10 at the ‘Kondhwa Shaheen Baugh’ on Tuesday turned down the police’s appeal to suspend their stir till March 31 in view of the health hazard posed by the Covid-19 contagion.

They have, however, agreed to “significantly reduce” the number of demonstrators at the protest site.

Senior inspector Vinayak Gaikwad and other police officers held a meeting with the protesters on Tuesday afternoon to convince them about the need for such measures. The protest, which sees the attendance of hundreds of women and girls every day, has been organised outside Konark Mall in Kondhwa under the banner of Kul Jamaat-e-Tanzeem (KJT), an umbrella organization of several groups.

Deputy commissioner of police (Zone V) Suhas Bawache told TOI, “We appealed to the protesters to suspend the agitation. If they are not considering our plea, then we will take a call on taking action against them depending on the situation.”

Alsaba Shaikh, one of the KJT committee members, said, “We have decided to reduce the number of protesters from around 400 to 10-15 people. Our agitation is peaceful and will continue till our demands of revoking Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019, National Population Register (NPR) and National Register of Citizens (NRC) is met.”

Gaikwad told TOI, “We approached the protesters following a directive from the city police’s special branch. We have given them copies of the decision taken by the state government and the district administration regarding large gatherings. We will decide on action against the protesters under Section 188 (disobedience of order duly promulgated by a public servant) of the Indian Penal Code, if the agitation continues.”

The district administration has already invoked provisions of the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897 and the Disaster Management Act across Pune district.

Another committee member Gazala Shaikh said, “We have created apt awareness on coronavirus in slums and lower middle class localities and struck a balance by reducing the number of protesters in the larger public interest.”

Haji Gafur Pathan, a PMC corporator and one of the organisers of the agitation, said, “Altogether 25 organisations have come together for the protest. The district administration has been requesting us from Day 1 to discontinue with the protests. We have taken adequate precautions to see that the virus situation does not affect our agitation.”

Title: AFMC to soon have lab for Covid-19 sample test
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: The Armed Forces Medical College (AFMC) will soon have a dedicated laboratory for testing of samples for coronavirus collected from across the state.

The Indian Council of Medical Research on Monday announced that nine additional laboratories, including the one at the AFMC, would soon be made operational for testing of suspected coronavirus patients’ swab samples. “A team of microbiologists, laboratory staffers and technicians recently received training at a facility in New Delhi,” a senior Armed Forces Medical Services (AFMS) officer told TOI on Tuesday.

The laboratory is coming up at the AFMC’s microbiology department. “This department has several laboratories, out of which one will now function as Covid-19 sample testing centre. The facility is equipped with requisite kits,” the officer said.

“Our team will work in tandem with the health department. We are in the process of formulating a standard operating procedure in consultation with the health department. The number of tests to be performed every day and the roles of our experts will be decided soon,” the officer added.

“Besides the experts, senior doctors from other departments will provide requisite assistance,” another AFMS officer said.

“The new facility will enhance our testing capabilities and reduce the time as well,” a senior district administration official said.

Title: Govt plans corporation to mitigate pollution
Content:
Vijayawada: Expressing concern over rising pollution levels, chief minister YS Jaganmohan Reddy said the government would set up a separate corporation to control pollution in the state.

While reviewing pollution levels in AP with officials of Pollution Control Board (PCB), Jagan said the corporation would monitor pollution causing industries, hospitals and other establishments and look into machinery required to treat effluents. “Untreated effluents from industries is being let into water bodies resulting in pollution. There is an urgent need to protect water bodies,” Jagan said.

The corporation will focus on effective collection of effluents and processing and treatment of waste. The body will mitigate pollution levels without affecting industrial growth, he added.

Andhra Pradesh will adopt the best practices of developing nations to deal with rising pollution levels for a bright future for future generations. tnn

Title: How far is safe enough with corona patients, suspects?
Content:
NAGPUR: Many residents expressed concern when pictures of district collector Ravindra Thakare visiting isolation wards in government hospitals appeared in newspapers. On Tuesday, mayor Sandip Joshi visited the family of Covid-19 positive patients to boost their morale.

So, were the district collector and mayor risking their lives by exposing themselves to corona suspects? Doctors say keeping a safe distance from the suspects is enough, and there is no need to run from them.

“We must deal with this crisis seriously and strictly maintain safe distance from Covid-19 suspects, even those who are in home quarantine. But, this doesn’t mean we should not visit their homes, or stop talking to them, or run away from them,” said physician and former IMA national president Dr YS Deshpande .

“Suspects who have tested negative and are in 14-day home quarantine are not patients. They are in quarantine to ensure safety of others. If they are not showing any symptoms after testing negative for Covid-19, it’s safe to visit them. You can also talk to both patients wearing safety masks,” he said.

Those who test positive are immediately admitted to the isolation wards of GMCH. Doctors treating them shared some important rules to deal with these patients.

“Those who have been found positive in test are infected, and they are admitted in isolation. Only doctors can enter their rooms, that too wearing all protection gear. Others may talk to them, but from outside their room, maintaining a safe distance and wearing masks,” said a resident doctor who is treating three positive patients admitted in GMCH.

“When district collector, DDHS and dean of our college visited these patients, they interacted with them from outside their room. There is no risk in it,” the doctor added.

Microbiologist Dr Pritam Agrawal shared some basics regarding Covid-19 that clarify many things about the distance to be maintained.

“Similar to seasonal flu, people can get infected with Covid-19 if they inhale water droplets containing the virus, such as when someone sneezes on them, or by touching a surface contaminated by the virus and then touching their nose or mouth or rubbing their eyes. We can easily avoid this by maintaining distance and hand hygiene,” she said.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: No fresh cases, Pinarayi Vijayan cautions against slightest lapse
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan has cautioned against even the slightest of lapse in precautions to check the spreading of Covid-19 in the state. “The virus is spreading the world over. Hence even the slightest of lapse cannot be tolerated. At present, lapses are happening,” the chief minister said after the review meeting.No fresh case was reported in the state on Tuesday. The total positive cases reported in the state is 27, of which 24 are in the hospitals and three have been cured. However, a 68-year-old Malayali woman, who had returned from Saudi Arabia on March 13, was tested positive in Mahe, which is part of Puducherry on Tuesday. The CM said the three-year-old kid who was under treatment at Ernakulam after testing positive for Covid-19 has been cured.The state health department has put 18,011 people under observation in the state, of which 268 are admitted at designated isolation facilities. Till date 2,467 samples have been sent for testing, of which 1,807 came as negative. On Tuesday, 65 people were hospitalized and 5,342 people were put under observation.More number of people hospitalized are in Thiruvananthapuram (66), followed by Thrissur (38) and Palakkad (27). Seventeen of the 30 primary contacts of the Italian tourist who was in Varkala have tested negative.The CM said the government has decided to constitute an expert committee to advise the government on Covid-19 emergency. He said as a prelude to this he had a meeting with the expert doctors and scientists. An interactive web portal is also being planned to disseminate information on Covid-19 to the common man and health workers.He said the service of medical students and para medical staff will be used to create awareness among the people. The government has decided to give special focus on people above 60 years of age, especially those with respiratory or heart problems.He said the situation is under control and no reports of community spread have been reported. He also urged those under quarantine to follow the protocol.Meanwhile, in Malappuram, 475 primary and secondary contacts of the two Covid-19 patients have been identified and the health authorities have ensured home quarantine of these people. Others have been directed to report to district-level control cell at the earliest.Malappuram district collector has asked all Umrah pilgrims from the district who returned from Jeddah after March 1 to register their names at the control cell via covidtravel@gmail.com.Meanwhile, Ponnani police have registered a case against Tharbhiyathul Islam Sabha for organizing a prayer meet in Ponnani on Monday night.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Air India Express cancels Bahrain flights from Mangaluru
Content: MANGALURU: The Air India Express (AIE) on Tuesday withdrew its flights from Mangaluru International Airport (MIA) to Bahrain over the Covid-19 situation.“Flights to/from Bahrain have been withdrawn as Bahrain Civil Aviation Authority permits only a single Air India Express flight per day.”Meanwhile, in a letter to the airport director, MIA, AIE stated: “This is to inform you that Air India Express flight withdrawn due to Covid-19 notification issued for the suspension of travel.”However, Bahrain has not officially restricted arrivals from India.“This is totally unacceptable, the AIE should at least operate one flight from MIA instead of restricting all. So far there is no travel restriction to Bahrain,” said Vincent who moved to Bahrain two decades ago.“My son was to fly to Bahrain from MIA on Wednesday but flight stands cancelled now. The AIE in its communiqué stated that flights are operational from airports in Kerala. On an average 60-70 passengers travel to Bahrain from MIA in each flight. Why can’t AIE operate one flight in a week to accommodate all those expats,” he questioned.Bahrain has over one lakh expats from undivided Dakshina Kannada.Sources from corporate communications, AIE told TOI that flight may have been grounded due to load factor.

Title: Fix Rs 10,000 per quintal as MSP for turmeric: Govt
Content:
HYDERABAD: Telangana Pradesh Congress Committee (TPCC) president Uttam Kumar Reddy demanded that the centre should fix Rs 10,000 per quintal as minimum support price (MSP) for turmeric in the state.

Raising the issue in Lok Sabha on Tuesday, Uttam Kumar said that the condition of turmeric farmers is pathetic while reminding that Rajnath Singh had given assurance in the last elections that a turmeric board would be set up.

Title: Despite govt orders, General & OBC employees continue stir
Content:
DEHRADUN: Despite a state government order prohibiting assembly of 50 or more people, members of Uttarakhand General and OBC Employees Association, along with their families, staged a massive protest at Parade Ground on Tuesday. Even the children of these employees joined the protests on the day. The protesting state employees remain adamant on boycott of work till the government issues orders to restart promotions in government jobs.

However, the association has decided to limit the number of protesters at Parade Ground in the wake of coronavirus. The association has also announced that the hospital staff, which till now was staging a 150-minute-long protest, will go for a symbolic protest of one hour from Wednesday onwards. Besides, the protesters also demand the state government to provide risk allowance to nurses, who “put their life in danger for the treatment and welfare of patients.”

Following health alerts, the body has also demanded that other government employees should also be given leaves like staff of government schools.

Deepak Joshi, president of the Uttarakhand General & OBC Employees Association, told TOI, “We have been very clear in our demand that we will not back off till the government complies with Supreme Court orders on reservation in promotion. However, in wake of coronavirus scare, we have made slight changes to our protests. The number of protesters at Parade Ground will remain limited.”

Meanwhile, Virendra Gosain, general secretary of the organisation, told TOI, “Nurses play a crucial role in serving people, therefore, we have sought a risk allowance for them. In view of the coronavirus outbreak, the protest time of hospital staff has also been reduced to just one hour.”

Title: Health ministry experts stresses on extensive contact tracing in Pune
Content:
Pune: Extensive contact tracing of infected people is the only way forward to rein in the spread of novel coronavirus (Covid-19) in the city, stressed experts from the Union health ministry’s National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC).

In the city to review the containment plan, the experts advised the health officials to track and isolate even low-risk contacts of infected people to reduce the risk of exposure in the community.

Simply put, it means if an infected person visited a neighbourhood doctor for an initial check-up for flu symptoms, then not just the doctor, other patients waiting for their turn in the lobby area and all the paramedics present there should also be tracked and home-quarantined for 14 days.

Confirming it, senior public health expert Subhash Salunke, former director-general of state health department, said, “Pune has reported maximum cases of Covid-19 in India. This has prompted the visit of the NCDC experts, who reviewed Pune’s containment plan and suggested a few measures. Their foremost advice is to carry out extensive tracing of contacts of Covid19 infected persons.”

Salunkhe, a part of the technical team of the state government that abreast the NCDC experts about the state’s containment plan, said, “That means everyone who was around that person should be tracked and isolated at their homes for 14 days. This includes infected person's high-risk and low-risk contacts. And if any of them develop any symptoms, then they should be moved to hospital’s isolation facility and tested for the contagion.”

Currently, officials have adopted cluster containment strategy to track everyone residing around 3km periphery of the infected person’s residence to see whether they have influenza-like symptoms.

“Instead of tracking every household within the 3km periphery, it is more important to first make an extensive list of all the contacts of the infected persons falling in high- as well as low-risk category and isolate them at their homes for 14 days to reduce the risk of exposure, if any, to the community,” Salunke said.

State surveillance officer Pradip Awate said, “The Union health ministry experts held a meeting of all the staffers involved in contact tracing in Pune, Pimpri Chinchwad and rural parts on Tuesday (March17) to underscore the importance of extensive contact tracing in the current situation.”

THE CONTACTS

Close (high-risk) contacts of a Covid-19 infected person include those living in the same household and having had direct physical contact (shaking hands) with him/her, those having unprotected direct contact with infectious secretions of an infected person, a person who was in a closed environment with an infected person for 15 minutes or more and at a distance of less than two metres.

The low-risk contacts are persons who were in a closed environment with a Covid-19 infected person for less than 15 minutes or at a distance of over two metres, a person having had face-to-face contact with an infected person for less than 15 minutes and at a distance of less than two metres or travelling together with an infected person in any kind of conveyance.

Title: Komatireddy-PM Modi meet raises eyebrows
Content: Hyderabad: Bhongir MP Komatireddy Venkat Reddy on Tuesday met Prime Minister Narendra Modi and urged him to cancel the permissions given to set up a pharma city in Medipally in Rangareddy district. Though the MP ostensibly met Modi to hand over a petition against the pharma city, it raised eyebrows in Congress circles. TNN

Title: Covid-19 in Pune: More than 800 restaurants down shutters for three days
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: A majority of restaurants and bars in Pune city have decided to voluntarily down shutters for three days from Wednesday till Friday in an attempt to arrest the spread of Covid-19. Many restaurants in the city had decided to batten down from Tuesday itself.

While the commissioner of police told TOI that the police has suggested restaurants continue parcel and home delivery services for customers dependant on the establishments for daily meals, Pune Restaurants and Hoteliers Association (PRAHA) said that restaurants may take a call such services if it was viable.

A quick check on online food ordering and delivery platforms showed that many restaurants in the city were unserviceable on Tuesday. Nevertheless, many others, like fast food chains, remained functional on Tuesday.

After a meeting with the police commissioner on Tuesday and appeals sent out by the police to shut establishments that see high footfall, PRAHA decided to send a ‘closed for business’ call to all associated restaurants for the next three days. Earlier on Tuesday morning, the police requested several restaurants, including Vaishali, Roopali, Good Luck, Wadeshwar, among others, on FC Road to close. This was followed by a meeting between the Pune police commissioner and PRAHA members, where the decision was taken.

Pune commissioner of police K Venkatesham said, “We are following instructions issued by the Union government on maintaining sanitation, personal hygiene and social distancing. Wherever this can be followed, those establishments can open. But, as we are aware, maintaining social distancing may not be possible in case of restaurants if they are functioning. Hence, we requested restaurateurs to close establishments temporarily in view of the current situation. Out of their own volition, restaurant owners then decided to keep their establishments shut for three days.”

Venkatesham added that because the city is home to a number of people dependent on restaurants for meals, parcel and home delivery services will be available. “The feasibility of this should be decided by the restaurants because the priority here is to opt for social distancing and other measures to avoid the stage-3 of Covid-19 outbreak,” he said.

PRAHA vice president Vikram Shetty said, “The police authorities have told us to cooperate in the endeavour to curb the spread of infection and we have decided that keeping the restaurants closed for three days is best in the current situation. Oftentimes, people do not understand the gravity of a situation and throng restaurants considering it to be a holiday. Hence, the association has made a conscious call to ask members to remain closed till Friday.”

Ganesh Shetty, president of the association, said, “It was decided that all restaurants and bars will voluntarily close for business from March 18 to 20 initially. We will assess the situation and decide on Friday if there is need to extend the closure.”

Sources from the Pune Hoteliers’ Association added that hotels too have curtailed their restaurant operations in the wake of the decision.

Title: FDA warns against charging excess for masks, sanitisers
Content:
Nashik: Rajendra Shingne, the state Food and Drugs Administration (FDA) minister, on Monday warned of legal action against anyone found selling hand sanitisers and masks at marked-up prices. He said the FDA has received a few complaints.

Shingne was speaking to the manufacturers and dealers of masks and sanitisers at a meeting organised at the government guest house in Nashik.

After reviewing the demand and supply status of these two products, Shingne said the demand has increased by more than 30%. He said that to meet the demand, sanitisers should be manufactured at the local level. All efforts would be made by the government to provide the necessary permissions, the supply of raw materials etc.

He also said the production of masks should be increased. He said that if someone was found selling the masks and sanitizers illegally, the FDA would take action against the dealer concerned.

Shingne added that while some manufacturers had shown willingness to manufacture alcohol-free sanitisers, permission in this regard would be given only after checking their effectiveness.

Gorakh Chaudhary, the president of the Chemists’ Association, Nashik, said that while the demand of masks and sanitisers has increased over the past couple of weeks, the chain of demand and supply has been disturbed. Nonetheless, he said the association members they would restore the supply of sanitisers and masks in the next two-three days.

Many wholesalers are running out of stock in the city. The wholesalers said that the demand from chemists and druggists in the city and other parts of the district was huge, but they were awaiting the supply from manufactures.

Shingne said should stop going to crowded places, use handkerchiefs instead of masks and make use of sanitisers to clean hands.

FDA seizes sanitizers worth Rs 50 lakh in Aurangabad

The food and drug administration (FDA) sleuths on Sunday night raided a godown in Waluj area of the city where people were removing stickers from expired hand sanitizers and pasting new ones at a higher maximum retail price (MRP).

Title: MSRTC, pvt bus operators to curtail operations
Content: Nagpur: The spread of coronavirus is all set to hit state’s biggest public transporter Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) and private bus operators hard. With over 40 testing positive for Covid-19, Maharashtra seems to be the worst-affected.MSRTC’s deputy general manager (DGM) Shivajirao Jagtap said, “As per government orders, bus services cannot be stopped completely. However, as schools and colleges have been ordered closure, we have been rescheduling our trips by withdrawing buses meant for students.”“In the region, at least 15% operations will be reduced. We are keeping a close watch on the situation. Traffic from Pune to Nagpur is satisfactory but there is thin volume towards Pune. If this continues, we will have to withdraw the number of trips to Pune, which are 40 now,” Jagtap said.The coronavirus scare has also led the MSRTC’s Nagpur division to curtail operations. Divisional controller Nilesh S Belsare said, “With schools closing down, we have chalked out a plan to curtail operations in the district by 35,000km (25%). Currently, the division operates buses on 1.70 lakh km routes. From March 18, it will operate on 1.35 lakh km. Considering the revenue of Rs30 per km, we will lose around Rs9 lakh per day.”“From March 20, we will also curtail some trips on trunk routes like Wardha, Amravati, Yavatmal, Chandrapur, Bhandara and Gondia where frequency is good,” said Belsare.He said, “From Wednesday, MSRTC plans mass distribution of 1,000 masks daily to conductors and supervisors who are more vulnerable to public contact. Due to shortage of masks, we will distribute at least 750, which will be destroyed at the end of the day.”Similar piquant situation is being faced by private bus operators who fear the number of trips between Nagpur and Pune will come down below 50% from Wednesday. If at least 70 buses are operating towards Pune from Nagpur, it is expected to come down to 25-30.“In the advent of temporary closure of IT sector in Pune, most of the people from Vidarbha employed there have returned. In the last 15 days, there was a rush on Pune-Nagpur route as people have been asked to work from home. Most of them have returned. During the same period, buses leaving from Nagpur to Pune had few passengers,” said Mahendra Luley, president of Nagpur Private Travels Association (NPTA).“The rush from Pune had even led to increase in fare from Rs1,000 to Rs1,700, but for Pune now there are no bookings even for Rs800 in sleeper class bus travel,” said Bobby Saini of Saini Travels.Saini added, “It is not only Pune route that has been hit. Similar is the case with Shirdi and Hyderabad. People have been avoiding travel to other cities. If the virus scare continues for a month, it will be difficult to even pay EMIs of buses.”

Title: Finding solace & strength in the sands of Dubai
Content:
Last year, I took a trip to Dubai along with my family. The sights, sounds and sheer architectural brilliance of the place left me spellbound. Our itinerary was packed from day 1. We visited a host of places, but the images that stayed with me were from the mesmerizing cruise, the stroll we took along the sprawling Gold souk, the adventurous desert safari, the marvel that was Abu Dhabi.

The huge mosque in Abu Dhabi, complete with intricate carvings all over its interiors, is picturesque and a treat to every eye. It is huge, beautiful and the chandeliers adorning the inside are breathtakingly beautiful. So are the tall buildings in Dubai with glass façades. Though a complete contrast in design, these too are praiseworthy.

The Palm Island which is totally man-made, stretching across kilometres of land extending right into the sea, has huge hotels like Atlantis lining its side. The entire frame makes one makes one wonder the power of man.

Although the place is a desert, there’s a lot of greenery that has been developed to create a sense of calm and peace.

As part of our trip we also visited Burj Dubai known for its unique shape and finally ended at the Burj Khalifa – the tallest and the most exquisite building on the face of the earth today. It was something I had never seen or experienced before. It’s a classic mix of top-notch design and advanced technology. The lift here took us to 124th floor within a span of just a minute. The view from top is amazing. It gives goose bumps, makes one feel on top of the world. This is the highest point in the world – it feels like one has conquered the world. It was really a mind-blowing experience for us. We were in awe looking at the design and construction of the huge buildings around each with a unique design of its own.

Finally, the trip made me realise that if a person wishes he/she can conquer anything in life. It is just a matter of vision and dedication. It was really a life-changing experience for me and my family.

(The writer is faculty and vice-principal at FIITJEE World School, Dilsukhnagar)

Title: IIM Lucknow cancels class after protests, exams optional
Content:
Representative image

Lucknow: Amid the coronavirus threat, Indian Institute of Management-Lucknow (IIM-L) on Tuesday suspended all classes.

It also said that end-semester examinations for its first-year postgraduate programme (PGP) students were optional.

The move came after students staged a protest outside the director’s residence late on Monday night.

Now, first-year PGP students have two options. They can either appear for the exams scheduled from March 21 or appear in June when they return from their summer internship. In the case of latter, dates will be notified about 10 days before the exams. Those taking the exams in June have been asked to vacate the campus by 5pm on March 18. Students have to make their choice latest by 11am on Wednesday through an online form.

According to an email from PGP chairman Ajay Garg to the teacher fraternity on the campus, students met the director late on Monday night with serious concerns about their stay on campus amid virus scare.

Regarding classes, the mail stated that attendance of students for Monday and Tuesday and all suspended classes will be deemed present. The PGP chairman sought cooperation from his colleagues in dealing with the situation and in setting up two question papers, one for March and the other for June.

According to chairperson of corporate communications and media relations at IIM-L Prof Vikas Srivastava , “All classes have been suspended due to coronavirus. Those taking exams in March, adequate distance of 2m will be maintained. We have monitored the situation and followed all guidelines..”

Title: CMDRF scam: Fresh fund diversion of Rs 4.7L found
Content:
KOCHI: The crime branch team probing the diversion of money from the Chief Minister’s Distress Relief Fund has found that an additional Rs 4.7 lakh was siphoned off by the accused bringing the total amount to Rs 27.73 lakh.

The remand report filed before the Muvattupuzha vigilance court, which heard the bail petitions of the accused on Tuesday, said the money was transferred from the account of the first accused.

The court on Tuesday dismissed the bail application of three people arrested in connection with the case. It dismissed the petition of first accused Vishnu Prasad , sixth accused Nidhin NN and seventh accused Shintu Martin .

The accused were not produced in the court in view of the Covid-19 situation in the state. While hearing the plea, the court noted that the current case is a serious one. The scam is reported in flood relief fund, the due beneficiaries of which are flood victims.

The prosecution objected to the bail stating that it would jeopardize the probe. The probe into the scam is still going and investigation also look into whether more cheating was taken place in the fund.

The second accused Mahesh B has not filed bail application. The court sent the accused in remand till March 31.

The investigation team is yet to arrest three more persons accused in the case.

It was found the first accused transferred Rs 10.54 lakh from the treasury account to a CPM leader in Thrikkakara , after duplicating the names of 325 beneficiaries.

Title: Pimpri Chinchwad resident tests positive for Covid-19
Content:
PUNE: A 26-year-old resident of Pimpri Chinchwad tested positive for the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) on Tuesday, taking the tally of infected patients in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad to 17.

The man had returned from the US recently and was quarantined thereafter at Yashwantrao Chavan Memorial (YCM) hospital in Pimpri, after he developed mild symptoms.

Of the 17 cases in Pune, 10 are Pimpri Chinchwad municipal limits, while the other seven are from Pune. Incidentally, there has been no fresh case of the contagion within the limits of Pune Municipal Corporation in the past four days.

“He returned from the US on March 14. When he came to know that US has been placed on the list of countries to be monitored by the government for Covid-19 infection, he self-reported to YCM hospital on March 16. He is in good health and only has very mild symptoms,” municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar said.

“There was no one at home when he came back from the US. Those he is likely to have interacted with on the way from Mumbai airport to Pune are still being traced. It is becoming difficult for people to recollect others they have interacted with or come in close contact with in the past 7-10 days. They take about 2-3 days to recollect and then we have to trace them,” Hardikar added.

“As many as 105 people suspected of carrying the infection were quarantined mainly in Mumbai, Pune, Nagpur, Aurangabad and Yavatmal on Tuesday alone. They include travellers and close contacts of patients who tested positive earlier,” said state surveillance officer Pradip Awate.

Meanwhile, a Union health ministry official said, “So far, India has reported 137 positive cases of Covid-19 as of 5pm on Tuesday. This includes 24 foreign nationals.”

Title: No patient moving out due to panic: Sree Chitra
Content:
THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The new admissions and surgeries (elective) have been postponed at Sree Chitra Tirunal Institute of Medical Sciences till the staff strength is restored. The hospital administration has informed that only routine discharges are happening from the hospital and no one has moved out of panic .

“High priority and emergency surgeries and care of patients attending the OP are conducted at the hospital. Elective procedures (non-emergency) and admissions have been postponed till staff strength is restored, and patients have been informed about this,” said a hospital official. Primary contacts of the affected doctor have been identified based on prescribed criteria and they have been placed under home quarantine. The hospital staff who are not contacts as per criteria are attending normal duties.

On Union minister of state V Muraleedharan’s visit to the hospital, the institute has clarified that “he was met by only two officials from the institute and two from the technology wing in Poojapura and none of them had any contact with the affected doctor for months. The meeting occurred at the director’s office which is in a separate building away from the hospital”. “The Union minister did not visit the hospital. The deputy director’s (who had also come from Spain) quarantine period had ended during the minister’s visit,” said the hospital administration.

Title: Covid-19 in Pune: After many leave for home towns, food deliveries fall
Content:
PUNE: Food delivery partners across the city remained extremely busy till Sunday. On Monday, there was a big drop as Punekars opted for social distancing. On Tuesday, restaurateurs said deliveries fell by nearly 60%.

Kunal Udane, owner of German Bakery, said, “Last week, food deliveries increased, though walk-ins reduced. However, on Monday, we noticed a significant drop in delivery orders as well.”

Abhishek Shetty, owner of Kalinga Pure Veg, said, “Home delivery orders have dropped as people are wary.”

Fewer deliveries were visible on Tuesday as restaurants began closing. “Thousands have opted to go back to their home towns. This has hurt our business,” Shetty said.

After colleges shut, students from other cities have gone back home and hostels have emptied out affecting delivery orders, a restaurant employee said.

Spokespersons from online food ordering and delivery platforms, Zomato and Swiggy, said they have undertaken several measures in wake of the spurt in Covid-19 cases.

Both offered contactless delivery, where patrons can pay online, call them and request for the parcel to be dropped at the door.

A Swiggy representative said that masks have been provided to delivery executives and they are trained on respiratory hygiene practices, washing hands and identification of symptoms.

A company spokesperson from Zomato said, “We are using multiple channels of communication to sensitise our employees, users, restaurants as well as delivery partners.”

Shetty said some restaurants are not able to pay the staff from other states whose families want them back. Many restaurants may close down as they do not have the money to pay for the hiked excise licence charges.

Title: Sharp fall in passenger count in Nashik divn, MSRTC cancels few trips to Pune
Content:
Nashik: The Maharashtra State Road Transport Corporation (MSRTC) has witnessed a sharp fall in number of passengers using its services.

“The flow of passengers from Nashik to Pune grew thin after 10am. The MSRTC had to cancel a couple of trips in the morning,” a senior state transport utility official said.

According to the official, the inflow of passengers from Pune to Nashik was very high on Sunday. “On Sundays we see number of people traveling from Nashik to Pune. However, on March 15, we had more than 1,000 people travelling to Nashik by MSRTC buses. There are also reports that people chose to travel even by private cars in groups,” the official said.

The passenger occupancy on Monday was below 50% when compared to the average movement. “Since schools, colleges, institutions have been closed, the movement of students is completely off the road. Now, those who are using the buses are office-goers. Even citizens have stopped travelling,” another MSRTC official said.

The average load factor of MSRTC’s Shivshahi buses is around 60 units and the same on Thursday and Friday was below 50 units. “It fell below 50 percent on Sunday combined for all buses that originated from Nashik division. The only solace on Sunday was the passengers travelling towards Dhule,” he said.

The fate of MSRTC’s city bus was also the same. “We have a near normal movement of people going to Ambad and Satpur from the various places, but apart from that passenger count has dropped drastically. Shops and establishments have also been closed by the government for a fortnight — till March 31. This has cut down the chances of the movement of the people,” the officer said.

The MSRTC official, however, clarified that there would be no cut in services on regular routes despite the weaning number of passengers.

Title: UP Students log onto Google hangouts, Skype for lectures
Content: LUCKNOW: With schools, colleges and universities in UP being ordered shut till April 2 to contain the coronavirus scourge, academic institutes and coaching cradles have turned to online classes, assessments and tests.While engineering colleges are falling back on free webinar services such as Google Hangouts and Skype to conduct online classes and complete syllabuses on time, coaching institutes are preparing students for entrance exams via virtual tests. Dr APJ Abdul Kalam Technical University (AKTU) vice-chancellor Vinay Pathak said teachers had been asked to share lessons through digital class notes, video lectures and PPT. “Since classroom teaching remains suspended, we have started online sessions to stay on course,” he added.At a coaching centre that prepares students for IIT-JEE, everything from assessment to test series are being conducted online. “Each student has been given a login ID and password to enter the online portal, where he/she can attend sessions, get queries cleared, take tests and submit assessments,” said NK Dubey, the centre head.Nivedita Bhatt, the media co-ordinator of a cradle for medical coaching, said a test scheduled for March 16 had to be cancelled because of the Covid-19 outbreak. “The next test slated for March 23 will be held online. A crash course, which was supposed to begin from March 26, has been deferred. If required, we will send online tutorials to students,” she added.At engineering and management colleges affiliated to AKTU, faculty members are uploading subject assignments. A circular has asked teachers “to ensure continuous online assessment of these assignments for optimal coverage of subjects”.In addition, teachers also need to maintain record of online assessments and interactions with students so that the latter earns the benefit of attendance. The idea, officials said, is to not load students at the end of the semester and prevent derailment of academic session.‘Online’ is the buzzword at Babasaheb Bhimrao Ambedkar University (BBAU) too. Professor of journalism and mass communication Govind Pandey said, “Taking virtual classes with the help of Google Classroom has been a wonderful experience. We are sharing audio, video and other documents with students in real time.”

Title: Coronavirus: Three PMC officials to be home-quarantined for Australia visit
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: Three civic body officials would be home quarantined, as they had gone on a tour to Australia, a senior PMC official said on Tuesday.

The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) had suggested travel restrictions for its civic officials in the wake of the coronavirus spread. The trio had not sought permission for the Australia, a senior PMC official said.

“Show cause notices will be issued to these officials. We will hear their views. Action may be taken against them for flouting the travel advisory,” PMC additional commissioner Rubal Agrawal told TOI.

Ramchandra Hankare, head of the PMC’s health department, said the three officials would have to undergo tests on arrival. “If any Covid-19 symptom is found, they will be sent to Naidu Hospital. Otherwise, they will have to be home quarantined. The 14-day isolation will be mandatory for them,”

PMC sources said the officials who have gone to Australia belonged to the water department and wanted to see the pipeline and drainage system there.

Title: Kozhikode medical college prepares its own hand sanitizers
Content: KOZHIKODE: Kozhikode Government Medical College has been making hand sanitizers to keep their staff safe from the threat of Covid-19.A first-of-its-kind initiative by a government medical college in the state, the College of Pharmaceutical Science under Kozhikode Government Medical College began producing the hand-rub solution following reports of hand sanitizer scarcity in market due to its increased demand.The pharmacy college doctors and students prepared the hand-rub solutions in 100ml, 200ml and 500ml bottles. The sanitizers will be supplied to various institutions of Kozhikode government medical college hospital (KGMCH), Kozhikode Government Medical College, Institute of Maternity and Child Health, super specialty hospital, institute of chest diseases, hostels at the medical college campus and all administrative offices. The medical college has sanctioned a sum of Rs 22,000 which include Rs 11,000 each from the fund of the hospital development societies of KGMCH and IMCH to purchase the ingredients needed to prepare the required quantity of the hand sanitizers.College authorities held discussions with labour and excise minister T P Ramakrishnan for ensuring the supply of methyl alcohol from excise department for production of hand sanitizer.Dr Sreekumar, superintendent, IMCH, said the dearth of hand sanitizers has severally hit all the institutions on the medical college campus. “The hand-rub solution is prepared using 80% of methyl alcohol and the remaining 20% of hydrogen peroxide and glycerin, he said.Meanwhile, Dr V R Rajendran, principal of the Kozhikode government medical college, said they have submitted a request letter to excise department for the supply 600 litre of seized alcohol for the preparation of hand sanitizer. “We used to purchase the hand sanitizer, from local suppliers. Now, it has been decided to make our own sanitizer to be provided to all employees on campus and ensure their safety, since patients from other districts too visit hospitals on the campus for treatment,” he said.

Title: Agra university cancels exam till April 1
Content:
Agra: Dr Bhimrao Ambedkar University administration on Tuesday declared the cancellation of annual exams from March 18 to April 1. The pre-PhD exams scheduled to take place from March 26 to 28 have also been cancelled.

Varsity vice-chancellor Ashok Mittal said, “To prevent the spread of coronavirus, exams of all courses have been cancelled. New dates will be decided very soon. Further details will be uploaded on the official website.”

Title: Covid-19: Two MBBS students stranded in Malaysia
Content: Mahima Gupta and Naveen Mallya, fourth-year MBBS students from Kasturba Medical College , Mangaluru, who went to International Medical University , Malaysia, for a one-month surgery elective, got stranded after their flights back to India were cancelled.They landed in Malaysia on March 12 and were scheduled to return on April 9. Mahima said the flight booked by her to India was cancelled, after the Indian government imposed a travel ban on those coming in from Malaysia. “I wish to return home as soon as possible. There is a possibility that Malaysia likely to go under lockdown to contain Covid-19, and we will be left in the lurch,” she said. She added that the ministry of external affairs and Manipal Academy of Higher Education is trying to help them.KMC Mangaluru dean M Venkatraya Prabhu said that MAHE has made arrangements for students to be put up at Manipal International University, Malaysia.

Title: Temples empty as coronavirus scare keeps people home
Content: Nagpur: After section 144 was imposed in the city until March 31, people are staying away from temples too. Renowned temples were open, with sanitisers or soap and water at the entrance, and staff and pandits on duty, but there were no devotees on Tuesday. For the first time, most holy places TOI visited had negligible people.The usually crowded Sai Mandir on Wardha Road was so quiet that the sound of the bell echoed. The vendors selling flowers, garlands and prasad had no customers to serve. A liquid soap bottle hung near the washing area, to wash hands before going inside. “The temple is open, but only two devotees came since morning. We have also stopped mahaprasad. There will be no celebrations on Thursday as well,” said Deepak Borgaonkar, a committee member.It was disconcerting to see the pundits worshipping and cleaning the idols with their masks on.The security guard at the entrance of Ganesh Tekdi Mandir was applying nilgiri oil on the wrists of all devotees, a measure to prevent corona according to them. Pouches of soap were also kept near the tap. “In last three days, very few devotees have come. We stopped serving meals or prasad, and only offer modak to Lord Ganesh in the morning,” said Sandeep Sharma, a pandit.On Tuesdays, which is the day of Lord Hanuman, devotees arrive in huge numbers at Ram Nagar Hanuman Mandir. But only two people were there in the evening. The famous Shani Mandir at Sitabuldi had literally no devotee.On the other hand, devotees of Lord Buddha were present in decent numbers at Deekshabhoomi. “Since morning, there was no one inside Deekshabhoomi , but since afternoon people have started to come. We have not kept it closed,” said Bhanteji, a monk.While some devotees were wearing a mask, some had a do-not-care attitude. “We have a wedding in a few weeks in our family. Hence, we came to seek the blessings of Buddha,” said Sonal Uike, a primary schoolteacher.Even Telangkhedi Temple bore a deserted look. The prasad distribution and aarti has been called off until March 31 here. There were no arrangements for sanitizers or soaps too. “Today is Tuesday, and usually devotees line up all the way to the stairs to offer prayers. Today, there is nobody,” said Nilesh Tiwari , head pandit. Other priests believe the number of devotees has decreased from 100-150 to 5-10 in just a day.The staff at all temples was working diligently with masks, cleaning and mopping the courtyards, especially the breathtakingly beautiful Swaminarayan and Balaji Mandir. “We are aware of coronavirus but couldn’t resist visiting the temple. Anyway slowly everything will be shut down, hence we decided to offer prayers,” said a devotee.

Title: Counsellor alleges harassment for reporting sexual abuse in school
Content:
MALAPPURAM: A child counsellor of a government school in Malappuram approached the education minister and social justice authorities with a complaint that she was being mentally harassed by school authorities for reporting a child sexual abuse case to police.

The counsellor of Government Girls Higher Secondary School at Kottappadi complained that she was being subjected to mental torture by school authorities after she reported sexual abuse against students allegedly by a Malayalam teacher. In her complaint, she alleged that some teachers, including the headmaster, raised baseless allegations to defame her.

The counsellor, who has been working in the school for past seven years, has so far reported 13 Pocso cases and 15 child marriages. She alleged that after she reported the sexual abuse case on November 26, 2018, the PTA lodged a complaint against her to social justice authorities. She said the headmaster and a teacher had asked her to privately settle the case. “There is pressure from various corners to avail transfer from the school. But, I want justice and authorities should take proper action against the school authorities including the headmaster and PTA president who raised baseless allegation against me for intervening in issues related to children,” she said.

Based on her complaint, Kerala Women’s Commission has started an inquiry.

The complaint was also submitted to director of women and child development T V Anupama and chid welfare committee chairman of Malappuram, Shajesh Bhaskar.

Title: 2,000 foreign arrivals under home quarantine
Content:
PATHANAMTHITTA: Three students who came from Kalaburagi on Tuesday have been sent for home isolation since they have not developed any symptoms, said district collector P B Nooh .

“The isolation has been done since the first Covid-19 death in the country was reported from Kalaburagi in Karnataka . They will be shifted to hospital, if needed. A health team is specially monitoring them,” Nooh said.

The 24-year-old who arrived from Italy at Pandalam has been tested negative and is under isolation in the general hospital.

The district collector said the administration is all set to meet any emergency and is well equipped to quarantine even a 100 hundred people at a time. “Preparations are on for being equipped for a mass evacuation, if needed. There is no need for any emergency at present but the administration is getting prepared to face it if it comes,” he said. The district collector said 2,000 people, who have come from different countries to the district after February 25, have been identified. “This number was 788 on Monday,” he said.

A doctor from the health service has also been put under isolation. Even though he had no direct contact with any of the positive cases, he was isolated since he had fever, said district medical officer Dr A L Sheeja.tnn

Title: Covid-19: PCMC in talks with eight private hospitals to quarantine people
Content:
PUNE: The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC) is in talks with eight private hospitals in the twin industrial townships for carrying out isolation of people coming in contact with the Covid-19 affected persons and have developed symptoms such as cold, cough and fever.

Municipal commissioner Shravan Hardikar, who met the representatives of these hospitals, on Tuesday said the health hubs have responded positively and agreed in principle to make 48 beds available for isolation .

Pimpri Chinchwad has so far registered 10 Covid-19 positive cases, highest in the state so far.

“Our effort is to have adequate facilities for isolation and ensuring quarantine of the infected people. Though the current inventory is meeting our requirements, support from private hospitals is being planned as a contingency measure,” he told TOI.

The civic body has made available two more hospitals to quarantine patients, if required. An additional capacity of 80 beds could be available for isolation purposes, Hardikar said, adding that the hospitals might need at least two or more months to establish the required set-up for testing of samples after getting the requisite permissions from the authorities.

Hardikar also said instead of ostracizing anyone, housing societies must focus on home quarantine. “It is the best strategy. There is no other way. Societies telling infected people to go out is like sending the infection out to a broader population”.

Hardikar added that societies must ensure all support, such as providing food, for the home quarantined people so that they did not have to come out. He said people with travel history must self-quarantine for 14 days.

The commissioner said quite a few people from the PCMC limits have approached the corporation to state that they have come from outside. “We are lucky that a lot of our people who travelled and possibly came in contact with the infected people have come forward to self-report,” he said.

Hardikar said of the 10 people testing positive, eight had shown no-symptoms whatsoever. “The ninth person is showing only mild symptoms. The tenth person, who tested positive on Monday, also had very mild symptoms,” he added.

Title: Covid-19 in Maharashtra: FIRs possible against travellers flouting home quarantine rules
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: Divisional commisisoner Deepak Mhaisekar on Tuesday said stringent measures, including filing of FIRs under Section 188 of IPC, would be taken against incoming travellers violating home quarantine norms.

“Though a tracking method is in place and our staffers are conducting regular checks, it is the duty of the individual to adhere to the home quarantine rules. Over 1,090 people are currently under home quarantine and there will be more under institutional quarantine,” he said.

The state government has made health check a mandatory for travellers from the US, Dubai and Saudi Arabia and suggested institutional quarantine and home quarantine for them in accordance with the Centre’s guidelines.

The Centre had earlier issued instructions for all incoming travellers, including Indians, arriving from China, Italy, Iran, Republic of Korea, France, Spain and Germany after February 15, should be quarantined for a minimum period of 14 days.

The state on Monday said incoming passengers screened at airports and told to remain under home quarantine would be stamped on the back of their hand, “home quarantine”, with immediate effect.

As part of the home quarantine protocol, the Pune district administration has made an mobile application. Once downloaded by the quarantined person, the officials can keep a track of the individual. “If the person switches off the cellphone, our teams will visit his or her residence,” Mhaisekar said.

Presently, Pune distirict has 250 people for surveillance of such quarantined persons. All corporations have appointed operators and they are calling the home quarantine people. The operators are checking their condition and the scanned copies of the latters’ addresses would be with the administration to ensure that they were not out of the administration’s radar.

Under Section 10 of the Epidemic Act, 1897, the administration can take steps to contain the spread of the virus. Forceful institutional quarantine can also be imposed on people not adhering to the home quarantine protocol. Officials said housing society members might also be reached out to for keeping a track on the home quarantined individuals.

Title: Agra administration debunks claims of ‘dirty toilets’ at govt hosp isolation ward, releases real photos on Twitter
Content:
Bathroom picture shown is not in use & certainly it’s not of corentine ward; each ward have seperate attached toile… https://t.co/IemCe0JgX9 — Prabhu N Singh (@PrabhuNs_) 1584422714000

AGRA: After photos of a clogged toilet shared by a family friend of the Agra woman undergoing treatment for Covid-19 went viral, Agra district magistrate Prabhu N Singh shared photos from the hospital on Twitter debunking the claim. This came even as some websites ran photos of the hospital that the health department said were “fake”.The DM said, “One should verify facts instead of misinforming the general public”.Chief medical officer Mukesh Kumar Vats said, “The clogged toilet photos were not of the isolation ward in SN Medical College and the district hospital. I have personally inspected the isolation facility at both places several times.”Satish Verma, superintendent in-charge of district hospital where the 25-year-old woman was brought for treatment, said, “The pictures shared by woman’s relatives are not of the isolation ward. We have a dedicated team to take care of the high-standard sanitation and hygiene at the isolation ward having 10 beds and two toilets.”Last Friday, eight members of the family were admitted to the isolation ward at the district hospital. They were discharged on Saturday after they tested negative for Covid-19. The woman was shifted to SN Medical College. She was tested Covid-19 positive on Sunday.The Agra district magistrate said, “It has been verified that the toilet pictures circulated on the social media are not of quarantine facility at SN Medical College or district hospital. We have designated staff at both centres to take care of the cleanliness protocol. Sanitization of the isolation wards is taking place on a daily basis. All the guidelines by the Union ministry of health are being followed. Health team in Agra is making the best possible efforts to put a tab on the danger of coronavirus”.“Sharing any misleading information related to Covid-19 will be considered an offense. Legal action will be taken in such cases. In the case of the woman, an FIR has already been registered against her father for misleading the health officials. People are advised to verify the information before posting it on social media platforms,” he said.The DM also shared a 105-second video on the social media showcasing the procedure of the disposal of hazardous bio-medical waste collected from the isolation wards.CMO Vats said, “Packed food and mineral water is being provided to all the people admitted to the isolation ward. We have placed hand sanitizers on each bed and washrooms. Masks are also provided to all those quarantined.”

Title: Lucknow: In House of Gods, sensors installed, priests wear masks, garbh grih barred
Content:
Temple management has made arrangements for hand washing for devotees and deputed volunteers to provide alcoho... Read More

LUCKNOW: Amid calls for social distancing to check the spread of Covid-19, religious institutions and prominent temples across Uttar Pradesh have joined campaign against the virus.

In Varanasi, Kashi Vishwanath Temple Trust announced measures to keep devotees safe from infection. Entry of devotees inside ‘garbha griha’ has been banned and priests have been given masks and sanitisers to check infection.

Temple management has made arrangements for hand washing for devotees and deputed volunteers to provide alcohol-based sanitisers. Thermal scanners been installed at the helpdesk of foreign visitors.

Similar steps have been taken by the management of Annapurna Temple in Varanasi. Volunteers serving food at ‘anna kshetra’ were seen wearing masks while people were allowed to enter the temple only after washing hands.

Towards Sarnath, as many as 12 Buddhist monasteries have been closed for a month. Superintending archaeologist, ASI (Varanasi circle) Neeraj Sinha said, “Monasteries have been voluntarily closed to check arrival of foreign visitors. Over a hundred ASI sites under my jurisdiction have been closed in view of coronavirus threat.”

In Lucknow, Hanuman Setu Temple Trust cancelled ‘bhajan sandhyas’ and appealed devotees to follow preventive measures. Mankameshwar Temple has put up handwashing protocol at entry points. “People must exercise self-restraint. Anyone who is not well should stay at home and take all possible steps to ensure they do not even spread common cold,” said Mahant Divya Giri. In Mathura, Dwarkadheesh Temple management committee has put up posters to appeal people to follow precautionary steps.

Title: Gogoi’s move has shaken confidence of people in judiciary’s independence: Kurian Joseph
Content:
NEW DELHI: Strongly criticising former CJI Ranjan Gogoi for accepting nomination to Rajya Sabha , former Supreme Court judge Justice Kurian Joseph on Tuesday said the ex-CJI’s decision had compromised independence and impartiality of the judiciary and shaken people’s confidence in it.

“We have discharged our debt to the nation - was the statement made by Justice Gogoi along with the three of us (Justices J Chelameswar, Madan B Lokur and Kurian Joseph) on January 12, 2018. I am surprised as to how Justice Gogoi, who once exhibited such courage of conviction to uphold the independence of judiciary, has compromised the noble principles of the independence and impartiality of the judiciary,” he said. He was referring to a press conference of four SC judges against then CJI Dipak Misra .

Justice Joseph said he had decided not to take up any post-retirement assignment from the government to keep the independence and impartiality of judiciary intact. “According to me, the acceptance of nomination as member of Rajya Sabha by a former CJI has certainly shaken the confidence of the common man on the independence of judiciary, which is also one of the basic structures of the Constitution,” he said.

“Our great nation continues to be firmly grounded on the basic structures and constitutional values, thanks mainly to the independent judiciary. The moment this confidence of the people is shaken, the moment there is a perception that a section among judges is otherwise biased or looking forward, the tectonic alignment of the nation built on solid foundations is shaken,” he added.

“Only to strengthen this alignment, the collegium system was introduced by the Supreme Court in 1993 to make the judiciary completely independent and not inter-dependent. I came out in the public in an unprecedented move along with Justices Chelameswar, Gogoi and Lokur to tell the nation that there was a threat to this foundation and now I feel the threat is at large,” he said.

Title: Two more Noida residents test Covid +ve, push UP tally to 15
Content: LUCKNOW: Two more persons in Noida tested positive for Covid-19 on Tuesday taking UP’s tally of coronavirus cases to 15. The total number of coronavirus cases in Noida has also risen to four.Nodal officer, coronavirus, UP, Dr Vikasendu Agarwal said one patient, a resident of sector 100, had returned from France recently, the other patient is a resident of sector 78.Dr Agarwal said three of the 15 patients have recovered.Chief medical officer, Gautam Budh Nagar , Dr Anurag Bhargava said a woman from sector 100 was under isolation since she returned from France last week, while the other patient has been quarantined at a government hospital.The health department is taking all steps to sanitise the localities in which the two live and samples of their contacts have been collected and sent for testing, the CMO added.UP nodal officer Vikasendu Agarwal said, “As many as 21 persons have been quarantined in different hospitals in the state, including in Lucknow and Agra. Besides, as many as 98 samples of suspected cases were sent for testing, including 40 to King George’s Medical University .”The government has closes all schools and educational institutions till April 2 and cancelled all state examinations but this has been done to curb chances of virus spread, he added. “The closure has been ordered to ensure students stay at home, but they should not flock to markets or malls. No one should move out of home unless necessary,” said Dr Agarwal.Meanwhile, government hospitals in Lucknow, including Balrampur, Ram Manohar Lohia and others started a separate clinic for suspect Covid-19 patients. “We urge people not to bring more than two attendants,” said Dr Ashutosh Dubey, medical superintendent, SPM civil hospital.

Title: PMC restricts visitors’ entry at all its offices, pushes e-mail correspondence
Content:
Pune Municipal Corporation

PUNE: The Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) has restricted entry of citizens and visitors at its zonal and ward-level offices as well as at the main building located in Shivajinagar as a precautionary step to contain the spread of coronavirus.

The Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation has also followed suit and restricted entry of citizens to its offices.

An official, however, clarified that PMC staffers will continue to work as per scheduled timings in their respective offices. The restrictions pertain only to visitors, the official added.

The civic administration is prompting citizens to e-mail their complaints and suggestions instead of visiting the office till further notice. The administration has published over 80 e-mail addresses of various departments, ward offices and deputy commissioner’s offices on its websites to enable citizens to register complaints and for further correspondence.

On Tuesday, the entry-exit gates of the main administrative building of the PMC and other offices were closed and were put under surveillance. Staff deployed at the gates prevented people from entering the premises and asked them to get in touch via e-mails.

Sources from the administration said that PMC’s main building sees over thousand visitors every day. A similar footfall is registered at other premises in the city, including at ward offices. Most visitors include PMC’s own staffers from other offices, contractors, employees of other government offices and common people. The entry of most people was restricted on Tuesday barring some exceptions, sources said.

A circular, signed by the municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad, has also asked civic departments to prefer communication through e-mails instead of delivery of urgent letters by hand. “There is an attempt to restrict movement of people at offices spread across the city. We want to cut short the visits and visitors can postpone their plans by some days in the wake of the Covid-19 scare,” an official from the administration said.

Of the 80 e-mail addresses provided by the administration for correspondence, around 40 are of various departments including road development, solid waste management, electrical and office of municipal/additional municipal commissioners. The remaining are e-mail addresses of ward offices, zonal heads, the tree authority, and deputy commissioners.

Title: Mathura’s Rangnatha temple cancels rath yatra
Content:
Agra: Several temples in Mathura issued an advisory to devotees and priests on Tuesday to take steps to prevent spread of coronavirus, even as the Sri Rangnatha temple cancelled its rathyatra, scheduled on Wednesday.

Talking with mediapersons, Rangnatha temple’s priest, Purshotam Swami, said the decision to cancel the rathyatra was taken to avoid large gatherings amid fears of coronavirus infection. He said that fireworks scheduled for the yatra have also been cancelled.

The Sri Krishna Janamsthan temple authorities have also issued directions to priests to maintain distance of at least a meter from devotees and avoid taking a garland directly. The religious feast and “kirtan” have also been cancelled. They have also requested devotees not to visit temple in case they are suffering from any kind of ailment.

In an order, secretary of the temple Kapil Sharma said the temple priests should not participate in any rituals organized by any individual and avoid going out of the premises except during unavoidable situations. All temple employees have been directed to use masks and avoid mass gatherings.

Similarly, Banke Bihari temple in Vrindavan issued an advisory, saying that elderly persons, children, and people suffering from infections or any other disease should avoid visiting the temple. Devotees should avoid visiting crowded and public places.

Title: Dead poultry dumped in Dham river, villagers panic
Content:
Wardha: Amid novel coronavirus (Covid-19) fears, panic has gripped Tuljapur village in Selu tahsil after some unidentified person(s) dumped a large number of dead poultry birds in Dham river. The incident came to light on Tuesday when villagers complained to Selu police about unbearable stench in the area and demanded action.

One of the villagers expressed apprehension that the river water has been contaminated because of the rotten birds and this might pose danger to the residents down stream. “It has become impossible to even stand near the riverbank because of the stench,” said the villager.

According to sources there is hardly any demand for poultry birds for fear of contracting coronavirus infection. This has resulted in steep decline in prices. The mounting losses may have compelled poultry farmers to dump these birds in the river.

The police are trying to identify the culprit. Meanwhile, the district administration has advised villagers to maintain hygiene in the area.

Title: Two more Noida residents test Covid +ve, push UP tally to 15
Content: LUCKNOW: Two more persons in Noida tested positive for Covid-19 on Tuesday taking UP’s tally of coronavirus cases to 15.
