The total number of coronavirus cases in Noida has also risen to four.Nodal officer, coronavirus, UP, Dr Vikasendu Agarwal said one patient, a resident of sector 100, had returned from France recently, the other patient is a resident of sector 78.Dr Agarwal said three of the 15 patients have recovered.Chief medical officer, Gautam Budh Nagar , Dr Anurag Bhargava said a woman from sector 100 was under isolation since she returned from France last week, while the other patient has been quarantined at a government hospital.The health department is taking all steps to sanitise the localities in which the two live and samples of their contacts have been collected and sent for testing, the CMO added.UP nodal officer Vikasendu Agarwal said, “As many as 21 persons have been quarantined in different hospitals in the state, including in Lucknow and Agra. Besides, as many as 98 samples of suspected cases were sent for testing, including 40 to King George’s Medical University .”The government has closes all schools and educational institutions till April 2 and cancelled all state examinations but this has been done to curb chances of virus spread, he added. “The closure has been ordered to ensure students stay at home, but they should not flock to markets or malls. No one should move out of home unless necessary,” said Dr Agarwal.Meanwhile, government hospitals in Lucknow, including Balrampur, Ram Manohar Lohia and others started a separate clinic for suspect Covid-19 patients. “We urge people not to bring more than two attendants,” said Dr Ashutosh Dubey, medical superintendent, SPM civil hospital.

Title: Medicos lend a helping hand
Content: KOZHIKODE: MBBS students pursuing their first to final-year courses will help in the fight against Covid-19 by screening those coming into the state at all border checkpoints The MBBS students will screen the passengers for Covid-19 to detect the people with suspected symptoms at the various screening centres set up at boarder checkposts, railway stations and bus stations across the state. A proposal in this regard was placed by the Indian Medical Association ’s Medical Students Network (IMA-MSN) before chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan recently. The IMA-MSN has prepared a list of more than 600 MBBS students from 32 medical colleges, including both private and government medical colleges in the state, and those who have come forward to render voluntary service to help the state government in combating the Covid-19 cases effectively.Presently, the state police department with the help of paramedical staff and local volunteers are screening the passengers arriving in the state through the 24 identified checkposts on the national highways, railway stations and bus stops.

Title: Ignou extends assignment deadline, cancels classes
Content:
Nagpur: In light of the state government’s decision to shut down educational institutes till March 31, Indira Gandhi National Open University (Ignou) too has decided to not only cancel counselling sessions but also extend assignment submission deadline by a month.

P Sivaswaroop, regional director of Ignou, said, “Due to the coronavirus epidemic in the country, Ignou has taken several preventive steps. All theory and practical counselling sessions for students have been suspended till March 31.”

“Ignou won’t commit to new dates as of now. They will be rescheduled after the government gives clearance. Revised dates will be intimated to all students,” said Sivaswaroop.

Assignment submission deadline was initially March 31, but now Ignou has extended that as well. “The new deadline is April 30 and its main purpose is to prevent large groups of students gathering at the study centre while submitting assignments. Home assignment question papers are available on Ignou’s website and students are advised to download the assignment question papers and prepare the answers,” said Sivaswaroop.

Ignou is also scheduling some of the counselling classes through Gyanvani FM radio station. Students will be intimated through SMS/e-mail about the radio classes schedule. Gyan Vani is available on 105.6MHz and students can interact with teachers on 0712-2510002.

Title: TOI Impact: Even NMRDA schools to shut down till March 31
Content:
Nagpur: Ending the confusion over different shutdown periods for schools and colleges within Nagpur district, the authorities on Monday evening declared that all will remain closed till March 31.

TOI was the only newspaper to report about the discrepancy in which educational institutes under Nagpur Metropolitan Region Development Authority (NMRDA) were to be closed only till March 25, while others were to be shut till the month-end.

The confusion started with the original state government circular which said that areas under corporation, council and panchayat jurisdiction will remain shut till March 31. There was no mention of NMRDA in the circular. Though local authorities immediately sprung into action to rectify this, but their decision to enforce shutdown only till March 25 came in for flak from all quarters. TOI on Monday highlighted the confusion this date discrepancy had created. The same evening, a rectified order was issued changing the date to March 31.

NMRDA covers area under 25km radius starting from Nagpur city limit. It covers about 36% of Nagpur district. It includes nine tehsils of Nagpur rural, Hingna, Kamptee, Parsheoni, Mauda, Saoner, Umred, Kalmeshwar and Kuhi which is an area of roughly 3,500sqkm.

It is, however, confusing to figure out which school or junior college would come under NMRDA because there are many land tracts within the area which are excluded from the urban planning agency’s control. For example, NMRDA does not control Mihan, MIDC, Kamptee cantonment, Kamptee town and Kalmeshwar town.

Schools are pleased that the date has been extended till March 31 as it helps them to avoid confusion. “On Saturday night, we have informed parents through SMS and school app that everything is shut till March 31. Then on Sunday night news came that our schools, being under NMRDA, are to remain closed only till March 25. Had we revised our message at that time, yet another change in the communication to the parents would have been needed,” said a school owner.

Title: Walayar rape case: Three of 4 accused arrested, let off on bail
Content:
Representative image

PALAKKAD: Three of the four accused who were acquitted by Pocso special court in the Walayar case were arrested on Tuesday by police and produced before the trial court after the high court ordered their arrest on Monday. They were later released on bail.

The accused, M Madhu, V Madhu and Pradeep Kumar , were produced before the court, while the fourth accused Shibu could not be traced. Police said an arrest warrant has been issued against him.

The high court directive came after appeals were filed by the state government and the mother of the victims challenging the verdicts by the special court. The government had said in the appeals that the probe conducted in the cases were faulty and that the angle of murder was not probed.

Meanwhile, there were allegations from the beginning that the investigation was derailed due to political pressure to help the accused. The Pocso court had acquitted all the four accused for want of evidences and the failure of the prosecution to prove the charges.

Since the postmortem report had indicated that both the sisters aged 13 and 8 years were sexually exploited, the case could have been proved by the police if they had taken sincere efforts right from the beginning to collect evidences and firm up witnesses, alleged the victims’s mother.

Title: Animal markets with poor hygiene to be sealed: Corporation
Content: NEW DELHI: Pointing out that several establishments were not maintaining hygiene, the veterinary department of South Delhi Municipal Corporation has issued warning to markets dealing with live animals, animal produce, birth control centers and veterinary doctors to regularly disinfect and sanitise their establishments with broad spectrum disinfectants.Dr Ravindra Sharma, director, veterinary department, said at a time when world was in the grip of the novel coronavirus , no laxity would be tolerated and would lead to sealing of such units.Though there is uncertainty about the origin of Covid-19 , health officials believe the virus could have been transmitted from Huanan wholesale animal and seafood market in Wuhan (China), as several of first 44 cases of initial patients (December 31, 2019 to January 3, 2020) had visited the said market, the report pointed out.The advisory issued by the department stated that the condition in many ABC (Animal birth control) centres was below standards mandated by the Supreme Court. “The protocols for maintaining aseptic procedures is not maintained, which may lead to spread of contagious and infectious diseases among street dogs, which are released after sterilisation in the same area,” the notice read.Dr Sharma said all these establishments would have to incorporate precautions, including provision of regular hand washing points with soap and potable water after touching animals and its products. “People in these markets are also advised not to touch their eyes, nose or mouth and avoid any direct contact with sick animals or spoiled products,” he added.

Title: US team developing coronavirus vaccine tailored for elderly
Content: PUNE: A team of researchers of the Precision Vaccines Program (PVP) at Boston Children’s Hospital and Harvard Medical School in the US is developing a vaccine for the elderly to guard against the novel coronavirus The team is combining the spike protein of the novel coronavirus with known vaccine adjuvants. Adjuvants are agents which are added to a vaccine to boost the recipient’s immune response to produce more antibodies and longer-lasting immunity.The antigen that is currently being used for vaccine development is the spike protein from the novel coronavirus. This protein sits atop the spikes on the virus and mediates coronavirus entry into human cells. The antibodies developed by the immune system act against this spike protein to prevent infection.PVP director Ofer Levy said the team is testing known and new vaccine adjuvants, which were discovered by screening human cells. “For the testing, adjuvants are cheaper to make compared to the spike protein. We can make effective vaccines with lower amounts of costly spike protein, which is important when you plan to produce millions of doses of vaccine,” he said.PVP already has an ongoing project for the elderly through the US National Institutes of Health (NIH). “We were screening small molecules with a focus on influenza and have a biobank of elderly white blood cells. We have been given permission to shift our focus to coronavirus,” Levy said.The blood samples of the elderly patients were provided by Lindsey Baden, director of clinical research at Brigham and Women’s Hospital in Boston, Levy said. The samples were from relatively healthy people aged above 65 and followed at the out-patient department.Levy said the elderly are most at risk from Covid-19. “The immune system of the elderly is distinct. It is harder to get a protective vaccine response in the elderly compared to healthy middle-aged individuals. Therefore, we are working on a vaccine tailored for the elderly,” he said.The research is being funded by the USNIH, specifically the National Institute of Allergy & Infectious Diseases (NIAID).Dr David J Dowling, PhD faculty member in the PVP and co-lead of the coronavirus vaccine effort, said the first mice have already been inoculated with a similar coronavirus spike protein derived from the Sars-2003 coronavirus — with and without a lead adjuvant combination — to get an early read on the antibody response.The timeline for clinical application of these studies depends on the adjuvant identified and its path to clinical trial, but is anticipated to be some months to a year.

Title: Gujarat: Fear of coronavirus sends devotees on the e-mode
Content: VADODARA: If fear of coronavirus has sent professionals to work-from-home mode, their devotion has gone a step ahead — it has gone on the e-mode, with scared bhakts showering piety digitally.While the deadly virus has virtually brought the world to a standstill, it has failed to deter the die-hard spirit of devotees who have easily switched lane to follow online aartis, havans and discourses!Stating that all religious events for the next fortnight have been cancelled across its more than 1,200 centres in India and abroad, Swami Vivekjivandas of Bochasanwasi Akshar Purushottam Sanstha (BAPS) said that the temple trust has asked devotees to organize online satsang on Sundays instead of organizing gatherings at temples. “We have already appealed to the devotees to avoid crowding at temples and instead utilize the facility of online darshan,” he added.Talking to TOI, Gyanvatsal Swami of Swaminarayan BAPS Temple, Vadodara said: “Ever since the outbreak of coronavirus in the country, there has been a ban on large gatherings. In such a scenario, the BAPS has also issued an advisory to its devotees asking them to take all precautions. But there are many devotees too, who would make a round of the temple daily, come what may. So, we decided to relay live images of Lord Swaminarayan to the devotees through our website.”Gyanvatsal Sami said that the followers have been enabled to witness live aarti as well as listen to the discourse of Mahant Swami Maharaj online. “We will continue with this digital darshan till the coronavirus scare subsides,” he added.With the holy month of Chaitra beginning March 21, many temples plan to organize havans and other religious gatherings in the city.A popular Hanuman temple in the city has also adopted technology to help devotees pray together at the grand yagna. “We organize Navratri in Chaitra every year and a yagna is performed in Tarsali area. This year, we won’t have a huge gathering due to coronavirus threat,” said Rakesh Patel, president of Shree Maruti Mandal Trustee of Shree Somnath Trust, PK Laheri, said that devotees to the shrine are being screened with temperature guns and given sanitizers at the entrance to the premises for the past few days. Protective masks are also being provided to the staff members. Somnath Temple has online darshan for several years now. In the meantime, the temple trust has cancelled all major gatherings.

Title: ‘Cheater’ priest now accused of raping married woman
Content:
Dr Prashant Upadhyay

Vadodara: Dr Prashant Upadhyay, priest of Shri Baglamukhi Brahmastra Vidya Mandir, seems to have been caught in the quagmire of his misdeeds. After being accused of cheating, he is now accused of rape by a married woman living in Manjalpur.

Upadhyay is currently in jail for two separate cases of cheating a businessman and a couple.

The 28-year-old woman lodged her complaint at Gotri police station on Tuesday in which she has alleged that Upadhyay has raped her several times at his home in Gotri since November 2016.

According to the woman, she started attending Upadhyay’s sermons in 2016 as her husband was Upadhyay’s follower. During the sermons, she started sharing her household issues like conflicts with husband and mother-in-law with Upadhyay. The priest told the woman that she will attain a form of ‘devi’ but will have to make some sacrifices for that state.

On November 22, 2016, Upadhyay asked the woman to meet him at his home in Gotri. When she reached his home, he called her to his bedroom where he raped her and also asked her not to tell anyone about it. The woman told police that she was afraid of getting defamed and so kept mum. She stated that Upadhyay continued calling her to his house on several other occasions until December last year when he forced himself upon her physically without her consent.

Recently when she learnt about his followers approaching the police with criminal complaints, she too got the courage to open up about her ordeal. The woman went to the Gotri police station on Tuesday along with a social worker and filed her complaint.

Police have registered an offence of committing rape on the same woman repeatedly and sexual harassment.

Title: Mundhe proposes multi-level parkings under Smart City Project
Content:
Nagpur: Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe on Wednesday proposed to develop multi-level parkings under Smart City Project.

Mundhe held review meeting with officials of Smart City special purpose vehicle — Nagpur Smart and Sustainable City Development Corporation Limited (NSSCDCL) on Wednesday. Deputy chief executive officer of NSSCDCL and other officials were present.

Mundhe said, “Multi-level parkings need to be developed to address the problems of parking, increase in number of vehicles and traffic congestion. Identify lands reserved for parking across the city and submit the report,” he told officials.

Currently, the city has only one multi-level parking at Sitabuldi which was developed by the Nagpur Improvement Trust (NIT) under PPP model. It is lying abandoned for lack of operators.

Mundhe said a vision is needed for transforming city into a Smart City. “Plan and execute public bike sharing project also under Smart City Project which are necessary for environment conservation. Entire project should function on one app so that it will encourage people to use it. Prepare detailed project reports for developing five Smart Markets,” he said.

Mundhe also directed the officials of NSSCDCL to facilitate 50 types of government services on Smart Kiosks installed at city bus stops immediately.

The civic chief also took review of area based development projects to transform Pardi, Punapur, Bharatwada and Bhandewadi into Smart City. He also took update of bio-mining project underway at Bhandewadi dumping yard.

Title: Allow teachers to work from home, demands BUTA
Content:
Cap

Vadodara: The Baroda University Teachers Association (BUTA) on Tuesday demanded that M S University should provide work-from-home option to its teachers too as a precautionary measure to deal with the coronavirus pandemic.

Following state government’s decision on Sunday to close down all schools and colleges till March 29 to combat spread of COVID-19, the varsity has also suspended teaching on its campuses for the next two weeks.

Exams which were scheduled to commence from Monday will also continue only till Wednesday.

“From March 19 onwards, there will be neither be any class nor exams on the campus. So, what is the need for calling teachers to the campus?” asked Dr K V R Murthy, BUTA president, who raised the demand during a meeting with MSU’s officiating registrar Dr K M Chudasama on Tuesday.

BUTA has received communication from IITs and other universities’ faculties which have closed down following government orders.

“Gujarat government too has declared closure of all educational institutions. Some IITs and universities have closed down hostels and asked their students to vacate the premises while teachers have been advised to stay at home,” he said.

“The university should also provide option to research scholars who want to come at the campus to pursue their research work,” he said.

Title: No medicine without prescription
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Health minister K K Shailaja has issued a warning against sale of medicines to public without a doctor’s prescription “which could cause severe health issues, especially when the state is facing the Covid-19 pandemic”.The state drugs controller has been directed to take stringent action against medical stores which ignore the warning and sell medicines to patients sans proper prescriptions, said an official release issued on Tuesday. “Such illegal sale of medicines will create severe health issues during the time of Covid-19,” the release said. tnn

Title: Indore: Smart control centre to make power supply network smarter
Content:
Representative image

INDORE: Smart solutions for Smart Indore — going high-tech, discom has set up its first control centre for live feed and monitoring of smart meters.

This master control and command centre, which has been set up at discom’s meter testing building an estimate cost of Rs45 lakh was inaugurated on Tuesday. Discom had introduced smart meters for domestic connections in Indore in 2017.

Madhya Pradesh Paschim Kshetra Vidyut Vitaran Company Limited (MPPKVVCL) managing director Vikas Narwal said that the master control and command centre would allow them to monitor and manage remote disconnection and re-connection 24x7.

“A team of some 20 employees including 10 engineers have been appointed to work at this control centre in three shifts,” Narwal told TOI.

He claimed that Indore’s smart metering system has helped discom curb power theft and line loss related cases amounting to a total recovery of up to Rs50 crore.

“As many as 1.10 lakh smart meters installed in domestic connections under Indore City circle have been connected with this facility. We will have live feed and consumption records of each one of these smart meters at this centre 24x7,” he said.

“There are plans to replace around 3.5 lakh conventional meters in Mhow, Dewas, Ujjain, Ratlam, and Khargone with smart meters. These meters would also be connected with this new control and command centre,” he added.

Officials said that smart meter works on radio frequency technology and it comes with series of benefits including real time consumption data, remote disconnection and re-connection.

“Apart from power loss that occurred due to tampering with meters or illegal tapping, use of smart meters has also helped us increase our billing efficiency by 10 per cent,” said officials while adding that assess billing or wrong meter reading related issues have also come down in both these feeders.

Title: Varanasi man back from Italy Corona horror
Content: LUCKNOW: “The ten-hour journey from Milan to New Delhi seemed like a lifetime. The experience taught me that even the simplest things in life are a gift,” said 22-year-old Pratyaksh Agarwal , who was among the 211 Indian students brought back from Italy by Indian government on Sunday (March 15) by a special flight after all commercial flights to India were cancelled amid novel coronavirus outbreak.Born and bred in Varanasi, Pratyaksh, who went to Italy to study fashion business, told TOI, “We survived the lockdown for a week. Our flights were booked for March 10, but on March 7 the city was closed down completely. People began rushing to stores, cafes were closed and city seemed like coming to a standstill. We couldn’t even buy groceries without showing a medical certificate at the store, but getting a Covid-19 certificate was even more difficult as all hospitals were crowded with patients.”“Several students like me were stranded at Milan Malpensa Airport for two days. They were not letting us board since patients were being given first preference. On March 11, my brother, who is stuck in US, shared our video on twitter and tagged the government and PM Modi. Finally, we were evacuated on March 14,” Agarwal said.Back home in Varanasi, his father made all arrangements for his check-up at a private hospital on arival. “They were restless as they kept hearing about rising cases and deaths in Italy due to the virus in the news. We have been put up at an isolation centre. The family is relieved since I am healthy and will be with them in 12 days,” he said.Pratyaksh’s father Mukesh Agarwal cried with joy when he heard that government was evacuating him with others. “We lived in anxiety and were relieved when he landed in India. We are waiting for him to come home. It was a nightmare as one son was stranded at airport and the other confined to his house in New York,” he said.

Title: Rajasthan CM holds all-party meet to tackle coronavirus menace
Content: JAIPUR: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Tuesday convened an all-party meeting and invited all religious leaders at chief minister’s office to discuss the threat of coronavirus and devise ways and means to tackle it.Gehlot asked the religious leaders of various communities to spread awareness among devotees visiting holy places and advise them of the precautions to be taken against the virus. The religious leaders also issued an appeal asking devotees to avoid visiting religious places and festivals.He said the situation in the state is under control but the next two three weeks are very crucial in containing the disease.“Holding all-party meeting at CMO to discuss the threat of coronavirus and to collectively deal with it. Informed the leaders about the steps taken by the state government to deal with the disease so far,” Gehlot tweeted.“It is our collective responsibility to ensure that people are made aware, prepared and that everybody takes precautions,” he said. The meeting discussed political parties to minimise political meetings, events, programmes in the present situation.“Our focus should be to ensure that the spread of the virus is contained,” he said.Members of different political parties were present in the meeting.At the all religious meeting the chief minister emphasized the need to keep the numbers minimum during festivals and other auspicious days.It is important that all religious leaders convey the message to communities not to panic or fear but to focus on adopting measures to protect and save themselves, the chief minister said at the meeting.Four coronavirus cases have been reported in the state so far and three of them have been recovered. The government has taken a slew of preventive, precautionary and remedial measures to contain the spread of the virus and to deal with the situation.

Title: VHP launches campaign against forced religious conversions in Lucknow
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: The Vishwa Hindu Parishad has launched a fresh tirade against forced religious conversion of Hindus.

Speaking exclusively to TOI, VHP’s national general secretary Milind Parande said that a campaign has been launched nationally, especially in states like Jharkhand , where tribes are being subjected to conversion to Christianity.

“They (Christian missionaries) are destroying the ancient culture and indigenous religion of the tribals and are resorting to trafficking of their children. The VHP will not allow the heinous conspiracy to succeed,” he said. “We have asked our functionaries to speak to the tribals and remind them of their traditional customs which essentially originate in Hindu traditions,” Parande said.

“Issues like love jihad, where Hindu girls are lured to marry Muslims, are also being brought back. Every year, we bring back at least 2,000 people who have got converted,” he said.

VHP sources said that the right wing body has asked its cadres to work among tribals to nullify the potential threat of religious conversion. Parande said that tribals had produced many brave fighters who had laid down their lives fighting foreign invaders and heretics.

“Some of these valiant efforts like those of Rana Punja’s struggle against Akbar on Maharana Pratap’s side, the struggle of Govind Guru of Bhil tribe against British and the 1857 struggle of Tatya Bhil are renowned all over the world,” he said.

Vishwa Hindu Parishad also seeks to invoke Birsa Munda as a tribal who laid down his life fighting for the cause of Hindu tribal society and the indigenous culture “while facing atrocities of Christians”.

Parande said that the church was conspiring to create an atmosphere of hatred and fear to instigate the people in the name of amended citizenship law.

“The recent violence in the name of protests against CAA happened because of this false propaganda. The missionaries as well as so-called secular gang should desist from such falsehood,” he said.

Vishwa Hindu Parishad leader said that Christian missionary organisations, which had been banned from indulging in illegal trafficking of tribal children, had restarted their operations in the past few months.

“This is very disturbing and a ban should be imposed on them,” he said.

Title: Rajkot: Man sentenced to death for three-year-old’s rape-murder
Content:
Court accepts DNA, medical reports as proof

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme Court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

RAJKOT: A 27-year-old man was sentenced to death for rape and murder of a three-year-old girl in the city in February 2018.Judge D D Thakkar of special Pocso court awarded capital punishment to convict Ramesh Vedukiya while ruling that the brutal crime was a ‘rarest of rare’ case.On February 9, 2018, Vedukiya had abducted the girl from a construction site near Chunarwada Crossroads where her parents were engaged in masonry work. He took the girl to a dilapidated building behind PTC College near Amul Crossroads and raped her. After this, he repeatedly banged her head on the building’s wall and killed her.Next day, her body was found beneath a blanket and police also recovered a blood-stained shirt along with a pouch of country-made liquor from the spot.District government pleader S K Vora said the court considered the reports of DNA test and girl’s medical examination as a clinching proof of his crime. The blood stains found on the shirt matched with that of Vedukiya’s. “In all, 13 witnesses were examined and none of them turned hostile,” Vora added.In the 124-page judgement, the court also recommended to the Rajkot District Legal Services Authority to work out proper compensation for the girl’s parents.In fact, Vedukiya was already in the police custody after being arrested on February 11 for murder of a 75-year-old woman whom he had killed near Sokhda village on the city’s outskirts February 7.A sole CCTV footage, that too from a long distance, was the sole evidence that police had in the rape case. However, the detection of crime branch (DCB) sleuths saw his gait and confirmed that he was involved in this heinous crime too. On being grilled, Vedukiya confessed to rape and murder of the girl.The 75-year-old woman Asma Sadikot had boarded Vedukiya’s rickshaw go to her house in Bhagwatipara from her daughter’s house in Para Bazaar. Noticing that her eyesight was weak, Vedukiya drove the rickshaw to Sokhda village and smashed her head with a big stone. Based on the CCTV footages of the rickshaw, police had nabbed him on February 11 and booked him for murder.

Title: Chaitra fair in Jaisalmer’s Tanot Mata temple cancelled this year
Content:
Jaisalmer: In a bid to control spread of coronavirus, the border visits to Tanot area in Jaisalmer have been discontinued for tourists. The Army has also closed the war museum. On the request of Jaisalmer collector Namit Mehta, BSF has decided not to organize Chaitra Navratra fair at Tanot Mateshwari temple this year.

Besides, guidelines have been issued to cap the number of devotees coming for aarti at the temple.

The wellness centre and isolation ward with a capacity of 400 people has been made at the Jaisalmer Military Station so that patients can be quarantined here.

The district collector has issued guidelines to Ramdeora temple and ordered the Ramdeora trust to take measures and regulate the number of devotees. The devotees are screened daily and efforts are being made to minimise crowds during the aarti.

The Fort Museum of Sonar Fort has been closed till March 31.

“I had requested BSF Rajasthan frontier IG Amit Lodha to cancel Chaitra Navratra fair or hold it at a small level. Guidelines have been issued to all prominent religious places to limit the number of pilgrims,” said the collector.

Lodha said that on the request of the collector, the fair will not be organized from March 25 at Tanot temple.

In a meeting with hoteliers and tourism businessmen, the collector asked to obtain self-declaration forms from foreign tourists before check-in, get the C-form filled and conduct medical screening. They are required to give the details of tourists to the district administration and the medical department every day.

Also, he urged the hoteliers to spray 1% sodium hypo chloride mixed with water in hotel rooms and keep a route chart record of tourists going on sightseeing.

Title: Price of platform tickets hiked to Rs 50
Content:
Vadodara: To dissuade people from thronging the railway platforms, price of platform tickets has been hiked to Rs 50 from from Rs 10. This decision taken on Tuesday has been implemented at all railway stations falling under Vadodara railway division.

The price of platform tickets have been hiked at nine railway stations including Vadodara, Anand, Bharuch, Nadiad, Kim, Kosamba, Ankleshwar, Miyagam-Karjan and Mehemdabad-Kheda Road railway stations that fall under Vadodara railway division of Western Railway.

“The decision has been taken to regulate crowds and in a bid to discourage gathering of large crowds in view of the coronavirus disease,” said Khemraj Meena, public relations officer of Vadodara railway division. The validity of platform tickets is two hours. The railways had delegated the power to divisional railway managers to increase the rate of platform tickets beyond Rs 10 in March 2015 in a bid to regulate rush at platforms in specific conditions.

Title: No qualms, they rise to the challenge
Content: THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Coronavirus could have scared people for a while. But, after the initial hesitation , more people are coming out to extend helping hands to people who are under isolation. Volunteers in Thiruvananthapuram have started reaching out to people on home quarantine who could not go out for various needs. Mathew Jacob , managing director of Seeds Holidays, is one among those who took the initiative.“We had offered volunteer support during the last two floods. There was a hesitation among people initially due to the spread of the disease. Soon, we realised the difficulty people face in isolation. After we published our contact number, we immediately got a call from an NRI woman in the city who was left alone after she returned from abroad and is in home quarantine. She had money, but she had no option even to drink a cup of tea,” Jacob said.Jacob said that he and his staff have free time as a result of the slump in the travel and tourism business due to the pandemic. “So, we are utilizing it in the best possible way. We will buy food, medicines and other essentials and deliver it to those in quarantine. We don’t charge any money. Those who wish to pay can pay for the products purchased. We don’t charge anything from people who have financial difficulties,” he added.Jacob said that after he announced the plan on social media, several others have agreed to join the cause.WeCreateLives, an NGO which empowers people with disabilities, have begun distributing masks, sanitizers and other essentials to disabled persons.While the health workers are waging a non-stop war against Covid-19, the NGO union Thiruvananthapuram north unit decided to offer solidarity by providing home-cooked food to all doctors, nurses, paramedical and other staff at the isolation ward of medical college hospital.

Title: Madurai division increases platform ticket fare to Rs 50
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Madurai railway division has hiked the platform ticket fare to Rs 50 with effect from 12am on Wednesday (March 18) until further orders. The five-fold increase from the usual fare of Rs 10 is part of the crowd control mechanism for social distancing to prevent Covid-19 from spreading.

A senior railway official said that it will come into force in all the 139 railway stations under Madurai division. “It could be in effect for at least 10 days,” the official added. It is learnt that 15% of the public stepping into the stations are platform ticket holders and the escalation in fare will drastically reduce their numbers.

“In many cases, there is an unnecessary crowd to send off and receive passengers. With more crowd the chances of Covid-19 spreading is more. So reducing the crowd is good for the passengers as well as those who accompany them,” added the official. The hike would also help keep the platforms clean.

Thought the move will take a hit on revenue generated through the sale of platform tickets, but it is necessary considering the welfare of the passengers.

Officials said that apart from Madurai, platform ticket fares have been hiked to Rs 50 in Chennai Central , Chennai Egmore and Tambaram railway stations till March 31. TNN

Title: Govt scraps fairs & festivals till March 31
Content:
Jaipur: The state tourism department has cancelled celebrations of all festivals till March 31 including Rajasthan Foundation Day.

The other festivals include Shekhawati tourism festival, Gangaur fair in Jaipur, Gangaur festival in Sahapura, Mewar festival in Udaipur and Baldev cattle fair in Nagore.

Since the state government has urged people to avoid large gatherings, there is no other way than to cancel the festivals, said a senior official in tourism department.

“Containing the spread of coronavirus is the top priority of the government. That’s why we have cancelled these festivals as they gather huge crowds. We have not taken any decision on festivals that fall in April or afterwards. The government will decide on that at the appropriate time,” said Bhanwar Lal, director, tourism department.

The tourism department sponsors these festivals to keep alive the traditional culture of the state. But over the years, they have become a great interest to tourists. The tour operators and travel agents also sell these festivals to global tourists.

Many of these events are also organised on private-public partnership mechanism. Another official in the tourism department said they had decided not to sponsor the Gangaur festival in Shahpura.

“This is a private event and we used to sponsor. But now we have decided not to support the event. They are planning to continue it. But it all depends on the local authorities for giving them permission for the event,” said the official.

Earlier, the government had planned to go ahead with the Rajasthan Foundation Day with scaled down celebrations which are spread across four days, displaying the cultural treasure of the state. But with the virus being declared a pandemic, the government did a quick rethink to cancel the event.

Title: Chennai metro takes safety measures, may cut down frequency
Content: CHENNAI: After cleaning and disinfecting two major metro stations last weekend, CMRL has started sanitizing all the 32 stations and trains on a daily-basis to protect commuters from the novel coronavirus . Metro rail has also instructed its station staff to adopt precautionary measures and spread awareness among passengers.“We give extra attention to cleaning contact points like handrails at the stations, elevators and escalators. We have been disinfecting all station premises,” a metro rail official said. Last weekend, CMRL began sanitizing the premises of Central and Airport stations that attract passengers from other cities.It has started conducting monthly maintenance activities like fumigation in the trains on a daily basis apart from spraying disinfectants and manually cleaning the handrails with a chemical approved to be effective against corona virus strains.The same chemical is used to sanitize trains on the mainline during maintenance, which happens after operational hours. “Maintenance activities like fumigation of trains, which we used to carry out only once a month, is now being done every day. We have also identified another chemical effective against Covid ,” a metro rail official said. “We are also sending precautionary measures as text messages to passengers. Dos and Don’ts are put up at all metro stations. Announcements are also regularly made,” the release said.At the CMRL head office in Koyambedu , staff members have been asked to manually mark their attendance in a register instead of using biometric devices. Large LED screens have been put up at the entrance that play awareness messages.CMRL officials said they may scale down operations if the daily footfalls drop at the stations drpop below one lakh. The daily average ridership has gone down by 5% after educational institutions shut down and companies asked their employees to work from home. Officials said they have seen a drop of around 6,000 in the average daily ridership in the last one week. The average daily patronage has been 1.2 lakh. CMRL operates 35 trains during peak hours and 25 during the non-peak hours.

Title: Bus crushes 4 to death in Sultanpur
Content:
Representative image

LUCKNOW: Four persons were killed while 11 others were injured after being hit by a speeding bus on Banda-Tanda highway in Sultanpur. The victims were trying to rescue an injured biker on the highway on Monday night when the accident occurred.

The deceased identified as Hasan Ali (30), Aleem Khan (39), Gagan Tiwari (28) and Sunil Agrahari (35) weer residents of Motiganj area in Sultanpur. Hasan and Aleem died on the spot while Gagan and Sunil died at KGMU trauma centre on Tuesday morning where five injured were admitted. The other eight injured are undergoing treatment at Sultanpur district hospital. ASP Sultanpur Shiv Raj said the accident occurred around 9pm under Gosainganj police station area.

“A group of villagers had first gone to rescue a biker who was hit by an unidentified vehicle. In the meantime, the speeding private bus coming from the direction of Azamgarh crushed the villagers,” said the ASP.

Title: Woman arrested for torturing daughter in Madurai
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: The Tallakulam police on Tuesday arrested a woman for torturing her nine-year-old daughter, while the search is underway for her friends. The girl was rescued on Saturday after she ran away and took refuge at her relative’s house in Meenambalpuram .

The girl was malnourished and had burn marks on her foot, a scar on her head caused when her hair was plucked and injuries on her private parts. Her head was also tonsured to hide the scar. Based on a complaint from her aunt, a case was registered with the Tallakulam police station on Saturday.

Tallakulam inspector Malaisamy said they arrested the child’s mother Murugeswari from Bibikulam on Tuesday. After an inquiry with her, she was sent to judicial remand. Meanwhile, her friends Sunilkumar and Shahul Hameed have gone underground. He said that all the three were involved in physically abusing the child. The child’s relatives said that Murugeswari was in a relationship with Sunilkumar and did not take of the child well. She was only given biscuits in mornings and used to have food provided under the noon meal scheme. She was shifted to the district welcome home and officials are taking efforts to put her in a hostel to enable her to continue education.

Title: Vadodara jail inmates to talk to kin using video calls
Content:
Vadodara: Although mobile phones are not allowed inside the premises of Vadodara Central Jail, inmates will now be able to talk to their relatives using video call facility and mark their presence during hearing in court through video conferencing.

Jail officials said that the infrastructure for such facilities are already in place but in wake of coronavirus pandemic, these facilities will be encouraged.

The inmates have been appealed to use the broadband services of the jail to talk to their family members instead of meeting them in person. The prisons department has a special application which avails this facility.

“The family members of the inmates can download the application on their Android-based phones and on the other hand the inmate will have access to it through our systems in the jail and they can talk through video call,” said jail superintendent Baldevsinh Vaghela. The system known as ‘e-mulakaat’ was in place for some time but was hardly used.

Even if inmates do not want to use the video call facility, in-person meeting has been allowed by jail officials. However, the number of visitors has been capped at two per inmate. “Earlier we used to allow five visitors to meet every inmate and allow seven inmates in the visitors’ room. But now the number of inmates in the visitors’ room will also be no more than five minutes,” Vaghela added. The visitors too will have to wash their hands before entering the visitors’ room.

Video conferencing facility will also be availed for those inmates who have to mark their presence for hearing of their case. Vaghela said that if any inmate has to be part of the hearing like getting examined or give testimony then he or she will be taken to court.

Meanwhile, the jail staff have now started wearing masks inside the jail premises as a precautionary measure.

On Monday, doctors from SSG Hospital met jail inmates to make them aware about the pandemic and how they can prevent it by using various sanitization methods within the jail premises.

Title: Covid-19: HIV drugs for virus patients only when needed, says panel
Content: JAIPUR: The drugs (lapinavir/ritonavir) useful in treating HIV provided to Covid-19 patients by SMS Hospital doctors can cause adverse effects too, states the 2019 Novel Coronavirus Prevention and Management, Preparedness Document of AIIMS, New Delhi.The Indian regulatory authority, Central Drugs Standard Control Organisation, has accorded approval for restricted public health emergency use of this treatment protocol (lapinavir/ritonavir).Additional chief secretary (health) Rohit Kumar Singh said the use of two drugs, which were provided to three Covid-19 patients in SMS Hospital, who were cured with the help of the two drugs, can be used in public health emergency only. There are provisions of using them in such emergency cases. He said before giving the drugs to patients, they took nod of ICMR and the Indian Drug Regulatory Authority.An article published in Indian Journal of Medical Research, the experts of ICMR and AIIMS pointed out that the ICMR has suggested lopinavir/ritonavir combination therapy for laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 patients based on the observational studies of clinical benefit amongst patients with SARS-CoV and MERSCoV, as well as the docking studies conducted by the National Institute of Virology, Pune. The Indian Regulatory Authority, Central Drugs Standard Control Organization , has accorded approval for restricted public health emergency use of this treatment protocol.The article was written by Tarun Bhatnagar of ICMR, Chennai, Manoj V Murhekar of AIIMS, Nivedita Gupta, Naveet Wig and Raman Gangakhedkar of ICMR-Delhi, which further stated that the initial treatment protocol was for administering the combination treatment to all laboratory-confirmed patients.However, the first three laboratory-confirmed patients from Kerala had mild symptoms on diagnosis and had a stable course of illness. Hence, lopinavir/ritonavir treatment was not administered in these patients.“It is however, crucial to initiate the treatment before patient develops features of severe illnesses,” reads the article ‘Lopinavir/ritonavir combination therapy among symptomatic coronavirus disease 2019 patients in India: Protocol for restricted public health emergency use’.However, AIIMS Preparedness Document of AIIMS, New Delhi, advocates that a prior consent of the patient is required before giving these two medicines to patients.

Title: Covid-19: Rlys starts passenger screening, UP roadways sanitizes buses
Content: AGRA: Railway kick-started screening of passengers at Agra cantt railway station. A long queue of passengers waited for their turn to get screened by railway medical staff for Covid-19 infection.Meanwhile, Agra region of UP roadways distributed sanitising kit to their employees in order to get their fleet of buses cleaned.

Title: Chennai: No screening as scores board EMU trains
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The state government may have shut malls, theatres and pubs to prevent gatherings, but Moore Market Complex suburban railway station was teeming with thousands of commuters returning home after work on Tuesday.

Railways has begun to spray disinfectant at the platforms and trains, but has chosen to leave these thousands unmonitored. There are no desks to sensitise people, and no screening to check if anyone had flu-like symptoms.

More than 2 lakh commuters travel by suburban trains on the Chennai-Gummidipoondi and Chennai-Tiruvallur lines every day. On Tuesday evening, trains were packed. People who work in government offices, private firms and shops in Parrys, Anna Salai and other localities commute to work and return home by these trains.

Though footfalls have reduced at MGR Central and Egmore stations, the volume of people who take the express trains is so huge that it was hardly discernible in the evening peak hour.

Alex P, a regular commuter, said, “There is no checking of suburban commuter anywhere. I travelled to Perambur yesterday and went by train to Ambattur on Tuesday morning. The trains were packed and there seems to be no awareness or caution among people. There is no visible attempt to sensitise people about Covid-19.”

This could be a disaster waiting to happen, said commuters who have no choice but to use the trains as they have to report to work at shops and firms. “Many people who travel on the route are those belonging to middle class and low-income group who work as daily wage workers, maids, sales assistants at shops, workers in industrial estates and others. It is life as usual for them,” said an official.

Title: Don’s murder in Lucknow jail: CBI to grill Rathi & Baghpat prison brass
Content:
File photo of Munna Bajrangi

LUCKNOW: Ten days after registering an FIR in connection with murder of dreaded don Munna Bajrangi alias Prem Prakash in Baghpat jail on July 9, 2018, the Central Bureau of Investigation will start questioning the main accused Sunil Rathi and the jail officials.

CBI has sought permission to question Rathi from authorities of Tihar jail where he was shifted due to security reasons on October 6, 2019, said senior officials of the agency.

The case was transferred to CBI on direction of Allahabad High Court , which said the matter required an in-depth and impartial probe. CBI had then lodged an FIR against Rathi on March 7.

A senior officer privy to the probe said the case papers and chargesheet filed by Baghpat police against Rathi has been collected along with all evidence.

“A detailed questionnaire has been prepared for jailer Uday Pratap Singh, deputy jailers Shivaji Yadav and S P Singh, head warder Arjinder Singh and warder Madhav Kumar who were posted in Baghpat jail at the time of incident,” the officer said.

The questioning of jail staff is important since it is not yet known how the .32 bore pistol used in the killing was sneaked into the prison.

In its chargesheet, Baghpat police had failed to reveal how the murder weapon was sneaked inside and given to Rathi.

A senior CBI officer privy to the probe said Rathi did not have any enmity or connection with Munna Bajrangi and hence it needs to be probed thoroughly as to what prompted him suddenly to take such a drastic step and kill him.

Title: Sports complexes in city shut, vigil upped
Content:
Sports complex at Manjalpur area wears a deserted look on Tuesday

Vadodara: In wake of COVID-19 pandemic alert, the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) has asked its health department to ensure that only medical officers follow-up with people advised home quarantine after they returned from coronavirus-affected countries or states.

While no cases have been reported in the city, the civic body has upped precautionary measures.

VMC mayor Dr Jigisha Sheth said, “We have decided that such persons advised home quarantine will not be examined by any other health worker.” She further said that the civic body has sufficient amount of medicines and materials to deal with any situation. Besdies education institutes, cinema halls, swimming pools and other places listed by the state government, the civic body had also decided to close down its zoo as well as sports complexes, Sheth said, adding that it has come to light that 550 to 600 people visit the sports complexes every day.

Regular visitors to the VMC gardens were also being advised to avoid going there for sometime.

On Tuesday, the civic body also sanitised its city buses and sanitizers were provided at the city bus depot and control room for commuters as a preventive measure. The buses also have displays regarding COVID-19 prevention.

Title: Police personnel advised on Covid-19 preventive measures
Content: TIRUNELVELI: A Covid-19 sensitisation and preventive measures awareness programme for armed reserve police personnel was organised jointly by the Tirunelveli city police and Tirunelveli Corporation here on Tuesday. It is part of the two-day initiative to cover more than 450 police personnel on Covid-19 preventive measures.“Private companies are promoting work from home option to prevent spread of Covid-19. The government is emphasising on social distancing for this purpose. But police personnel at the field level cannot enjoy these as duty demands their presence in hard conditions in which they have to work with the masses,” deputy commissioner of police, A Saravanan said.The officer said that armed reserve personnel have to escort prisoners to the courts in other districts and neighbouring states and they cannot avoid touching handrails and similar things that could result in spreading Covid-19. Police engaged in crowd control too can contract with carriers of the virus.“They cannot wash their hands with soap and running water 10 times a day. Under their working conditions they could end up becoming carriers of the virus. So we asked them to wash their hands with soap soon after reaching home. They were also asked to use masks or handkerchiefs to cover their nose,” the officer said. Saravanan said that liquid soap and water to wash hands have been made available at all police stations in the city and at the office of the city police commissioner.tnn

Title: Covid-19: Rlys starts passenger screening, UP roadways sanitizes buses
Content: AGRA: Railway kick-started screening of passengers at Agra cantt railway station. A long queue of passengers waited for their turn to get screened by railway medical staff for Covid-19 infection.Meanwhile, Agra region of UP roadways distributed sanitising kit to their employees in order to get their fleet of buses cleaned.

Title: Over 500 masks manufactured by Aligarh jail inmates
Content: AGRA: As a precautionary measure to curb the spread of Covid-19, inmates of Aligarh jail have manufactured 565 masks in the past two days for in-house distribution among prisoners and their relatives who come to meet them. Besides, sanitisers have been placed at every corner of the prison.Confirming this, Aligarh jailor Pramod Kumar Singh said that around 3,100 inmates are present inside the jail and masks are being provided to curb the spread of any kind of infection. Jail superintendent Alok Kumar said, “Disposable masks are distributed to the visitors to curb any kind of infection”.

Title: Bars closed: Tipplers open bottle on streets in Chennai
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: What if the government has ordered closure of bars as part of precautions against the virus? Tipplers have turned streets with Tasmac outlets as open bars. And the worst hit are residents in the neighbourhood.

As soon as the shutters of liquor outlets were pulled up at noon on Tuesday, many were found drinking in the open in many neighbourhoods. There they stood, barely hiding the bottles; one held out a plastic tumbler into which another poured a stiff drink and water before the two gulped down. On Canal Bank Road near the Kasturba Nagar MRTS station, the public drinkers littered the place with empty bottles, caps and leftovers of food.

Ashok Kumar, a resident of Adyar, said public drinking has always been a menace, now it has been double the trouble. “Usually they drink on the streets in the late evening hours, mostly after the bars shut at 10pm. Now this menace has started early in the day,” said an auto rickshaw driver. “In fact, the government should have closed the liquor outlets along with bars.”

Employees at Tasmac outlet counters said tipplers don’t listen to them if told not to drink in front of the shops. “They ask us where would they go to drink after we closed the bars but not the shop,” said a Tasmac salesman in the northern suburbs. But at some places some men were seen soliciting customers into alleys and selling water and snacks. Luz Corner, a man was seen ushering in prospective customers on the street adjacent to the Thirumayilai MRTS station. No policeman was seen in the vicinity. When contacted, Adyar deputy commissioner Pakalavan said action would be taken against such individuals. “Nobody can use such public space to consume liquor,” he said.

Tasmac officials said they would form special teams to control the spillover on streets. A senior official said police assistance would be sought to check such public nuisance near the outlets. “The teams will visit the outlets and their vicinities,” the official told TOI. Chennai region, which comprises the city and the neighbouring districts of Chengalpet, Kancheepuram and Tiruvallur, has 718 bars attached to Tasmac outlets, of which more than 300 are in the core city.

Title: Rajasthan: 5 Iranians screened in Sikar, 10 Covid-19 suspects in SMS hospital
Content: JAIPUR: At least 10 Covid-19 suspects, including two Australians and a New Zealander, was admitted to the isolation ward of Sawai Man Singh Hospital with symptoms of influenza-like illness on Tuesday. Besides, a group of five Iranian tourists has been found staying at a hotel in Sikar. The group had reached India in January and have a visa till September.“We conducted screening of Iranian tourists and all of them were healthy. They do not have symptoms of Covid-19,” said Dr Ajay Chaudhary, chief medical health officer, Sikar, adding that they reached Sikar on Monday night.Chaudhary said so far they have identified 110 people who have returned from other countries. Out of those, 26 people have completed the duration of 28 days of home quarantine. Still, 84 people are under observation as they are quarantined at their homes. In Sikar, 18 samples have been tested and all of them turned negative for the disease. Moreover, district health department in Sikar has identified five places, which can be converted into quarantine facilities, whenever required. Dr Chaudhary inspected five places, including two dharamshalas and two primary health centres and one Kalyan Aarogya Sadan, where 400 beds can be accommodated.Besides, 10 suspected persons were admitted to SMS Hospital on Tuesday. “We have kept them in the isolation ward,” said Dr DS Meena, medical superintendent, SMS Hospital.

Title: Kanyakumari SHGs to manufacture sanitizers and sell them at low price
Content:
Representative image

KANYAKUMARI: The Kanyakumari district administration has initiated the process of manufacturing hand sanitizers and cloth masks with help from self-help groups (SHGs) to bridge the gap in demand and supply to combat Covdi-19. “A decision on the same was taken at a meeting on Monday evening,” district collector Prashant M Wadnere told TOI.

There is a wide gap in the demand and supply of hand sanitizers. At the same time, sanitizers made by government medical college hospitals and the health services department are hardly enough for the health department personnel. Face masks too are running out of supply. So, the district administration has decided to seek the help of SHGs.

The collector said they are keen on maintaining medical standards of the sanitizers to serve the purpose. “We are collecting the list of SHGs who are interested in manufacturing hand sanitizers at their place. We are also in the process of arranging for the chemicals that are required for the process. Priority will be in making the sanitizers available for the health department and the public,” he said.

Procurement of bottles for the required size and logistics is also being worked out. Wadnere said that the SHGs will be directly marketing the product in their locality on a no margin or very less margin basis so that it is easily available to the common man. Sanitizers manufactured by SHGs are likely to be available for the public from this weekend.

The health department in Kanyakumari has also provided training to pharmacists from the inter-state bordering areas to make sanitizers and asked them to sell them at an affordable price.

Title: 19-year-old kills grandparents in cold blood for money
Content:
K J Chauhan, PSI with Gir Somnath LCB, at a press meet

Rajkot: In a horrific incident , a 19-year-old youth committed a cold blooded double murder for want of money in Rampara village of Veraval taluka in Gir Somnath district on March 3.

Gir Somnath local crime branch (LCB) sleuths, who arrested culprit Rohit Devusinh Bhadarka from his house in Beej village near Rampara, said that the youth, who works as a compounder with a private hospital, hacked his 60-year-old grandfather Ram Bhadarka and also Lakshmi (56), Bhardarka’s second wife.

While the body of the man was found on the door step of the house, the woman was found lying in a pool of blood on her bed inside the home. Police also recovered the murder weapons, a blood-stained axe and a bamboo stick from the house.

According to police, Rohit, a Class XII drop-out decided to bump-off his grandparents and steal their gold ornaments as he was in dire need of money.

On questioning, Rohit told the police that he had went to his grandparents’ house and knocked on the door during the wee hours. When the garndfather opened the door, Rohit hacked him with an axe, killing him on the spot. Thereafter, he went inside the room and killed his grandmother, too, who was sleeping on the cot. The two bodies were discovered almost a day later on March 4, said police.

Initially, police believed the elderly couple to have been murdered by robbers. But after the probe was handed over to the LCB, it was found that Rohit was seen in Rampara village on the day of the murder. “Investigation confirmed that Rohit had allegedly killed his grandparents,” said K J Chauhan, sub-inspector with Gir Somnath local crime branch.

Title: Rumour-mongers now spread alarm in Lunawada
Content:
Vadodara: The Mahisagar district administration has asked the Lunawada taluka health officer to file an offence under Information Technology Act following rumours about COVID-19 positive cases being spread by some miscreants.

Rumours were rife that that two persons had tested positive for COVID-19 even when no such cases were reported there.

The miscreants morphed screen grabs of prominent local satellite television channels and circulated them on smartphones. One of the doctored grabs stated that two cases having coronavirus were seen in the Cottage Hospital at Lunawada. The other morphed grab stated that the coronavirus had created havoc in Mahisagar district.

In one message, the miscreants had even named a person claiming that he was suffering from coronavirus infection. In another, an old grab of a television news item of a person from Godhra being suspected of suffering from coronavirus infection was circulated widely a month after the person who never suffered from the disease had gone to the hospital. Such rumours were circulated in central Gujarat and twice in Godhra too, said the administration.

Title: Madurai: Callous sanitary workers throw safety to the wind
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Sanitary workers with the Madurai Corporation , who are one of the most vulnerable to infections, are yet to take any preventive measures with the Covid-19 scare looming large, though the civic body has provided them with protective gear. Most of them can be seen working without wearing the protective gear such as marks and gloves in various parts of the city. The employees handle all sorts of waste collected from households and from collection points without any gloves or masks on. As they visit door to door every morning to collect waste, they can be potential carriers of infections.

A sanitation employee on condition of anonymity said that although they have been issued with protective gear, they do not wear it since it makes the job difficult. “I was issued with masks and gloves, but I left it nearby. It is difficult to wear them and work,” the employee said.

Another employee said that although he is aware of Covid-19, he does not take wearing protective gear seriously since there has not been any detected cases from this part of the state. “Public too are yet to wear masks. There are no used masks seen in the garbage. We will wear them when there is a need,” he said.

Corporation commissioner S Visakan said that all the employees are issued with protective gear. The have also been instructed on the importance of maintaining personnel hygiene in zonal level and ward level meetings conducted by officials. “All employees will be monitored. Those who are found not wearing masks and gloves will be taken to task,” he said. Sanitation employees have been swung into action to disinfect all public places.

Title: Agra: Seven held for robbing Rs 35 lakh from courier
Content:
Representative image.

AGRA: In a joint operation carried out by Mantola police, along with the surveillance and criminal intelligence wings of Agra police, seven men were arrested a fortnight after a courier delivery man was robbed of Rs 35 lakh in cash.

On the morning of March 2, Prakash Bhai Patel, a native of Gujarat currently living in Chhata , was robbed by four motorbike-borne gun-wielding masked men near Hathighat, while he was walking down the road to catch some public transport on his way to Delhi.

Police said after gathering manual and technical intelligence, they arrested seven men — Suresh Sengar of Agra, Pawan Singh, Rishi Kumar and Manoj Singh of Etah, Ghanshyam and Dewan Singh of Hathras, and Akash of Firozabad. However, prime accused Rahul Donny alias Pradeep is still on the run.

Agra SSP Babloo Kumar said, “It was a well-planned robbery. The gang had done reconnaissance of the victim on February 28. On the morning of March 2, as the victim was heading for the national capital, he was waylaid by four bike-borne members of the gang. They robbed him of the cash and his mobile phone.”

“Our team has recovered Rs 2.17 lakh and three motorbikes, including one which was newly purchased with the looted cash. The gang had distributed the rest of the amount among themselves. We’ll soon recover the rest,” he added.

All seven arrested men are history-sheeters.

Title: Rajasthan: 5 Iranians screened in Sikar, 10 Covid-19 suspects in SMS hospital
Content: JAIPUR: At least 10 Covid-19 suspects, including two Australians and a New Zealander, was admitted to the isolation ward of Sawai Man Singh Hospital with symptoms of influenza-like illness on Tuesday. Besides, a group of five Iranian tourists has been found staying at a hotel in Sikar. The group had reached India in January and have a visa till September.“We conducted screening of Iranian tourists and all of them were healthy. They do not have symptoms of Covid-19,” said Dr Ajay Chaudhary, chief medical health officer, Sikar, adding that they reached Sikar on Monday night.Chaudhary said so far they have identified 110 people who have returned from other countries. Out of those, 26 people have completed the duration of 28 days of home quarantine. Still, 84 people are under observation as they are quarantined at their homes. In Sikar, 18 samples have been tested and all of them turned negative for the disease. Moreover, district health department in Sikar has identified five places, which can be converted into quarantine facilities, whenever required. Dr Chaudhary inspected five places, including two dharamshalas and two primary health centres and one Kalyan Aarogya Sadan, where 400 beds can be accommodated.Besides, 10 suspected persons were admitted to SMS Hospital on Tuesday. “We have kept them in the isolation ward,” said Dr DS Meena, medical superintendent, SMS Hospital.

Title: Now courts crack a whip to contain corona outbreak
Content:
Jaipur/Jodhpur: Amid corona containment across the state, the high court and lower courts in the state witnessed limited footfall on Tuesday.

After issuing an advisory to subordinate courts in the wake of the looming threat, Rajasthan High Court has now decided to restrict its functioning to urgent matters till March 31.

The court observed holiday on Tuesday, however, the advocates were asked to submit their request for urgency of their matters to the high court administration on Tuesday upto 4.30 pm citing the cause of urgency in a prescribed format provided by the court.

“The advocates need to cite the reason why their case should be taken as urgent. Based on the merit of the urgency, the court will decide whether the matter deserved to be listed as urgent matter for hearing in next 3 days,” said an officer.

Meanwhile, the regular matters, which had been listed for hearing on these 3 days — Wednesday, Thursday and Friday — have been respectively deferred till April 15, 16 and 17.

The decision was taken in a meeting held on Tuesday through video conferencing attended by the chief justice.

Title: Yogi Adityanath says private universities in Uttar Pradesh to check brain drain
Content:
File photo of Yogi Adityanath

LUCKNOW: Paving way for setting up private universities in the state, chief minister Yogi Adityanath on Tuesday distributed letters of intent to establishments opening non-public universities in Uttar Pradesh . A total of 28 LoIs were distributed at a programme organised at the chief minister’s residence.

Speaking on the occasion, CM Yogi said the upcoming private universities will create a competitive environment in the state and check exodus of students to other states. The setting up of 28 private universities will bring Rs 3,000 crore investment, besides creating more job opportunities, the CM said.

“There were only 27 private universities in the state since independence, but our government has paved way for opening 28 new private universities in three years. Similarly, there were only 12 medical colleges in the state till 2016, but now, 29 more are coming up,” said Yogi.

“My government is committed to making UP a hub of education. The private universities should explore the possibility of signing MoUs with top 100 universities of the world,and making them knowledge partners.,” the CM said.

He also urged the upcoming universities to connect with Indian diaspora in different parts of the world. All new universities should run job-oriented courses and set up placement centres to provide jobs to students, he added.

The CM said that all existing private and government universities and upcoming ones should have develop coordination among themselves to improve the quality of education.

Title: Madurai: Board exam centres urged to follow WHO-advised social distancing
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: With no specific preventive measures for Covid-19 in place yet at the public board exam centres for Classes X to XII, students, teachers and parents urged the school education department to facilitate proper social distancing as per World Health Organisation (WHO) advisory.

“Apart from washing hands, a key measure for prevention of COVID-19 is social distancing. This is why the state government itself has shut down all places where public gather in masses. But, hundreds of children will be gathering at board exam centres. It takes only a minute of carelessness for infection to spread,” said Keerthana S, parent of a Class X student, who will be writing board exams from March 27. In Madurai district alone, 120 centres each for Class XI and XII board exams are functioning, catering to a total of 73,250 student candidates. As per WHO advisory, social distancing requires persons to maintain a distance of at least 3 feet or 1 metre. “Usually, we have two to three students seated on a bench. The distance between the students sitting on the same bench is already around 4 feet. However, the distance between one bench to the one in front or the one behind it, is usually much closer,” said a school staff at one of the board exam centres.

“The government should definitely start bringing in preventive measures for Covid-19 in board exam centres too, especially with Class X exams set to begin. Either the number of centres could be increased or the school education department can ask the centres to use more rooms and accommodate lesser number of students in each with ample space between one student and another,” said the principal of a private school.

Meanwhile, education department officials maintained that they are yet to receive further specific instructions regarding COVID-19 preventive measures to be implemented in the board exam centres.

Title: Uttarakhand Congress vice president home quarantined after he visits hospital
Content: DEHRADUN: Uttarakhand Congress vice-president Suryakant Dhasmana was on Tuesday home quarantined after he visited isolation ward of Doon Hospital to meet Covid-19 positive patient.The health department is also looking for a journalist who has allegedly accompanied the Congress V-P to the isolation ward.In a two-minute-long video, that went viral on Monday, Congress V-P was seen speaking with two Covid-19 suspected students kept in quarantine at Doon hospital. He was also seen entering the isolation ward where coronavirus positive IFS trainee is admitted.Chief medical officer (CMO) Dr Meenakshi Joshi confirmed that Dhasmana was home quarantined as he went to the isolation ward at the Doon Hospital on Monday.“No one is allowed to visit the patient inside the isolation ward. There are strict government guidelines regarding the same. Dhasmana has been advised to remain in isolation for 14 days. Even his family members are vulnerable so, they should maintain minimum social contact,” the CMO said, adding that some journalists had also accompanied the Congress VP inside the isolation ward.She added, “We request those journalists to get in touch with us and the health department will help them. The chances of them getting infected cannot be neglected and if that would happen, they will risk the lives of their family members and many others.”Meanwhile, speaking to TOI, Dhasmana said that the purpose of his visit was to review the preparation of the health department to tackle Covid-19 cases. He also claimed that he entered the quarantine ward with N-95 mask and had taken all necessary precautions that are prescribed to avoid getting in contact of the deadly virus.“No one told me that I shouldn’t enter the isolation ward. There were no guards, no banners and no posters in the hospital to guide visitors or even patients. Also, how can I, being a leader, leave the people to die? So, I felt it was my responsibility to meet the IFS trainee. Also, I didn’t go close to him,” he said, adding that he is ready to take all precautions advised by the CMO who has briefed him on how to stay in isolation at home.

Title: Three booked for setting ablaze coal conveyor belt at power plant
Content:
Rajkot: Three unidentified persons have been booked for setting the coal conveyor belt on fire at Essar Power plant in Salaya of Devbhoomi Dwarka district on Tuesday. The fire had destroyed about 500m of rubber conveyor belt used to transport coal from the Vadindar jetty to the power plant directly.

According to the FIR lodged by Indris Abdul Sayyed, head of security at the power plant, at around 11pm on March 15 fire had engulfed about 500m of the conveyor belt on the jetty side. On investigation it was found that some miscreants who had come on two bikes from near the jetty had allegedly set the belt ablaze.

The accused had allegedly cut the fencing wire and used cow-dung cakes and inflammable liquids to ignite fire on the conveyor belt. According to the company, the fire had caused losses to the tune of Rs 2.5 crore.

GR Gadhvi, police inspector of Salaya police station, said that they had found tyre marks of the bike and foot prints of three different persons near the fencing. “Based on this we have assumed that three persons were involved in the crime,” he added.

Title: 67 newly screened, 47 under home quarantine
Content:
Vadodara collector Shalini Agrawal visiting the government hospital

Vadodara: An elderly woman and a middle-aged man, who were admitted in the isolation ward at the SSG Hospital, have tested negative of coronavirus disease (COVID)-19. The woman and the man who had recently returned from Saudi Arabia and Germany respectively had shown symptoms similar to that of COVID-19 and were being treated as suspected cases.

“Both have tested negative. We will however keep them under medication till their medical condition improves,” said Dr Rajeev Daveshwar, medical superintendent, SSG Hospital.

A total of 67 new persons were screened for COVID-19 at the hospital till Tuesday late evening and none of them have tested positive.

After sample of the US return Karjan native who was the first one to be admitted in the isolation ward tested negative of COVID-19, the male has been discharged as his medical condition too improved.

Earlier, in the day, Vadodara collector Shalini Agrawal visited the government hospital. She informed that 638 persons including 100 from district areas and 538 persons residing in the Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) areas had been screened till Tuesday. “Presently, there are 47 persons under home quarantine and 53 others have already cleared their observation period,” she said.

She asked the hospital authorities to set up a flu corner near the isolation ward, start a help desk to assist those coming to resolve their queries and make seating arrangements for relatives of those who come for screening.

“A flu corner equipped with a team of medical officers can help in carrying out preliminary screening of those who come for check-up. After preliminary screening, if required, they can be admitted in the isolation ward,” she said.

Samples of suspected cases are presently being sent to Ahmedabad civil hospital. “If required the hospital is equipped to carry out such tests in future,” she said, adding that all the required logistics, medical staff, medicines and ventilators are available.
