Title: Now, insurance cos offer Covid-19 cover
Content: Visakhapatnam: Following the outbreak of novel coronavirus ( Covid-19 ), companies selling health insurance are floating advertisements recommending policies targeted for the treatment of this viral infection Sources say that while the policies remain the regular ones, they are being marketed highlighting coverage of Covid-19. One particular company however, has even floated a benefit policy exclusively for patients infected with Covid-19.Speaking to TOI, DS Raju, a senior official of a leading insurance company said, “What is happening right now is that insurance companies are selling existing health insurance highlighting entitlements for Covid 19-affected patients. This is a sheer marketing policy of selling old wine in a new bottle.”Marketing experts say owing to virus outbreaks such as Ebola, Zika and Nipah, insurance companies have begun designing policies to cover such infections. As Covid-19 is an infection, like other infections, coverage for it will be available with insurance products that cover hospitalisation costs.Coverage for in-patient treatment, pre-hospitalisation, post-hospitalisation, OPD and ambulance that a certain health insurance policy offers will be available for Covid-19 as well.TK Sarathi, a senior official of a nationalised health insurance company said, “Recently, the IRDA issued strict instructions to health insurance companies warning against rejecting claims related to coronavirus. The regulatory authority has stated that all claims reported under Covid-19 shall be thoroughly reviewed by the claims review committee before repudiation.”“Following this, insurance companies have decided to go for this all-out campaign for highlighting coverage for Covid-19 affected patients,” Sarathi added.Meanwhile, a private company has introduced an exclusive Covid-19 exclusive benefit plan, but “people above 60 years of age are not entitled to this policy,” said Kamal Thelagathoti, a senior official of an insurance brokerage agency.Experts are unsure of how successful these marketing strategies will be. There has not been an increase in people buying policies after insurance companies started marketing policies highlighting coverage for patients suffering from Covid-19.

Title: 260 more Indian evacuees to arrive in Jaisalmer today
Content: Jaisalmer: More than 260 Indians from Iran will be brought via Delhi to Jaisalmer civil airport in two flights for being quarantined at the Jaisalmer military station’s wellness center and isolation ward on Wednesday afternoon. Prior to this, 289 Indians were brought here in three flights over the last three days. The flight will first land in Delhi and after clearing customs and immigration, it will reach Jaisalmer. It may be mentioned that the tests of 289 people quarantined at Jaisalmer military station have come out negative. Earlier, the military station had received 236 Indians on Sunday and 53 on Monday. tnn

Title: Coronavirus scare: Sanitisers, paper tissues replace finger bowls, napkins at eateries
Content: KOLKATA: Don’t be surprised if the waiter offers you a shaft of paper instead of a sparkling white napkin the next time you dine out. Dining etiquette is changing fast in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. Hand sanitizers and paper tissues have started replacing finger bowls and cloth napkins. This apart, restaurants are also increasing the gap between two tables to at least 1.5m as a precautionary measure.There’s more. If you are walking in at your favourite joint anytime soon, be prepared for the mandatory temperature screening. You are allowed in only if the infrared thermometer reads normal. The Hotel and Restaurant Association of Eastern India (HRAEI) has convened a meeting and came up with the dos and don’ts, along with a host of other measures to keep customers and staffers safe.“No one — patrons or staff — will be allowed inside the property if the thermometer indicates that they have high temperature,” HRAEI president Pranav Singh said on Tuesday. “We have had a meeting with our members on safety against the coronavirus spread and decided to take a whole lot of measures,” he said.The restaurants have adopted stringent policies on maintaining health and hygiene. Tables, door handles and knobs will be periodically sanitized. “Guests will be asked to use hand sanitizers instead of finger bowls. And paper tissues will replace the cloth napkins,” Singh said.Even before the guidelines were issued, certain restaurants were already on a hyper-hygiene mode. “We at Chowman, Oudh 1590, Chapter 2 and Master Dimsum have been taking steps to keep the virus at bay. Our delivery persons are wearing masks and frequently using hand sanitizers,” said Shiladitya Chaudhury, partner of the chain of restaurant. Co-partner Debaditya Chaudhury said business has remained steady but noticeably lighter ever since the outbreak. “The inherent anxiety is there, but what has remained the same is people’s enthusiasm. If there’s a 10 % decline in walk-in-and-dine-in ratio, our orders through delivery have gone up considerably,” he said.On Monday, Saz on Camac Street made a hard decision to close the restaurant “with an end goal to limit the danger of Covid-19 at our restaurant as much as could be expected, we are closing down.”

Title: Quacks, herbal drugs add to chaos
Content: Visakhapatnam: Confusion over the number of positive coronavirus cases, rumours on social media and confusing suspects and those quarantined with confirmed cases, quacks promising natural cure of the virus are adding to the chaos even though the city has not reported any confirmed case so far.Claims that the risk of acquiring Covid-19 risk increases with eating non-vegetarian food and can be prevented by consuming alcohol or cow urine are further augmenting the confusion among residents of the city.“There are no vaccines for preventing coronavirus so far. But quacks and alternate medicine experts are advertising natural or herbal medicine claiming that coronavirus can be cured by consuming these. There is no scientific basis to their claims, rather consumption of quack’s medicines may prevent timely treatment and worsen suspected or affected cases. People should be aware that all suspected or fever cases do not mean the person is virus-affected unless lab tests confirm them to be positive. Since this is the first time that the pandemic has struck, it is too early to say if the virus will die in hot or cold weather,” said Dr PV Sudhakar, principal of Andhra Medical College.”Legal experts said spreading rumours and not adhering to government orders is a punishable offence. Senior advocate and president of Forum of Legal Professional, Kuppili Muralidhar said, “Spreading rumours through social media or otherwise and false propaganda are punishable offences under Section 188 of the Indian Penal Code and may invoke both fine and jail term. Under the Epidemic Diseases Act, 1897, disobeying government orders regarding screening, escaping from quarantine or isolation wards is an offence under law.”

Title: Flights, trains cancelled due to fewer passengers
Content:
Jaipur: The corona scare has now started affecting the flights and trains from Jaipur. The international flight from Jaipur to Bangkok was cancelled by its operator on Tuesday till April 15, while two domestic flights, including Jaipur to Delhi and Jaipur to Dehradun, were cancelled for Tuesday due to poor passenger load. Some of the passengers travelling to Bangkok by Air Asia on Tuesday were taken aback when they got a message that their flight would remain cancelled. Thereafter, the flight operator clarified that it would remain cancelled till April 15.

“Earlier, Jaipur to Kuala Lumpur flight was cancelled and Bangkok is the second destination from where one flight would remain cancelled. There are two flights to Bangkok from Jaipur out of which one of the operator has cancelled it while Thai Smile is still operating,” said a senior officer of airport operation. On the other hand, western railways, Mumbai have decided to cancel some of its trains which also included Jaipur to Mumbai and Mumbai to Jaipur Duranto. “These trains would remain cancelled from March 22 to March 31,” said a senior officer at NWR.

North Western Railways (NWR) has decided to cancel Sriganganagar to Ambala Cantt train. “This has been decided after seeing a very poor passenger’s load in this train,” a senior officer of Bikaner division of north western railways added.

Ongoing corona scare has also curtailed the occupancy in flights and trains to 60 percent as many people are applying for cancellations.

Title: Anganwadis, SHGs to visit every house in Bhubaneswar for health & travel updates
Content:
BHUBANESWAR: The Bhubaneswar Municipal Corporation (BMC) has decided to take the help of anganwadi workers and self-help groups (SHGs) to check the health of people in every house within the city limits over the next few days.

The BMC commissioner on Tuesday discussed the proposal with block education officers and child development project officers. They were asked to tell anganwadi workers and SHG members to move from house to house and fetch not only the health details of individuals in every household, but to check if anyone from the family had visited any coronavirus-hit area inside or outside India.

The travel history of the family members and their health profile will have to be filed by the workers on a daily basis.

“The aim of using the services of anganwadi workers and SHGs is to ensure that we have the health profile and travel history of people. During the drive, the workers will sensitise people on how to maintain sanitation, especially basic things like hand washing, avoiding socializing and maintaining one metre distance from each other,” he said.

Sources in the BMC said they had identified 374 anganwadi workers for the job. They will start visiting families from Wednesday.

The BMC on Tuesday started zone-wise awareness drive by rolling out three vehicles. “The vehicles will be covered with posters. Leaflets will be distributed among the people. Emphasis will be placed on market places where people gather in numbers,” said a BMC officer.

The BMC on Monday came up with a Standard Operating Procedure (SOP) for wedding halls, public parks, fast food centres, roadside eateries and lassi stalls, restaurant owners, dance bars, markets and haats owned by it and the Bhubaneswar Development Authority (BDA) and shopping malls, big commercial establishment and corporate houses.

The BMC has also said no traders or vendors would be allowed to sit at the daily markets if he or she had a cough or fever.

Title: Dhoni’s India comeback looks difficult: Sehwag
Content: Ahmedabad: India’s former opener Virender Sehwag feels that former India skipper Mahendra Sigh Dhoni’s comeback into the Indian fold looks very difficult. The selectors have already moved forward and found replacements for Dhoni, he said.“Who will he replace? With the likes of Rishab Pant and KL Rahul already in form, especially the latter performing exceptionally well of late, I think there is no reason why should we not stick with them,’’ said the 41-year-old, who was in the city to inaugurate a sportswear store on Tuesday.On India’s dismal run in New Zealand, especially in the one-dayers and the Test series, the swashbuckling opener said the Kiwis played better than us after losing the T20I series. “We must admit that the Kiwis were superior to us in the ODIs and Tests. In the T20s, Kiwis lost close matches and in the shortest format it is always difficult to make a quick comeback,’’ he said.On Indian captain Virat Kohli’s poor form in recent times, Sehwag said Virat’s form has dipped.“He is a class batsman but that has happened to all the great batsmen in different eras be it Sachin Tendulkar, Steven Waugh, Jaques Kallis or Ricky Ponting,’’ said Sehwag.And who are the favourites for the T20 World Cup in Australia later this year? “I think in T20, one cannot predict favourites. Such is the unpredictable nature of the format, any single player can change the complexion of the game on a given day,’’ he said.“The return of Hardik Pandya will make a huge difference to the Indian team. The whole combination will change with an all-rounder of the caliber of Hardik,’’ he said.With the recent rise of teams from Gujarat in the Ranji Trophy, Sehwag said most of the traditional powerhouses were going through a transition period. However sides like Saurashtra, Gujarat and Bengal have their key players available throughout the Ranji season and as a result they are more consistent and able to play better than others. For example, Delhi miss players of the stature of Virat Kohli, Shikhar Dhawan, Rishab Pant and Ishant Sharma, who are mostly on national duty and are unavailable for their side in domestic competitions. Whenever top players have played the domestic season for Delhi, the team has at least reached the semifinals.’’Sehwag has fond memories of Ahmedabad where he slammed the last century of his Test career at the Sardar Patel Stadium at Motera. “I vividly remember my last Test century against Alistair Cook-led England at Motera. That memory is very special to me,’’ he concluded.

Title: Decks cleared for Ring Road
Content:
Jaipur: The long-pending land acquisition work to construct cloverleaf structure at Agra Road under the 47-km Ring Road project will begin soon as the state government cleared the proposal to provide compensation to the affected landowners.

In absence of cloverleaf structure, which ensures the connectivity to the highway and the transport corridor of Ring Road, the project remained non-operational even after its inauguration.

At Agra Road, the work was stalled as the JDA had to acquire 3,200 square metre land from a petrol pump that is obstructing the construction of the structure. After receiving the directions from the state government, the JDA will now provide land in Chitrakoot Nagar sector-4 as compensation.

An official said, “We have identified 1,100 sq metre land which will be allotted to the affected owner. The proposal was sent to the state government as JDA at its level cannot decide if compensation is provided in other zone,” he said.

The project is two years late as JDA failed to acquire land till date. A senior JDA official said, “After signing a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with National Highway Authority of India (NHAI), the JDA was liable to provide 26 hectare land for flyover construction by August 2018. However, the acquisition process was pending after many hurdles emerged.”

According to sources, the NHAI will spend Rs 238 crore to construct cloverleaf and flyovers. The JDA has earlier proposed an overbridge to cross Tonk Road. Similarly, construction of cloverleaf interchanges was proposed on Agra and Ajmer roads.

“The land at other places has already been acquired. The final hurdle was cleared,” said source.

The JDA on June 19, 2018 signed a supplementary memorandum of understanding (MoU) with NHAI, after it agreed to provide Rs 200 crore in advance to acquire 26 hectares of land. The funds were transferred in JDA’s account to acquire land for the construction of cloverleaf and flyovers under the 47-km Ring Road project. As per the contract condition, the JDA had to acquire land within one month and provide it to NHAI. However, the civic body failed to adhere to the condition as it took over one-and-a-half years.

Title: Team tracing contacts of Indonesian group in Karimnagar
Content: Hyderabad: A Corona Rapid Response Team has been activated in Karimnagar district to find out people who came in contact with a 10-member group from Indonesia. District collector, Shashanka, who held a meeting with the Corona Rapid Response Team on Tuesday, told TOI that it was being ascertained where all the Indonesian nationals went, and that officials were following all necessary protocols. “The group had come for a religious programme,” Shashanka said.According to sources, the Indonesian group came for what is called an ‘ijtema’, and had stayed at a local madrassa after their arrival on March 14. They approached the police the following morning to register their presence in the district as required by law. The police then asked them to get medical certificates, and they reportedly went to a local hospital on March 15. Shashanka said a medical check-up was done at the local government hospital, and it was noticed that one of them had coronavirus symptoms. “We shifted them to Gandhi hospital immediately,” he said.Karimnagar town ACP, Ashok Kumar, said the mosque where the Indonesians had stayed has been identified. From there, they travelled by train to Ramagundam. At the Karimnagar local government hospital, authorities had a tough time restricting the Indonesians as they reportedly tried to leave the premises to avoid being shifted to isolation.The hospital authorities informed the district health officials, who in turn sought the help of the police to restrict them, and sent them in a 108 ambulance to Secunderabad. District authorities in Karimnagar are now engaged in identifying everyone with whom the Indonesians had met or come in contact with. The contacts are being brought to the local hospital for a medical check up.

Title: All elective surgeries put on hold till March 25
Content: Hyderabad: The Telangana government on Tuesday said that elective surgeries in all teaching and speciality hospitals under the aegis of director of medical education (DME) would be stopped till March 25.Chief secretary Somesh Kumar and special chief secretary A Shanti Kumari, who held a meeting on coronavirus preparedness and preventive measures, said except emergency surgeries, other surgeries would not be performed.“Regular out-patient services, emergency surgeries and emergency services will continue as usual. Superintendents of hospitals have been asked to implement the orders immediately,” a circular issued by the government said.The chief secretary, who held a video-conference with district collectors on Monday, asked them to strictly implement the instructions issued by chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao to contain the spread of the virus.Somesh also directed the district collectors to constitute an inter-disciplinary team to monitor those who arrive from foreign travel . “Quarantine is mandatory for all those who come back from China, South Korea, Iran, Italy, Spain, Germany and France. It should be strictly adhered to. The person and his contacts are to be tracked constantly as part of the containment plan,” the chief secretary said.He said the situation must be dealt with in a professional manner so that general public don’t panic. The move to stop surgeries comes close on the heels of shutting down educational institutions, pubs, film theatres and function halls.

Title: Rama-Sita celestial wedding sans masses
Content: Hyderabad: The coronavirus scare has hit the famed Bhadrachalam temple also. In a first, devotees are set to miss an opportunity to watch the celestial wedding of Lord Rama and Sita at the Sita Ramachandra Swamy temple in Bhadradri on April 2 on the occasion of Srirama Navami. The move comes close on the heels of temple boards of Tirumala, Srikalahasthi and Annavaram taking steps to restrict the influx of pilgrims and cancelling some sevas and rituals in wake of the coronavirus pandemic.Speaking to mediapersons, transport minister Puvvada Ajay Kumar said the government had taken a decision to restrict participation of pilgrims in Bhadradri. “We are appealing to people to not come to Bhadradri to attend the festivities. Priests will perform the wedding which is telecast live,” Ajay Kumar saidNormally, over 20,000 devotees gather at the temple to witness the celestial wedding. Devotees from both Telugu states and nearby states flock to the temple during the occasion. Chief minister presents the silk robes to the deities on behalf of the state government. The temple authorities have already stopped the sale of the wedding ceremony tickets. Officials said money would be returned to those who had already purchased their tickets.

Title: Two test negative for Covid-19 infection
Content:
Rajkot: Two patients admitted in Rajkot Civil Hospital and a private hospital tested negative for nCOVID-19 infection even as the district administration has started surveillance of close contacts of people who returned from abroad in the last two-and-a-half months.

According to health department sources, officials will visit relatives of patients who were under observation for 14 days for acute respiration symptoms.

Nearly 290 people came to Rajkot from foreign countries in last two-and-a-half months and medical history of nearly 700 people will be checked.

Meanwhile, the railways has suspended operation of Jamnagar-Bandra Humsafar Express upto March 31 in wake of rising number of cases in Maharashtra.

Title: CMRS begins safety check for underground Metro Phase-IB
Content:
Jaipur: The acid test for Jaipur Metro Phase-IB begun on Tuesday with the commissioner of Metro Railway Safety (CMRS), R K Sharma, launching his two-day mandatory safety inspection before the corridor is thrown open to public.

During the inspection, the CMRS checked signalling, fire fighting system and civil structure designs on the ground. According to sources, the JMRC has constructed a 1.5km tunnel inside the Walled City area, a 905.2-metre tunnel between Chandpole and Chhoti Chaupar and a 620.8-metre tunnel between Chhoti Chaupar and Badi Chaupar.

The internal diameter of the tunnels is 5.8 metres. An official source said, “Before giving a nod to commercial operations, the CMRS checked emergency exit plans, electrical, signalling and train control, civil works, stations and traction system.”

In case of an emergency in the 2.349-km underground Metro corridor, the JMRC has constructed mini-tunnels connecting the twin tunnels for commuters to exit if there is a fire or train breakdown.

An official explained that these are termed as cross-passages. The JMRC has constructed five cross-passages which are smaller in diameter and connect the two tunnels through which people can pass. They are provided to serve two primary purposes – emergency escape and maintenance work. These cross-passages are built as per the NFPA (National Fire Precaution Association, USA) 130, 2014 guidelines. Out of the total project cost of Rs 1,126 crore, Rs 969 crore has been provided by the Asian Development Bank (ADB).

Title: Two arrested for selling masks at a premium
Content:
Kolkata: The Enforcement Branch (EB) of Kolkata Police on Monday evening detained two persons for selling masks on the open pavement in the Burrabazar area for Rs 100-Rs 150. Cops said several young men were selling “basic one-time usable masks” that costs between Rs 20-50 for triple its costs, claiming them to be of the N-95 variety.

“These people were selling these masks barely 100m-300m from Bagri Market and Mehta Building. When we caught one of them red-handed, he took us to a trader at Mehta Building. In the absence of any document, we could not link the two. Later, we came to know that several manufacturers, without any experience in preparing masks and with no quality control, were trying to take advantage of the demand-supply gap,” said a police officer.

The EB carried out raids across the city even on Tuesday. “We are receiving inputs of masks being sold at a premium . Several chemicals are being passed off as sanitizers,” added the officer. “We are visiting even the smallest markets. We are trying to ensure customers get at least some masks and sanitizers,” said DC (EB) Biswajit Ghosh.

Title: Pilot slams BJP’s charges against Venugopal
Content:
Jaipur: Deputy chief minister and PCC president Sachin Pilot on Tuesday strongly condemned the false charges against AICC organization secretary and party Rajya Sabha candidate from Rajasthan K C Venugopal. BJP state president Satish Poonia on Monday alleged that Venugopal had rape charges against him.

Alleging that BJP had the habit of making false allegations, Pilot said the charges BJP was levelling was part of the conspiracy to dislodge the UDF government against 22 Congress leaders and officials including chief minister Omman Chandy.

The charges were levelled against the leaders to get political mileage. He said the charges were levelled in 2011 and 2012 and the CPM government had field an FIR in 2018. But in the absence of evidence, nothing could be established. The then UDF government had also set up a judicial commission which submitted its report saying that it had not received any complaint from any quarters.

Title: The Whitefield entrepreneur multiplying B-school chances
Content:
Shubhi.Mehrotra@timesgroup.com

Bengaluru: A robust resume, exhaustive essays , letters of recommendation and a nerve-wracking interview — it takes more than just perfect scores for MBA aspirants to make a mark on admission committees of foreign universities. A city-based entrepreneur makes it easier.

For eight years, Whitefield resident Namita Garg, 43, has been mentoring business school aspirants through her admissions consulting firm, MBA Decoder. She and her team of three senior consultants handhold candidates through the challenging application process , one step at a time. “B-school applications are highly competitive. For instance, European B-school INSEAD is a melting pot with students from 90 nationalities,” Namita says.

She adds: “Committees look for applicants with leadership skills. Therefore, candidates must demonstrate their ability to take initiatives, drive people, manage stakeholders and make tangible impact to their organisations. While aspirants understand this, it’s difficult to coherently translate it on paper. This is where we come into the picture.” Her clients are professionals with 2-15 years of work experience, who wish to pursue MBA to advance their careers or change track.

“We begin by coaching them to think like leaders. Most applicants have a sketchy understanding of what leadership is. We make them aware of their strengths and weaknesses. We help convey it on paper by strategically telling their life stories through a resume, essays, letters of recommendation and interview. The process is highly introspective as applicants need to comb through their entire lives. They end up discovering themselves and we end up learning a lot from the gritty, driven achievers,” elaborates Namita.

A mother of two with experience in marketing and client servicing, she was bitten by the entrepreneurial bug in 2011 when she wanted to begin a new professional innings. “I had taken long leave from work between late 2005 and 2007 to bring up my daughters. We were in the US and my husband decided to pursue an MBA. Since I wasn’t employed, I offered to help him with the application. I read voraciously on the subject and became his best critic,” she says. “We moved across continents when my husband joined London Business School in 2007. His roommate connected me to the consulting firm he had approached. I worked with them but felt they lacked a personalised approach while dealing with candidates. However, the exposure kindled my interest in the field.”

In 2010, they relocated to India and that’s her new plans began to take shape. “Having seen the average quality of services provided to Indian aspirants, I decided to venture into the space,” she recalls.

But is it a niche area? “In the US, it’s very common to approach admission consultants. In India, applicants are slowly warming up to it, thanks to the vast pool of information available online. I’ve been lucky in getting clients through word of mouth. However, I don’t believe in the numbers game and work with a few applicants every year but in an intensely collaborative way,” Namita says. Pointing out that it can get taxing during application season, she adds: “Thankfully, I don’t have to negotiate Bengaluru’s crippling traffic as I work from home. But my biggest challenge is to stay relevant. I don’t advertise on online platforms, so I am constantly present on MBA admission forums advising applicants pro-bono. It gives me the satisfaction of sharing my knowledge built over 10 years. Secondly, my work is very labour intensive so scaling up can be an issue as I’m quite wary of hiring people.”

She believes an entrepreneur’s journey is marked by ups and downs. “Start a business only if you really believe in your idea and feel it can help users benefit. Only this belief can keep you going in moments of distress,” she advises.

Title: Saudi returnee from Nzb taken to Gandhi
Content: Hyderabad: A Nizamabad man who has been unwell after his return from Saudi Arabia recently has been shifted to Gandhi Hospital. Nizamabad district medical and health officer Sudarshanam told TOI that the 40-year-old had gone to a private hospital complaining of fever. When the fever did not subside, he was referred to a bigger hospital where he was admitted for a day.“Since the fever did not come down, the hospital sent him to Gandhi Hospital on Monday night for further investigations,” Sudarshanam said.It was only four days ago that he developed cough and fever. The man from Morthad village had returned from Saudi Arabia 10 days ago. At Gandhi, tests would be conducted to check for coronavirus and if it is positive, another confirmatory test will be done in Pune. The man was screened at Rajiv Gandhi International Airport upon arrival but was not running a temperature then.Meanwhile, district health officials have written to all private hospitals and Indian Medical Association (IMA) that any suspicious case should be reported to the authorities concerned.

Title: Covid-19 is Telangana’s overriding concern
Content: HYDERABAD: Amid growing concerns over spread of coronavirus, doctors at several government hospitals are demanding a cap on the number of outpatients (OP). In this regard, hospitals are considering sending text messages to patients, whose contacts are available on the database, to not visit the hospital unless it is absolutely urgent. Hospitals are also arranging for tele-consultations.“Crowded elective OPD (out patient departments) in all hospitals should be shut down and only emergencies should be attended. I request the director of medical education to ensure that only emergencies come to hospitals,” said resident medical officer at the government ENT Hospital in Koti, Dr Manish Gupta. The ENT Hospital, in recent days, has seen a spike in number of outpatients with the numbers increasing each day, according to hospital sources.While the ENT Hospital has seen a spike, the patient flow at Gandhi Hospital — the nodal centre for treating positive coronavirus cases — has seen a sharp decline in OP since the first positive case was reported in the state. On Tuesday, only 450 patients had visited the hospital as compared to the daily average of over 2,000 patients.“Hospitals should SMS patients to not visit the hospital with fever and cough, unless it is absolutely urgent. Arrangements should be made by hospital for tele-consultation to determine whether such patients should visit the hospital. All patients with cough and fever should be provided a surgical mask at the reception and should get priority,” said president of Association of Surgeons of India, Dr P Raghu Ram.Speaking about the challenge that lies ahead for hospitals and doctors, Indian Medical Association (IMA), Telangana general secretary Dr Sanjeev Singh Yadav said that a move to restrict the number of patients is an ideal one.“From the hospitals point of view, it is good to restrict patients (from) coming and getting affected...While routine things need to be deferred, a patient has to be seen by a doctor to ascertain whether or not it is an emergency. For instance, an unwanted ultrasound should be deferred but a pregnant woman needs to be checked. Patients should first go to a local clinic or doctor to get an assessment and if suggested, go to a bigger hospital,” Dr Yadav said.

Title: Govt: CAA not an answer to all religious persecution in world
Content:
NEW DELHI: The Centre on Tuesday responded to petitions challenging the constitutional validity of the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) in the Supreme Court, asserting that it was a narrowly tailored law addressing problems in grant of citizenship to some communities persecuted on the basis of religion in neighbouring Islamic countries and assured it did not impact citizenship of Indians.

Countering the allegation that CAA was discriminatory as it did not consider grant of citizenship to persecuted minority communities like Ahmadis, Shias, Bahaiis, Hazaras, Jews and Balochs, the Centre said, “CAA does not seek to recognise or seek to provide answers to all kinds of purported persecution that may be taking place across the world or that may have taken place previously anywhere in the world. CAA is a narrowly tailored legislation seeking to address the specific problem which awaited India’s attention for a solution since several decades.”

Its 129-page affidavit termed CAA as a benign piece of legislation which seeks to provide a relaxation, in the nature of an amnesty, to specific communities from specified countries with a clear cut-off date. Terming its bulky affidavit as a “preliminary reply”, the Centre said CAA’s key mode of classification was identification of six communities — Hindus, Buddhists, Sikhs, Jains, Parsis and Christians — to provide them a limited exemption under the CAA.

The Centre's affdiavit in the Supreme Court said Afghanistan, Pakistan and Bangladesh had Islam as state religion with “acknowledged religious persecution”.

“History clearly depicts that persecuted minorities in the said three countries were left without any rights and the said historical injustice is sought to be remedied by the amendment without taking away or whittling down the right of any other person,” the Centre said. It added, “CAA does not impinge upon any existing right that may have existed prior to enactment of the amendment and further, in no manner whatsoever seeks to affect the legal, democratic or secular rights of any Indian citizen.”

It said the existing regime for obtaining Indian citizenship remained untouched by CAA and “legal migration, on the basis of valid documents and visa, continues to be permissible from all countries of the world, including Afghanistan, Pakistan and Bangladesh”.

“All foreigners, irrespective of their religion and living in these three countries or any other country, can legally migrate to India subject to fulfilment of conditions mentioned in the Citizenship Act, 1955, apply for and get Indian citizenship if found eligible,” the Centre said.

Referring to scores of pleas filed by politicians, rights activists and even state governments to challenge the CAA, the Centre said it amounted to misuse of PIL instrument created by the SC for benefit of poor and downtrodden who have no voice or access to court. “Matters concerning the sovereign plenary power of Parliament, especially in regard to citizenship and the contours thereof, cannot be questioned before the SC by way of a public interest petition,” it said.

“The cardinal principle of locus standi has been diluted by this (PIL) jurisprudence evolved by the SC only in limited fact situations which cannot be extrapolated to include the present constitutional challenge to the legislative measure of the Indian Parliament in the domain of issues concerning citizenship/immigration,” it added.

On the petitioners’ reference to alleged violation of international covenants, and the purported move by the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights seeking to be amicus in the SC, the Centre said, “India is neither a signatory nor has ratified the 1951 Refugee Convention or the 1967 Protocol on Territorial Asylum .”

“The fundamental rights provisions of the Constitution, in the context of this case Articles 14 and 21, cannot be interpreted with reference to any international convention or treaty to which India is neither a signatory not it has ratified the same.” the Centre said. Assertion of petitioners that the principle of non-refoulement (non return of refugees) is a part of customary international law is erroneous in law.

“The principle of non-refoulement cannot be derived from the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights.”

Title: Gujarat HC nod to sale of shops by Hindus to Muslims in disturbed area
Content:
AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court has granted permission to sale of shops by Hindus to Muslims in a Vadodara area, where the state government has imposed the Disturbed Areas Act. The HC said that the authorities do not have to verify except the free will of the seller and fair price of the property, that it is not a distress sale and without fear.

In this case, the authorities denied permission for sale of the properties by Hindus to Muslims on consideration that it would reduce the strength of Hindu traders in the area. This happened after the initiation of a police inquiry whether law and order would be disturbed if Muslims purchase properties in the area, which falls under the Gujarat Prohibition of Transfer of Immovable Property and Provisions of Tenants from Eviction from Premises in Disturbed Areas Act, 1991, which requires prior permission for sale/purchase of properties involving people belonging to different faiths.

The high court has quashed the orders by Vadodara deputy collector and the secretary denying permission to sale/purchase of properties by two brothers Dinesh and Deepakbhai Modi to Muslim traders Onali Dholkawala and Iqbal Tinwala . In 2016, they went to register the sale deed, but realizing that it is Disturbed Area, they applied for permission from deputy collector.

The deputy collector ordered Vadodara police commissioner to probe whether the sale is with free consent; there is a likelihood of law and order problem; the sale is likely to affect the balance in the majority Hindu/minority Muslim strength; and to affect the neighbourhood.

The police reported that purchase of shops by Muslims from Hindus will disturb the balance between the communities’ trade strength. On the basis of this report, the authorities – the deputy collector and then the secretary – denied permission for sale.

The Muslim purchasers approached the HC, which observed that the invocation of Disturbed Areas Act may be with a view to bringing order, but the prime question of adjudication for authorities in sale/purchase of properties is to ascertain whether it is not a distress sale, and that the transaction is bona fide and free-willed. “The object to get into such sale consideration is not to see whether it would create a law and order problem…” the court said and termed the inquiry against the law.

Title: Tractor driven by Bundi man overturns, 2 sons killed
Content:
Kota: Two minor brothers were killed after the tractor-trolley driven by their father overturned on Bordamal bypass under Kapren police station of Bundi district on Tuesday morning.

The police have lodged a case of negligent driving against the man and handed over the two bodies to family members after post-mortem on Tuesday morning.

The two deceased were identified as Shyam Banjara (9) and Ganesh Banjara (4) of Kapren town.

The mishap occurred around 8.30am on Tuesday morning when the driver lost control over the steering causing the tractor-trolley to overturn on Bordamal bypass.

“The two minor brothers travelling in the trolley were buried under it,” said Budhi Prakesh Nama, SHO, Kapren police station.

The siblings were killed on the spot, he added.

Their father, identified as Faitah Singh Banjara,, was booked for negligent driving, he added.

Title: 150 Gujarat students stranded near Manila
Content:
Saytayjeetsinh Rana

RAJKOT: Close to 150 students from Gujarat are stranded in a city near Philippines capital Manila after the government of India suspended flights to several coronavirus-hit countries including those in Southeast Asia.

The Philippines is the one of the worst-affected countries by Covid-19 and President Rodrigo Duterte has declared a state of calamity for a period of six months after 12 deaths and nearly 142 positive cases.

According to Indians residing there, the government has shut down Manila and its surrounding cities since March 12. The country gave 72 hours starting Monday evening local time to foreign citizens to leave the country.

Saytayjeetsinh Rana, a native of Surendranagar, who is stranded there told TOI over phone, “We are stranded as flights to Malaysia and Singapore , which are the most preferred route to fly to India, have been suspended. Some students who left are stuck in Malaysia. We have approached Indian embassy and requested for evacuation, but there has been no response yet.”

Limited food stock with stranded students

Milind Patel, a student from Godhra , said, “There are nearly 150 Gujarati students in our college. We are very scared due to the spreading epidemic. We are vegetarians and the food stock is also limited.”

Milind and Rana are MBBS students at University of Perpetual Help System DALTA in the City of Las Piñas, roughly 27 km from Manila. The duo live in a rented apartment with four other students.

Rana’s father Girirajsinh told TOI, “Initially, our children did not tell us the seriousness of the situation as they didn’t want us to worry. They were trying to return but when all the options were closed, they informed us today noon. I am contacting other parents after which we will approach the government for help.”

Students said that the city has been locked down and curfew declared during the night time. The educational institutes are shut till April 12 and this may be extended too.

Some students are also facing visa extension problems as they have to renew it every year.

Title: Naroda factory fire: 'Culpable homicide charge not tenable’
Content:
Seven employees lost their lives in Narol factory fire on February 8.

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court on Tuesday observed that the fire officer’s charge of culpable homicide not amounting to murder and the SC/ST atrocity against the owners of Chiripal Industries are not tenable for the factory fire in Narol , which resulted in death of seven employees on February 8.

After the shirting section in Nandan Denim Company caught fire and seven employees including one belonging to the Scheduled Caste were killed, the father-son duo – Jyotiprasad Chiripal and Deepak Chiripal — along with employees of the company were booked under section 304 of the IPC and the SC/ST Atrocity Act. The duo challenged the invocation of these charges and the FIR itself.

After preliminary hearing, Justice S H Vora stayed arrest of both the accused and observed that there did not appear any intention on part of the accused to cause accident to kill the employees. The court issued notice to the government, which has accused them of not making provisions of any escape for employees despite recurrence of fire incidents in the industrial units, and sought reply by September. The investigation will continue and the accused will be cooperating with it meanwhile, the HC said.

In his order, Justice Vora said, “Here is a case, where there is neither allegation as to guilty intention nor guilty knowledge on the part of the applicants.

The invocation of Section 304 of the Indian Penal Code r/w section 3(2)(v) of the SC/ST Act on the face of the FIR even if taken at its face value and then accepted it in entirety, do not prima facie disclose commission of offence either u/s 304 of the Indian Penal Code r/w section 3(2)(v) of the SC/ST Act. So, in view of overall facts of the case leading to filing of the impugned FIR, present application deserves consideration.”

Title: Lonely in time of corona: Elders fear further isolation
Content: NEW DELHI: Mohammad Zakir had to cancel his annual trip to his native town just two days before the scheduled departure. The 72-year-old, a resident of Janakpuri, retired over a decade ago and settled with his children in Delhi. But every year, he goes back to his hometown for a fortnight.“My children insisted that I drop that plan this time. They also convinced me to stay at home and I am not even going out for the Friday prayers. But I know it’s important to be safe right now. Prevention is the key,” Zakir told TOI.The most vulnerable demographic group — those aged 70 and above — is also facing piercing emotional challenges in the times of Covid-19. Cancelled plans and indefinite stay on social activities have resulted in a heightened sense of anxiety and fear of further isolation among the elderly.Several old-age homes, NGOs and collectives are stepping up their efforts to raise awareness among the elderly about the pandemic. Himanshu Rath, Founder Agewell Foundation, which has been working with senior citizens since 1999, told TOI that the not-for-profit organisation has been crowdsourcing face masks and distributing it to the elderly.“We have distributed over 1,300 masks so far, but plan to give out over 5,000. We know masks are just symbolic, but for those who can’t afford them, they offer a psychological comfort. The biggest problem right now is that people living alone are extremely disturbed. They keep asking us what would happen to them if they contract the virus,” Rath said.The number of calls on Agewell’s helpline has also doubled. “We used to get at least 50 calls every day. But yesterday, there were more than 100 calls, with most callers seeking information on the symptoms and cure,” he said.Hena Faqurudheen, a mental health professional who works with the elderly and specialises in geriatric mental health, said there was “heightened anxiety”. She said: “A lot of the elderly patients’ children are abroad. So, there is already some level of loneliness that they are coping with. Most of them depend on emergency support and social support network groups to deal with their feelings. But with the fear of the virus, these gatherings have also taken a hit. And now, the elders don’t have anyone to talk to.”Mathew Cherian, CEO of Helpage India, another NGO that works with the elderly, pointed out the complete absence of outlets where the elderly can speak of their fears.“We have told people to stay inside their homes and not go out unnecessarily. But we deal with people who belong to the lowest socio-economic category. They do not even have the money to buy daily essentials. So, they can’t stock up on food items or vegetables,” he said. Cherian added that the elderly population was going through a lot of “trauma” because of Covid-19.The NGO, which runs shelter homes, has started awareness programmes where it educates the elderly on the symptoms of Covid-19. They have also issued an advisory to the authorities to keep people in isolation in case they display any symptoms related to the virus.JR Gupta, chair of the confederation of senior citizens’ associations of Delhi, an umbrella body of 18 lakh elderly people, told TOI that their main philosophy right now is “prevention is better than cure”.He said: “We are raising awareness and conducting programmes to assure people that they are not alone. Though the elderly population is more vulnerable to the virus, we can minimise the damage by avoiding crowds and public places,”he said.

Title: Pvt schools close till March 31, teaching shifts online
Content: Visakhapatnam: With the Centre advising closure of all educational establishments to curb the spread of coronavirus , most private schools in the city voluntarily closed down from Tuesday while other private schools will be shut from Wednesday to March 31.While a few schools have started online classes and deferred examinations, others have cancelled scheduled examinations.Subha Dalai, principal of Ralla Bella School, said, “The school examinations which were going on have been cancelled because we wanted to keep children isolated. The results will be declared based on the aggregate of previous examinations and current class performance. Meanwhile, the books for the new academic year have been made available on the school premises. Since we plan to begin the new academic year next month, children can go through their books.”“The teachers are working from home and the parent-teacher interactions are being done over phone,” added Dalai.Stating that holidays were declared from Tuesday, Elizabeth Prasad, a senior teacher at Bethany School, said, “The children have been asked to stay at home till March 31. However, the ICSE board examinations are being conducted and all the required precautionary measures are being taken.”Government schools, however, are waiting for instructions from the state government. Although precautionary measures such as maintaining cleanliness and encouraging students to wash hands frequently are being followed, school authorities are of the opinion that it is advisable to close schools, as in other states.A teacher from Queen Mary school said, “Since most of the children are from slum areas, there is very little awareness among parents on the severity of coronavirus. We are worried about children as they sit close together in the classrooms. We hope the government gives orders on closure of schools.”Speaking to TOI, Visakhapatnam district educational officer (DEO) B Lingeswara Reddy said, “We have not received any orders from the state government regarding the closure of schools. As a precautionary measure, all schools have been asked to organise awareness sessions for teachers and students. Students have been advised to maintain personal hygiene and to consult the doctor if they have any flu-like symptoms.”

Title: Naravane to visit isolation centre at military station
Content:
Jaisalmer: The Chief of Army Staff General Manoj Mukund Naravane reached Jaisalmer on Tuesday for a two-day visit of Gujarat-Rajasthan border. He reached the military station by helicopter where he was welcomed by Battle Axe Division GoC Maj Gen Rakesh Kapoor.

He held a meeting with the Army officers at the military station and took stock of operational readiness.

On Wednesday, Naravane will go to the Tanot area and take stock of the security arrangements.

He will also visit the wellness and isolation centre at the military station and oversee the facilities provided to 289 Indian passengers from Iran quarantined here. He will return to Delhi thereafter. tnn

Title: Rajasthan: 52-yr-old man kills wife, ends life over suspected affair
Content:
Representative image.

UDAIPUR: A 52-year old man strangulated his wife to death in Sector 14 and later committed suicide by hanging himself at his rented house under Goverdhan Vilas police station area.

Sunil Soni killed Suman (38) on Monday night suspecting her of having an extramarital affair. Thereafter, he hanged himself, police said.

Police found a suicide note scribbled on one of the walls in which Sunil held one Uma Shanker alias Senti Banna responsible for their deaths.

“Uma Shankar lives in the same locality and is known to the couple. We will investigate his role in the case. Prima facie, Sunil doubted his wife so much that he didn’t like her stepping out of the house or speaking to anyone,” said Chena Ram, SHO, Goverdhan Vilas police station.

The house owner spotted the bodies on Tuesday morning.

Sunil hailed from Ajmer and undertook painting jobs for a livelihood while Suman worked as a cook in an ashram, sources said.

The couple was living in the house for 4-5 years. They didn’t have any children and quarrelled frequently. A few weeks ago, they had filed complaints against each other at the mahila thana but later withdrew them.

There were strangulation marks on the woman’s neck, police said, adding that broken pieces of bangles were recovered from the bed where the body was found. The bodies have been sent for a post-mortem, the officer said.

Title: Missed deadline: Gujarat high court junks candidate’s NEET request
Content:
Gujarat high court (File photo)

AHMEDABAD: The Gujarat high court has refused to intervene in the schedule of National Eligibility-cum-Entrance Test (NEET) for UG, 2020 after a student pursuing medical studies abroad missed deadline to apply.

Khushi Shah from Surat approached the HC and requested for permission to sit in the NEET exam that is scheduled on May 3. She sought HC directions to the National Testing Agency because she missed the deadline for online registration. She told the court that she is studying medicine in Georgia at present. Therefore, she was not aware of the NEET schedule and missed registration in time.

Shah told the court that the deadline for online registration was postponed on various occasions from December 31, 2019 to February 9, 2020. She missed the step-1 deadline. Though the window was open for correction, she could not register herself.

The central government vehemently opposed the student’s petition and submitted that a public notice was issued announcing NEET schedule. Moreover, the apex court has ordered to strictly adhere the timeline of medical exams and admissions.

After hearing the case, the HC said, “On one hand, the authorities are bound to follow the time schedule, on the other, the students are also duty bound to abide by the dates prescribed so as to ensure that the entire process is not delayed.”

It further said though the court has all consideration towards the student who missed online registration by a whisker, considering the enormity of the task assigned to the National Testing Agency wherein about 16 lakh candidates have registered for NEET 2020 examination, “it will not be in the fitness of things to grant the prayer as sought for in the present petition”.

Title: Awareness progs at KGH, dist court
Content:
Visakhapatnam: Coronavirus sensitisation programmes were held at King George Hospital ( KGH ) and the district court on Tuesday.

At KGH, superintendent Dr G Arjuna organised and led the awareness programme with house surgeons, nurses, sanitation staff and data entry operators at the surgery gallery hall in the department of general surgery. Dr Arjuna emphasised the need to take precautions against Covid-19 and the importance of washing one’s hands regularly.

Nodal officer for Covid-19 in KGH, Dr S Lakshmi Sowjanya and assistant professor of community medicine, Dr D Yarrayya were present at the event.

At the district court, training officer and epidemiologist MVV Muralimohan addressed advocates, officials and judges. DMHO Dr S Tirupathi Rao distributed masks. President of Vizag Bar Association GM Reddy, district judge BS Bhanumati and president of Forum of Legal Professionals Kuppili Muralidhar attended the programme.

The district court on Tuesday was deserted following a circular from the high court that directed that for two weeks only urgent matters be heard.

Title: Puri king, IAS officer set example with self-isolation
Content: BHUBANESWAR: Puri ‘king’ Gajapati Dibyasingha Deb and senior IAS officer Vineel Krishna on Tuesday began 14-day home isolation following their return from abroad.The duo were among the 1,239 foreign returnees who registered themselves on the government portal (https://covid19.odisha.gov.in). Everyone who has arrived in Odisha from abroad on or since March 4 has to register themselves on the site. While Deb and Krishna confirmed that their 14-day home quarantine began on Tuesday, there is no confirmation about that of others who registered themselves on the portal.“Two of my family members and I attended several programmes at the different Jagannath temples in the US in the past one month. We travelled to the US on February 12 and returned on March 15. As law-abiding citizens, we immediately registered ourselves with the state government’s Covid-19 registration portal. By Lord Jagannath’s grace, we are fine and have no coronavirus-related symptoms,” the Puri ‘king’ said.Deb, who is chairman of Puri Jagannath temple managing panel and revered as the first servitor of Lord Jagannath, said his family and he were staying put in their residence in Saheed Nagar in Bhubaneswar.“I appeal to everyone who arrived in Odisha from abroad after March 4 to register themselves on the government portal and remain in home isolation for 14 days,” he said.Chief minister Naveen Patnaik appreciated Deb’s move. “Thank you Shree Gajapati Maharaja ji and family members for self-registering on online portal https://covid19.odisha.gov.in after return from the US. Appeal everyone coming from abroad to self-register and help us in tracking & monitoring to control #Covid19 situation in #Odisha,” he tweeted.Krishna, who is director of state sports and youth services department, released a video message in which he announced his home quarantine. “I have remained under home quarantine after coming across the government’s advisory. Though I do not show any Covid-19 symptoms after returning from abroad, I registered myself on the portal,” Krishna said. Though he did not share details of his trip abroad, sources said he had toured Toronto and Chicago.Senior BJD leader and deputy chairman of state planning board Sanjay Dasburma's son Achin, who returned from London on Sunday, also remained in home isolation. Achin pursues business management in a university in London.

Title: Covid-19 in Surat: Passengers arriving from Sharjah to undergo compulsory quarantine for 14 days
Content: SURAT: Surat Municipal Corporation ’s ( SMC ) health department has started preparations for compulsory quarantine of passengers arriving from Sharjah at Surat airport to check the spread of Covid-19 in the Diamond City on Tuesday.The civic body has set up a 1,000-bed quarantine facility at Samras hostel of Veer Narmad South Gujarat University (VNSGU) where passengers from Sharjah will be kept. The decision was taken on the basis of travel advisory issued by central government’s health ministry for compulsory quarantine for a minimum period of 14 days for passengers arriving in the country from UAE, Oman, Qatar and Kuwait from March 18.Dr Ashish Naik, deputy municipal commissioner (health and hospital), told TOI, “We have created a 1,000-bed quarantine facility at VNSGU’s Samras hostel for compulsory quarantine of passengers arriving from Sharjah at Surat airport. They will be kept under observation for 14 days and this exercise for Sharjah passengers will go on till March 31.”Surat airport has a lone international flight between Surat and Sharjah operated by Air India Express. The flight is operated four days a week and an average of 100 passengers arrive in each flight.About 647 passengers have undergone thermal screening at the airport and not a single suspected coronavirus case has been detected since March 4. SMC has deputed medical staff of five people, including two doctors, for screening passengers arriving from Sharjah.

Title: Gogoi’s nomination will erode people’s faith in judiciairy, says CM Gehlot
Content: Chief minister Ashok Gehlot on Tuesday said the nomination of former Chief Justice of India Ranjan Gogoi to Rajya Sabha will erode people's trust in judicial system and cast a doubt upon fairness of his judgements. “Nomination of former CJI Ranjan Gogoi as a Rajya Sabha member by NDA, soon after his retirement is very surprising,” Gehlot tweeted. “It shows NDA is hell bent on destroying independence of every institution and as Justice (retired) Madan B Lokur said, it redefines the independence, impartiality and integrity of the judiciary. This will erode people's trust in judicial system and cast a doubt upon fairness of judgements delivered,” he said.

Title: No special darshan at Simhachalam
Content: Visakhapatnam: Authorities at the Simhachalam temple have decided to cancel certain rituals.Around 10,000 devotees visit the temple every day. The number of visitors have dropped to between 5,000 to 6,000, said temple authorities.Executive officer M Venkateswara Rao said the temple has cancelled special darshan and provided for rapid darshan instead. The Saharsrchana rituals, which is held at 5pm every day, has also been cancelled temporarily.The timings for Mahanivedana, which is held every day at 11.30 am, will now be held for 20 minutes against its usual duration of one hour.Temple authorities have requested devotees to not bring children and the elderly for darshan till further instruction. Devotees have also been requested to wear masks.Special medical camps are being conducted at the temple, temple authorities said.Meanwhile, Sarada Peetham Uttaradhikaari seer Swatmanandendra said the peetham would perform yagams for 11 days to neutralise Covid-19.The main seer of the Peetham Swaroopanandendra after examining ayurveda texts has initiated yagas advised in Yogavaasistam, he said.The seer postponed the Hindu Dharma Prachara Yatra at Rajahmundry and returned to Vizag on Tuesday to perform the yagams.

Title: Gangrape of minor girl: Accused held within 8 hrs
Content:
Jaipur: Churu police have arrested two persons, including a minor, within eight hours of raping a minor girl.

Churu SP Tejaswani Gautam said the uncle of the 8-year-old girl had filed an FIR on Monday. Her uncle mentioned in the FIR that his niece had gone out to buy milk from a nearby shop around 8pm on Sunday. Three boys of the colony stopped her as she was walking alone in the street. They forcefully took her to an isolated place where cattle are kept. He alleged that all the three raped her and dumped her there.

When she did not reach her house, her relatives searched her in nearby areas. Around 11.30pm, they spotted her lying in the cattle farm in an unconscious state.

An FIR was registered under IPC Sections 365 (kidnapping), Section 342 (wrongful confinement), Section 323 (voluntary causing hurt), 376 D ( gangrape ), and other provisions of POCSO Act.

Title: GVMC surveys 100 foreign returnees
Content:
Visakhapatnam: The public health department under the Greater Visakhapatnam Municipal Corporation ( GVMC ) has surveyed around 100 of the 112 people who returned to the city from abroad.

Speaking to TOI, a senior GVMC health officer said that the civic body has kept the data of the foreign returnees . The returnees are from Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, Europe, the UK, the US and Singapore.

The GVMC has also issued warnings to the returnees that criminal cases would be filed against them if they failed to isolate themselves at home for two weeks.

“The government took the decision on Tuesday to have criminal cases filed if the order is not followed. Cases will be booked under Section 188 of IPC if the foreign returnees violate the instructions,” a GVMC official said.

Special teams for health inspection were sent to the homes of the foreign returnees on Tuesday.

“We have sent the suspected cases to the government hospital and advised the healthy returnees to not go out for sometime,” the officer added.

The officer said that nearly 7,500-odd people had returned to the state from abroad in the first week of February. In Vizag city, the number stood at around 640, he added.

Ten help desks have been set up at Visakhapatnam Railway Station, YMCA, RK Beach, Kailsagiri and Maddilapalem, among other places in the city.

Title: 11 years post retirement, Gujarat HC orders promotion for mamlatdar
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

AHMEDABAD: Eleven years after her retirement, the Gujarat high court ordered the state government to grant promotion to the post of deputy collector in a case of a mamlatdar who was denied promotion over a mistake committed in passing order in land title matters.

The case involves one K R Joshi, who retired in 2009 as a mamlatdar and in 2015, the government decided to deduct Rs 1,000 from her pension amount towards penalty. Justice A S Supehia not only ordered to grant her due promotion with effect from 2007, when she was superseded, the government has also been ordered to pay her the arrears by increasing her salary. The government will also have to refund the money deducted from her pension towards penalty, said Joshi’s advocate Sharvil Majmudar.

In ordering back-dated promotion for Joshi, the HC made important observation that that if a revenue officer while working as a quasi-judicial authority commits an error and there is no element of mala fide involved in passing orders pertaining to land title, the officer’s gesture does not fall within parameters of misconduct. While working as mamlatdar in Nadiad , Joshi passed certain orders by treating tenants as permanent tenants. The government thought that her decision caused the exchequer a loss of over Rs 64 lakh. The order was against the two resolutions adopted by the state government. This led to an inquiry, in which she was exonerated. But the authorities still considered her guilty and imposed penalty. She was not granted promotion also.

Title: Odisha: Aahaar centres tweak timings for social distancing
Content:
BHUBANESWAR: The state government on Tuesday implemented social distancing norms at its subsidized food canteens or Aahaar centres.

People queuing up for the cheap meals will have to stand 1.5 metre apart. The government has also tweaked the lunch timing. Food will be served from 10 am to 4 pm, instead of the usual noon to 3 pm. The move is meant to avoid overcrowding inside the centres. The government would also take the help of police or home guards to force people, if needed, to maintain the required distance from each other, said the official order issued by principal secretary (housing and urban and development).

Each Aahaar centre will install a sink at the entrance and provide liquid soap or soap bars for people to wash their hands before they join the queue for food. Temporary handwash counters, usually installed during weddings and other functions, are expected to be hired for this purpose.

The government also said steps would be taken to de-congest the Aahaar centres. People will be asked to take their food-laden plates outside the centres, finish eating and then place the plates in bins. To reduce physical contact, the persons might be asked to put their money in a box and collect a token for the food. The centres have to be cleaned rigorously and sanitised using disinfectants.

When TOI visited several Aahaar centres in the city a couple of hours after the issue of the notification, it did not find the rules to be implemented. Some of the centres had not opened even after 11.30 am and people were standing close to each other in queues.

“We have not received any order from the government so far, so we opened our centre as usual at noon. The guidelines will be implemented from tomorrow (Wednesday),” said an employee at an Aahaar centre near the Bhubaneswar railway station.

The state has a total of 157 Aahaar centres.

Title: Quite a stretch: Bus commuters clueless about social distancing
Content:
Commuters rushed in groups to board buses on Tuesday, maintaining no distance from the next person

PANAJI/MAPUSA: Even as the government has been urging citizens to practice social distancing to contain the spread of Covid-19, commuters at interstate bus stands seem oblivious to the infection threat.

Every time a bus pulled into the bus stand, commuters were seen rushing, in groups, to board it— maintaining no distance from the next person, seemingly more keen on getting into the bus first to bag a window seat, than avoiding the spread of germs.

Hardly anybody at the ticket booking counters at the KTC bus stands at Mapusa and Panaji wore face masks, while fewer passengers covered their face with either mask or handkerchief.

Even as the state transport department had announced that all bus stands would be sanitised regularly, the Mapusa bus stand is yet to be sanitised, and looked as unhygienic as any other day, with waste collecting in its corners.

Saraswati and five members of her family, including a toddler, arrived in Goa from Solapur, Maharashtra, on Tuesday. The family was waiting to board a bus at the Mapusa bus stand that would take them to Sakhali, where they sell toys. The lone man in the group, her young brother-in-law, was covering his mouth and nose with a black mask. “I have my dupatta,” said Saraswati, holding up a soiled dupatta.

All the benches around her were occupied, and she in the dirt. Even if she understands the science of how the virus spreads, does she have a wherewithal to take care?

Another woman seated on the floor of the Mapusa bus stand, 65-year-old Gangubai (name changed), prepares her paan as she waits for her bus home. Ask her about her precautions against the virus, she retorts, “Kon go thaey bai. Haav na olkhona?” (Who is corona? I don’t know her).

Fifty-something Malti Kudchadkar has heard about Covid-19 and that the virus has killed thousands of people. Sharing the narrow bench with several other travellers, she is more anxious about her bus being delayed than her potential exposure to the infection.

Title: Thrash defectors in public: Hardik
Content:
Hardik Patel

Surat: Congress leader Hardik Patel , who appeared in Surat court on Tuesday , said that political leaders who switches sides should be thrashed in public.

Hardik said this while interacting to media persons outside the local court here. He was responding to questions over the resignation of Congress MLAs ahead of Rajya Sabha polls in the state.

“Those political leaders who switch side should be thrashed in public. In democracy, MLAs are elected by public. But for few bucks they switch sides,” Patel said.

He arrived in the court campus wearing a mask. Hardik is facing number of cases in Surat including one of sedition. Total five Congress MLAs have resigned from Congress party in last four days.

Title: Ahmedabad: Tax advisor loses Rs 16 lakh to Aadhaar-linked con
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: A tax practitioner from Navrangpura on Monday filed a complaint with the Navrangpura police, stating that a fraudster made him send a copy of his Aadhaar card, got a new sim of the same number, and withdrew Rs 16 lakh from his bank account.

Nitin Shah, 64, stated in his FIR that on March 9, he had received an email from an unknown person who had said that if Shah did not give his Aadhaar card details, his phone services would be disconnected.

On March 12 evening, the services on Shah’s phone were disrupted. When he went to the telecom company’s outlet in Navrangpura, he found that somebody had closed the services of the old sim and had obtained a new sim of the same number. Later, the accused withdrew Rs 16 lakh through netbanking from Shah’s account.

Police sources said that through the Aadhaar information, the fraudsters got Shah’s banking details. As Shah’s old sim card had been suspended, he did not get any messages alerting him to transactions.

Navrangpura police have registered a complaint and have began an investigation.

Title: DCW rescues five children from placement agency
Content:
Image used for representational purpose only

NEW DELHI: Delhi Commission for Women has rescued five children belonging to UP, Odisha and Chattisgarh from outer Delhi’s Nihal Vihar. They had been brought to Delhi by a placement agency on the pretext of a vacation or for sending them to school.

An NGO working in the area called DCW’s 181 helpline and informed the commission about the illegal acts of the agency. DCW dispatched its team immediately to the spot and reached the address in the presence of police.

The team found that seven children were staying at the placement agency. The children were very scared and were not in a condition to speak. The owner of the agency was also present at the time of visit at the office.

Police and the DCW team brought the children and the owner of the agency to Nihal Vihal police station for further investigation. DCW chief Swati Maliwal also counselled the children and after interacting with them late on Monday night, demanded an FIR in the matter.

It was learnt that one of the children is a 13-year-old orphan who hails from Unnao in Uttar Pradesh. His aunt had sent him to Delhi saying that the people were taking him for admitting him to a school. The child had been living at the placement agency’s office for a month.

The youngest girl is five-years-old and belongs to Sundergarh District . The girl informed the team that she had come to Delhi with her mother two days ago and that she had left her at the agency’s office.

Apart from this, two children were brought to Delhi on the pretext of taking them for a vacation. Another woman, who is 20-years-old, had been working in Delhi for the past one year through the placement agency and was allegedly not allowed to talk to her family and was not paid her dues.

“It was observed that all the children had been brought to Delhi by luring and deceiving them. It was also found that the agency’s owner’s husband is already charged with a rape case and is behind bars for the same. All the children were sent to a shelter home after undergoing medical examination. The children have been presented before the Child Welfare Committee,” Maliwal said.

She added, “A huge human trafficking racket is being run in Delhi in the name of placement agencies. Children are being lured to Delhi from small towns and villages and being put to work. They are so young that they are not even able to tell about their family and their age. At this tender age, these children are being exploited and pushed into labour. It is absolutely intolerable and we appeal to all the governments to make strict laws for the regulation of these placement agencies as soon as possible. We want police to file an FIR, arrest the culprits and get the children safely to their homes. In addition, the children who are orphans also need to be rehabilitated.”

Title: Guj MLAs mandate Sonia Gandhi to name candidate for RS
Content:
Congress legislators from Gujarat at Jaipur airport on Tuesday.

JAIPUR: The Congress legislators from Gujarat, camping in Jaipur fearing poaching by the BJP for Rajya Sabha elections, have authorised party president Sonia Gandhi to decide on the name of the candidate for the March 26 polls after five of the party MLAs resigned.

The Congress is now left with only 68 MLAs as against 72 required for winning both the seats.

AICC observers on Tuesday held meetings with Gujarat MLAs, to seek their opinion on candidate for the RS polls. They met the MLAs both individually and in groups. The leaders then left for Delhi to meet party president Sonia Gandhi as the last date for withdrawal of nomination is Wednesday.

“A proposal has been passed unanimously authorising party president Sonia Gandhi to decide the number of candidates for elections. The observers will be going to Delhi to meet Gandhi,” the party sources said here.

Gujarat Congress president Amit Chavda before leaving for Delhi claimed that the party is in talk with one NCP and two Bharatiya Tribal party leaders for their support. He also claimed that some disgruntled BJP MLAs are also in touch with them.

He said we will apprise the party president of the ground situation and decision will be arrived at after consultation with the Sonia Gandhi. Deputy chief minister and PCC president Sachin Pilot visited the Gujarat MLAs in the evening at the hotel.
