Title: Will vote for BJP nominees: Kandhal Jadeja
Content:
Ahmedabad: Kandhal Jadeja, the lone Nationalist Congress Party (NCP) MLA in the Gujarat assembly said on Tuesday that he will vote in favour of BJP candidates in the Rajya Sabha election on March 26.

When Jadeja arrived at the Gujarat assembly on Tuesday morning, and was quizzed over whom he will vote for, he said, “I will vote according to directions of the party high command.” However, within an hour, Jadeja emerged out of the Gujarat assembly and declared that he has decided to vote for candidates of the BJP. Sources said Kutiyana MLA Kandhal Jadeja met CM Vijay Rupani and minister of state for home Pradipsinh Jadeja on Tuesday. Later in the afternoon, Pradipsinh Jadeja said that all three candidates of the BJPwere assured of a win, as two MLAs of the Bharatiya Tribal Party and the lone MLA of the NCP had extended their support. Chhotu Vasava and Mahesh Vasava, could not be reached for comment. tnn

Title: Covid-19 outbreak: Central Railway cancels 23 long-distance trains
Content: MUMBAI: Central Railway has decided to cancel 23 trains, including the CSMT-Nizamuddin Rajdhani, Howrah Duronto and Deccan Express for a few days as a preventive measure to curb the spread of Covid-19 and due to low occupancy rate. A CR spokesperson said, “We have cancelled trains to contain the effects of Coronavirus and non-occupancy of trains.”The trains that will be cancelled till March 31 include Mumbai-Pune Deccan Express, Nagpur-Mumbai Nandigram Express, LTT-Manmad Express, Mumbai-Pune Pragati Express, Kalaburagi-Secunderabad Express, Howrah-Mumbai Duranto Express and Nizamuddin-CSMT Rajdhani Express.The trains that will not ply till March 30 include Pune-Mumbai Deccan Express, LTT-Ajni Express, CSMT-Nizamuddin Rajdhani Express and Nagpur-Bhusaval Express. Trains that will not run till March 27 include Ajni-LTT Express and Nagpur-Pune Express. Those cancelled till March 28 include LTT-Nizamabad Express and Pune-Ajni Express.Trains cancelled till March 29 include Nizamabad-LTT Express, Bhusaval-Nagpur Express and Ajni-Pune Express. Those cancelled till April 1 include Mumbai-Nagpur Nandigram Express, Pune-Mumbai Pragati Express and Mumbai-Howrah Duranto Express.Nagpur-Rewa Express will be cancelled on March 25 and Pune-Nagpur Express on March 26 and April 2.

Title: Local polls can be held after health minister assurance: Andhra Pradesh SEC
Content:
Representative image

VIJAYAWADA: State election commissioner N Ramesh Kumar on Tuesday said the election process for local and civic bodies will be resumed only after getting an assurance from the national task force on Covid-19 or the Union ministry of health.

In a reply to the letter written by chief secretary Nilam Sawhney, he said the decision to put off the poll process by six weeks was taken in view of the coronavirus threat.

Sawhney had written to the election body chief on Monday, urging him to revoke the postponement order and hold elections as per the earlier schedule as the Covid-19 situation in the state was under control.

Referring to the contention that the state will lose central funds if polls are not held by March 31, Kumar said he worked as finance secretary prior to his stint in the state. “Release of funds to local bodies (basic grant and performance grant) and holding of elections to local bodies is one of the conditions. In the past, the state government was able to successfully access withheld funds after holding elections,” he said, and added that the election commission will support the AP government’s efforts to access central funds through any requisite documentation from their end.

“Based on my experience, release of basic grant is on a more flexible terrain and performance grant has different parameters. But since AP is not alone in the present situation, the states, in a similar situation, can make a common pleading. On my part, l will vouch for the state’s and our collective efforts,” he added.

Pointing out that coronavirus is a circumstance beyond anticipation, he said the states of Maharashtra, West Bengal and Odisha have also put local body elections on hold. “In fact, all election commissions to my knowledge have deferred the holding of bye-polls. Bihar is one such example,” he stated.

“AP is not alone at the present juncture facing the Covid-19 challenge. All state election commissioners are accessing World Health Organisation (WHO) warnings and the Union health ministry’s guidelines. I have a duty to safeguard the high Constitutional status of the commission as well as to clear the air about its conscious and objective decision-making process.”

He further said that in the absence of scientific data for which no one can be faulted, the chief secretary may refer the case to the national task force set up by the central government to revisit the issue.

Title: 432 people under home quarantine in Surat and Tapi
Content:
Surat: Rumour mongers had a field day in Surat city and district after a 21-year-old man, who recently returned from the United Kingdom , was kept in the isolation ward of New Civil Hospital (NCH) here on Tuesday. His Covid-19 test report is awaited. Surat district health administration issued a rejoinder to fake news that had gone viral on social media in this regard.

Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) officials said a 23-year-old engineering student was admitted to NCH as a suspected Covid-19 patient and his samples sent to Ahmedabad for testing. He had also travelled to Spain and Poland in the recent past.

“As on Tuesday, 428 people are under home quarantine in Surat city and are being constantly monitored as per government guidelines,’’ said Dr. Ashish Naik, deputy municipal commissioner (health), SMC. Besides the student, there is another person who has been kept in isolation ward of a hospital in Surat. Meanwhile, SMC on Tuesday ordered closure of Narmad Central Library, Dr. Vishnuprashad Trivedi Library, Atal Bihari Vajpayee Library and other libraries in different parts of the city. The science centre too will remain closed until March 31.

Meanwhile, a person, who returned from Saudi Arabia, has been kept in isolation ward at Bharuch Civil Hospital on Tuesday. He hails from Amod village in Bharuch district. Health department officials said samples of the suspected coronavirus patient have been sent to Ahmedabad for test. His test report is expected soon.

“We have 70 beds in isolation ward in civil and private hospitals and about 150 quarantine beds in the district. We plan to increase the quarantine beds to 500,” Dr Nilesh Patel, epidemic medical officer, Bharuch, told TOI.

In Tapi district, about 18 non-resident Gujaratis (NRGs) were under home quarantine for 14 days. “Of the 18 NRGs, home quarantine has ended for 14 people. Four persons are still under home quarantine,” said Dr. Harshad Patel, chief district health officer (CDHO), Tapi district.

“We have created a special six bed isolation ward for suspected coronavirus patients. We have also set up a control room where people can lodge their complaints about high priced sanitizers and masks. The local body of Vyara town has started to fine people found spitting in public,’’ Dr. Harshad Patel added.

Title: DGGI unearths Rs 12.40 cr tax evasion by textile units, concrete supplier
Content:
Surat: The Directorate General of GST Intelligence (DGGI) has detected Rs 12.40 crore worth of GST evasion by five textile units in Surat and a concrete mix supplier based in Vadodara on Tuesday.

Officials said that textile units manufacturing unstitched lehenga were clearing their stock having sale value exceeding Rs 1,000 showing them as ‘sari cloth’. The unit owners were paying 5% GST instead of the actual 12% on the unstitched lehenga, thereby evading tax of Rs 11 crore since July 2017.

The officials had raided the Krishna fabrics at Umarwada, Abhivandan designers, Shree Swagat NX, Braj Gopi creations and Namo Navkar collections located at Bombay market.

During the search operation, DGGI officials seized incriminating documents indicating evasion of GST to the tune of Rs 11 crore. A total of Rs 3.60 crore was voluntarily deposited by the textile unit owners with the assurance to deposit rest of the evasion amount in the stipulated time frame.

In the second case, the DGGI conducted search operation at MCC Concrete at Vadodara regarding the evasion of service tax. During the search it was found that the unit was registered with the department and was paying Central Excise duty on the clearance of ready-mix concrete, but was not paying service tax. A total of Rs 1.40 crore worth of service tax was evaded against which the company paid Rs 25 lakh.

Title: Konark Sun Temple in Centre’s ‘iconic list’
Content:
BHUBANESWAR: Union tourism minister Prahlad Singh Patel on Tuesday confirmed in the Rajya Sabha that the world-famous Sun Temple at Konark has been included in Centre’s iconic tourism sites list, an initiative to develop iconic tourism sites into world-class tourism destinations.

Patel’s announcement came in response to a supplementary question by BJD’s Sasmit Patra during question hour in Rajya Sabha.

Besides the 17 iconic sites announced last year, two more — one from Gujarat and Konark Temple — have been included in the list taking the total number to 19. “I have received letters from Odisha chief minister, Union petroleum minister and from other delegates in this regard,” Patel said in his reply.

With inclusion of the 13th century shrine in the iconic tourism site list, the Centre would release money for overall development of the tourism site, which attracts tourists from across the globe.

The Union government, in the annual budget 2019-20, had announced a list of 17 iconic tourism sites to develop them into world-class tourism destinations while not a single tourism site from the state was included in the list. The issue had triggered a political war of words.

The Union minister also said they will soon take a call on the issue of removing sand from the ASI-protected monument. The sand filling was done by the British in 1903 to provide stability to the monument. The discussion to remove sand from the monument was held at a national conference on conservation of the temple that was also attended by the minister.

Title: 4.65L property, land documents registered
Content:
Gandhinagar: Over the past two years — from February 1, 2018 — 4.65 lakh property and land documents were registered in Ahmedabad city and district. In 2019, a marginal increase of 0.34% was recorded as compared to 2018’s figures.

Replying to a question from Khadia MLA Imran Khedawala, the state government said that between February 1, 2019, and January 31, 2020, 2,32,720 documents were registered with the government. In 2018, the figure was 2,31,925 in the same period.

In 2019, there was a marginal increase of 795 documents. The government said that the use of the online payment facility is still to pick up. Of the 2.33 lakh documents registered in 2019, the payments for only 8,204 were done electronically.

The government said that the income in 2019 registered a decline of 1.4%. Between February 1, 2019, and January 31, 2020, the income received for the registration of the documents was Rs 359.34 crore. The figure in 2018 was Rs 364.59 crore in the same period.

The officials said the documents registered were of the properties whose possession is being given now. The officials said that though the increase is marginal, the Ahmedabad property market has been able to maintain sales despite the market conditions.

“Given the slowdown pressures in the real estate market over the past two years, registrations should have been lower,” said Ajay Patel, president, GIHED-CREDAI. “However, the number, on the contrary, is marginally higher. That is a good sign for the real estate industry. It shows that demand exists.”

Title: At central jail, a lockdown of a different kind
Content: Panaji: With 539 inmates , undertrials and convicts included, Colvale Central jail is gearing up to deal with a potential Covid-19 threat. Prisons authority has decided to suspend interviews with prisoners by visitors till March 31.Voluntary organisations engaged in reformatory activities will not be able to engage with inmates till March 31, an inspector general of prison (IGP) official said.He added that the entire jail premises will be sanitised and an isolation facility will be created if any inmate needs to be quarantined. “Those who are returning from parole, will be kept separately,” he said.The modern jail has 10 isolation cubicles that are normally use to temporarily lodge inmates who turn violent or are a cause of disturbance to other jail mates even after a warning is sounded.“Those cells are rarely used and are currently not in use,” said a jail official at Colvale prison.The IGP official, however, said they have adequate empty blocks that can be used as a quarantine facility, if needed. Unlike other prisons in the country, ours is not over crowded, he said.Besides, new undertrials will be kept separately. “Our jail premises are clean and hygiene is maintained but extra measures will be taken,” he added.Currently, jail inmates are allowed two hours of outdoor activity each in the first and second half of the day. “Jail inmates will now be allowed out of their cells—within jail premises either working or playing—for five hours a day to reduce chances of them getting exposed to the virus in the cell,” he said.The thermal gun to record temperature of persons entering jail premises will be procured as will hand sanitizers. Inquiries were initiated to make the purchases on Monday.

Title: Covid-19 threat: Gujarat Sports Club makes room for flyers
Content: AHMEDABAD: Gujarat Sports Club near Sardar Patel Stadium has closed for all activities for members and guests. The club management took this decision around noon on Tuesday, and notified all members of it, following a request from municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra.“We got a request from the municipal commissioner to shut the club, so rooms could be used as observation wards for international passengers arriving at Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel International (SVPI) airport,” said N K Patel, president, Gujarat Sports Club.“The club has been closed for all activities from 6pm on Tuesday. Some 26 rooms at the club will be used to monitor patient health by state health department officials,” he further added.Club sources said that there was no resistance from members as the decision comes in extraordinary circumstances, in the interest of public health.Other clubs in Ahmedabad took similar decisions as part of precautions against the COVID-19 outbreak. The Karnavati Club management has decided to suspend all sports coaching activities.“Taking into consideration the safety of our members, all coaching for sports such as table tennis, billiards, tennis, chess, karate, badminton, swimming, among others will remain closed from March 17-29. Fees paid by members will be carried forward,” read a message sent to members of Karnavati Club.After state health authorities imposed a shutdown on schools, colleges, cinema halls and even swimming pools, clubs have already shut down their health centres, card rooms and swimming pools till further notice.Rajpath Club has taken similar measures. “We have completely barred the entry of members’ guests. Members will be the only ones allowed in. The card room, health club and the swimming pool has already been shut and we have also suspended coaching for all sports till March 29. A decision on resuming these activities will be taken after reviewing the situation later.”

Title: Coronavirus: Reporting SARI made must for all hospitals in Gujarat
Content: AHMEDABAD: On Tuesday, the state government added another layer for the identification of coronavirus disease (Covid-19) cases in the state. It made the reporting of severe acute respiratory infection ( SARI ) cases mandatory for government and private health facilities. A few other states have already issued notifications on similar lines as the condition is identified as the definite medical proof of the viral infection.Jayanti Ravi, the principal secretary (health & family welfare), on Tuesday said that from 2.30pm on Tuesday, all the pulmonologists, physicians, intensivists and staff of government and private hospitals and medical colleges will report all cases of SARI as a matter of precaution. “We will gather information on all such cases and initiate further action,” she said.The symptoms associated with Covid-19 point to the presence of SARI after a few days of the onset. This sets it apart from the common flu and other respiratory diseases, said experts.Ravi said that with the help of EMRI 108 services and the medical network system, the government is keeping an eye on the spike in symptoms of flu and respiratory illnesses in any pocket of the state to pick up early signs of infection. “There are three stages of spread — contact, cluster, and community. We have fortunately not reached the cluster or community stage yet and our efforts are focused on identifying and isolating persons coming from foreign countries,” said Ravi. “But we need to be cautious and follow instructions on hygiene and social distancing strictly.” She said that as on Tuesday, no confirmed positive case of Covid-19 has been reported in Gujarat The principal secretary also said that the government is encouraging the work-from-home policy for the private sector wherever possible. “We are yet to take a call for government offices,” she said. She added that the state has adequate supply of masks and personal protective equipment (PPE) kits for health workers in isolation wards. “We will procure 10,000 more PPE kits,” Ravi said.

Title: Coronavirus scare: People in Ahmedabad cut down on eating out, footfalls dip by 30%
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: With government efforts raising awareness about the Covid-19 pandemic, eateries have taken a hit as citizens have become reluctant to visit spaces frequented by large numbers of strangers, which have have higher risks of cross-contamination and infection.

With malls and multiplexes temporarily shut down and the government advising people to stay indoors and try to remotely work from home, footfalls at restaurants and eateries across the city dropped by at least 30% over the last 7-10 days. Even the numbers of takeaway orders have declined. Citizens have begun to prefer the relative isolation of their homes and the peace of mind provided by home-cooked food.

Coronavirus in India live updates

“The footfalls have gone down by at least 30%. Even though all restaurants are taking extra precautions and ensuring hygiene measures, customers are clearly avoiding restaurants,” said Rajmohan Modi , a city-based restaurateur.

Many restaurants have amped up hygiene measures, right from encouraging staffers to wash hands more frequently to keeping hand sanitizers on tables and upping sanitation and waste segregation.

“We have kept sanitizers on each table and are taking extra precautions to ensure that our water and food quality is maintained at par with standards. We have also ensured our staff members wear gloves and masks while serving food,” said Dilip Thakkar, partner of a city-based restaurant.

“Against at least 50 orders a day, we are getting 10 for non-vegetarian food,” said Rohit Khanna, co-founder, Food Entrepreneurs’ Association.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Shaheen Bagh protesters keep distance, but stay put
Content: NEW DELHI: Despite Delhi government banning a gathering of more than 50 people, the women protesters at Shaheen Bagh on Tuesday laid beds at the site with two of them sitting on one to maintain a safe distance while continuing with their agitation. The women had earlier been sitting on the ground.Fatima, a protester at Shaheen Bagh, said, “We will not get up whatever may happen. We are taking extra care with regard to cleanliness and sanitising our hands often. There are also arrangements for people to wash hands. If more people come, we will put more beds.”Later, police and RWA members reached the protest site to interact with the women, but they refused to end their agitation.“We have been making repeated requests to the protesters with the help of imams and maulvis. The meeting could not be held for the last two weeks. We went especially because of the coronavirus outbreak. There was no positive outcome of the meeting, but we will keep trying,” said a senior police officer.Jamal Haider, RWA member from Jamia Nagar , who was also present in the meeting, said, “Residents are afraid that if one person gets infected, then everyone will suffer. The protest is on despite the coronavirus outbreak, which is not right.”On Tuesday, Delhi Police , in an appeal to the public to prevent the spread of novel coronavirus, said, “(We make) a fervent appeal to the general public to remain indoors as far as possible and not come outside unnecessarily for leisure or entertainment activities, which involve close contact with more than five people.”Anil Mittal, additional PRO, Delhi Police, said, “We also appeal to people not to assemble at any place for protest, dharna, rally or any other activity, whether in closed space or outside, till March 31. Delhi Police will not give permission for such gatherings. Also, no licence will be issued for public entertainment activities.”

Title: DGCA to hold building height hearing on March 19
Content:
Buildings obstructing runway path are facing demolition under section 6 of aircraft rules, 1994

Surat: Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) will hold personal hearing of residents of 198 buildings obstructing runway path of aircraft landing and taking off from Surat airport here on March 19.

DGCA officials will be arriving on March 19 after Union civil aviation ministry directed them to conduct hearing in Surat.

Earlier, DGCA had asked owners and society presidents of buildings facing demolition under section 6 of aircraft rules, 1994 to remain present on March 4 at its deputy director’s office in Mumbai for personal hearing.

In December 2019 in a public interest litigation, Gujarat high court had ordered Centre, Airports Authority of India (AAI) and Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) to look into the issue of unauthorized construction near the airport. Builders and residents of 48 projects had approached the high court.

DGCA’s personal hearing is being organized after the high court’s order to authorities to take up the building height obstruction issue seriously. It had criticised inaction on the part of AAI and SMC after issuing notices for demolition of buildings which do not even have building use permission (BUC).

An officer of AAI said, “Residents and builders of affected buildings have been summoned for personal hearing on March 19. Before conducting the final hearing with regard to obstacles to flight path of the aircraft, DGCA will like to meet the residents.”

Removal of obstacles on approach surface of runway-22 at Vesu side will pave the way for clearing displacement of 615 metres imposed by DGCA. This means an aircraft landing from Vesu side will be able to use the full length runway of 2,905 metres, instead of current 2,290 metres.

Sources said the survey of buildings obstructing the flight path within 6.6 kilometres on the approach funnel of runway at Vesu end was done in 2018. About 198 buildings of 48 projects were identified as violators of permissible top elevation and coordinate rules.

Title: Exports of lab-grown diamond up 60% in Feb amid Covid-19
Content:
Surat: At a time when coronavirus outbreak in Hong Kong and China has taken the sheen out of Surat's famed natural polished diamonds, cheap lab-grown diamonds seem to have become best friend of consumers in the United States and Dubai.

While exports of natural polished diamonds have declined by almost 41% in February, exports of lab-grown diamonds registered a 60% increase during the same month.

According to figures provided by Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC), exports of lab-grown polished diamonds increased by 60% to Rs265 crore in February 2020 compared to Rs166 during the same month in previous year. However, total exports of lab-grown diamonds between April-February 2020 increased by 102% to Rs2,800 crore compared to Rs1,370 crore during the same period in previous year.

On the other hand, exports of polished diamonds in February 2020 declined by 41% at Rs9,800 crore compared to Rs16,600 crore during the same month in previous year. Overall exports of polished diamonds between April-February 2020 declined by 19% to Rs1.24 lakh crore compared to Rs1.53 lakh crore during the same period in previous year.

Industry sources said majority of lab-grown diamonds are exported to the US, where many leading jewellery brands like Zales, Kay, Jared and Signet Jewellers sell lab-grown diamonds from their stores and online platforms. Majority of lab-grown diamonds are cut and polished in Surat and the raw material is sourced from China and Singapore.

Lab-grown Diamond and Jewellery Promotion Council (LGDJPC) chairman Shashikant Shah told TOI, “If consumers don’t get diamonds cheaper, they will buy lab-grown diamonds. Now, lab-grown diamonds have found acceptance in the US, Dubai, Australia and Germany. We don’t see export graph going down anytime soon.”

According to Global Diamond Report-2019 by Bain & Company, most of lab-grown diamonds are purchased in the US, but produced in China and India. While China accounts for nearly 50% of global production of lab-grown gems, India produces 20% with focus on polished diamonds sales.

Paul Zimnisky, New York-based independent diamond industry analyst, told TOI, “I estimate that man-made diamonds produced for jewellery will be around 5 million rough carats this year, up 35% from last year. Based on my analysis, man-made diamonds are selling 45-55% less than equivalent natural diamonds.”

Title: Odisha: Rain likely from today, cough & cold cases to rise
Content:
BHUBANESWAR: Amid Covid-19 pandemic, the India Meteorology Department (IMD) on Tuesday issued yellow warning (be updated) for rain and thundershowers in several districts of the state from Wednesday. The rain and thundershowers are likely to continue till March 21, the IMD bulletin said.

When asked if the change in weather will have any impact on the coronavirus outbreak, state government’s spokesperson on Covid-19 Subroto Bagchi said, “The impact of rain or weather change on coronavirus is not known yet. But the only way with which people can protect themselves from the virus is by frequently washing their hands and by practising social distance or home isolation.”

Doctors are also not very sure about the impact rain will have on the spread of the deadly virus. “Since it is a new virus, not much research or study has been done on it. It is difficult to know the impact of rain on corona but change in weather may increase the number of patients suffering from cold, cough and flu. And all patients with these symptoms need to be very careful,” said Dr P N Sahu, a senior medicine specialist at AMRI Hospitals here.

“A cyclonic circulation is brewing over north coastal Odisha and its neighbourhood. Light to moderate rain or thundershowers are likely to occur at one or two places over Rayagada, Koraput, Gajapati, Keonjhar, Mayurbhanj, Balasore and Kandhamal districts in the next 24 hours while dry weather is likely to prevail in rest of the districts,” the bulletin added.

Several districts of the state like Jajpur, Cuttack, Kendrapada, Mayurbhanj of north Odisha and Gajapati of South coastal Odisha witnessed light to moderate rain on Tuesday.

However, the weatherman said, there will be no major change in maximum and minimum temperature across Odisha. The temperature is below normal in the interior Odisha and above normal in coastal region. The highest maximum temperature of 36.2 degree Celsius was recorded at Sonepur and the lowest minimum temperature of 16 degree Celsius was recorded at Sundargarh, the Met office said.

Title: Central library may be shut till month-end
Content: Panaji: The Goa state central library has cordoned off its study rooms to stave off large gatherings. The study rooms see an average of 60 students at any given time.While the remainder of the library, including the rare archives section, can presently be used by visitors, this privilege may also soon be denied as officials are planning to close the space till March 31 as a pre-emptive measure against coronavirus.“We are having a discussion with the directorate of art and culture to keep the library closed till March 31. We will announce the dates of closure soon,” library curator Carlos Fernandes said.Until then, the housekeeping staff and those manning the book-lending counter have been asked to wear masks. The library is also being frequently sanitised.“However, unlike other public spaces, we cannot spray the books here with disinfectant. The shelves and cupboards are being cleaned every few hours, but the sanitation of books requires a scientific process,” Fernandes said.The library saw a huge gathering of students on Monday, the day from which schools in Goa were ordered to be closed. The staff said that working parents brought their children there because they didn’t want them to be at home, alone. However, other readers raised apprehensions about the library getting crowded.“Some readers themselves have requested us to close the library due to fears surrounding coronavirus. They are aware of the gravity of the situation ,” Fernandes said.Ten other libraries (town, district and taluka-level) in the state that come under the central library may also be shut till the end of this month.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Ensure sanitisers, masks are available, says Haryana chief secretary
Content:
Representative image

CHANDIGARH: The Haryana food and civil supplies department has been directed to ensure the availability of medicines, masks, and sanitisers to the public at reasonable prices. In addition, the government has set-up two helpline numbers 8558893911 and 108, where information regarding the Covid-19 suspects in the state can be given.

Haryana chief secretary Keshni Anand Arora on Monday issued special guidelines to the divisional commissioners, deputy commissioners, chief medical officers and other senior officials of the state through video conferencing from Chandigarh. She told all officers to make proper arrangements by coordinating with various departments to prevent the spread of the coronavirus.

In order to generate awareness among the people, hoardings should be installed in public places and campaigns be organised through advertisement, television, radio, SMS, she said.

The chief secretary said retired medical officers, paramedical staff, and ex-servicemen should also be involved in this task to handle any emergency situation in future, along with government officials and medical students.

All the officials, along with the food and civil supplies department, should ensure that medicines, masks, and sanitisers were available to the public at reasonable prices. Government staffers should also be informed about the coronavirus and sanitisers made available in offices of all departments, mini-secretariats and other populated.

Arora said the deputy commissioners should request the private companies in their respective areas to inform the chief medical officer regarding employees who visit from other countries. Apart from this, the companies should also allow employees to work from home if possible. She instructed to prepare at least 100 isolation-beds in all districts and more than 500 isolation-beds in Gurgaon, adjoining New Delhi.

Meanwhile, additional chief secretary for health Rajiv Arora has been appointed as resident commissioner of Haryana at New Delhi and the nodal officer for coordination with the Centre for dealing with situation arising out of Covid-19.

Title: Desi varieties bloom as sanitizer shortage worsens
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: Instead of complaining about unavailability of hand sanitizers in the market, several organizations have started producing their own sanitizers, which has become essential at the time of spread of Covid-19 . Frequent hand washing either using soap or hand sanitizer has been suggested as the best measure to prevent spread of the virus.Vikram Sarabhai Space Centre (VSSC) is setting an example in the fight against the spread of Covid-19. In order to ensure proper care for its 7,500 employees, the VSSC has started preparing WHO-recommended handrub at its Propellant Fuel Complex. The state pharmaceutical controller has given license to produce it on Monday. The formulation is prepared as a ready-to-use solution which dries fast.VSSC has used isopropyl alcohol, which has been stocked for cleaning electronic circuits and other materials. Other major components are hydrogen peroxide, glycerol and sterilized water.The formulation is water soluble and can be carried in a small bottle for personal use. In addition to hand sanitizer, VSSC is making face masks to meet its in-house demands.Attingal Government College too has started producing hand sanitizers. A team headed by polymer chemistry department head Prabha and professors Sumi, Bhagyashree, Dhanya and Thushara made the sanitizer. Principal V Manikantan Nair distributed sanitizers among students of a nearby government school free of cost.Block resource centre, Kilimanoor, also became part of ‘break the chain’ campaign by producing hand sanitizers. They distributed sanitizers free of cost to students writing Class X and Class XII examinations.Considering the huge requirement of hand sanitizers, DGP Loknath Behra has directed Armed Police Battalion to produce hand sanitizers.Sanitizers were distributed at police headquarters and other police stations. The police have taken steps to procure more hand sanitizers from Delhi.On Tuesday, city police received 1,000 masks and sanitizers which were sourced by NSS taluk union. At a function held at city police commissioner’s office, taluk union president Sangeeth Kumar handed over the masks and sanitizers to city police commissioner Balram Kumar Upadhyay. The commissioner said that masks and sanitizers will be handed over to policemen who are on duty at various city centres.

Title: Rane for ban on tourists from M’rashtra, K’taka
Content: Panaji: Health minister Vishwajit Rane on Tuesday said he has proposed a ban on entry of tourists through road from the bordering states of Maharashtra and Karnataka for “at least two months”, as a precautionary measure against coronavirus The decision, Rane said, needs to be taken in the interest of the state. “A lot of tourists come from the neighbouring states in four-wheelers. It could become a disaster point,” he said, adding CM Pramod Sawant should take a call.“I have sought advice from Union health minister Harsh Vardhan to see how we can block the borders. We have to at some point seal the borders with the neighbouring states. I have moved a parallel note in this regard to the chief minister,” Rane said.He said only two entry points could be kept open for vehicles bringing in essential supplies into Goa.Goa relies on the neighbouring states for the supply of vegetables and grains.While there are four entry points into Goa from Maharashtra, there are three routes from Karnataka.Both the states have reported Covid-19 positive cases and one death each, while Goa is yet to report anyone positive, while four suspects have been placed in isolation.Rane said the state government would also ensure that it keeps track of railway passengers. “Rail travelers will be checked,” he said.A senior health official said it would be difficult to conduct checks at border points, as they do not have adequate manpower to do the job. “We will be left with fewer doctors to conduct surveillance, if border checking is undertaken,” he said.

Title: Closed care homes, hostels to turn quarantine camps
Content: Thiruvananthapuram: The district administration and the corporation have begun converting care homes, hostels and hospitals lying closed in the city into quarantine camps as a precautionary measure to house passengers arriving in Trivandrum and have to travel long-distance either to another district or to neighbouring states like Tamil Nadu.The first such quarantine camp began functioning at a care home at Kadakampally in which passengers who arrived at Thiruvananthapuram and were set to depart to Malappuram and Thanchavur would be housed. The district administration is making sure that they do not use public transport and remain under strict quarantine for 14 days. The authorities are co-ordinating with the corporation for the supply of food and water for them.Sources said IMG hostel at Bartonhill, Youth hostel at Veli, vacant buildings of two private hospitals at Kunchalumoodu and Kochulloor are also being prepared to house passengers.According to authorities, by housing passengers from Covid-hit countries in quarantine camps they can effectively prevent any kind of exposure of locals to the virus. The district administration is also taking preparatory steps in accordance with additional travel advisory for Covid-19 issued by the Union government.In continuation of the travel advisory issued on March 11, the Union ministry issued an additional advisory expanding compulsory quarantine for a minimum period of 14 days for passengers coming from/transiting through the UAE, Qatar, Oman, and Kuwait. This will come into effect from 1200 GMT on March 18, 2020 at the port of first departure.With the new advisory coming into effect from Wednesday evening, the administration has also identified 5,000 beds. Airport officials said the number of passengers coming to Thiruvananthapuram from European countries and even China are very nominal on a daily basis, however with the inclusion of UAE, Qatar, Oman and Kuwait, they are expecting a huge inflow of passengers.If the state government decides to implement the advisory, they will have to be taken via a special corridor directly to quarantine camps. No direction has been issued by the state government on this regard as on Tuesday. The airport authorities said a call will have to be taken by state health department on how it can be done.The fourth Covid-19 patient in the district, the doctor who had travelled from Spain, had exposed 27 passengers on board the QR506 flight from Doha to Thiruvananthapuram on March 2 to risk. Though there were 183 passengers on the flight, 27 who had sat near the patient have been identified as high risk.On Tuesday, the district administration released the flow chart tracking the movement of the person from March 2 to March 3. He visited Hotel Bismi at Kumarapuram at 6pm on March 2 and 3. At 7.30pm on March 3, he visited Hotel Ambadi Kannan at Medical College Jn. At 6pm on March 5 and 5pm on March 10, he was at Hotel Thamarassery Churam, Medical College Jn. From 7.30pm to 8.30pm on March 8, he was at Kunnil Margin Free Market, Medical College Jn and from 5pm to 6pm on March 11, he was at Hotel Kochi Peedia at medical college Jn.

Title: More Cong MLAs will resign: Patel
Content:
Gandhinagar: Deputy chief minister Nitin Patel on Monday hinted at the possibility of more Congress MLAs tendering their resignations before the March 26 Rajya Sabha election. He added that all those who wanted to join the saffron party are welcome.

Speaking to the media in Gandhinagar on Tuesday, Patel said, “As I hear, there will be more resignations by Congress MLAs in the coming days. We are just watching.”Patel said: “I have said earlier that there is groupism within the Congress and I reiterate that irrespective of where the Congress takes its MLAs, many of their legislators have made up their minds to quit the party.” He went on to say: “Those who are willing to go by the BJP’s ideology are welcome in the party.”

Inside the house, Patel took a dig at the Congress MLAs camping in Jaipur, saying they could get infected with coronavirus there. The Congress has moved a majority of its Gujarat MLAs to a resort in Jaipur to prevent horse-trading ahead of the election.

Patel said he will send an email to Rajasthan chief minister Ashok Gehlot and request him to ensure the well-being of the Gujarat MLAs. “The Rajasthan government will be responsible if any of the Gujarat MLAs get infected by coronavirus,” stated Patel, who holds the health portfolio.

He went on to say that the home department should test all Congress MLAs for the virus on the Rajasthan-Gujarat border when they return. He sought permission from the speaker to allow the health department officials to examine them before they enter the state assembly to vote, as they could risk the health of BJP MLAs. Jitu Vaghani, the state BJP president, said the BJP will comfortably win three of the four Rajya Sabha seats. “There will be cross-voting by Congress MLAs in the Rajya Sabha election,” he said.

Title: Covid-19: Chotila temple to remain closed along with three others in Ahmedabad
Content:
TimesView Major temples in the country, including the Siddhivinayak and the Shirdi shrines, have already closed to prevent COVID-19 infections and spread. The Government of Gujarat has put the onus on individual organizers of religious gatherings. While several socio-religious organizations have toned down events or cancelled them, as the Chaitri Navratri is approaching it’s high time the state government issues orders to reduce public gatherings in the interests of public safety.

AHMEDABAD: In the fight against Covid-19, Surendranagar collector K Rajesh decided to close Chotila temple on Tuesday. Along with the famed Chamunda Mata temple, three other temples — Vadvala temple near Wadhwan, Lalji temple at Sayla and a temple in Little Rann of Kutch — are closed as a precautionary step.Officials close to the development said that as the Gujarati month of Chaitra is approaching, the district administration was expecting lakhs of devotees to take part in the darshan and the fair associated with the events.In Ahmedabad, the famed Camp Hanuman temple would be off-limits for the devotees till March 29, mentioned a notification issued by the Ahmedabad Cantonment Board.However, no statewide step has been taken for the religious places. A few of the temples have already initiated online darshan and have appealed to the devotees not to approach the temple if not necessary. Masks and hand sanitizers are already provided to the devotees.Jayanti Ravi, principal secretary (health & family welfare), told media on Tuesday that all the social and religious organizations have been appealed to cancel or postpone their events so as to prevent mass gatherings. “We have not taken any decision on the Chaitri Navratri functions yet. But we are appealing to the organizers to take the call and put the public safety as a priority along with the faith,” she said, adding that the collectors and district administrators are talking to the communities.

Title: ‘Being alone, my husband is stronger than I am’
Content:
In A Freewheeling Chat, The Wife Of The First Patient Who Tested Positive Says That The Four Affected In City Are Keeping Their Spirits High Through WhatsApp Group ‘Corona Pyaar Hai’

Nagpur: “You are a great mother as you didn’t let the virus come near your children. And you are a great wife as you are sharing your husband’s pain,” reads a letter kept on top of a mirror in Asha’s (name changed) isolation ward.Staying at the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) in Nagpur since almost a week, Asha reads the letter written by her 14-year-old daughter few times in a day. It’s the first time that the family has been kept apart this way. “Things changed overnight for us when my husband’s test came positive,” she says.Before the family could reconcile itself to the fact that Rakesh (name changed) has been diagnosed with one of the world’s deadliest disease , Asha too was tested positive for coronavirus . “Unlike my husband, I showed no symptoms,” she says.Rakesh returned to India from USA on March 6 from a business trip with his colleagues. An IT professional, he was complaining of fever and sore throat since he came back.“Initially, we went to our family physician. My husband started feeling better but around March 9, he was feverish again. With the news of coronavirus getting viral, our doctor advised us to get him tested,” recalls Asha.Rakesh went to Mayo hospital for the tests. The same night, his results were out. “The next morning, my in-laws, two kids and I were taken for tests. Except for me, all tested negative,” says Asha.Though Asha had taken conscious efforts to make certain that the children don’t enter their room when Rakesh was sick, she being an altruist wife could not keep the virus away.Rakesh, who is “guilty of passing on the disease” to his wife, is kept in an isolation ward at Mayo Hospital. His two colleagues who accompanied him to USA and have also been tested positive are with Asha in the same hospital. “I would say Rakesh is mentally stronger than me. After all, he is alone there,” she says.‘Corona Pyaar Hai’ (a WhatsApp group) is what is keeping all four of them connected to combat loneliness. “We keep sending motivational messages to each other and keep constant touch. During this adversity, we are trying everything possible to find our source of happiness,” says Asha.A trainer of Montessori teachers, she spends a lot of her time ideating new teaching concepts. “The best part amid all this is the cooperation I am getting from the hospital staff. They are taking care of all my requirements — be it a table, a pair of scissors glue or anything else,” she adds.While battling the disease, the mother of two is finding solace not just in solitude but also spirituality. “Reading Gita is helping me retain my sangfroid. I have come to believe that when human limits end, God’s begin,” she says.Not once during the 21-minute-long phone call with TOI did she sound downhearted. The only overpowering emotion that came across was gratitude — for proactive doctors, her strong kids, concerned relatives and friends and the sweepers who “take a big risk but come every day to clean her ward”.Asha is pragmatic enough not to let the social stigma attached with the disease affect her. “If I was on the other side of the world, I would have probably behaved the same way. The fear is natural. It took me time to accept this. Had you called me yesterday, I would have not been in a condition to speak with you,” she tells TOI.Asha wants everyone to pray for her and the family. “I know we are going to come out of this very soon. And when that happens, I will personally thank everyone who stood by us. After all, it’s during the worst storms of your life that you get to know who stand with you,” Asha hangs up with a “see you soon”.

Title: Covid-19: Competitive exam coaching in Ahmedabad goes online
Content:
Some of the centres are even conducting live lectures.

AHMEDABAD: After the state health department announced shutdown of educational institutions, coaching classes and even cinema halls and swimming pools, students taking competitive exams and their parents were left concerned over their studies. However, a number of coaching classes across Ahmedabad have begun taking mock tests online and making study modules available online.

“We have made video lectures available and the syllabus is on track. Even the mock tests we conduct have been taken on the online platform and WhatsApp groups have been created for students to discuss any difficulties they face or even to monitor their syllabus,” said Tushar Parekh , vice-president of a city-based coaching centre for National Eligibility Entrance Test (NEET) and Joint Entrance Examination (JEE)

“Students are also free to call up teachers as all the classes have been suspended,” he added.

Some of the centres are even conducting live lectures. “After shutting classes, we have begun with telecasting all the lectures live which students can access with user IDs and password. We also upload the solutions online and if there is any confusion among students, they can always approach the faculty over the phone,” said the manager of another coaching class.

Rakesh Bothra, owner of a city-based coaching centre, said, “We have strictly shut the classes and asked students not to come in the interest of public health. The preparations and modules will be conducted online with virtual classes running. The batches for class 11 will begin after April, based on situation.”

Title: Urgent matters only at subordinate courts
Content:
Ahmedabad: A day after it decided for itself to hear urgent matters only in the wake of Covid-19, the Gujarat high court on Tuesday ordered all subordinate courts across Gujarat to follow the suit till March 31 and postpone all trials for three weeks.

In a circular, the HC registrar said, “The district courts and other subordinate courts are instructed to entertain urgent matters only, such as bail applications, temporary injunction applicants, remand matters, etc. the trial in all other cases be postponed for a period of three weeks from today.” The courts have been asked not to insist on presence of litigants unless unavoidable. They will consider favourably the exemption requests by accused, witnesses etc.

The courts will have to conduct remand proceedings through video-conferencing as far as possible. The lawyers have been instructed to discourage their clients from visiting court premises.

The prison authorities have also been asked to avoid crowding of prisoners. The Bar associations are instructed not to allow gathering of lawyers on court premises. Interns have been prohibited for next two weeks. The court staffs, who suffer from cold, are instructed to follow medical advice strictly.

Meanwhile, all Bar associations insisted the respective courts to curtail their functioning so that possible coronavirus spread can be contained. City’s family court immediately followed the HC instructions and put up a notice informing litigants not to remain present in court till March 31.

Meanwhile, chief justice of Gujarat high court Vikram Nath on Tuesday inspected various facilities on the campus and issued necessary instructions. The HC has also ordered all principal district judges to supervise court premises to maintain cleanliness standards.

Title: Snack seller dies in lock-up of Varachha police station
Content:
Varachha cops claimed that Dipak Modi suffered a fit inside the lock-up

Surat: A 49-year-old snack seller died in lock-up of Varachha police station here on Tuesday. Preliminary medical examination revealed that the man died after he had a fit. Family members staged a protest outside postmortem room in SMIMER hospital and demanded action against the cop who arrested him. The man was arrested as a preventive measure. The inquiry into circumstances leading to his death will be conducted by C K Patel, assistant commissioner of police, A division.

Police claimed that Dipak Modi suffered a fit in the lock-up of Varachha police station at around 1.30pm and was shifted to SMIMER hospital where doctors declared him brought dead at around 2pm. Police suspect that Modi died in the lock-up because of the fit. Police are yet to find out if Modi was a patient of epilepsy or he suffered the fit for first time.

"Postmortem report will reveal how he died. Family members are not revealing his medical history,” said a police officer at Varachha police station.

A panel of doctors would conduct postmortem on the body and the whole process will be videographed.

Modi was picked up by police from a spot on A K Road near his roadside cart for selling khaman. "He was not at his cart, but found at a nearby location. There was no specific complaint against him, but we had information that he may get involved in some criminal activity. Thus, he was arrested as a preventive measure,” said C K Patel.

Police sources said Modi was involved in gambling activity and this is why he was arrested.

On March 11, 30-year-old Vimal Yadav, a worker, had also died under mysterious circumstances in the lock-up of Pandesara police station. His family alleged that police did not shift him to hospital despite he feeling breathlessness in the lock-up. Inquiry into his death is being done by assistant commissioner of police, F division.

Title: Goa: Private doctors must report Covid-19, H1N1 cases to govt
Content:
PANAJI: The Goa government on Tuesday framed new rules mandating that doctors and hospitals must report all Covid-19 and H1N1 (swine flu) cases to the directorate of health services. The government identified them as notifiable diseases under the Goa, Daman and Diu Public Health Act, 1985.

Last week, the government invoked the Epidemic Act, 1897, to better combat the Covid-19. A health official said that not all private practitioners notify cases treated by them, and so, it does not give them a correct picture of diseases.

Title: Temple priest dies in Amona road accident
Content:
Bicholim: A temple priest died in an motorcycle accident late Sunday night at Amona after he was blinded by the lights of an oncoming vehicle.

Bicholim police said Abhay Vasant Paranjape, 44, resident of Gokulwadi , was proceeding towards Ponda at 10.30pm on Sunday. He was travelling with a pillion. On reaching the Amona junction, he lost control and sustained head injuries as his helmet was not clipped. He succumbed to injuries while being shifted to GMC.

Title: HC notice to EC over Congress MLA’s plea
Content:
Ahmedabad: The Gujarat high court on Tuesday issued notice to the Election Commission of India and the district authorities concerned over a petition filed by the Congress MLA from Dhanera, Natha Patel, who expressed apprehension that his voting rights for the Rajya Sabha elections may be taken away at the behest of the ruling BJP.

While the bench of Justice Sonia Gokani and Justice Gita Gopi sought a reply on Patel’s allegations, the state government assured that it would not initiate any action against Patel till next hearing, which is on March 20. Patel was seeking protection at least till the RS polls. Last week, a bench headed by Justice J B Pardiwala recused itself from hearing the matter. In his petition, Patel claimed that his voting rights might be taken away ahead of the RS polls. He said that a local BJP leader Mukesh Thakkar recently filed a complaint before the Banaskantha district collector claiming that Patel had suppressed “many things” while filing his affidavits for the 2017 assembly elections. Patel’s disqualification is sought by Thakkar under section 125 of the Representation of People Act. On basis of this complaint, the district collector ordered local police and Dhanera constituency’s returning officer to undertake an inquiry and necessary steps. tnn

Title: Savarkar to Jinnah: Signs of fresh row at JNU
Content:
Sign defaced to read BR Ambedkar Marg

Picture of Jinnah removed, black paint erased to show the BR Ambedkar Marg inscription again

Ambedkar’s name blacked out from the signboard and a picture of Muhammad Ali Jinnah pasted on it

NEW DELHI: Controversy never seems to leave Jawaharlal Nehru University alone. While students and university authorities are wrangling over the closure of hostels after suspension of classes due to the threat of the novel coronavirus, there is also an anachronistic war under way over signboards.After a lane was named after Hindutva stalwart V D Savarkar , the signboard was vandalised and the name of B R Ambedkar inscribed over it on Monday night. But early on Tuesday, even that was the target of defacers, who blacked out the name and pasted a picture of Mohammad Ali Jinnah at the side.The signboard was cleaned on Tuesday evening by the RSS-affiliated Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad , though the name of Ambedkar remained. The student organisation alleged that Jinnah’s picture was the handiwork of Left student groups, but said it didn’t know who had replaced Savarkar’s name with Ambedkar’s.“The JNU administration took the decision last year to name the various roads on the campus. Therefore, the road near Subansir Hostel was named after Savarkar ,” said ABVP JNU president Shivam Chaurasia. “However, the leftist students took midnight action to deface the road sign with the Mohammad Ali Jinnah poster.”While condemning the act, Chaurasia also alluded to the left students painting graffiti on the walls of the administration block last year during the agitation against the hostel fee hike. Chaurasia, however, had no clue to who had inscribed the name of Ambedkar on the signboard.It was JNUSU president Aishe Ghosh who, in a tweet at 1.11am on Tuesday, posted the image of the defaced signboard bearing Ambedkar’s name. Alongside she wrote, “We can never ever accept apologists and stooges of the British who undermined our secular fabric. Let’s respect those who gave us our Constitution.”JNUSU itself denied involvement in the issue but declared, “JNU believes in the ideals of Bhagat Singh and Ambedkar, not Savarkar or Jinnah as ABVP does” and charged the saffron student organisation with “crossing all levels of shamelessness” and “maligning JNU by circulating morphed images of the road in the name of Jinnah”.JNU Teachers’ Federation, breakaway faction of JNU Teachers’ Association, condemned the vandalism and accused the miscreants of trying to “vitiate the peaceful environment” and called for the immediate identification and punishment.JNU vice-chancellor M Jagadesh Kumar explained that the naming of different roads on the campus had been approved by the Executive Council based on the recommendations of the campus development committee in 2016. “In the past two years, several roads have been named after great personalities,” Kumar said. “Last night some miscreants indulged in defacing the road signage. This is highly regrettable. In an educational institution, one can disagree intellectually but stooping to such acts is unwarranted.”

Title: Covid-19 test, treatment in city pvt set-up still a distant dream
Content: Nagpur: Even though government of India has decided to allow private laboratories accredited by National Accreditation Board for Laboratories (NABL) to conduct tests for novel coronavirus (Covid-19), Nagpurians are not going to get this facility in near future.At present, the city has only one laboratory that fulfils all conditions for Covid-19 tests. However, the health department has not issued any directives in this regard yet.Similarly, Maharashtra health minister Rajesh Tope said on Tuesday that private hospitals can treat Covid-19 positive patients in their isolation wards. However, no private hospital in the city has isolation ward that meets the required criteria for Covid-19 treatment. This means suspects and patients in Vidarbha willing to undergo tests and treatment in private hospitals will have to rely only on government set-up at least for a considerable period.At present, only government labs are permitted to conduct Covid-19 tests and positive patients are treated in isolation wards of the government hospitals only.Central guidelines allow testing only for symptomatic individuals with travel history to affected countries. There are many who are symptomatic, but do not fit the current criteria. Central government has said that all such persons who wish to undergo tests can do so in private labs. But the city has only one such lab ready for conducting the tests after getting a go ahead from health department.“Several labs in Nagpur have NABL-accreditation, but this is not enough to conduct Covid-19 tests,” said Dr Madhavi Deshmukh, vice-president of Vidarbha Association of Medical Microbiologists (VAMM). “Labs must have necessary equipment, ambience, isolation facilities, technicians trained in National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, and the testing agent which is to be provided by government agencies,” she said.Presently, Dhruv Pathology and Molecular Diagnostic Lab is the only one in Nagpur where the tests can be started immediately.“We have trained technicians, polymerase chain reaction (PCR) machines with open platform. We use same ABS system which is used in Indira Gandhi Government Medical College & Hospital (IGGMCH). I have personally informed health department that our lab is fully equipped and willing to conduct these tests. Authorities have asked us to wait as the state is yet to release permissions for private labs,” said Dr Shailendra Mundhada , managing director of Dhruv Lab.Dr Sandeep Yadav, president of Maharashtra Association of Practising Pathologists and Microbiologists, said there are only a few such labs in the state. “As there are only some labs that fit into the government criteria at present, instead of allowing private labs, government should rather focus on strengthening lab facilities at GMCHs,” he said.Private hospitals not ready: VHAMany Covid-19 patients may be willing to get treatment in private hospitals, but no corporate hospital in Nagpur is designed for it, said Dr Anup Marar, secretary of Vidarbha Hospitals Association (VHA).“We can’t provide separate isolation, separate air conditioning and oxygenation to Covid-19 patients. Instead, we have suggested government to take over one full hospital with less occupancy. Other hospitals will provide necessary infrastructure and trained staff, if necessary. We can’t admit these patients in our existing set-ups,” he said.During swine flu outbreak, many private hospitals experienced that patients admitted to other wards left as soon as they came to know about serious patients being treated in the same building. Because of this, not many private hospitals will come forward to treat Covid-19 patients.Govt Is Only HopeCentre has permitted private labs to conduct Covid-19 testsThe test, which is conducted free in govt labs, may cost up to Rs9,000 in pvt set-upState health minister has permitted pvt hospitals to treat Covid-19 positive patientsBut, not many private labs or hospitals in Nagpur fulfil required criteriaLabs may have NABL accreditation, but don’t have PCR machines, separate premises etcCorporate hospitals don’t have separate entrance, isolation wards, separate oxygenation, air conditioning and trained staff to treat such patients

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: Punjab and Haryana high court suspends all judicial work barring urgent cases
Content: CHANDIGARH: Judicial work in the Punjab and Haryana high court remained suspended on Monday due to fear of the coronavirus spread. However, the high court administration has decided that all anticipatory bails/habeas corpus/protection matters will be listed according to the prevalent filing system on Tuesday. In case of urgency, the matter will be listed only by mentioning.The HC administration has also decided that those who are not directly involved/associated with a matter listed before any court shall not be permitted to enter the premises. Advocates have also been requested to opt for e-filing, unless unavoidable.All ordinary/regular list cases, however, will be adjourned. In case of urgency in ordinary list mentioning will be made before the respective bench and accordingly case will be posted in urgent for next day or thereafter. However, in cases of states/UTs/Union of India, an advance notice of mentioning has to be made by the counsel to the respective representative of the state/UT/government of India, the HC administration has decided.The decision was taken on Monday by the high court administrative committee led by Chief Justice of the Punjab and Haryana high court.The meeting was also attended by advocate generals of both the states of Punjab and Haryana, standing counsel, Chandigarh administration and assistant solicitor general of India, who represented the Union government.

Title: Social distancing does not mean social boycott
Content: Nagpur: After four persons tested positive for coronavirus , their families are being ostracized, not only by the society, but also by their friends and relatives.Even those working with the patients’ families as maids and guards are now facing the heat. They, too, are being boycotted. Some of them have even lost their jobs because they were employed at the homes of patients Expressing concern, social workers have urged citizens to support the families of patients and not to ostracize them.Warning those who have distanced themselves from the affected families due to the fear that they might contract the disease, social workers said it’s time to stand united, with precautions.Leading by example, mayor Sandip Joshi , accompanied by wife Devyani paid a visit to one of the affected families and assured them of all the support possible. Both husband and wife from this family tested positive and have been put up at different hospitals. Their teenaged children are at home, close to their grandparents who reside in an adjacent house. The city’s first couple also plans to visit families of the other two patients in next couple of days.“I decided to visit their place after coming across disturbing reports regarding ostracization of their kin. People must understand that the patients and their relatives are not criminals or leprosy patients. They are just normal human beings who have been infected. In all likelihood, they will be cured soon. One does needs to take care while meeting them, but boycotting them is criminal,” Joshi told TOI.He pointed out that even the maid, employed with the patient couple’s family, was thrown out of her home by her landlord and another one was asked to discontinue work by neighbours.“Civic workers are not collecting garbage from their house. People should stand by such families and encourage them to fight the menace. My purpose of visiting them was to give them support and encouragement and to convey the message that we are solidly behind them,” said Joshi.An employee of an IT firm, whose three employees tested positive, said that he, too, faced a similar problem after he uploaded his videos on social media. “After I came in contact with three of my colleagues, I decided to self quarantine myself at home. I uploaded my videos for a noble cause to create awareness, but people took them in the negative sense. They thought that I had contracted the virus. I was forced to upload a new video to dispel doubts. I clarified that I’m just taking precautionary measures,” he said.Social workers like Smita Singalkar felt that people shouldn’t distance themselves from patients or their families and should be kind to them.“People should take steps like wearing masks before meeting patients or their families, but boycotting them won’t serve the purpose. The government should also ensure that masks and sanitizers are made available in sufficient quantity,” she said.Even patients, who talked to TOI over phone, said they were concerned about their families, especially after their names were disclosed through social media. “I experienced this feeling when people started distancing themselves at home and in hospital despite the fact that I’m in good condition. Even our families are suffering,” a patient told TOI.

Title: Man gets life term for raping minor
Content:
Surat: A 25-year-old man was convicted for rape of a 16-year-old girl and sentenced to 10 years in jail by a local court on Tuesday. The convict forcibly took the minor to his home in August 2016 and had raped her there.

Shyamu Mishra, a resident of Udhna, was convicted by a court for rape under sections of Indian Penal Code and Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act (POCSCO). He was sentenced to 10 years in jail.

Mishra pulled the minor to his room when she was coming out of a common bathroom in the house on August 13. In her complaint the minor alleged that she was harassed by the convict in the past as well after which her father had sent her away to Mumbai at a relative's place. The survivor returned to the city after she fell ill.

Scientific and medical evidences collected by police proved the charges. Police had recovered clothes of the convict and the minor from which samples for forensic examination were collected.

Title: Gujarat: ‘Promote students to higher classes’
Content: AHMEDABAD: Amid growing concerns of coronavirus pandemic, the Gujarat Rajya Shala Sanchalak Mahamandal (GRSSM) has in an internal meeting suggested that all students from class 1 to class IX be promoted to a higher standard based on their performance in half-yearly and internal exams.At a convention of GRSSM held in Ahmedabad, it was also proposed that the new academic year, which was to begin from April 20, should be postponed to July.“The new academic session should begin from first week of July and schools should remain closed till then. We hope that by that time the coronavirus threat would be gone,” said Bhaskar Patel , president of GRSSM. He further said they would make representation to the state government about the recommendations they have made at their Tuesday meet.The convention was attended only by the general secretaries, president and vice-president of the association as a precautionary measure to the pandemic disease.Among others, the school management association has suggested that self-financed and grant-in aid schools having student strength of less than 30 be allowed to function if the school management wishes to do so.In order to bring uniformity to the academic years of the central board and the state board, the state education department has decided to begin the academic year from April instead of June.

Title: Masks in place, colours of faith fly high at Zambaulim
Content:
MARGAO: Notwithstanding the restrictions on mass gatherings in view of the coronavirus scare, Madgaonkars kept their tryst with their patron deity Lord Damodar, or Dambab, as the deity is reverentially known, as they flocked to Zambaulim to celebrate the annual ‘gulal’.

It’s their ardent belief that Dambab plays gulal with the Madgaonkars on this auspicious day. However, a large number of revellers were seen masks in a bid to ward off the threat of the virus as advised by the Ramnath Damodar Devasthan committee.

As the ‘Zambaulecho Gulal’ got underway, it was a riot of colours. Shouts of ‘Shree Ramnath Damodar Maharaj ki Jai!’ and ‘Har Har Mahadev’ rant the air as devotees flung fistfuls of gulal at the ‘palakhi’ carrying the idol of Lord Damodar stationed in the courtyard of Shree Ramnath Devasthan.

History has it that the original temple of Lord Damodar was located in the area known as ‘Madd’ in Margao, which is now referred to as ‘Lingakadden’ and where the ancient temple tank still stands. During the early conquests by the Portuguese in the 16th century, locals attempted to shift the Shivling to a safer place, but only managed to sever a part of it which they shifted to Zambaulim where the current temple of Shree Damodar stands.

It’s in honour of Shree Ramnath and with a sense of gratitude to Him for offering his place for Lord Damodar that Dambab’s palakhi is brought to the temple of Shree Ramnath, on the night preceding the Gulal.

The week-long Shishirotsav at Zambaulim began with the arrival of the traditional nal’l (holy coconut) from the house of late Purushottam Keni in Comba , Margao, to Damodar temple, Zambaulim, in a grand procession, on Thursday.

‘Dhulpeth’ is celebrated the day after Gulal, which is famous for the sumptuous meals served to the devotees that day. The shigmotsav culminates with the immersion of the nal’l into the river on the conclusion of Dhulpeth.

Title: Testing times as MCH facility works non-stop
Content:
Thiruvananthapuram: A small team led by the Government Medical College Hospital’s department of microbiology has been working round the clock to test the large inflow of samples with primary and secondary contact numbers rising in the district. The facility, which opened on March 11, tested over 100 samples in the first five days. By Sunday, the team had completed testing of 135 samples.

With the administration opening new collection centres in the district, samples from these centres are being added to those from the corona clinic at MCH. Samples from private hospitals in the city are also being tested at the facility.

The team is now equipped with confirmatory kits to deliver faster results; which means that the samples tested positive at the MCH lab need no longer be sent to the NIV facility in Alappuzha for confirmation. This is proving crucial especially as time is of the essence in preventing spread of the infection.

The team, comprising research assistants, molecular biology scientists, technicians led by head of microbiology, are not even following specified duty hours simply due to sheer number of samples being handled.

The technology used for detecting the virus is called polymerase chain reaction (PCR) and tests are done using real-time PCR thermal cyclers/thermocyclers.

On the opening day the team tested three samples, which soon jumped to 20-40 samples a day.

What was initially a two-member team soon inducted two molecular scientists from the pathology department as sample numbers increased with each passing day.

The first 10 samples and test results were sent to NIV Pune, which validated the test results and quality-control measures. This was a shot in the arm for the team.

While a PCR machine can load 20 samples at a time, preparation takes 5 hours with loading taking 1.5 hours. It takes nearly 6.5 hours to get the result. The team then carries out a reconfirmation test which takes same amount of time.

The team members wear personal protection kits while loading samples.

All precautions taken by a doctor during treatment or collection of the swab specimen of an infected patient are followed in the lab as well.

The team, which is already working overtime, knows that they are in for more challenging days ahead as more primary contacts are tracked down and samples are collected from latest cases.

Title: CRly cancels 18 trains to Pune, Mumbai from Nag till Mar 31
Content:
Nagpur: In a bid to curb spread of novel coronavirus (Covid-19) infection, the Central Railway has cancelled 29 trains which were scheduled to run from March 18 to March 31. Eighteen of the cancelled trains are from Nagpur and some passing through the city.

The railways also decided to increase platform ticket price fourfold from the present Rs10 to Rs50 to prevent overcrowding at six major stations. The new rates have been made applicable with immediate effect at Nagpur, Chandrapur, Ballarshah, Wardha, Betul and Sewagram stations.

“On an average, 5,200 platform tickets are sold at Nagpur. The decision has been taken to avoid crowding at the station,” said assistant commercial manager (ACM) SG Rao.

Sources, however, said that the number of visitors on platforms could be even more.

“At times, more people come to see off passengers than the actual number of travellers. We need to avoid crowding to keep coronavirus at bay,” said railway officials.

However, passengers need not panic over cancellation of trains towards Mumbai, Pune and Howrah. The 18 trains that have been cancelled between March 18 to 31 have low occupancy. Some trains operate weekly and twice a week.

Regular mail/express trains like Pune-Nagpur, Garib Rath, Gondia-CSMT Vidarbha, Sewagram, Maharashtra have not been cancelled. Barring Nandigram Express, the other trains that have been cancelled are weekly or bi-weekly trains.

The trains that have been cancelled include 11201-11202 LTT-Ajni-LTT, 22135/22136 Nagpur-Rewa-Nagpur, 11401-11402 Nagpur-CSMT-Nagpur Nandigram, 11417-11418 Nagpur-Pune-Nagpur, 22139-22140 Ajni-Pune-Ajni, 22111-22112 Bhusawal-Nagpur-Bhusawal & 12261-12262 CSMT-Howrah-CSMT Duronto. Six weekly special trains between Nagpur-Solapur-Nagpur (02111-02112 & 02113-02114) have also been cancelled.

Railway officials said occupancy of the trains that have been cancelled will be adjusted in regular trains to Pune, where otherwise the number of travellers has gone down.

Bharatiya Yatri Kendra (BYK) general secretary Basant Shukla has welcomed the decision to hike platform ticket rates. “Officials should keep all the exit and entry gates open so that crowding is minimised. Also, the number of reservation counters should be increased,” Shukla said.

In the last 15 days from March 1 to 14, the Nagpur division of Central Railway has refunded over Rs5.25 crore towards cancellation of tickets by 82,725 passengers. Most of these passengers had plans to travel towards Pune and Mumbai.

Title: Fed up of illness, mother kills son, self in Nana Varachha
Content:
Surat: A 34-year-old wife of a diamond artisan allegedly killed her three-year-old son and ended her own life by consuming poisonous substance at home in Nana Varachha on Monday.

Before killing herself, she fed the poisonous substance to her son and strangled him to death, police investigation revealed. Family members told police that the woman and her son were suffering from some prolonged illness and this is suspected to be the reason behind such drastic step.

Diamond artisan Atul Dhaduk found the bodies of his wife Shital and son Parthiv when he returned home from work in the evening.

Family members told police that Shital was suffering from high blood pressure while her son Parthiv had some respiratory problem. As they were not keeping well for the last few days, they went to stay with Shital's brother in Pasodara village adjoining the city.

On Monday afternoon, Shital told brother that she was feeling better and said he wanted to return home.

Traces of poisonous material were found in body of both the deceased in preliminary postmortem report. Doctors found strangulation mark on face and neck of the child.

Police are registering statements of the family members, relatives and neighbours to find out the more details.

Title: Coronavirus in Amritsar: Quarantined, group says misbehaved with
Content:
Police personnel wearing facemasks speak with Indians who arrived from Spain, at an isolation facility in Amri... Read More

AMRITSAR: Ten Indian passengers, who have been kept in a makeshift quarantine centre in Amritsar upon arrival from Spain via Doha on Sunday midnight, have complained of poor hygiene and illtreatment by staff.

Out of the 11 travellers, one had cough and fever, and which he was shifted to the isolation ward of Guru Nanak Dev Hospital on Monday morning. After the passengers and their relatives went to the press over hygiene at the centre, the civil surgeon’s office released pictures of bathrooms to show hygiene maintained by them.

The passengers had arrived by Qatar Airways, from Doha to Amritsar, on Sunday past midnight. All of them had originated from Spain. As they landed at Amritsar’s Sri Guru Ram Das International Airport, they were frisked to the quarantine centre set up at Swami Vivekanand De-addiction & Rehabilitation Centre.

The passengers talked to journalists from across the iron gate of the centre and complained that beds were soiled, bathrooms were dirty and they were maltreated by staff. Outside the centre, their relatives threatened to block the road if they were not allowed to go since they claimed that none of them had the symptoms of coronavirus.

The administration had erected the quarantine facility for incoming travellers, including Indians, from seven countries — China, Italy, Iran, Korea, France, Spain and Germany — for 15 days.

A medical officer who didn’t wish to give his name said they would examine the patients on Tuesday and decide on whether to keep them for rest of 14 days or allow them to go.
