He said a person had been admitted on March 4 and was tested positive for Covid-19. He said the man was stable, while two of his relatives, who were tested negative, were still in the isolation ward along with one of the 11 passengers who had arrived on Sunday past midnight.

Amritsar deputy commissioner Shivdular Singh Dhillon said people should cooperate with the administration to check the virus’s spread as it was for everyone’s benefit. On the allegations of misbehaviour, he said, according to his reports, passengers also misbehaved with staff and kept them awake all night.

Title: Hyderabad: Locals to rope in priests to curb plastic in puja items
Content:
Water was drained out recently from Kapra Lake for desiltation

SECUNDERABAD: Residents of Sainikpuri have decided to rope in the Brahmin and Pujari communities along with resident welfare associations to urge people to avoid plastic items in ‘puja samagri’ and prevent plastic pollution at Kapra Lake.

The Kapra Lake is undergoing major overhaul what with the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation (GHMC) desilting the lake and developing walking tracks. While the GHMC is doing its bit of connecting storm water drains and diversion of polluted water to a channel, residents have come forward to educate the people, temple committees and Brahmin and Pujari communities in the vicinity on zero waste.

Every year, over 4,000 idols are immersed at the lake, spread over an expansive 113 acres. The immersion pond is only used during the festive season with people disposing the puja items inside the lake throughout the year.

“We have identified five temples in the neighbouring colonies, members of which will be educated on the zero waste initiative. We will be inviting both pujaris as well as temple committee members,” said Chandrasekhar, secretary of Federation of North-Eastern Colonies of Secunderabad.

While the first meeting with all the stakeholders was planned on Sunday, it was subsequently postponed owing to the state government’s restrictions on public meetings. “We have postponed our proposed meeting with Brahmin & Pujari Sanghams in view of the present situation. The state government had imposed ban on public meetings and seminars till March 31 as precautionary measures to curtail further spread of coronavirus,” tweeted Green Sainikpuri, the official handle representing Sainikpuri residents, who now plan to hold the meeting in the first week of April.

The residents are also planning to install a bin near the immersion pond that can be used to dump puja waste instead of disposing it in the lake. Residents plan to have vermicompost pits in every temple in the neighbouring colonies near Kapra Lake.

On a pilot basis, residents of Sai Baba Officers colony (SBO colony) have started converting garden waste leaves and kitchen waste into vermicompost. The residents intend to extend the model to other colonies too. “In SBO colony, we are using few open plots for cultivation of vegetables and nursery. We collect saplings from residents and multiply them,” said Chandrasekhar.

Title: Over 90% buildings face threat of triple property tax
Content:
Nagpur: Over 90% buildings in the city are facing the threat of paying triple property tax if plans of municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe materialize. Mundhe announced that the Nagpur Municipal Corporation (NMC) will levy triple property tax on buildings lacking occupancy certificate (OC).

He presented the NMC’s budget before the standing committee on Monday. A standing committee member told TOI that Mundhe made an announcement in this regard in his budget speech.

On Tuesday, Mundhe said, “OC is mandatory as per building rules. There is a provision in the rules to recover two times more property tax for violation of building bylaws. Therefore, it is expected from all owners of buildings and builders to obtain OC so that they are not penalized. NMC will give them a chance to obtain OC and then start penalizing,” he said.

OC is mandatory for every building since introduction of the Maharashtra Regional and Town Planning (MRTP) Act, 1966. The state government had made it mandatory for all urban local bodies to recover triple property tax on unauthorized constructions since the last eight years.

NMC had levied penalty property tax only on a very few buildings. There are over 3,000 buildings which were served notices under the MRTP Act. But, the civic body did not levy penalty on all such buildings.

Congress corporator Praful Gudadhe said, “Mundhe’s decision is not justified. Over 95% buildings do not have OC. It is the mistake of NMC and NIT for not implementing rules effectively all these years. Also, a building cannot be termed as unauthorized if it lacks OC. The number of individual buildings is high, so many will suffer. Instead, NMC should hold special camps, regularize unauthorized structures in compounding scheme and then compel for OC,” he said.

BJP corporator Virendra Kukreja said, “I came to know that Mundhe announced it in his budget but it will be an anti-public move. There are many buildings which can’t get sanction due to hassles in ownership titles. It should be implemented only on flat schemes and malls, that too by allowing internal changes,” he said.

Credai president Mahesh Sadhwani said NMC should not implement it with retrospective effect. “I also feel that all buildings should have OC. Therefore, NMC should implement it on buildings which will be given sanction from now onwards. It will consume a lot time and also need many documents for getting OC for existing buildings,” he said.

Rules and lack of implementation

OC is mandatory for all buildings since introduction of MRTP Act, 1966

Over 90% buildings do not have OC in city due to ineffective implementation of rules by NMC and NIT for all these years

State government made it mandatory for urban local bodies to recover triple property tax from unauthorized constructions in 2012

It means property tax will become Rs3,000 if existing tax is Rs1,000 till demolition or regularization of unauthorized construction

NMC levied it only on a very few unauthorized buildings

It did not even levy it on buildings which were served notices under MRTP Act

Municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe has announced that NMC will start levying triple property tax on buildings lacking OC

Mundhe said a chance will be given for obtaining OC first

Title: Private firms explore work from home options for employees in Coimbatore
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: Many offices in the city are in the process of going into lockdown mode. Many of them are arranging laptops for employees, who are asked to get WiFi connections to start working from home. Many foundries in the city that don’t offer the work from home option are trying to improve sanitation and ventilation at their places.

Fearing a sudden government instruction to remain closed for a specific period, many offices had on Monday begun the process of making their employees work from home. Prominent electric and home appliances firm Bosch on Monday instructed all their employees in the city to work from home from Tuesday to Friday, when they would be issued fresh instructions.

Ashish P (name changed), an employee, said, “The company is taking the next four days like a trial to see how work from home will suit the firm, so that it is prepared if the government asks it to shut down.”

The human resources and information technology staff of an IT company in Saravanampatti is frantically in the process of hiring laptops for employees, who do not have one, and loading their work software on to them and arranging server access. “We want to be ready with infrastructure for our 3000-odd staff to work from home by Wednesday if the government orders it,” the HR said.

Manufacturing companies, which cannot give their employees a work from home option, are a worried lot. “We have been taking some measures like keeping windows open, placing sanitizers at the entry and exit of every unit and asking our employees to wash their hands every few hours,” said Santhosh H, a factory manager of a foundry in Chinna Vedampatti . “We are also trying to ensure no crowding of employees in any spot while working.”

The fitness freaks in the city, who regularly workout from gyms, were disappointed when the state government ordered all gyms to be closed. Though gym operators have promised home workout videos and workout plans that could be done at home, people are disappointed. “Not all of us have the right flooring or equipment like timers. They have now banned outdoor gyms too. Now, we have no option but to simply run or walk,” said Shireen B, a postpartum mother on a weight loss diet.

Title: Two held for hit-and-run of Valpoi priest
Content:
Valpoi: Valpoi police on Monday arrested two brothers in connection with the hit-and-run on Sunday at Advoi which claimed the life of Valpoi parish priest Fr Daniel Alfonso.

Police said that Sahil Sadekar, 24, resident of Tarwada-Colvale surrendered at Valpoi police station early Monday morning bringing along the four-wheeler he was driving at the time of accident. He was immediately arrested.

Police added that at the time of the accident on Sunday, his brother Nakul Sadekar , 23, came to Valpoi police station and falsely confessed that he had been driving the vehicle and was responsible for Alfonso’s death.

He has also been arrested for providing wrong information. On Sunday night, over 100 people gathered at the police station and demanded the arrest of the main accused. PSI Sarvesh Gaddi is investigating the case under the supervision of PI Shivram Vaingankar.

Alfonso’s remains were brought to Valpoi on Tuesday at 11am and a memorial mass was held at 4pm. The funeral will be held on Wednesday at 3pm at Aldona church, followed by a burial.

Title: Face police action if you spread coronavirus rumours in Kolkata
Content: KOLKATA: Kolkata Police has set up special teams — both at Lalbazar and in each police division — to flag down and take action against widespread rumour-mongering regarding the Covid-19 scare. The cops have decided to take the carrot and stick policy in this regard — it will be encouraging for those who bring baseless rumours to the police’s notice, while legal action will be taken against all those spreading canards.Special drives have already been undertaken across the city where cops are trying to reach out to the community asking them to desist from any speculation. The cop action comes amid reports of Odisha police arresting a person for spreading Covid-19 related rumours and the social media being flooded with “home grown remedies” and theories about the outbreak.Police commissioner Anuj Sharma himself led from the front with a tweet in Bengali on Tuesday morning. “Do not listen to rumours or pay heed to them. Do not believe anything unless checking its veracity and truthfulness. Take all precautionary steps to stop the spread of the coronavirus. Stay safe, stay healthy,” he tweeted. His tweet got 60 tweets and 220 likes within a short span of time.The Behala police division — officially the southwest division — has promised to take out a tableau in the area on Wednesday. “We will highlight on how it is important not to spread fake news and rumours as that can only manifold the care and stop people from taking proper care,” said DC (SWD) Nilanjan Biswas.The cyber and social media cells of Kolkata Police are keeping an eye on the social media. Sources said that it was necessary to act given a section of men was selling fakes evoking God while others were living in false beliefs neither propagated by the state administration and World Health Organization (WHO) nor any established doctor.A senior IPS officer said that “forwarding unverified message as true in effect was fostering nothing less than creating fakes”. He recounted how once — after a fake message went viral — he had to call up the control room and verify facts. “In case of any misinformation or when you feel unsure about a piece of information, do get in touch with the nearest cop or police station. We urge all individuals to carry the numbers of the local police stations,” he said.

Title: Bhopal: Chouhan warns officials not to ‘pressure’ BJP MLAs
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Amid political crisis in Madhya Pradesh, tight security arrangements have been made at the hotels where BJP MLAs have been lodged for the last two days.

About 106 MLAs, who aborted their plan to fly to a private hotel in Manesar of Gurugram, were shifted to two private resorts in Sehore, 40 km from the state capital, to keep the MLAs away from the Congress leaders.

Former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan also reached the resort on Monday evening and stayed for the night before leaving for Governor's house on Tuesday morning. Chouhan accompanied by BJP state chief VD Sharma, discussed current political situation with the MLAs and also warned the government officials to desist from putting undue pressure on the MLAs through their family members.

“We are getting information that some officials are pressurizing the family members of BJP MLAs and putting undue pressure on them to be cowed into submission. We are preparing a list of such officials who are trying to target the MLAs. We have warned those officials the nobody will be spared if they try to interfere in political affairs," said Chouhan.

Amid tight security, the personnel appointed at the resort were not allowing anybody to enter. On Tuesday, former minister and MLA from Ichchawar, Karan Singh Verma was waylaid by the security at the entry of the resort. Later, the police identified him and allowed his in.

"I had gone to my village Jamunia. When I returned, there was some confusion. Some security personnel were not willing to let me in. But, tight security is good. Noting happened and I was allowed in later," Verma told reporters after the incident.

After Chouhan, BJP leaders including Narottam Mishra , Gopal Bhargava and VD Sharma also met the MLAs. The party has booked 50 rooms in the hotel after 100 MLAs who were destined to leave for New Delhi on Monday evening were shifted to Sehore amid Governor's directives to conduct floor test in the House on March 17.

Title: Taluka-level committee to ensure home quarantine
Content: Kolhapur: Sangli district administration has formed a taluka-level special committee to monitor movement and treatment of people who have been advised home quarantine Sangli district collector Abhijit Chowdhary, in a press statement, said that tehsildar will be the ex-officio president of the committee while a police inspector, block development officer and chief officer of the concerned local self-body would be the members.The committee has been asked to visit houses of those people who have been asked to remain under home quarantine and ensure that they are following the guidelines issued by the government.The committee will also warn the people of using force if they come to know about people not following the guidelines. “If the individual concerned is found not following advisory even after issuing of warning, police would forcefully take him to a government hospital,” sources said.The committee will carry out the activity on a day-to-day basis and submit a report to the district collector. The committee will also get regular update from local tour operators about people who are travelling and have returned to their homes, and will decide the future course of action. People travelling or returning from the foreign countries will be under scanner of the committee.“The committee has been empowered to take on the spot decision considering the situation prevailing at that time,” Chowdhary said.Meanwhile, district collectors of Sangli and Satara have appealed to the citizens to refrain from coming to government offices and use the online services for any work.Local authorities have been asked to ensure that only vegetables and fruits are sold in weekly markets. They have also been asked to ensure safe distance between two vendors during the weekly-markets.

Title: Cane crushing dips, 1/3 mills stop manufacturing
Content:
KOLHAPUR: Sugarcane crunch in the district has seriously affected the crushing activity with more than one third sugar mills have stopped manufacturing of sugar.

Just four months into the cane crushing season as 56 out of 146 sugar mills have stopped crushing cane.

Sources in the sugar commissionerate office said that cane crushing has drastically come down in the current season as compared to the last two years. Mills, which have obtained crushing license this season, have crushed just five crore tonne cane so far by manufacturing 5.58 lakh quintals of sugar.

According to industry sources, the cane availability has been a serious issue in Solapur and Ahmednagar districts. Even though both districts had 16 and 12 factories each, none went into cane crushing this season bringing down the sugar production. The majority of these factories did not start crushing because of financial difficulties or lack of cane availability.

It is no surprise that western Maharashtra received extended rains while the Marathwada region had a drought-like situation. Both conditions drastically affected sugar can development in the region.

As many as 195 sugar factories were involved in crushing last year while the number has come down to just 146 in the current season. They said that 45 sugar mills, which included private and cooperative, were not involved in the cane crushing, which resulted in a fall in sugar production across Maharashtra.

Till last year, sugar mills have crushed 9.50 crore tonne of cane as compared to a mere five crore tonne this year. Sugar mill operators feel that crushing season, which normally continues till May end, is expected to get over in April this year. They pointed out that cane availability in sugar-rich western Maharashtra is at a gradual decline for the past few years.

Title: Dwindling powers see ZPs used as gateway to assembly
Content:
Margao: Ever since they were set up as the second tier of the panchayati raj institution in 2000, zilla panchayats in Goa have been fighting a losing battle over devolution of funds , powers and functions by the state government. But when it comes to elections to these district-level bodies , which have otherwise almost been reduced to non-entities, the euphoria it generates on the political landscape is at once electric and infectious.

While there are differing views among proponents of ‘self-governance’ over the need for the second-tier panchayat body in a small state like Goa, experts in the field of panchayati raj say the government has used the ‘powerlessness’ of the ZPs as leverage to wield greater power for itself.

They say that ideally, the gram panchayats and ZPs should have been linked by ensuring that projects and proposals of the gram panchayats are routed through ZPs. In the absence of interlinking, the gram panchayats and ZPs effectively become subservient to the MLAs and MPs when it comes to seeking funds and approvals for development works.

“The current system defeats the very idea of self-governing bodies. If funds for village projects had been routed through the ZPs instead of MLAs and MPs, it would have ensured accountability and transparency,” a senior bureaucrat said.

Ironically, ZP membership is seen by many contestants as the gateway to the portals of power in the legislative assembly.

Panchayati raj researcher, Tanaji Halarnkar , however, says, “There are many contestants who still believe in local self-governing bodies as agencies of rural development. However, for those who seek to gain political mileage, it may not be an easy task anymore, as money and muscle power have dominated power politics.”

With the ZP elections now being conducted along party lines, they serve dual purposes for political parties. “While it helps parties reach out to rural voters and wield sway over them,” Halarnkar says, “It also helps them assess their strength in the rural heartland ahead of the assembly elections. Also, every MLA takes keen interest in ZP elections to strengthen his hold over his constituency, and to fortify his position in his party.”

Nevertheless, holding of ZP polls on party lines hasn’t gone down well with panchayati raj proponents. “The basic philosophy of panchayati raj does not permit open participation of political parties. The open entry to parties will prove disastrous to these people’s republics,” Halarnkar said.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Sanitisers essential commodities in Himachal Pradesh
Content:
Representative image

SHIMLA: Surgical and N-95 face masks, and hand sanitisers, have been declared as essential commodities within the purview of Himachal Pradesh, Hoarding and Profiteering Prevention Order, 1977, till June 30. Any act of hoarding and profiteering in respect of these commodities would attract penal provisions of the Essential Commodities Act, 1955.

A state state government official said the food, civil supplies and consumer affairs department and health department staff had been given powers for conducting inspections, searches and seizures.

Meanwhile, Himachal Pradesh High Court Bar Association also held a general house meeting on Monday in which it was decided that only urgent matters would be listed before courts till March 31.

Shimla deputy commissioner Amit Kashyap on Monday said to mitigate Covid-19 threat in Shimla, no langars and bhandaras would be held in the district till March 31. He said dhabas, bars, food courts, restaurants and hotelshad been asked to keep hygiene and ensure staff wore masks to avoid any transmission of virus.

He said HRTC managing director will ensure all public and private buses would be sanitised with prescribed disinfectants regularly. He said the transport department will sensitise their drivers, conductors and cleaners through staff and necessary advisories will be displayed at bus stands and inside buses and taxis.

Kashyap said tourism director will ensure precautionary measures are taken by all hotels and home stays.

Title: Kamal Nath replies to Governor, asks for 16 Congress MLAs to be ‘freed from BJP captivity’
Content: BHOPAL: Chief minister Kamal Nath on Tuesday replied to Governor Lalji Tandon ’s letter — in which he was asked to hold a floor-test “or it would be considered that his government does not have majority” — and said giving such a diktat was ‘unconstitutional’.“Your direction for a floor test on March 17, 2020, or else you will consider that I have lost majority support is baseless and unconstitutional. I have come to know that BJP leaders have filed a petition in court as well,” says the CM’s letter, dated March 17. “You mentioned in your letter that the proceedings of the House were adjourned till March 26, 2020, but prefer to remain silent on the reasons for the deferment, the CM added, and went on to explain the Coronavirus crisis and the Union government’s advisory to avoid large gatherings.“You must be aware that our country and the whole world are facing a threat from Coronavirus. WHO has already declared it a pandemic and the Government of India issued an advisory in which there are directions not to hold any function or crowd a public place,” the CM reasoned. “This is why the Speaker adjourned the House till March 26.”Nath reiterates that he has the numbers. “In your letter, you regretted that I tried to skip the floor test, for which you had set a deadline. I would like to bring to your attention that I have proved majority in the House on several occasions in the past 15 months.”BJP can bring a no-confidence motion to get majority tested on the floor of the House, the CM pointed out. “I have also come to know that BJP has given a notice for a no-confidence motion, which is pending before the Speaker. The Speaker will take a decision on the notice according to rules and norms of the assembly, and who has majority in the House will soon be clear,” the chief minister’s letter argued.“I have been reminding you through letters and personal interaction that 16 MLAs of Congress have been held hostage in a Bengaluru resort where BJP leaders are also present,” Nath points out, adding: “On the one hand, Congress MLAs (in Bengaluru) are not being permitted to speak or meet with anyone, and are being stopped from coming to Bhopal . On the other hand, BJP leaders are in touch with them, putting them under pressure through threats and allurements, asking them to give fake statements to the media.“Let these 16 Congress MLAs held captive in Bengaluru be freed. Let them live without fear in the free atmosphere of their homes for some days so that they are in a position to take decision on their own,” he demanded.The Governor, in his letter sent on Monday, had said he did not like the language of the CM’s earlier letter. To this, the chief minister wrote, “I have always observed dignity and decorum in 40 years of my political career. After reading your letter, dated March 16, I am pained since you have accused me of not abiding by Parliamentary norms.”

Title: DGGI raids three driving schools of city
Content:
Nagpur: In a major crackdown against tax evaders, the Directorate General of GST Intelligence (DGGI) Nagpur unit raided three city-based driving schools and found them evading service tax and Goods and Services Tax to the tune of over Rs10 crore over last five years.

Acting on a tip off, officers of DGGI Nagpur unit carried out search operations at the offices of M/s Wazalwar Driving School Pvt Ltd at Shivaji Nagar (proprietor Manish Wazalwar and Rachana Wazalwar), M/s Desai Driving School at Plot No.1, Main Road, Jiwan Akshay Society , Manish Nagar (proprietor Usha Manohar Desai), and M/s Shree Driving School at Block No. 5, Gadge Maharaj Dharamshala , Medical Chowk, Nagpur (proprietor Dilip A Chitre).

During investigations, it was observed that these entities were engaged in providing motor driving lessons, which are taxable services, for over 20 years but they had not taken registration or continued registration with the department either under service tax or under GST.

It was also observed that a very small number of the receipts were being accounted for by these entities in the statutory records like income tax returns and other financial documents, whereas the bulk of the receipts were taken in cash from trainees in order to systematically evade payment of both service tax and GST.

On preliminary inquiries, including analysis of the ‘kaccha’ receipts and registers recovered and seized during the search operations, it has been estimated that taxable value of over Rs10 crore has been suppressed by these entities in just the last five years involving service tax, and GST of approximately Rs1.86 crore. The department has also recorded statements of the proprietors and seized documents for scrutiny.

Offices where search operation was carried out

* M/s Wazalwar Driving School Pvt Ltd at Shivaji Nagar

(Proprietor - Manish Wazalwar and Rachana Wazalwar)

* M/s Desai Driving School at Plot No.1, Main Road, Jiwan Akshay Society, Manish Nagar

(Proprietor - Usha Manohar Desai)

* M/s Shree Driving School at Block No.5, Gadge Maharaj Dharamshala, Medical Chowk

(Proprietor - Dilip A Chitre)

Title: K’taka virus positive flew with 26 from Goa, state tracing flyers
Content: Panaji: After it was revealed that a 67-year-old woman who tested positive for Covid-19 in Bengaluru had come from Dubia via Goa, the state government on Tuesday frantically launched steps to trace 26 passengers who travelled by the same flight. Health minister Vishwajit Rane said all 26 persons who came to Goa from Dubai and were in the flight with Bengaluru woman will be traced and placed in isolation.“Health secretary Nila Mohanan is in touch with the airline to trace travellers to Goa who came by that flight. We have got addresses of all 26 persons who came to Goa and they will be traced tomorrow (Wednesday),” Rane said.“Test of each of them (26 travellers) will be done. Persons showing symptoms will be lodged in the isolation ward of the GMC for full 14 days as per the government of India guidelines,” he said.Rane said the government has been pro-active and taking several measures to fight Covid-19.The 67-year-old woman had returned to Bengaluru from Dubai via Goa on March 9. Officials said she was under strict home quarantine ever since she landed in Bengaluru.On March 16, she was taken to a government hospital when she showed symptoms of fever and cough. She has a history of chronic kidney disorder.

Title: Hyderabad: Registration rush crashes RTA server, halts services
Content:
Heavy rush for registration of BS-IV vehicles at Trimulgherry RTA office

HYDERABAD: The online services of the state transport department came to a halt on Monday due to server problems, preventing the applicants from booking their slots on the website.

Applicants complained that the department is sending the entire functioning of the online system into chaos by restricting them from accessing certain services on the website.

Satish Naik, a resident of Banjara Hills, said, “I have been trying to book a slot for learner’s license on the website the entire day and I am directed to a page that says, ‘Access is denied’. What is the use of having an online registration system to book slots if they don’t give us access to it?”

Another applicant Ashish Kumar said, “I wanted to book a slot for my license renewal but I’m just not able to do that despite trying for several hours. They transport department should at least notify the public about this before deciding to stop allowing the public from booking slots.”

“We do not even know for how long this will continue. In case the traffic police levies a penalty on my vehicle for not renewing the driver’s license on time, will the transport department compensate for my loss?”

Meanwhile, sources close to the department informed that that is being done by RTA officials to tackle the rush for registration of BS-IV vehicles.

“The RTA offices across the state are seeing a spurt in vehicle registrations as the deadline for the sales of BS-IV vehicles are round the corner. The applicants who are waiting to renew their driver’s license, book slots for learning license tests and other services are now suffering because neither the applicants nor the traffic police department was informed about this beforehand,” a source told TOI.

As per the Supreme Court directive, new vehicles that have BS-IV engines cannot be registered after March 31.

During a recent inspection at RTA office, Khairatabad, transport commissioner MRM Rao urged motorists to finish the registration process before the deadline.

Reiterating the SC directive, Rao said even if the vehicle is purchased a few days before March 31, vehicles with BS-IV engines cannot be registered after March 31. He asked the motorists not to wait till the last day and get the registration done early.

When contacted, C Ramesh, joint transport commissioner (IT) said, “We had to discontinue certain services as we are experiencing a heavy rush. This will continue for a few days.”

Title: Medical student found dead in Salem
Content:
Representative image

SALEM: A 35-year-old medical student, who went missing on Sunday, was found dead in the Vellakkalparai area here on Tuesday evening.

The Steel Plant police identified the deceased as Gourav Begara , 35, of West Bengal. He was a third-year MS ortho student of a private medical college in Ariyanur.

According to a police officer, Gourav, along with five of his friends, had went on a trekking to Kanjamalai, a hillock near their college, on Sunday morning. “They come down from the hillock around 12 noon. Gaurav, who was very tired, asked his friends to fetch him some water. They made him sit on a boulder and returned in few minutes. However, Gourav was not to be seen anywhere there,” the officer said quoting the complainants.

As their search for him didn’t yield any fruit, the five on Monday lodged a complaint with the Steel Plant police, who recovered Gaurav’s body at Vellakkalparai area and sent that to the government hospital for postmortem.

“We are yet to ascertain whether it’s a case of mudar or natural death. We are waiting for the postmortem report to confirm the same,” the official said. tnn

Title: Hindu outfit functionary attacked in Tirupur
Content:
COIMBATORE: An unidentified gang attacked a functionary of Hindu Makkal Katchi at Perumanallur in Tirupur district on Tuesday night.

The injured person was identified as Nandakumar, 45, of Kanakkampalayam in Tirupur district, Tirupur north district deputy secretary of Hindu Makkal Katchi.

Nandakumar was attacked around 9.30pm while he was passing through Perumanallur on his motorcycle, police sources said. “Two men stopped his vehicle and attacked him using sickles. The attackers managed to flee from the place before local could stop them,” a police officer said.

Nandakumar, who suffered injuries on his right arm, has been admitted to the Tirupur Government Hospital.

The Perumanallur police have registered a case and are investigating the incident.

Title: Tendulkar in RS: Centre should permit bullfights
Content:
PANAJI: Rajya Sabha MP Vinay Tendulkar on Tuesday demanded that the Union government grant permission to conduct bullfights in Goa, to boost tourism.

Speaking at the zero hour notice, Tendulkar said Goa’s bullfights stopped after 1998.

He said that it affected local employment as well as tourism activities. The MP said that states like Tamil Nadu and Karnataka also had traditional bullfights and the bulls that were used in the sport received special training.

Tendulkar said that bullfights were held in Goa even before the Portuguese colonised the state. “There is lot of investment into it and locals too get employment. It also boosts tourism. I urge the government to grant permission to hold bullfights in Goa like in other states,” he said

Title: Diamond industry turns down shutdown proposal
Content:
Surat: Diamond industry stakeholders have unanimously decided against shutdown of the industry despite outbreak of coronavirus hitting exports of polished diamonds in the wider interests of unit owners and workers’ community.

Surat Diamond Association (SDA) and Gems and Jewellery Export Promotion Council (GJEPC) had jointly organized a meeting of industry stakeholders here on Tuesday, where the proposal of shutdown was rejected. Industry stakeholders suggested taking safety precautions in diamond units, including placing hand sanitizers, distributing face masks and screening of diamond workers and unit owners.

They decided the diamond markets at Varachha and Mahidhapura will operate from 11am to 6pm. Unit owners wanting to shut their units will have to take prior approval of SDA.

SDA president Babu Kathiriya said, “SDA will be running awareness campaign in the industry on health safety measures to deal with coronavirus outbreak. Pamphlets will be distributed in the diamond hub for creating awareness. We are in constant touch with the state government and local civic body.”

Exports of polished diamonds could decrease by over 25% during the end of the financial year due to trade disruptions caused by coronavirus, especially in China market, the United States, Europe and UAE among others. Exports of polished diamonds to Hong Kong between April-January 2020 have declined by 24% at $5.7 billion against $7.6 billion during the same period in previous year.

GJEPC regional chairman Dinesh Navadia told TOI, “The industry employs about 5.5 lakh diamond workers and closure would mean rendering them jobless for 15 days. At present, the industry is operating at less than 40% capacity due to decline in export orders following coronavirus outbreak. Still, the unit owners are running the factories to keep their workers employed.”

Title: Do not panic, adequate amount of essentials available: Dist collector
Content: Kolhapur: The district administration on Tuesday appealed to the citizens to not panic and avoid rushing to the market and hoarding daily essentials as there is adequate stock available.District collector Daulat Desai on Tuesday held meeting with district supply office, officials of agriculture produce market committee, officials from oil supply firms and traders to access the situation.During the meeting, the representatives said they have adequate stock of essentials like grain, cooking oil, gas and fuel. There is also regular supply from oil companies and vegetable producers.For the past two days, people have got into panic mode and have been rushing to supermarkets and grocery stores to stock essentials.“Panic may lead to increase in prices and traders may tend to hoard the essential goods. For the last two days, most petrol pumps saw rush of the citizens to get their vehicles filled with fuel. Vehicles with public announcement systems are making rounds in retail and vegetable markets along with fuel stations advising people to not panic,” Desai said.During the meeting, the grain traders informed Desai that they have adequate stock to last for next 12 months.Desai suggested the officials to display boards with a message that adequate stock of fuel is available at petrol pumps to avoid panic. He also said that the action will be taken against the medical shops where masks and sanitizers are being sold at higher price.Meanwhile, number of coronavirus suspects under home quarantine is currently 170. As many as 39 have so far completed the 14-day home isolation period.So far, 10 swab samples have been sent for testing at the National Virology Institute (NIV) in Pune of which six have been rejected stating that the suspects do not have travel history while four tested negative.Details obtained from the health administration show that maximum number of 88 suspects has travel history to Dubai followed by Saudi Arabia which was visited by 26 suspects. The highest number of people who have returned from abroad and are under home quarantine is from Kolhapur city.“The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) has initiated house-to-house survey to search for foreign arrivals and rural administration has been asked to do the same in the rural areas,” Desai said.

Title: Traffic cops to get shoulder blinker lights in Coimbatore
Content:
COIMBATORE: Traffic cops in the city will soon get LED blinker lights that can be fixed on shoulders to ensure their safety on the busy roads during night hours.

The blue and red lights can be fixed on both shoulders, deputy commissioner of police (traffic) R Mutharasu said. “Motorists will be able to notice the lights at least 100 feet away. We hope this will ensure the safety of our personnel at night,” he said.

The city police had received Rs 86.56 lakh under the road safety fund to buy various equipment.

As many as 12 companies displayed their products at the city police commissionerate on Monday. Senior officers who checked the equipment, have instructed the firms to modify some of them.

“We plan to buy fiber road blocks, reflecting jackets, road LED studs, solar blinkers, public addressing systems, LED shoulder blinker lights and 10 breath analyzers to check drunk driving. Once the tender is finalized, we would distribute it to our personnel,” said Mutharasu.

Title: 50-bed quarantine facility set up at Coimbatore college hostel
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: From Wednesday midnight , all asymptomatic passengers landing in the city from 10 countries affected by Covid-19, will be quarantined for 14 days at one of the hostel buildings of Tejaa Shakthi Institute of Technology for Women at Karumathampatti .

Though the building is being equipped with 50 beds, it has provision to accommodate 200 beds, a health department official told TOI.

There was brief commotion in front of the facility on Tuesday evening when Coimbatore collector K Rajamani arrived to inspect it. Staging a protest against setting up the quarantine centre there, as many as 100 residents of the area blocked the collector’s vehicle. The collector got off the vehicle and explained that only asymptomatic patients will be quarantined there.

The district administration began identifying a space to quarantine Covid-19 patients two days after the Indian government made quarantine compulsory for passengers landing from the United Arab Emirates , Qatar, China, Oman, South Korea , Iran, Italy, Spain, Germany and France. “While patients with symptoms will be taken to the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital for treatment, testing for the virus and then isolation, the patients without symptoms will be housed in this building for 14 days,” deputy director of the public health department Dr Ramesh said.

Since it is a quarantine space for asymptomatic patients who require no treatment and only monitoring, officials said the hostel has all the basic facilities to make quarantine simple. “It already has beds, laundry facilities, adequate number of toilets and canteen facilities. The revenue department is yet to take a decision on extra facilities like books, television and Wi-Fi,” said Ramesh, who supervised cleaning of the building on Tuesday.

The move to set up set up pure quarantine facilities outside government hospitals seems to have been fuelled by reports of people not reporting symptoms and travel history, and even fleeing airports fearing quarantine in government hospitals, sources said.

Title: Bhopal: BJP MLA Tripathi meets CM again, fourth time in three days
Content:
File photo of Kamal Nath

BHOPAL: BJP MLA from Maihar, Narayan Tripathi , who a day ago, had called on chief minister Kamal Nath at his official residence, hit out at BJP on Tuesday for precipitating the political crisis in Madhya Pradesh . Amidst the political drama Tripathi is keeping his parent party— the BJP — on tenterhooks.

Tripathi said toppling a stable government is like murdering democracy. The BJP has not reacted on his statement.

"Toppling the Congress government is like murdering democracy. No one will contest elections if this continues," said Tripathi on queries over the political turmoil in the state. He also praised the Kamal Nath government for its welfare schemes.

"Chief minister Kamal Nath is doing a good work. Earlier, we used to get power bills worth lakhs of rupees. Now, we are paying only Rs 100," he said.

During the last three days, Tripathi met chief minister Nath four times. On Saturday, he met the CM once in the evening while on Sunday he met Nath twice. Every time he said that the meeting was to discuss development works to be undertaken in his constituency.

On Monday, he had supported the Congress government by saying there is no threat to the Kamal Nath government and Congress has majority in the House.

Referring to his frequent meetings with the CM when there was a political turmoil, Tripathi said he is only with development of his region. "Right now, there is Kamal Nath government. My aim is to make Maihar a district. My politics is based on the blessings of my voters and Ma Sharda of Maihar. I had also quit politics for my region," he said.

The BJP leader denied having discussed plans with Congress leader and former minister Ajay Singh during his visit to CM residence. He said he did not interact with Ajay Singh but, no one is enemy the in politics.

"Party leadership is aware of everything. But, Tripathi has not defied party whip nor resigned from the party, till now. He is very much with BJP," said BJP state spokesperson, Rajneesh Agrawal .

Title: RGIA free of single-use plastic
Content:
Hyderabad: The Rajiv Gandhi International Airport (RGIA) declared itself single-use plastic -free as it replaced all such products with eco-friendly alternatives from March 1.

According to a press release issued by the airport authorities, the airport has taken stringent measures to stop usage of single-use plastic and has eliminated all the plastic cutlery from the F&B outlets and carry bags below the stipulated norm of less than 50 microns thickness.

The waste management model at the airport uses the ‘two-bin’ system across the terminal buildings for effective collection and segregation of dry and wet waste.tnn

Title: Fuel bill default halts fogging by health dept
Content: Nagpur: At a time when the entire nation is worried over novel coronavirus , the Nagpur Municipal Corporation has stopped disinfection and de-choking of sewage networks from March 16. Reason: The civic body has defaulted on fuel payment of Rs1.18 crore, leading to stoppage of petrol and diesel supply to NMC vehicles.The health department has been affected the most as it had to stop spraying of disinfectants since Monday for want of vehicles, said officials.The department has been receiving many calls from citizens, seeking spraying or fogging in various areas in the wake of coronavirus scare. Even vehicles engaged in enforcement drive and hotmix department have also come to a halt. This has affected many works, the officials said. Nagpurians took to Twitter handle to express their anguish. One of them, vaibhav @Vairarchi said, “Hello @ngpnmc, We have been trying to reach you for a dog in need of medical care but your officials are stating the reason of “their vehicle failure”. We have tried to reach local rescue houses too but no luck. Can you please help? Or atleast guide us to take necessary action?”A senior official of NMC workshop on Great Nag Road said, “Around 170 vehicles have been stranded as the tanks are dry for the past 24 hours for non-payment of bills to the fuel station concerned. It is the first time in this financial year that the fuel station in Dharampeth refused supplies to NMC vehicles.”Sources said, NMC, with a fleet of over 170 vehicles, including 20 for senior officials, requires fuel worth Rs40 lakh per month. The fire and emergency services department, which has a fleet of 70 vehicles, has a different account. But the 20-odd top bosses and NMC office-bearers have been left untouched.The civic body defaulted on the payment of January and February due to which the petrol pump owner discontinued supply from March 16.Earlier this month, owner of Bole Petrol Pump had sent a reminder to NMC, requesting release of outstanding payments. As the civic body failed to clear the dues, the pump owner stopped supply of fuel.The officer said the process to release payment to the fuel station owner has started and the supply will resume by Wednesday evening.

Title: Coronavirus scare in Kolkata: 24 ID cabins with attached toilets have hosted over 50
Content: KOLKATA: A woman from Beniapukur, who had returned from Saudi Arabia last Sunday, was sent to Infectious Diseases & Beliaghata General Hospital, popularly known as ID Hospital, after health officials at the airport found she had fever and cold. But she initially fled the hospital, refusing to get admitted to the government facility, fearing dirty wards, unhygienic toilets and poor services.But a visit to the hospital’s isolation wards, earmarked for treating Covid-19 patients as well as those suspected of being infected with coronavirus, presented a picture in contrast: 24 small, clean, single-bed cabins line Ward IB6, completely isolated from each other. Each cabin has an attached toilet. Though the nursing station is common, the facility has separate sets of portable equipment,like ventilators and ECG machines. This 24-bed quarantine ward at the state’s nodal hospital for infectious diseases was the first lot of isolation beds that the state health department had reserved for treating coronavirus suspected cases as well as those infected.Till Monday, the hospital had dealt with more than 50 people suspected of being infected with coronavirus but none had tested positive. However, on Tuesday Bengal recorded its first Covid-19-positive patient. “These isolation wards are designed for highly contagious diseases. While one section of the ward at the hospital was created when Nipah virus cases were reported, the other section is meant for swine flu patients. These wards are barely used as they are kept for only an outbreak like this,” said ID&BG Hospital principal Anima Haldar. The hospital has another isolation ward with 12 cabins, which was set up when Ebola cases were reported. “That section was never used. This, too, can be used for Covid-19 patients if need be,” Haldar added.Four beds in the intensive care unit have also been kept aside in case someone does test positive for the virus and needs intensive care unit support. In addition to the nursing and para-medic staff, a small team of doctors has been formed to deal with Covid-19 suspected cases. The core team comprises only three doctors—Shekhar Ranjal Paul from the department of medicine who has been trained in handling Ebola cases, microbiologist Kheya Muherjee and chest specialist Koushik Chowdhury who recently attended the WHO workshop on Covid-19 in Delhi. “As the number of patients increases, manpower shortage could be a crisis soon,” said a hospital insider.

Title: Kolhapur: Optical cable, gas pipeline work to affect 90km roads
Content:
KOLHAPUR: Over 90 km of city roads are going to be dug up for laying optical fibre and gas pipeline.

The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation (KMC) is going to impose stringent conditions on the agencies taking up these works and ensuring that the roads are restored immediately.

In the past, the agencies had failed to restore the roads after completion of their work. The roads dug up remained in the same condition for a long time. The civic body then faces the wrath of the locals.

Harshit Ghatge, city engineer of divisional ward office number 4, said, “We have received the applications from two agencies. One agency is going to lay the optical cable network in the city. The work is given by the state government to connect the government offices. The government has sought waiver of all taxes or the charges to lay the cables for around 14km stretch.”

Ghatge said that another agency is assigned the task to lay the gas pipeline. The project has been launched by the central government to provide piped gas supply to the households. Over 30,000 connections are likely to be provided in the first phase of the work. The substations will be established outside of the city.

In the first phase, gas pipeline along 76km stretch will be laid. “The gas pipeline network will be laid for the entire city. The company has requested reduction in fees that we charge. The fees are used to restore the damaged roads. We are going to put up both the issues before general body to decide whether to charge the agencies or not,” added Ghatge.

The KMC charges Rs 4,600 as digging charges for one kilometre stretch. The gas pipeline agency was asked to pay Rs 69 crore. If the KMC charges fees, then the responsibility of restoring the roads will be of the KMC and not of the agency.

Title: Education department cancels exams up to Class VIII
Content: Panaji: All examinations up to Class VIII stand cancelled in state schools. The directorate of education issued fresh instructions to schools on Tuesday as a safety precaution against the spread of Covid-19 Exams for classes IX to XII, including board exams, will be held as scheduled, the directorate of education’s circular stated.Education director Vandana Rao said that administrative staff of school will have to report to work as usual.In a circular, Rao instructed schools that during the conduct of exams, they must ensure that ‘the protocol of social distancing of one metre between students is followed strictly’. These instructions are applicable to unaided schools in the state. The decision to cancel the examinations was taken based on the new guidelines issued by the Union health ministry on Monday ‘regarding measures to be taken for effective social distancing to curb the spread of coronavirus (Covid-19)’, Rao states in the circular.The ministry’s new guidelines had said the possibility of postponing exams should be explored and that ongoing exams should be held only after ensuring social distancing of one metre between students.Based on this, representatives from the Goa Headmaster’s Association met the director to discuss the demand made many parents, as well the cancellation of examinations up to Class VIII.Those in the know said that at the discussion, it was noted that as per the central government’s instructions, it was up to the management of each school to decide on cancellation of examinations. The director, however, felt that as a safety precaution against the spread of Covid-19, it was best not to have the examinations as there is already continuous comprehensive evaluation and a no-fail policy in force up to Class VIII, sources said.Schools having attached hostels also came up for discussion. “It was decided that any such schools should be advised not to tell their students to vacate,” a source said.Earlier, the state government had already suspended regular classes up to March 31, but had said examinations will continue as scheduled. Schools under the Diocesan Society of Education had scheduled examinations from March 20 to 30, which was within the period where the Union health ministry has advised social distancing.

Title: No classes at IIT-Ropar
Content: Patiala: With coronavirus Covid-19 ) cases rising in the country, the Indian Institute of Technology (IIT), Ropar, has extended its mid-semester break by suspending classes till March to reduce the risks of transmission.It has also announced suspension of public gatherings, conferences, workshops and seminars as a precautionary measure. Students pursuing undergraduate and postgraduate courses and research scholars have been asked to vacate campus no later than midnight of Wednesday.However, students from high-risk areas such as Kerala, Maharashtra, Uttar Pradesh and Delhi would be allowed to stay on campus with special permission. Around 2,100 students, including 574 Ph D students, 1,046 undergraduates and 348 students in master in science and M Tech, are pursuing education at the IIT. tnn

Title: WR increases platform ticket rates in south Gujarat
Content:
Surat: Western Railway (WR) has increased rates of platform ticket at the railway stations in south Gujarat for crowd management at a time of coronavirus scare from Tuesday.

The platform ticket rates have been increased from Rs10 to Rs50 at Surat railway station. The rates at Udhana and Vapi will be Rs40, Rs30 at Navsari, Valsad and Billimora and Rs20 at Vyara.

The decision to increase platform ticket rates has been taken for crowd management.

According to chief public relations officer, WR, Ravinder Bhakar, the railway has been taking various steps to contain the spread of coronavirus disease. The rates of platform tickets have been increased to discourage people who are not passengers from coming to railway premises.

Title: Covid-19 scare: Officials tighten vigil on Tamil Nadu-Karnataka border
Content: SALEM: Salem, Namakkal, Dharmapuri, Krishnagiri and Erode collectors have deputed special teams to monitor people entering the state from Karnataka. The teams have been deployed at eight entry points on Tamil Nadu-Karnataka border across these districts.Thalavadi block medical officer Dr K Siva, who is camping at Karapallam area on Sathyamangalam-Mysuru national highway, said they would check each and every vehicle entering the state from Karnataka. “Each person will be checked for fever, flu, cough and other Covid-19 symptoms.”Health department officials would also spray disinfectant on vehicles and distribute pamphlets explaining preventive measures.Similarly, police officials, including those from prohibition and enforcement wing, are at work at Bannari and Asanur check posts. “It's our duty to check the vehicles and passengers. We are using masks and gloves as a precautionary measure,” a senior police official said.Meanwhile, public parks, shopping malls, cinema theatres, marriage halls, gyms, playing grounds and bars remained closed on Tuesday as directed by the government.Salem municipal corporation commissioner R Sadheesh warned of strict action against the people who violate the government order. He said five teams were working under his supervision round the clock to keep the city clean and spray disinfectant wherever that was called for.

Title: Kolkata: Despite safety measures, OPD footfall drops at private hospitals
Content: KOLKATA: The Covid-19 scare has led to a sharp plunge in footfall across outpatient departments (OPD) at Kolkata’s private hospitals.Even as the number of suspects grows across the country and the city, patient count has come down considerably despite hospitals making arrangements to segregate those with symptoms of the virus. Several hospitals have issued advisories, asking patients to keep the elderly and children away unless there’s an emergency.Over the last five days, at least four hospitals have seen a 10%-25% drop in the number of patients seeking outdoor consultation. The figure could cross 30% by the end of the week, according to hospital sources.At Peerless Hospital , the OPD footfall dropped by 25% since last week. Authorities believe it could come down to 50% by this weekend. “Consultations are being deferred due to the fear. It has been quite drastic over the last few days and we expect the OPD footfall to drop further, though there has been no change in the indoor patient count,” said Peerless medical superintendent Sudipto Mitra. While the hospital receives around 400 OPD patients a day, it dropped to 300 this week.At Medica Superspecialty Hospital, too, OPD crowd has thinned by 10% despite the hospital setting up a separate enclosure for patients with cough and cold. “We are taking measures to prevent transmission and are not allowing suspects to get close to other patients. But people are wary since visiting a hospital OPD involves travel in public transport. A large number of our patients are from the neighbouring districts. Some of them are from countries like Bangladesh and Nepal. So, the OPD crowd may thin further over the next three-four weeks,” said Medica chairperson Alok Roy.“The scare persists as the number of patients swells despite the safety measures put in place at our facilities. Many of my patients called me to defer appointments this week,” said Fortis Hospital pulmonologist Raja Dhar. OPD footfall at Fortis plunged to 1,700 last week from 2,200 the week before.RN Tagore International Institute of Cardiac Sciences (RTIICS) had seen a footfall drop prior to Holi. It picked up for a few days only to plunge again this week. It dipped by 8% on Monday while the hospital has seen a 75% drop in the Bangladeshi patients’ count at the OPD. “We used to receive 200 Bangladeshi patients at the OPD till last week. It came down to just 50 on Monday,” said RTIICS zonal director R Venkatesh. The hospital issued an advisory stating that the elderly and children should stay away unless there’s an emergency.Woodlands Hospital has been spacing out patients’ appointments with doctors at their outdoor clinics. This is being done to prevent crowding at the waiting arena and at the OPD. The hospital is also seeking OPD patients’ travel history and those who have been to the affected countries are being given a ‘quarantined’ appointment. “We have set up a separate room for them and are putting them through thermal screening. Doctors are examining them in this room instead of their designated chambers,” CEO Rupali Basu said.The hospital is also using its app to curb the number of OPD patients each day. “Number of appointments are being restricted through the app. This not only helps prevent a crowd and reduce chances of infection, but also brings down the waiting time for each patient,” added Basu.

Title: ‘Now, prove Covid-19 spreads through chicken & claim Rs 1 crore’
Content: Tamil Nadu Poultry Farmers’ Federation and Tamil Nadu Poultry Farmers’ Marketing Society have jointly announced a cash reward of Rs 1 crore to anyone who could prove that coronavirus (Covid-19) was spreading through chicken meat.The announcement was made at the poultry farmers’ meeting that was held in Namakkal town on Tuesday to take a few important decisions to save the industry after chicken meat price plunged to Rs 10 a kg from Rs 80, following rumours associated with Covid-19.They also said nearly 15 crore eggs have been stagnating in the poultry farms across the district.Addressing the media, ‘Vangili’ Subramaniam, vice-president, poultry farmers’ marketing society, said there wasn’t any proof to show that Covid-19 could spread through chicken meat.He said the poultry farmers were facing a loss of nearly Rs 8 crore a day and that broiler chicken trade worth Rs 15 crore was affected in the state. “The industry has faced a loss of nearly Rs 500 crore in the past two weeks.”The poultry farmers have decided to meet chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami once again. “We will urge the government to advertise in print and electronic media for a month that chicken meat and egg won’t trigger Covid-19 outbreak. This is the only solution to save the industry,” Subramaniam said.

Title: Team to assess groundwater pollution in Choutuppal
Content:
Hyderabad: The Telangana State Pollution Control Board (TSPCB) has asked the collector of Yadadari-Bhuvanagiri district to constitute a multi-disciplinary team to assess alleged groundwater pollution caused by a firm in Choutuppal.

The team is to submit its report regarding the extent of alleged pollution and remedial action in three months.

The decision was taken after the board reviewed several plaints in this regard during a task force committee meet on February 7. The meeting was attended by complainants and industry representatives.

The complainants alleged that the industry is expanding illegally without taking statutory permissions.

One of the primary complainants, Damodar Reddy, said, “As a result of pollutants being released into groundwater, the soil has also become polluted. Farmers in about 10 villages nearby are unable to grow crops.”

The letter to the district collector said that after detailed discussions the committee had recommended that a multi-disciplinary team be constituted comprising representatives from revenue and agriculture department, from the groundwater board, TSPCB, IICT or NEERI.

Title: Prisoners to appear through video conference in court
Content: KOLHAPUR: On the backdrop of the coronavirus threat, the state prisons department has asked the Kalamba jail officials to avoid sending prisoners to court for hearing and instead use video conference facility. This will continue till March 31.Sharad Shelke, jail superintendent, Kalamba central prison, said, “Additional director general of police (prisons) Sunil Ramanand has issued orders stating that considering the outbreak of coronavirus, the prisoners will appear before the respective courts for the hearing of their cases through video conferencing till March 31. The prisoners will not be taken out from jail to the respective courts in the district for hearing as there are chances of them getting infected with coronavirus. This may affect the health situation in the jail.”Shelke said they have adequate facility and infrastructure, including quality cameras and internet connection, to conduct video conference through the prison. “Almost all the session courts from Kolhapur and other districts are equipped with video conferencing facilities. From Monday, we have not sent any prisoner out of jail for hearing. As many as 100 prisoners appeared in two days for hearing with various courts,” he said.He added that the facility of video conferencing is not available with some judicial magistrate first class courts and they are postponing the hearing of the cases associated with the prisoners till March 31.Kolhapur superintendent of police Abhinav Deshmukh had, two days back, stated that the police will take up this issue with the concerned authorities. “This would help in reducing the work of police force,” he said.He was speaking on the backdrop of the recent incident in which a prisoner booked under the stringent Maharashtra Control of Organised Crime Act escaped from Gadhinglaj court premises. As many as 230 police personnel were later deployed to nab him.

Title: Hindu outfit functionaries get security officers in Coimbatore
Content:
COIMBATORE: With communal tension continues to prevail in the district, police have provided personal security officers to various Hindu outfit functionaries, who are facing threat to life. While the rural police and city police had earlier provided personal security officers to 23 and 13 Hindu outfit functionaries, respectively , they were on Monday instructed to extent the security cover to more such members.

It is to be noted that district superintendent of police (SP) Sujit Kumar had earlier turned down the request of some Hindu outfit functionaries, seeking personal security officers. However, special branch-CID officials had sent a report to police officials in Chennai, recommending personal security officers to 11 more Hindu outfit functionaries in rural limits and another 12 in the city limits. Subsequently, director general of police (DGP) J K Tripathy had on Monday instructed the SP to provide them personal security officers immediately. The order was implemented on Monday itself.

A police officer said, “This is a temporary measure. The personal security officers will be withdrawn after getting orders from the DGP office.”

Title: Covid-19 outbreak: Stuck in foreign lands, Kolkatans race against time to return home
Content: KOLKATA: Scenes from Steven Spielberg’s 2004 movie ‘The Terminal’ that captured the days of an Eastern European man who got stuck in New York’s John F Kennedy Airport is being played out in real life with Indians from various walks of life in the role that was essayed by Tom Hanks in the Hollywood film. Ironically, Hanks, who played the lead in the movie, is down with Covid-19 at present.Rosary Manna, daughter of an advocate from Kolkata, was stuck at Kuala Lumpur airport after India suddenly decided to snap all travel links with Malaysia, Philippines and Afghanistan on Tuesday. Two Indian engineers who were stuck in Dusseldorf, Germany, have somehow managed to board an Emirates flight but remain uncertain of the future. A Swiss national, who has been stuck in Kolkata for a week, finally managed to get a ticket to Zurich. But he isn’t sure when he will reach there.Rosary is among the more than 100 students in Philippines who were returning home when they were caught unawares by the directive to ban all travels from the country as well as Malaysia, the country through which they were transiting. “The schools in Manila and rest of Philippines announced a closure on Monday. We immediately booked tickets to Kolkata and reached Kuala Lumpur around 5am on Tuesday. On landing, we were told that there were no flights operating to India,” said Rosary, who has appealed to Prime Minister Narendra Modi and chief minister Mamata Banerjee to help those stranded return to the country.“Philippines also put in place travel embargo and we can’t return there. Malaysia won’t allow us to enter as we don’t have any visa. So we are now stranded at the airport,” she added.Thousands faced uncertainties in foreign lands as they attempted to beat Wednesday’s deadline before India temporarily shuts its doors to even Indians returning from Covid-19-affected countries. The director general of civil aviation in a circular told airlines not to allow India-bound passengers board flights from Europe after 12 GMT on Wednesday or 5.30pm IST.Engineers Tuhin Subhra Maiti and Aru Bikash Samanta, who were in Dusseldorf, somehow managed to board an Emirates flight. But they weren’t sure of what lay in store once they landed in Dubai to take the connecting flight to Kolkata. “If they manage to reach on time, they will be quarantined at a facility in New Town,” an airport official said.Another travel agent was trying to make arrangements for a student stuck in Toronto. “I have been trying for hours but with so many flights being cancelled ad hoc due to travel disruptions worldwide, I have been unable to do so,” he said.With global ticketing systems like Galileo, Amadeus and Sabre shut down due to ad hoc cancellations, travel agents are unable to view which flights are operating and which aren’t. For travel agents, it is back to basics: calling up airline representatives over phone to inquire about a flight. A ticket is being issued only after there is a confirmation from the airline headquarters.While several airlines have suspended operations to Kolkata, Thai Airways and AirAsia are all set to pull out in the next few days. According to industry trackers, Thai Airways will suspend operations after the flight from Kolkata to Bangkok on Wednesday.AirAsia that flies to Kuala Lumpur and Bangkok will suspend operations after March 21.

Title: Police act tough, bring down fatal road accidents by 55%
Content:
COIMBATORE: The traffic wing of the city police have outshone their counterparts in the State by bringing down the number of fatal road accidents .

While 38 people lost their lives between January 2019 and March 15 last year in the city, only 17 people died in road accidents during the same period this year, deputy commissioner of police (traffic) R Mutharasu said. “Our personnel issued challans worth 7.40 crore till March 16 this year for traffic violations and collected fines worth Rs 1.38 crore till now. We have been issuing challans using Police-E-Eye app, automatic number plate recognition cameras at traffic signals and handheld challan devices. Traffic violators can pay using debit and credit cards on the spot. Otherwise, the challans will be uploaded on the parivahan.gov.in and the violators can pay through treasury or online,” he told TOI.

Police acted against traffic violators for red light jumping, overspeeding, using mobile phone while driving, drunk driving, carrying persons in goods vehicle and overloading goods vehicles. Those who failed to wear helmets and buckle up seat belts were also taken to task.

As per the data available with the city traffic police, while 10,466 cases were booked for red light jumping, overspeeding and drunk driving from January to March 16, 2019, as many as 40,000 cases were registered this year. While only 65,082 cases were booked for not wearing helmets and not wearing seat belts during the same period last year, 1,52,700 cases were registered this year.

Meanwhile, the number of fatal accidents in Tirupur city has gone up this year. While only 16 people lost their lives last year, 31 people perished on the roads in the neighbouring district this year.

“Among Chennai, Coimbatore, Tirupur, Salem, Trichy , Madurai and Tirunelveli that have city police, Coimbatore has reduced fatal accidents by 55.26%,” said a senior police officer.

Title: Dubai passenger held with 1.5kg gold
Content:
Vasco: The air intelligence unit of Goa Customs arrested a passenger at the Goa International Airport at Dabolim , for allegedly smuggling gold worth around Rs 57.6 lakh.

Customs officials said international passenger Mohammed Ayub, a resident of Bhatkal, Karnataka , was apprehended carrying gold bars weighing around 1.5kg. He was travelling from Dubai to Goa via Muscat by Oman Air flight no. WY0209.

“Valued at Rs 57.6 lakh, the gold seized was in the form of bars, and concealed in the check-in baggage of the passenger,” said a customs officer.

On Monday, customs sleuths seized 2.9kg of unclaimed gold, worth around Rs 1.1 crore, from the rear toilet of an international flight. The total value of gold seized in Goa in 2019-20, till date is Rs 3.4 crore.

The exercise was conducted under the supervision of the commissioner of customs, Mihir Ranjan. Further investigations are under way.

Title: Don’t make fun of us & the disease
Content: A young woman from Kalimpong , who is a first-year post-graduate student of English at Presidency University , has brought allegations of racial discrimination and derogatory remarks against a group of elderly men and posted a video of her harassment on social media last Saturday where she claimed she and her friends from the university were cat-called and touted as “coronavirus” as they walked past an alley on AJC Bose Road near Sealdah.Three days after the incident, by when the video had gone viral and was shared multiple times by different Facebook users, TOI spoke to the womanThis is not the first time that I have been cat-called and harassed because of my features, but what happened on Saturday broke me from inside. I am from Kalimpong and have been studying in the city for several months now. Last Saturday, two of my friends from Darjeeling and I were going to an orphanage where we teach the kids. We stay at Presidency University hostel and took a train to reach Sealdah and were walking down an alley when an elderly man, sitting beside a tea stall, suddenly began shouting, saying ‘coronavirus eseche ( coronavirus has come)’.He said it thrice and his friends began laughing. I knew the comments were targeted at us and I protested. I ran up to him and challenged him as one of my friends began recording the conversation. The man didn’t say a word but the friends started defending him and tried to cover up saying the comments were not meant to us.But I knew they were lying and didn’t realise we understood Bengali. I told them that me and my friends are from Bengal only and know the language very well.In fact, one of my friends from Nepal had faced a similar harassment inside a local train recently during a field work. She couldn’t protest as she was alone but we decided to protest and shoot the video and post it for people to know what we go through for no reason.The man later apologized for his deeds.But we were really hurt at the treatment meted to us because of out facial features at a time when the world is going through a crisis.I plead to everyone to not make fun of the disease and us, who are in no way connected with the spread of the same.( As told to Tamaghna Banerjee)

Title: Student dies in road accident
Content:
Hyderabad: A 16-year-old Intermediate student, M Vivek, died and his classmate, Lenin sustained injuries when their bike crashed into a pit on Tuesday morning.

The deceased and his friend, students of Sri Chaitanya College in Khammam in Rampuram village of Mahbubabad district, were going towards their college for an exam.

“At Bandipadu village, Vivek, who was riding the bike, lost control of the vehicle while trying to avoid a tipper coming from the opposite direction. The bike veered off the road and crashed into a pit. Vivek died on the spot while Lenin is out of danger,” Dornakal police said. tnn

Title: Fire at government cattle farm destroys 50 acres grazing area in Krishnagiri
Content:
Representative image

KRISHNAGIRI: A major fire broke out in the government cattle farm at Mathigiri near Hosur here on Monday night. While the cattle are safe, about 50 acres of trees, grass and herbs were destroyed in the incident.

The farm, which is spread across 1,640 acres, is the biggest of its kind in Asia. Besides 1,000 cows, both exotic and indigenous, the farm houses goats, sheep, roosters , hens and pigs.

Pointing out that trees, herbs and grass were cultivated on 50 acres for grazing the cattle, an official said fire engulfed the area around 10.30pm on Monday. As the fire began to spread, employees at the farm alerted the fire and rescue services personnel at Sipcot who sprang into action to douse the flames. It took them three hours to bring the fire under control.

The official said the cattle were put up on the right side of Hosur-Denkanikottai state highway, which passes through the farm, while the grazing area that caught fire was on its left side. “The fire didn’t spread to the area where the cattle were put up, thanks to the road in-between. All the cattle are safe.”

Preliminary investigation revealed that someone might have thrown a live cigarette butt or matchstick into the farm.

The Mathigiri police have registered a case and initiated inquiry.

Title: Trichy woman passenger quarantined at Kallikudi shops-turned-ward
Content: TRICHY: An woman passenger who returned from one of the countries most affected by Covid-19 was made to stay at one of the shops-turned-hospital wards at the central market for vegetables, fruits and flowers at Kallikudi late on Monday.It was the usual screening and verification process that revealed that she had returned from one of these countries. An employee of a private company, she had no symptoms, but public health department and airport health officials advised her to be quarantined at the makeshift ward at the central market at Kallikudi on the Trichy- Madurai national highway.As the passenger agreed to be quarantined, she was provided accommodation at the market. “Though the passenger has no symptom, the quarantine has to be done for a day to check for any symptom because of the passenger’s visit to the affected countries,” deputy director of health services (DDHS) Dr A Subramani told TOI. Such passengers have to be quarantined for 14 days but if the passenger seems healthy, the doctors will decide on discharge in a few days.A team of doctors has already been posted here to check the passenger for any symptom such as temperature, cough, sneezing and difficulty in breathing. A couple of policemen have also been posted for security. Besides providing food for the passengers staying here, the public health department has planned to set up Wi-Fi television in the rooms. Currently, the facility can accommodate 75 passengers. The department said protocols are being followed in keeping the information of the passengers confidential as it would cause stigma and also discourage people from taking treatment.

Title: Trichy: Cancellation of flights leaves flyers stranded
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: Cancellation of Air Asia and Malindo flights left about 50 Malaysia-bound passengers including women stranded at the international airport here on Tuesday. Citing the outbreak of covid-19, Air Asia and Malindo Air had cancelled their Kuala Lumpur flights and Sri Lankan Airlines its Colombo service from March 17 to April 15. Passengers from Malaysia who had booked return tickets on Air Asia and Malindo Air were shocked to know that the airlines had cancelled services.

Subsequently, the passengers picked up verbal altercations with authorities of the the airline as well as airport demanding alternate arrangements to reach their destinations. Revenue officials along with police arrived at the airport and held talks with the passengers. During the discussions, airport authorities agreed to make arrangements for accommodating two women, one of them pregnant, for one night on humanitarian grounds but asked the others to make their own arrangements.

Airport authorities told TOI that the revenue officials informed the Malaysian consulate in Chennai about the stranded passengers. The officials would discuss with them about the possibility of airlifting them to Malaysia.

Title: Digvijaya Singh’s bro removes ‘Congress’ from Twitter bio
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: Congress MLA Laxman Singh — Digvijaya’s brother — on Saturday removed the word ‘Congress’ from his Twitter handle, triggering a flutter in the party. He now describes himself as “Krishak, Vidhayak aur Gayak (farmer, MLA and singer)”.
