Laxman has been with BJP in the past, even getting elected to Lok Sabha on a BJP ticket, and has been sulking over not getting a ministerial berth. But when TOI spoke to him on his edited Twitter profile, he said: “I am in Congress and will remain with Congress.”

Asked if he had changed his Twitter bio, the Chachoda MLA said, “Yes, there was something like ‘ex-member of Parliament’, which I have dropped.” When specifically asked if he had removed mention of ‘Congress’ in his Twitter-bio, he didn’t give a clear reply, and repeated: “I am in Congress and will remain in Congress”.

Scindia had also changed his Twitter profile in November 2018, dropping all references to the posts he had held in Congress and introducing himself as a “public servant and cricket lover”. It says the same even now, when he has joined BJP.

As with Scindia, Laxman Singh’s new bio sparked speculation. He was a three-time Congress MP when he quit the party and joined BJP soon after Congress’s massive defeat in the December 2003 assembly election under the leadership of Digvijaya. Laxman won the 2004 Lok Sabha poll from Rajgarh on a BJP ticket but lost the 2009 election and came back to Congress in 2013.

A three-time MLA, he is upset at not being made minister and has made statements opposite to the party line. Last month, he urged Congress to “accept CAA” and in October last year, had sat on dharna at Digvijaya’s residence with his supporters, demanding that Chachoda be made a district.

Title: Delhi riots: House panel gets nearly 8,000 complaints
Content: NEW DELHI: Delhi assembly’s newly constituted peace and harmony committee will forward a social media message containing hateful content to Delhi Police for the registration of an FIR.The committee on Tuesday summoned two complainants to record their statements. After preliminary enquiry and statements of complainants, the committee found out that one case was fit for the registration of FIR. “The committee heard their submissions at length and reached the conclusion that one was a fit case for the registration of FIR,” committee chairman Raghav Chadha said. “Both the complainants also assured their support during the judicial process.”Interestingly, the nine-member peace and harmony committee was initially formed under Greater Kailash MLA Saurabh Bharadwaj . The Delhi assembly secretariat on Monday reconstituted it and made Chadha, MLA from Rajinder Nagar , its chairman. However, no reason was offered by the assembly secretariat or the AAP government on the change.It was formed after communal riots rocked northeast Delhi in the last week of February with an aim to calm the tempers of people and restore peace and harmony in violence affected areas.According to Chadha, the committee received 7,732 complaints since its launch two weeks ago. Of 2,110 complaints it screened, the committee found 504 to be inflammatory, provocative and incriminating in nature. “We are examining all these complaints on a mission mode,” Chadha said.The committee contacted 120 complainants and nine agreed to appear before it to record their statements. “The committee will meet all the complainants and alleged offenders in due course,” he added.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Maharashtra govt plans to allow quarantine unit in Mumbai's SevenHills Hospital
Content:
Some private hospitals wary of state government move

MUMBAI: In what would be a unique arrangement, the state government plans to hand over one of the floors in SevenHills Hospital , Marol, to private hospitals to set up and run an isolation facility. In a related development, public health minister Rajesh Tope on Tuesday confirmed that the state has allowed private hospitals to admit and treat Covid-19 patients.TOI has learned that civic and state officials are in talks with two leading private hospitals to set up a well-equipped isolation facility on the Marol hospital’s third floor, where a 40-bed ICU currently exists. A source said the ICU may be converted into an isolation facility and more beds will be added to it. Two south Mumbai hospitals are likely to jointly run the facility by dividing the beds between them. “Essentially, we will be running the facility and providing the manpower. Currently, the quarantine facility started by BMC is only to observe patients, there is nothing much to actively treat them,” said a management official of one of the hospitals.As per the new protocol, BMC has started screening all travellers, who are then sent to SevenHills Hospital for a risk profile evaluation. Besides Category A travellers (with symptoms) who were tested, the civic body has also begun testing those with no symptoms but belonging to a high-risk community. As on Tuesday, every patient who had symptoms and required admission had to be sent to Kasturba Hospital. “An isolation facility in SevenHills where patients can be treated will ease that burden,” said the management official. Around 120 patients are currently undergoing treatment in Kasturba.A discussion took place in Tuesday’s state cabinet meeting on allowing private hospitals to take one floor each in SevenHills hospital. BMC sources said facilities like Bombay Hospital have said they can set aside a few beds.However, other private hospitals were apprehensive about whether Covid-19 patients can be treated with others. “Coronavirus patients can only be admitted in a specific kind of negative pressure room. At our hospital, we do not have that kind of facility, and we are not an infectious disease hospital. We are, however, in process of developing one or two such beds to support this initiative on an urgent basis,” said Dr Tarang Gianchandani, CEO of Sir HN Reliance Foundation Hospital. BMC’s Dr Daksha Shah said Fortis Hospital in Mulund too has started a 15-bed isolation facility.BMC officials have in the last month surveyed around 5- 7 hospitals to look at their preparedness. “There is also the issue of who will pay for treatment if patients were to go there. Fortis, for instance, is a paying facility. At Seven-Hills, however, patients don’t have to pay for their treatment,” officials said.

Title: Covid-19 in Maharashtra: Mango trade likely to be hit as exports to foreign nations stalled
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

KOLHAPUR: Mango growers in the state seem unfazed by coronavirus though exports to foreign countries have been stalled. About 40% of the fruit produced in Konkan region is usually exported to the USA, Gulf and European countries.

Farmers as well as exporters said that since there will be a dip in the production of mangoes this season, they will not face any problem even if mangoes are not exported, adding that the produce will be more than sufficient to cater to the domestic need.

Anand Desai, a mango grower and exporter from Ratnagiri, said, “The outbreak of coronavirus will surely impact the mango export business as air service to all major exporting countries has been stalled. Mango is exported to European countries, Japan, Australia and USA through airways and Gulf by the sea. Usually the export of mangoes starts after April 15, but the contractors start visiting our sites to sign contracts in March every year. However, this year, rarely any contractor has visited our place to sign contracts for exporting mangoes. If this situation persists, it will affect the export business.”

“However, the mango production is expected to dip by 50% this year due to climatic changes and unfavourable environment. So, the rates of mangoes will remain high in the domestic market despite the reduction in the export,” he said.

Prasanna Pethe, another farmer and exporter, said, “Usually, we export mangoes to the United Kingdom and Qatar in March. This year, due to coronavirus we could not export mangoes. The export to the US and other countries takes place in late April and we expect that by that time the coronavirus threat will be reduced and the exports will be streamlined. The mango export continues till late May and there are possibilities of exporting mango after situation becomes normal. If the situation worsens further, it will be difficult for us to export the mango. However, the dip in mango production will help in meeting the demand-supply gap. This year, also the supply of mangoes will be less and the demand will remain high even if we could not export it as the available mango will not be able to meet domestic requirement.”

According to APEDA (Agricultural and Processed Food Products Export Development Authority), the mango export in 2018-19 worth Rs 385.62 crore was 48470 metric tonne. The production and export of mangoes in the last three to four years varies depending on the climatic and environmental conditions. Along with fresh mangoes, sliced, dried and mango pulp is also exported from India.

The government has granted Geographical Indication (GI) tag to the Alphonso mango from Ratnagiri, Sindhudurg and neighbouring Konkan region.

Title: Coimbatore cops wear masks as a precaution
Content:
COIMBATORE: City police commissioner Sumit Sharan has instructed cops on patrol duty and those conducting vehicle checks to wear face masks.

“We have distributed enough masks to the personnel and have also advised them to use hand sanitizers,” Sharan said.

Ramanathapuram police (law&order) inspector S Murugesan and team cleaned the police station and premises and sprayed sanitizers on the campus. Thirty cops in the station were given face masks.

“Our men, who are conducting vehicle checks at the Nanjundapuram check posts, are wearing face masks. We are sensitizing public about the importance of wearing the masks as a precautionary measure to fight Covid-19,” said Murugesan. As many as 230 traffic cops in the city have been given face masks, deputy commissioner of police (traffic) R Mutharasu said.

Title: One nabbed with ganja at Mapusa
Content:
Panaji: The crime branch of Goa police on Tuesday arrested a Rajasthan native with a narcotic substance worth Rs 2.3 lakh at Mapusa.

Crime branch received a tip-off that a person would deliver drugs to a customer at Mapusa. Based on this, the police constituted a team and laid a trap to nab the drug peddler. Police said they nabbed the accused when he arrived at the spot, and seized from him a polythene bag containing ganja weighing over 2kg worth Rs 2.3 lakh.

Crime branch officials also attached the two-wheeler used by the accused.

During interrogation, the accused revealed that he was involved in a drug deal in Mapusa, police said.

Title: Four new suspects isolated in state
Content: Panaji: Four new Covid-19 suspects, including two foreigners, were admitted to GMC ’s isolation ward on Tuesday. A British national, who was isolated, was discharged after her test reports came negative.One of the suspects is a Norwegian who came to Goa after travelling to other parts of India and showed symptoms of Covid-19. A Briton with travel history was admitted after she showed symptoms of Covid-19. Other two suspects are Indian nationals.State epidemiologist Dr Utkarsh Betodkar said swab samples of the four have been sent for testing and reports are expected on Wednesday. The number of persons under home quarantine is 49. tnn

Title: Trichy: Fishers seek nod to use banned seine nets
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: Hundreds of fishermen and women from the coastal hamlets of Nagapattinam district besieged the collector’s office demanding permission for using the banned purse seine fishing nets.

The government had banned purse seine nets stating that they seriously harm marine species and adversely impact marine life. The government also conducts checks to prevent the use of such of nets in 13 coastal districts, including Nagapattinam.

The fisherfolk from Poompuhar and surrounding areas in Sirkazhi taluk gathered in front of the collector’s office on Monday and staged a demonstration. Police allowed representatives to meet district revenue officer (DRO) Inthumathi and submit a memorandum seeking government’s nod to use the nets. In their memorandum, they said that around five lakh fishermen hailing from Nagapattinam, Cuddalore, Villupuram , Kancheepuram and Thiruvallur districts are engaged in fishing activities. Without using seine nets, fishermen are not able to get enough catch. TNN

Title: Trichy: Medicos seek adequate face masks, sanitizers
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: While appreciating the Tamil Nadu government’s decision to close down all educational institutions over Covid-19 fears, Tamil Nadu Medical Students Association has appealed to the government to ensure adequate stock of face masks and hand sanitizers for them through Tamil Nadu Medical Service Corporation (TNMSC).

Association state secretary B Arunandhi asked the state government to declare holiday for undergraduate medicine students of all government and private colleges. The association cited the shortage of face masks and sanitizers with government colleges and hospitals as also in the market as the reason for their demand. “Undergraduate students on clinical postings at the hospitals are exposed and vulnerable to the virus. Instead of pushing them to the risky situation, they can be given holiday and sent home for their safety,” said Dr Arunandhi.

Associate general secretary Dr Hari Ganesh said that all undergraduate medical students were not healthcare providers and were students like the ones in other courses. The doctors, house-surgeons and post-graduate students also face the same risk in their line of duty of saving the lives of patients. “Sadly, they are also running short of safety measures at their work place. Hence, we appeal to the government to make face masks and sanitizers on their own and supply free of cost to the medicos,” said Arunanandhi.

The association also pointed out the exorbitant price of masks and sanitizers in the market. The double layer masks that were available for Rs 10 now cost up to Rs 40. “So the government should produce them in large amounts with the help of TNMSC and prevent scarcity. The government should install hand sanitizer points in public places,” he said.

Title: Smart water meter trial to kick off in RS Puram
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: With the installation of smart water meters in 200 houses at RS Puram under the 24/7 drinking water supply project nearing complete, the city corporation is likely to start metering water consumed in the houses on a trial basis soon.

Suez India Private Limited is installing 100 multi-jet water meters, 50 ultrasonic water meters and 50 electromagnetic water meters at houses selected randomly 15 days ago. “While multi-jet meters are cheap, the other two varieties will have long life. As the minimum starting flow of the meters differs, accuracy will also vary from a meter to the other. So, the performance of the meters will be studied for two to three months. Based on the performance report, the best meter will be chosen and used throughout the city,” a corporation official said.

Meanwhile, the company is also laying new pipelines and giving household water connections in RS Puram. As of now, it has given connections to 3,500 out of the 5,785 houses and laid pipelines for 34.7 kilometres out of the total 41.82 kilometres.

Corporation commissioner J Sravan Kumar had directed the contractor to complete the works in RS Puram by March so as to conduct a test run before extending the project to the other parts of the city.

But sources privy to the development said that the works may get delayed. The firm has not started work on DB Road because of the ongoing model road project. Also, the process is still on to obtain no-objection certificate from the national highways to dig up the Mettupalayam Road.

In addition to RS Puram, works are being carried out to lay additional pipelines and to replace the existing ones at Mulai Nagar and Pari Nagar near Papanaickenpudur , from Meena Estate to Sowripalayam, Jayaram Nagar and Cheran Nagar near Telugupalayam Road.

Title: Coronavirus: Screening of passengers entering Kolhapur from today
Content: KOLHAPUR: The travelers coming to Kolhapur through state transport or private buses from Mumbai, Pune, Belgaum and Bangalore will be screened for symptoms of coronavirus at the six city entry points from Wednesday.The Kolhapur Municipal Corporation has decided to conduct the screening of passengers. The step has been taken to keep a check on the spread of the disease in the city.According to the KMC officials, they will focus on the long distance MSRTC buses and private tourist buses entering in city on National Highway 4. The passengers will be checked at at five identified spots including Shiye toll plaza, Shahu toll plaza, Shiroli, the routes from which buses enter into city via NH4 and at central bus stand and railway station.KMC’s chief health officer Dilip Patil said, “We will not conduct screening or check-up of all the passengers from the bus nor will consider the buses travelling short distance. Our focus is to gather information about the passengers travelling from long distance centres into Kolhapur.”Patil said they would be gathering information about the passengers with travel history to foreign countries and those who have come in contact with any person, who has recent travel history.“The information of the particular passenger will be gathered along with the location he is planning to visit in city. The ward office and the health department in the ward will be informed about such people. The offices will conduct screening of such people and check if they have any symptoms of cough, cold and flu,” he said.He clarified that they will not consider the passengers entering Kolhapur from nearby villages or towns or from other routes like Ratnagiri, Gaganbawada or Radhanagari.District collector Daulat Desai said, “We have issued instructions to the civic officials as well as RTO to deploy sufficient staff to run the exercise successfully and ensure that people entering the city are safe and do not have any symptoms of the coronavirus. This is one of the step to prevent the spread of coronavirus.”

Title: Five Thailand citizens admitted to hospital in Erode
Content:
Representative image

ERODE: The district health department officials have admitted five Thailand citizens to the government hospital in Perundurai after one of their teammates was found with Covid-19 symptoms at the Coimbatore airport on Sunday.

According to an officer, the six had come down to Erode from Thailand on Saturday to participate in some religious meetings.

“One of them suddenly fell sick and decided to return to Thailand. He booked a flight from Coimbatore airport, where he arrived on Sunday. Airport officials subjected him to a medical check-up and confirmed that he was having Covid-19 symptoms. Subsequently, he was quarantined in Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH), but tested negative for Covid-19 on Monday evening,” said Dr S Soundammal, deputy director, health services, Erode district .

Based on the information that he was accompanied by five others, the health department officials in Erode went to Perundurai, where they were staying, and admitted them to the government hospital.

“They are put in a special ward. Doctors have collected their blood samples and they will be treated based on the reports,” Soundammal said.

Meanwhile, their teammate died of renal failure at CMCH on Tuesday.

Title: Quick-win lake projects to be delayed
Content:
Representative image

COIMBATORE: The quick-win lake beautification projects being implemented along the bunds of Ukkadam Periyakulam and Valankulam under the smart city mission are likely to be delayed by a few months.

Following the directions of state municipal administration minister SP Velumani, the city corporation had set March as deadline for the projects and had been speeding up the works.

But a source privy to the develsopment said that as the contractors do not have prior experience in carrying out such work, it is likely to be delayed. “They have completed close to 70% of the work and installed most of the important components. But as the lake beautification project is being carried out for the first time in the State, the contractors lack experience and expertise,” he said.

As the project is expected to set a benchmark when it comes to beautification of lakes, the officials want all components to be perfect, the source said. “So, the workers have to remove and rework on the components whenever a suggestion is made or chances for improvement are high.”

Each project has as many as 450 components like floating decks, gardens, birdwatching towers, mist fountains, shade structures, bicycle track, benches, lamps, container restaurants and native plant species along the bunds.

The civic body had in July 2018 launched the quick-win projects for restoration and rejuvenation of Periyakulam on the Perur Bypass at the cost of Rs 39.74s crore, construction of a walkers’ plaza along the road that passes through the Valankulam lake and people promenade at the cost of Rs 24.31 crore, and rejuvenation of Valankulam lake at the cost of Rs 23.83 crore

Title: Covid-19 in Maharashtra: Prayers, discourses move online
Content:
Haji Ali mgmt appeals against overcrowding

shut

For the first time in history, the largest temples in Maharashtra closed for public darshan indefinitely from Tuesday due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Shirdi Sai temple, Tuljabhavani in Osmanabad and Shani Shingnapur in Ahmednagar shut. Some invited devotees to watch live prayers online on the temple app or website. In Mumbai, Siddhivinayak and Babulnath temples did likewise.Siddhivinayak chairman Aadesh Bandekar said devotees can watch all aartis live from morning till the night shejarti on their web site.In a rare move, lectures held in upashreyas—lecture halls and residences for Jain monks—have been called off. The upcoming holy week of Ayambil from March 31 till April 8, which sees the community eat at temple-kitchens, has been cancelled. Instead, groups of neighbours will take turns to cook food sans oil and masalas. “Police closed some upashreyas where lectures were still on,” said Babulal Jain, editor of the All India Jain Chaturmas Suchi. Some monks and Jain gurus have moved online. Shrimad Rajchandra Mission streamed a weekly lecture on Youtube.St Michael's Church in Mahim also suspended public entry to the Wednesday Novena prayer. The prayer will be streamed online. St Peter’s Church, Bandra, streamed the evening mass. Church services are expected to be suspended, with a formal decision likely on Thursday.Parsi houses of worship began to close on Tuesday. The Seth R N Rustomframna Agiary in Dadar closed at the behest of Matunga police station. Managing trustee Nasha Jassawalla said the boi, a ritual held five times a day for the consecrated fire, and other ceremonies, will continue.To contain the spread of Covid-19, managements of Haji Ali and Makhdoom Mahimi dargahs have appealed to devotees against overcrowding. They have been told not to stay for long at dargahs’ premises and leave as soon as they have performed essential prayers. Meanwhile, Maulana Burhanuddin Qasmi, director of Jogeshwari’s Markazul Maarif Research Centre said local madrassa is shut.Nehru Planetarium and Nehru Science Centre, both at Worli, will provisionally shut till March 31. The planetarium gets about 500 visitors a day and the centre 1,000 at this time of the year. Nehru Science Centre director Shivprasad Khened said, “We organized an exhibition about Coronavirus.”(Inputs by Hemali Chhapia, Bella Jaisinghani, Mohammed Wajihuddin, Srinivas Laxman & V Narayan)

Title: Trivendra Rawat government completes 3 years in office, Rawat first BJP CM to complete full 3 yrs
Content: Dehradun: Trivendra Singh Rawat is set to become the first BJP chief minister ( CM ) of the state to complete three years in office on Wednesday. He had taken oath on March 18, 2017.Earlier, Major General (retired) BC Khanduri was the longest serving BJP CM of the state. In his first term, the Major General had completed 2 years and 111 days (from March 6, 2007 to June 26, 2009) in office and his second term was for 184 days (from September 11, 2011 to March 13, 2012). Other BJP CMs had even shorter terms. Ramesh Pokhriyal Nishank was in office for 2 years and 75 days (from June 26, 2007 to September 10, 2011), Nityanand Swami for 354 days (November 9, 2000 to October 29, 2001), and Bhagat Singh Koshyari for 122 days (October 30, 2001 to March 1, 2002).Incidentally, Trivendra Rawat is also set to become the second longest serving CM of the state overtaking Harish Rawat who served for three years and a day.So far, ND Tiwari of Congress has been the only CM of Uttarakhand to complete his full five-year term. Interacting with TOI ahead of his government completing three years, CM Rawat said, “I consider that one of my big achievements has been to stop the mafia culture. Middlemen who were given a free run around ministers and even the CM have been wiped out. Mafias don’t dominate things in our state anymore and their nexus has been destroyed. Today, there is complete transparency between the state government and the people.”

Title: No Tolly shooting till March 30
Content: Kolkata: Though the news of complete shutdown of shooting in Tollywood till March 30 has come as a big jolt to producers, all stakeholders agree that it is an unavoidable and necessary step in the current circumstances. With scant episode banks of megaserials, tele serial addicts will now have to make do with repeat telecast of their favourite soaps.Minister Arup Biswas told TOI, “We have asked shooting to be stalled till March 30. I have no estimate of the financial losses. All I can say is the value of an individual’s life is greater than any financial loss.” When Biswas was asked if shutdown orders were meant for post-production units too, he said, “The objection is against mass gatherings.”Meanwhile, actress Pallavi Chatterjee has mooted the idea of organizing a charity show with stars once work resumes. “We can do this to raise funds for the daily wage-earners of our industry,” Chatterjee said.Meanwhile, Sani Ghosh Ray of Welfare Associations of Television Producers (WATP) said serial producers will stand to lose at least Rs 20 crore. Even those who rent out shooting floors or provide equipment including camera and grips, are counting heavy losses.Equally tense are the home-bound viewers whose evenings are spent in front of the televisions. With more now staying back at home, there is a higher need of daily dose of entertainment from television. Director Leena Gangopadhyay, co-founder of Magic Moments that produces ‘Sreemoyee’, ‘Nakshikantha’, ‘Mohor’, ‘Korapakhi’ and ‘Jeonkathi’, is trying hard to shoot enough content till Sunday. “We stand to lose a crore at least. That’s why we are requesting artistes and studio owners who have contracts with us to consider their monthly fees for these days,” Gangopadhyay said.SVF currently has episode banks till Friday for its seven serials — ‘Trinoyonim’, ‘Joy Baba Loknath’, ‘Prothoma Kadambini’, ‘Nishir Daak’, ‘Chuni Panna’, ‘Bagh Bandi Khela’ and ‘Durga Durgeshwari’.

Title: 2 French nationals among 4 quarantined in Coimbatore
Content:
Representative imageCOIMBATORE: Two French nationals and as many city residents with travel history and fever were quarantined to test for Covid-19 on Tuesday. With this, the number of people who are isolated and being tested for the virus in the district rose to six. While two other people were quarantined earlier, their test results are yet to arrive.

Public health department officials said the French nationals were in the city for ayurvedic treatment. “They reached the city via Mumbai. The treatment centre referred them to us and they have been quarantined in the ESI Medical College Hospital. Their throat swabs are being collected for tests and they will be sent to Chennai,” said an official.

In another instance, a 15-year-old boy from Mettupalayam who returned from Sharjah on March 5, and a 49-year-old man from Cheranmanagar with a travel history to Hyderabad have also been also quarantined in the Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH). Their throat swabs were collected on Tuesday.

Dr G Ramesh Kumar, deputy director of public health, said, “The boy has been having fever on and off for the past 10 days. He passed the thermal scanner at the airport because he had a paracetamol earlier. He was, however, suffering from high fever for the past two days and that prompted him to come to us.”

The 49-year-old man had travel history to Hyderabad and Kochi by flight and bus. He has been suffering from fever, accompanied by cough and dry cough, for the past two days. He had approached Kovai Medical College Hospital , from where they referred him to CMCH.

Earlier, a 35-year-old man from Udumalpet with a travel history from Singapore, and a 67-year-old woman from Valparai with a travel history to Kottayam, were put in isolation and their test results are awaited.

District collector K Rajamani, meanwhile, said the testing centre that is being set up at Coimbatore Medical College, Peelamedu, would become functional by Thursday.

Title: SC gives 24-hr notice to Nath govt to respond to floor test demand
Content:
New Delhi: The Supreme Court on Tuesday gave 24 hours to the Congress government in Madhya Pradesh led by Kamal Nath to respond to a petition filed by former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan seeking immediate floor test on the ground that the government had been reduced to a minority after the resignation of 22 MLAs.

It did not take much persuasion from senior advocate Mukul Rohatgi for a bench of Justices D Y Chandrachud and Hemant Gupta to order, “Issue notice. In view of the urgency of the situation, the notice is made returnable at 10.30 am on March 18, 2020.” It allowed the notice to be served through email and posted further hearing for Wednesday.

The MP assembly Speaker had accepted the resignation of six of the 22 MLAs and the MP Congress legislature party (MPCLP) swiftly moved the SC in the afternoon alleging that BJP had used money and muscle power to abduct the MLAs and kept them in captivity outside the state. It said if the floor test was to be held, it should be done after by-elections to the 22 seats which fell vacant upon the resignation of MLAs.

Before the MPCLP moved the SC, senior advocate Maninder Singh, appearing for the 16 MLAs, requested the bench to make them a party to the petition filed by Chouhan and other BJP MLAs.

Singh said the MLAs had resigned of their own volition, being peeved by the Kamal Nath government’s failure to serve the people. The 16 MLAs requested the SC to direct the Speaker to accept their resignations immediately. The bench ordered their petition to be served on the Kamal Nath government.

The 16 MLAs said, “None of the 22 MLAs either came out of Bengaluru nor did they appear before the Speaker. However, the Speaker for reasons best known to him accepted the resignations of only six MLAs on March 14.” While requesting the SC to direct the Speaker to accept their resignations forthwith, they said, “Floor test cannot be withheld under the pretext of the 16 MLAs not being available.”

The MPCLP petition, settled by senior advocate Devadatt Kamat, alleged that BJP had kept the 16 MLAs in complete isolation in Bengaluru to bring down the democratically elected government in MP by misusing the official machinery of the Union and the Karnataka government.

Accusing the governor of pre-judging the situation and directing floor test by concluding that the Kamal Nath government had lost majority in the House without taking into account forcibly taking away of 16 MLAs, MPCLP raised a constitutional question — whether a trust vote ought to be held in the absence of any representation of the electorate who had voted in support of the incumbent government.

“In the instant case, as 22 MLAs, who represent 22 constituencies constituting almost 10% of the total strength of the House, have purportedly resigned, the electorate of such constituencies are completely unrepresented. In these circumstances, a trust vote, if held, will be a complete sham and would be antithetical to the principle of representative democracy which is a basic feature of the Constitution. A floor test in such a situation ought to be held only after by-elections to the seats falling vacant as a result of resignations,” it said.

Title: Coimbatore: Elephant calf falls into tank, rescued
Content:
Forest department personnel broke down one side of the tank and allowed the calf to walk out of the water body... Read More

COIMBATORE: Forest department personnel rescued an elephant calf that fell into a water body in Periyanaickenpalayam range in Coimbatore district on Monday evening. They ensured that the calf reunited with its herd.

Around 6.45pm on Monday, the forest department received a message that an elephant seemed to be in trouble because many elephants were making noise in a place inside the forest.

“When we reached the spot, we realised that a one-year-old calf had fallen into a tank while drinking water. We then chased away the remaining nine elephants that stood around the tank. We ensured that no public came anywhere near the area and began the rescue operation,” said Periyanaickenpalayam forest ranger Suresh.

Forest department personnel broke down one side of the tank and allowed the calf to walk out of the water body.

The forest department personnel, numbering 25, then moved away and allowed the herd to return and join the calf again. “We saw the calf moving away with the herd comfortably,” said the ranger.

Title: No Jallikattu in Pudukottai till March 31
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: The Pudukkottai district administration has suspended all bull-taming events -- jallikattu , vadamadu and manjuvirattu -- till March 31 to prevent the spread of Covid-19.

Pudukkottai district organises the maximum number of jallikattu events in Tamil Nadu every year. More than five jallikattu events were happening in the district every weekend since the Pongal festival in mid-January.

District collector P Uma Maheswari said the decision had been taken after the state government on Monday asked people to refrain from organising any event that would witness mass gathering.

On Tuesday, the collector called for a meeting of the district tourism officer and officials from the Hindu religious and charitable endowment (HR&CE) department. She directed them to close down tourist places and defer religious festivals that were to take place before March 31.

Similarly, permission will not be given by the district administration to conduct jallikattu till March 31.

Speaking to TOI, Maheswari said that the district has already witnessed about 31 jallikattu events from January this year. “Permission was given to about 20 more venues but now we have deferred the events till March 31,” she said.

Title: U’khand invokes Esma on health staff, no strike for 6 months
Content:
Dehradun: To tackle the spread of novel coronavirus, the state government on Tuesday invoked the Essential Services Maintenance Act ( Esma ) on health department staff thereby barring them from taking part in any strike for six months.

According to a letter issued by additional secretary Yugal Kishore Pant, governor Baby Rani Maurya has given her approval for Esma on health staff in the state. It added that no health department employee, including doctors and paramedics, would be allowed to take part in any strike for the next six months as their services would be needed in combating coronavirus.

The development came a day after some OBC employees in the department announced that they would join the strike against the Supreme Court’s ruling on reservations in promotion.

Meanwhile, the health department on Tuesday collected samples of 19 suspected coronavirus patients in the state. While 10 were from Dehradun, six were from US Nagar and three from Haridwar. Similarly, samples of 27 trainee IFS officers were also collected by the health officials. The health department has so far sent 51 samples for Covid-19 testing, out of which 28 were found to be negative and one positive. The reports of 22 people are still awaited.

Food safety and drug administration commissioner Dr Pankaj Pandey also issued a letter to medical store owners and pharmacists in the state asking them not to prescribe any medication on their own to people suffering from common cold and flu, adding that they should make sanitisers available at affordable rates.

Teams from the Dehradun Municipal Corporation also sprayed bleaching powder and other disinfectants at various places across the city to prevent the spread of the infection.

INSET: An elderly couple from Vikas Nagar, who recently visited their son in Dubai, was brought to Doon hospital for Covid-19 testing on Tuesday after they complained of fever and cough. The doctors checked them inside the 108 ambulance and advised them to return home as they did not show any symptom. However, they had to spend over three hours inside the vehicle as the ambulance staff later refused to drop them home. The matter was sorted after CMO Dr Meenakshi Joshi ordered the designated ambulance staff to provide both pick and drop for suspected coronavirus cases.

Title: Bharathidasan Institute of Management holds graduation day
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: Insisting that students question themselves on their larger purpose and not chase short-term growth targets, Harpreet Singh Tibb , founder, Solaron Homes private limited, Mumbai, said that bright young minds are expected to help tackle challenges faced by every single organization – public or private — in the country. He was speaking at the 30th graduation day of Bharathidasan Institute of Management (BIM) Trichy on Saturday. Sustainability is one of the key highlights of the future, he said.

“People primarily associate sustainability with environmental conservation, but it is also about the people and the health of our communities,” said Harpreet. TNN

Title: Trichy: Railways urged to waive cancellation charges
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: When the Union government has declared Covid-19 as a national disaster and is imposing travel restrictions on the general public, it is unfair for railways to charge cancellation fees, say frequent rail travellers. Railways should come forward to waive the cancellation charges so that commuters remain at home and check the spread of the disease, they say.

Secretary of Thanjavur District Cauvery Farmers Protection Association Swamimalai S Vimalnathan said he booked nine tickets for travelling to Thiruvananthapuram on March 19 to meet Kerala chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan to thank him for fixing higher MSP for paddy. However, he was forced to cancel the tickets due to the evolving Covid-19 scenario. “The fare was Rs 560 for both up and down travel. After cancelling the ticket, I can get back only Rs 320, and forgo Rs 240 as cancellation charge. Railways is making money even after World Health Organization (WHO) announced Covid-19 outbreak as a pandemic”, Vimalnathan, who is also a member of divisional railway users consultative committee (DRUCC) said.

A Giri, advisor and media coordinator of Thanjavur District Rail Users' Association, has also appealed to the railway minister to waive the levy of cancellation fee on tickets booked for journeys up to April 15 and arrange for refunding the full fare. “Because of the virus attack, many passengers are cancelling their tickets. This will cause the loss of a huge amount to them by way of cancellation fee. Avoidance of such travel has helped the government to control mass spreading of the disease. The conveyance fee levied by IRCTC on those tickets while booking must also be refunded along with the ticket fare,”, he added.

Title: Thai man with Covid-19 symptoms dies in Coimbatore ward
Content: COIMBATORE: A 49-year-old man from Thailand who was tested negative for Covid-19 recently , died at the isolation ward of Coimbatore Medical College and Hospital (CMCH) on Tuesday afternoon. While hospital authorities said he died of renal failure, other sources pointed out his symptoms of fever The deceased has been identified as Donrosal Khamidoi, from Songkhla. He reportedly came to India with five others on March 6 to visit Hindu temples. He decided to return home on Sunday as he fell sick with fever and became very weak.Dr G Ramesh Kumar, deputy director of public health, said, “However, our thermal scanners in the airport detected his fever and we brought him to CMCH the same evening. We collected his throat swab and sent that to Chennai. When he arrived, he was suffering from fever, light breathlessness and an infected ulcer in his leg.”Dr Sadagopan, medical superintendent, CMCH, said Khamidoi had a history of diabetic nephropathy and that renal failure was diagnosed almost immediately after he was admitted. “So, we began giving him peritoneal dialysis for his failing kidneys and antibiotics to bring down his temperature. He did not mention having a cold before the fever. We isolated him as he could be a carrier of the virus. He also had uncontrolled diabetes.”The public health department said while the test result that came on Monday evening was negative, they continued to isolate him and treat him for his renal failure and septicemia, which he had developed. But he died on Tuesday, Dr Sadagopan said.Ramesh said, “We agree that fever followed by multi-organ failure is similar to Covid-19 symptoms, but he tested negative. As per protocol, we are to test suspected symptomatic patients only once. Only Covid-19 positive patients have to be tested twice before being declared negative.”The officials have decided not to do a postmortem. The district administration is in touch with Indian embassy in Thailand to send his body back home.The public health department officials in Erode have, meanwhile, admitted the teammates of the deceased to the government hospital in Perundurai, where they are put in a special ward. Their blood samples have been collected to test them for Covid-19.

Title: Coronavirus: Four new suspects isolated in Goa
Content: PANAJI: Four new Covid-19 suspects , including two foreigners, were admitted to GMC’s isolation ward on Tuesday. A British national, who was isolated, was discharged after her test reports came negative.One of the suspects is a Norwegian who came to Goa after travelling to other parts of India and showed symptoms of Covid-19. A Briton with travel history was admitted after she showed symptoms of Covid-19. Other two suspects are Indian nationals.State epidemiologist Dr Utkarsh Betodkar said swab samples of the four have been sent for testing and reports are expected on Wednesday. The number of persons under home quarantine is 49.

Title: ‘Coming out of trauma with help of family & friends’
Content: It was a traumatic experience for this IT professional after his test for coronavirus turned out to be positive. It was a shock for him and his family as, unlike his colleague from the same IT company who took ill, this professional didn’t have even a running nose.It took him a couple of days to realize that he has tested positive and needs to spend next two weeks in complete isolation, away from the family and friends. He has been kept at the Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) where mobile handset is his only companion.In a talk with TOI, the second positive patient from the city shares his experience and how he’s coping with it. He now advises all on taking utmost precautions to avoid getting contracted and on not to panic even if tested positive.Excerpts from the interview...You seem to have contracted the virus through your colleague.We three colleagues were together in the US and again met at Doha airport where we spent some time as the flight to India was late by three hours. Our first colleague, who has contracted the virus, was not keeping well at that time, but we thought it was due to his hectic schedule in the US. Frankly, we never imagined that he was sick due to coronavirus. After our colleague was found to have tested positive, the officials from the government’s disaster management team called me and family members at around midnight for testing our swab samples.What was the next step then? Did you panic?They told us to get immediately admitted, but I was unprepared. They shifted us to isolation ward where my colleague’s wife and I were offered separate rooms. We were surprised as both of us don’t have any symptoms till date of disease like cold, cough and fever. Though we’re fit, the doctors told us that we would act as virus carriers outside and therefore we need to stay for 14 days mandatory isolation.How do you pass the time in isolation?I’ve fixed a timetable for myself and sticking to it. I wake up early in the morning and get ready. Then I read a newspaper for a couple of hours. Later, I check my WhatsApp messages and speak with family members, friends and relatives. Both my sisters stay abroad and they also call me up. But due to poor connectivity, video calls can’t be made. I also read books and have fixed time for exercising every day. Being in a joint family is a big advantage as the members are constantly trying to pep me up. Our company is also supportive and helps in transporting our food from home to hospital and vice versa.How are the facilities at GMCH?Initially, they were not up to the mark but, in last couple of days, they’ve improved tremendously. The authorities have provided us rooms with attached toilets which are cleaned and disinfected daily. The doctors and nurses are very helpful and taking good care of us. I am really impressed with the kind of services offered by them.

Title: Training given to Trichy health centres to make cost-effective disinfectant
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: The public health and preventive medicine department has advised health centres to switch to conventional method of hypochlorite solution and bleaching powder instead of using Lysol IP solution, here on Tuesday.

The meeting, attended by around 200 people including government doctors and medical officers from private hospitals, was chaired by collector S Sivarasu at the collector collectorate.

At the training meeting, Dr S Dhanapal of department of microbiology at KAP Viswanatham Government Medical College , demonstrated how to produce disinfectant using hypochlorite, bleaching powder and water.

“Disinfectant remains a crucial part of fighting against Covid-19. The cleanliness of public places including hospitals is paramount. At the same time, the process should be cost effective so,” deputy director of health services Dr A Subramani told TOI.

Subramani said that the cost of making hypochlorite solution and bleaching powder will be three times cheaper than making 1% Lysol IP. “Only thing is the solution should be kept in a black container to avoid evaporation of the solution,” he said.

The public health department had encouraged people to use the Lysol IP (50% cresol and 50% liquid soap) as disinfectants. For hospitals, clinics and ambulances, 5% Lysol (one litre Lysol with nine litres of water) should be used. Bus stands, vehicles and other public places, should be disinfected with 2.5% Lysol (one litre Lysol in 19 litres water). Households can use 1% Lysol (one litre Lysol in 49L of water).

As hand sanitizers are out of stock in the outlets, the health department has planned to manufacture hand sanitizers on their own to supply to primary health centres and other government health facilities in the district.

Title: Tilamol locals up in arms over building project
Content:
QUEPEM: A group of residents held demonstrations outside Xeldem panchayat office and near the site of a multi-dwelling project, alleging violation of the approved plan and misrepresentation of facts by the builder about the project site access and other aspects.

On Tuesday, residents of Novimoddi , Tilamol shouted slogans against the panchayat and town and country planning (TCP) department for allowing the builder to proceed with the construction despite the violation.

The locals’ grouse in particular is the public access road which they claim has been shown in the project plan as the builder’s own property. They alleged that the builder has blocked the reserved internal access route leading to more than 30 mundkarial houses and began construction work within the proposed road area.

The private project is coming up around 60m from Tilamol junction. The locals said the project area is an open space reserved for residents, and that hey have been conducting cultural activities there for decades.

Title: On anniversary of Parrikar’s death, CM vows rural infra
Content:
Panaji: Chief minister Pramod Sawant on Tuesday said that over the next two years, the government would focus on fulfilling former chief minister Manohar Parrikar’s second dream of developing infrastructure in the state’s rural areas.

He also said the government would provide rural locales with 100% electricity and water connections by 2022 and would work towards making Goa garbage-free as a tribute to the late chief minister. Sawant was speaking to reporters after offering floral tributes on Parrikar’s first death anniversary, at Miramar beach, where the former chief minister was cremated and where an interactive memorial is being constructed.

“We will complete rural development in all sectors in the next two years,” Sawant said. “If we want to pay tribute to Parrikar, we have to make Goa no. 1 in all sectors.”

As part of developing rural infrastructure, the government will spend around Rs 90 lakh to provide solar power to 19 houses located in forest areas.

“Parrikar had a 25-year plan for development of all sectors of the state…Not a single day has gone by during the past year where we haven’t remembered him for his contribution to social and administrative work,” Sawant said.

He said Parrikar had provided Goa with solid infrastructure for healthcare and education and had even revived the waning agriculture sector .The infrastructure completed now would cater to the people of the state for the next 25 years, he added.

Title: Odisha: Hoteliers move government for revival plan, deferment of EMIs
Content: BHUBANESWAR: Hoteliers have sought the state government ’s help to tide over imminent financial crisis.The Hotel and Restaurant Association of Odisha (HRAO), the apex body of private hotels, submitted a memorandum to chief minister Naveen Patnaik on Tuesday, requesting the government to come to the rescue of the crisis-ridden hospitality sector.“We (HRAO) appreciate the steps taken by the state government to prevent the spread of Covid-19. The HRAO also pledges full support to the government at this time of crisis. But the travel, trade and hotel industry of Odisha is staring at huge financial losses as many inbound tourists are cancelling tours, conferences, banquet bookings and marriage functions,” said HRAO chairman J K Mohanty.The hotel body requested the government to float a revival plan for the industry. “We have taken loans from banks. In the current situation, it seems difficult for us to pay interest and EMIs. The state government should advise banks to cooperate with us and defer payment of EMIs and interests till the situation becomes normal,” the HRAO memorandum said.The hotel association also sought the waiver of state GST and fee for any upcoming licence/permit renewals (such as holding tax, bar licence renewal/groundwater fee and electricity charges) for the next few months.“We are yet to overcome the financial burden caused by Cyclone Fani in May last year. None of the affected hotels has received any help or incentive from the government. In the wake of the Covid-19 outbreak, the state government and the business community should come together and work for a better business environment. We expect our government will take a positive approach and help us in this crisis,” the HRAO memorandum said.The tourism department said the government would consider the HRAO suggestions only after the situation improved. “Our (the government’s) immediate priority is to take steps to stop the spread of the virus. We understand the financial losses to tourism and other sectors. Corrective steps will be taken when the situation is successfully handled,” a tourism official said.

Title: Delhi: Fight over marriage ends in girl’s murder
Content:
Heera Singh (left) told police that he killed Priyanka because she was against his decision of marrying someon... Read More

NEW DELHI: A 23-year-old pharmacist working at a hospital in south Delhi has been arrested for kidnapping and murdering his 23-year- old relative with whom he was in a relationship since 2017. The girl’s body was found in Uttar Pradesh’s Rampur on February 6.

The accused identified as Heera Singh told police that he murdered her because she was against his decision of marrying someone else.

“Around 8pm on February 5, Singh had gone to meet his relative Priyanka. He had to give her an old phone as she had lost her mobile a day earlier. Meanwhile, an argument broke out between them over him getting married to another woman, as they were in a relationship. She threatened to teach him a lesson and left the room in anger,” said Atul Kumar Thakur, DCP, South.

The victim, who was also a pharmacist, subsequently rushed and took a bus from the BRT corridor. The accused followed her and entered the same bus. Before alighting at the Anand Vihar stop around 10pm, they quarrelled in the bus as well. “He calmed her down and told her they would get married in Rampur,” added Thakur.

The two then boarded a UP roadways bus, which was going towards Bareily. Around 4.30 am the next day, they got off at Rampur bus stop and started walking. The victim walked ahead of him and refused to listen in anger. As per the accused, the victim did not like his wife-to-be.

“Soon, a scuffle broke out between them and Priyanka allegedly slapped Singh. In a fit of rage, the accused picked up a brick and hit her at her face. She fell down after which he allegedly hit her six more times. Realising that she was dead, he threw his gloves at a nearby location and rushed to the Rampur bus stand, along with the victim’s purse,” said another police officer.

On the way, he threw the purse after taking out all the money and the cards.

“Singh returned to Delhi on February 6 as he had to appear for an MBA exam. On reaching here, he changed a few metro trains and then took a bus to reach his house around 11.30am. At 2pm, he even appeared for the exam at a centre in Noida,” said Thakur.

Priyanka’s relatives had called up the accused on February 7, but he denied having any information about her. Scared he would be caught, he also burnt the items he had stolen from her purse.

Police had earlier questioned Singh and asked him to appear again in connection with the murder , but he had gone into hiding.

Title: Tourist spots, hotels to remain shut in Ooty till Mar 31
Content: UDHAGAMANDALAM: All the tourist spots in the Nilgiris were closed on Tuesday as a preemptive measure to curb the spread of Covid-19. The district administration has asked all the hotels in the district to shut their operations with immediate effect and remain closed till March 31.Addressing the media, collector J Innocent Divya said tourist attractions such as botanical garden and rose garden in Ooty, Sim’s Park in Coonoor and other sightseeing places would remain closed till March 31. The Nilgiri Mountain Railway (NMR) services would also remain suspended during the period.The collector also appealed the tourists not to travel to Nilgiris, as they won’t be able to access any of the tourist spots.“All hotels, guest houses and other accommodation facilities should be closed till March 31 and the owners should not make any booking for the period,” she said.However, the hoteliers have asked time till Wednesday morning to shut operations, considering the guests who have already checked in.Pointing out that the district was running out of hand sanitizers, Divya said, “Surgical spirit could be used for hand hygiene as an alternative.”She has advised all the shopkeepers in market area and restaurants to disinfect their shops and surroundings at least five times a day.“All the bus stands should be sanitized once in two hours by the respective panchayats and municipalities, while mini-buses should spray disinfectants daily,” the collector said.She said all vehicles entering the Nilgiris from Kerala and Karnataka would be checked and sprayed disinfectants. She also warned of strict action against the people who spread misleading information on COVID-19 cases in the district.According to the administration, permission would not be granted till March 31 for functions and events that would attract a large crowd. “All the sports auditoriums, clubs, bars and entrainment places should be closed till March-end.”Divya also requested people to avoid visiting places of worship, shopping complexes and marriage halls where community feasts are held.The forest department, meanwhile, said Mudumalali Tiger Reserve, ecotourism activities inside forest areas, Lamb’s Rock, Dolphin’s Nose in Coonoor would remain closed till further orders.People with coronavirus symptoms can contact 0423 2449250, 94432 08293 or 79047 78300 for help.

Title: CBSE’s 12 students per class seating plan a success
Content: Nagpur: CBSE ’s unique experiment on Tuesday to limit the number of students to 12 per class for the ongoing board exam , turned out to be a success. Students and parents appreciated the move aimed at preventing the spread of coronavirus . TOI was the only newspaper to report about CBSE’s hush-hush plan on Tuesday.The central board took a proactive step by deciding to keep a distance of one meter between two candidates. A notice from CBSE mentioned that the distance has to be maintained “in order to avoid close contact and stay away from contamination of coronavirus”.CBSE went on to add that the “present practice of 24 students in a room must be avoided and not to be encouraged”. What helped schools in Maharashtra execute the plan to perfection was the availability of extra classrooms and zero distraction, thanks to the shutdown till March 31.A teacher said, “With all students staying home, all classrooms were at our disposal. Hence, we could provide double number of classrooms as required under the new guidelines.” But doubling up of classrooms did not mean extra invigilators. “CBSE gave permission to keep just one invigilator, instead of two, per classroom,” said the teacher.Students told TOI that they loved the new arrangement. A student said “It was a good change as the rooms became more airy. It was a good initiative by CBSE because it felt less claustrophobic.” Another student said, “Considering the panic over coronavirus, the new seating arrangement made me feel safe. In my centre, even teachers were wearing masks and that made everyone very comfortable,” the student said.At some exam centres, the host school had made arrangements for free masks. Administrator of one such school said, “These masks are there for use by both staff and students appearing for the exam if they so desire.”A student said that wearing face masks must be made mandatory for students too. “There were some students who were coughing and that really scared me. It might be a normal sore throat or allergy, but if such students are forced to wear masks, then it is better,” said the student.“The environment of the class was safe and hygienic. We sat at a distance of 1m from each other. We were also provided mask and there were hand sanitizers available in each class,” said Harsh Chandak, a student of Centre Point School , Katol Road.

Title: Delhi court tears into Nirbhaya convict’s lawyer
Content:
Convict Mukesh Singh

NEW DELHI: Unfortunately, some mischievous brains have been projecting and consciously nurturing a misplaced notion that there is a premium over dishonesty and mendacity in this country, said a Delhi court in a strongly worded order reprimanding the counsel of a death row convict in the Nirbhaya case.

“...the authorities involved in the dispensation of justice are duty bound to dispel such ill-founded notion,” it added.

The court slammed the counsel for “resorting to schemes” to obtain relief for his client. It also directed the Bar Council of India to take note of the matter so that the counsel is “sensitised”.

Coming down heavily on advocate M L Sharma, additional sessions judge Dharmender Rana said, “Counsel for convict has not only made a false averment before this court, but also miserably failed to discharge his duties as a counsel to bring all the facts before the court for effective dispensation of justice.”

The judge, while dismissing the convict’s plea, added that the counsel’s duty was all the more “sacrosanct” when viewed against the fact that the death warrants were to be executed on March 20, 2020.

The matter pertained to a plea of convict Mukesh Singh , represented by his counsel M L Sharma, claiming he was not in the city when the gangrape took place. He said his client was arrested by the police from Rajasthan in the early hours of December 17, 2012 – a day after the crime.

The court inquired why such an argument was raised at a stage when all legal remedies had been exhausted by the convict. Sharma claimed someone only recently gave him the information about Mukesh being tortured inside the prison that rendered him incapable to divulge this fact earlier.

Special public prosecutors Irfan Ahmed and Rajiv Mohan had opposed the claim arguing that it was a “frivolous” plea and not maintainable. He said that the convict was resorting to desperate tactics to escape gallows.

Upon going through the records, judge Rana found out that the same contention had been raised, dealt with and rejected by Delhi High Court and the Supreme Court in 2014 and 2017, respectively.

“It is a well-known fact that the courts of the country are over-burdened and are hard-pressed for time. The duty to deliver justice expeditiously becomes all the more onerous when the court is dealing with the case of a death row convict when one wrong decision may lead to fatal consequences,” the judge said. In such a scenario, the judge added, assistance from the Bar is more enhanced and intense.

Title: Doon’s iconic Prabhat Cinema shuts after seven decades
Content:
yyyyyyyyyyyyyyy

Dehradun: The city's landmark Prabhat Talkies which had entertained generations of cinegoers since 1947 has now shut down. The iconic cinema hall was to close its doors forever after a screening of cult 1970s film 'Bobby' on March 30 but the order to temporarily close all cinema halls in the city till March 31 to contain the spread of coronavirus halted the plan of the cinema hall's owner Deepak Nagalia, to say goodbye to his establishment in the way he wanted. Nagalia who took over the theatre from his father, and has been running it for the last 55 years or so says that he had also invited Randhir Kapoor for the last movie show at his beloved theatre but "perhaps it was not meant to be."

“The frenzy that I witnessed for 'Bobby' remains unprecedented. Shows ran for over 25 weeks in Prabhat Talkies. My family has been very close to veteran actor Raj Kapoor, so, I had decided to close down the hall after screening a cult film made by Raj Kapoor,” said Nagalia.

Built in 1947, Prabhat Talkies was once the favourite of movie-goers in the city but the theatre had been running into losses for past many years. “The single-screen cinema halls have seen the golden era of Indian film Industry. Movies like 'Do Bigha Zamin', 'Mother India', and 'Devdas' revolutionised the Hindi film industry. But, it has now become tough for the single screens to survive in cities due to the advent of multiplexes. Leave aside profits, single screens are struggling to even recover operational costs,” said Nagalia whose family will now be converting the hall into a commercial complex. However, to keep the memory of Prabhat Talkies alive, Nagalia plans to dedicate a gallery to the cinema hall in the commercial complex. The gallery will have projectors, posters of iconic movies, and pictures of the movie stars who have visited the theatre for their film premieres in the past 73 years.

“Though I haven’t made any profit from the cinema hall for the last 10 years, it was a very hard decision for me to shut it down permanently. I have too many memories associated with the place,” he told TOI.

Title: Fake hand sanitiser unit raided, six held in Pune
Content:
Representative image

PUNE: The crime branch of the Pune police on Monday arrested six people after raiding a fake sanitiser manufacturing unit in Market Yard, leading to the recovery of Rs27 lakh worth of stock.

A team headed by senior inspector Datta Chavan, assistant inspector Santosh Tasgaonkar and sub-inspector Somnath Shendge raided the unit near Gangadham Chowk. A blue gel-like material in huge drums was recovered from the spot.

Upon testing by Food and Drug Administration officials, it was found that the gel was not used in hand sanitizers. The police have arrested Kunal alias Sonu Shantilal Jain (33) of Kondhwa, Chetan Madhav Bhoi (26) of Market Yard, Irfan Iqbal Shaikh (32), Aasim Arif Maniyar (27) of Kondhwa, Swapnil Shivaji Shinde (31) of Sadashiv Peth and Mahesh Ramchandra Tembekar (31) of Satara Road in the case.

“While Jain is a pharmacist, Bhoi is a businessman. they were running the illegal business from a flat located near Gangadham chowk which they have taken on rent. They were found mixing gel with other liquids and then packing in the bottles,” a Market Yard police officer said.

DCP (crime) Bachchan Singh said there was a huge demand for hand sanitizers owing to the Covid-19 spread.

Title: Reports on steps taken to save Thamirabarani river submitted
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: The Tirunelveli and Tuticorin district collectors submitted reports before the Madras high court with regard to the steps taken to safeguard Thamirabarani river.

A M Sundaravel, a resident of Tirunelveli district , in his petition before the high court Madurai bench had sought to safeguard Thamirabarani river from pollution by preventing the flow of waste from factories and local bodies. He also sought to remove the encroachments inside the river in both districts.

In his report, the Tuticorin collector stated that no industrial waste is released inside the river. No drainage water is drained inside the river from the 23 village panchayats which are situated on the banks. Though domestic waste was let inside the river in a few villages the same has been stopped by constructing soak pits. Effective steps are also being taken to remove the encroachments from the river.

The Tirunelveli collector in the report stated that sewage water is found mixing with the river in seven prominent locations in Tirunelveli Corporation limits. Though temporary measures are taken to prevent the flow of drainage water, the same would be completely stopped after the phase two and phase three works of underground drainage system are completed in 2021 and 2022 respectively. A joint committee has also been constituted to remediate pollution inside the river.

Taking cognizance of the submissions, a division bench of justice P N Prakash and justice G Jayachandran adjourned the case to March 30 for further hearing.

Title: Come here and address media: Congress to rebel MLAs
Content:
Representative image

BHOPAL: After rebels of the Scindia camp held a press conference in Bengaluru and targeted CM Kamal Nath , the state Congress went on the offensive, showing ‘before and after’ videos of the breakaway leaders, who went from praising the CM to criticizing him in just 10 days.

“Ex-minister for revenue Govind Singh Rajput , who claims that not a single paisa was allocated for his constituency, made a different comment before he left the state,” said law minister P C Sharma at a press meet. Congress showed videos of Rajput with the CM at a recent public meeting in Surkhi constituency, where he said, “Chief minister Kamal Nath has sanctioned Rs 3,000 crore for development work here. For 15 years, BJP government and former chief minister Shivraj Singh Chouhan only made announcements. When I told this to CM Nath, he said, ‘Govind, I work and don’t make announcements’.”

The video shows Rajput saying that a reservoir that was pending since 2008 is being constructed now. “It was waiting for CM Nath, who has allocated Rs 100 crore for it,” he says.

A second video at Sharma’s press conference showed expelled minister Tulsiram Silawat praising CM Nath’s ‘Shuddh ke liye Yudhh (war for purity)’ campaign against food adulterators. Silawat was put in charge of implementation of the campaign. In the video, he is seen thanking the CM at a public meeting on behalf of citizens for the campaign against adulteration.

Congress also showed videos of expelled minister Imarti Devi questioning BJP’s criticism of Nath. “What did BJP do in 15 years that they dare question the Congress government?” she asks reporters in the video.

Sharma said: “There are so many videos coming from a resort in Karnataka with former ministers making some allegations. Why is the press conference in Bengaluru? They should come here, to Bhopal, or go to their constituencies and address the media here.”

“Before leaving for Delhi and then Bangalore, these were the same ministers who were speaking highly of the chief minister and the government’s developmental projects. In 10 days, everything changed. Nearly 87% families in Madhya Pradesh are benefiting from government subsidized electricity bills. Within an hour of his swearing-in, the CM signed papers to implement farm loan waiver for 55 lakh farmers,” Sharma said.

The rebel MLAs and expelled ministers are under “tremendous pressure from BJP for making anti-Kamal Nath statements”, he said. “What they are saying is the result of BJP’s influence,” he alleged.

On the floor test, Sharma said, “The floor is not complete without the 16 party MLAs who are in captivity in Bengaluru. Once they return and the floor is complete, the floor test will happen.”

Nath loyalist, PWD minister Sajjan Singh Verma , trained his guns on the Scindia faithful. Speaking to reporters, Verma said, “There are five to six bonded labourers (the expelled ministers) of Scindia who are speaking that language. Look at the rest of Congress MLAs, they are shopping in malls and talking over mobile phones freely. There are no restrictions. But in Bengaluru, if MLAs ask for their phones, they are being beaten-up.”

Asked about the rebels’ allegation that CM Nath did not listen to them, Verma said, “No one can be bigger liars than the persons who made this allegation.” Regarding the floor test, Verma said, “We are 100% sure this government will complete its full term. The name of management is Kamal Nath.”

Title: Youth held for kidnap, sexual assault of 6-year-old girl in Trichy
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: The Fort All Women Police on Monday night arrested a 22-year-old man for sexually assaulting a minor girl in Trichy city .

The accused, N Selvamani, was arrested on charges of kidnapping and sexually assaulting a six-year-old girl. According to police, the girl was playing in the streets on Monday evening. Selvamani who was loitering in the area forcefully took the girl to the backyard of his house and sexually abused her.

The girl’s mother lodged a complaint with the police after the girl went home and revealed her ordeal. The police, after an initial enquiry, launched a search for the accused and nabbed him.

As per procedure, the girl was sent for medical examination at Mahatma Gandhi memorial government hospital (MGMGH) in Trichy. The protection of children from sexual offences (POCSO) Act has been slapped on the accused. He was produced before the court and was remanded in judicial custody.

(The victim's identity has not been revealed to protect her privacy as per Supreme court directives on cases related to sexual assault)

Title: Trichy: Bid to convert villagers to Christianity alleged
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: People in a Pudukottai village have lodged a complaint with the Illupur police accusing a group of people of attempting to convert villagers to Christianity through fraudulent means. Though the police detained the group, they were let off after inquiry. They have now sought legal opinion on filing case against them.

The incident happened on Sunday when a group of 15 people from Trichy visited Kattakudi village near Illupur. They were on their way to a church in Malakudipatti village in Viralimalai when they stopped at Kattakudi and interacted with children. Suspecting that they had come to convert people in the village to Christianity, E Rengasamy, a villager, lodged a complaint with the Illupur police station.

He said the group was distributing bible in the village and when questioned they threatened to create communal unrest there. Manokaran, inspector of police in charge of the station who carried out an inquiry with the group, told TOI that they were giving moral education to children in the village apart from reciting short stories. There was no evidence of forceful conversion of villagers but at the same time, they weren’t able to explain the reason for their visit to the village, he said. Deputy superintendent of police, Illupur, Sigamani told TOI that they have sought legal opinion to file a case based on the complaint lodged by Rengasamy.

Title: Man dies in accident on way to doctor
Content:
Representative image

POINGUINIM: A resident of Catebaga, Poinguinim, identified as Marshal D’Souza, 48, was declared brought dead when he was referred to the Canacona community health centre (CHC) after he met with an accident on Tuesday.

“The locals said that the deceased left for Poinguinim to visit a doctor after complaining of chest pain. On the way, he hit another bike parked along the road, after which he was rushed to the CHC,” Canacona police said.

Police has registered a case of unnatural death under Section 174 of CrPc.

An autopsy will be conducted on Wednesday, police said.

Title: Covid-19 in Mumbai: KEM Hospital to start testing; 20 new beds in Jogeshwari
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

MUMBAI: To ease the load on the Kasturba Hospital laboratory—the sole facility testing coronavirus samples in the city—the KEM Hospital laboratory will start testing samples from Wednesday. Officials said the centre will be able to handle up to 150 tests every day.

Besides testing, the BMC has added more beds to isolate travellers. A 20-bed isolation centre was started at Bal Thackeray Trauma Care Hospital in Jogeshwari on Tuesday. Civic officials said the centre will treat and even collect samples of coronavirus patients. The samples collected would be sent to Kasturba for testing. The Kasturba lab, where all suspected patients are being admitted, has been carrying out over 100 tests daily. On Tuesday, it processed 131 samples.

State officials said there are also plans to start treatment/quarantine centres at Cooper in Juhu and Shatabdi Hospital, Kandivli.

Title: Impasse ends, trucks start carting garbage
Content:
Pune: Trucks started carting tonnes of trash strewn across the city from Monday giving relief to residents, as the impasse between the civic body and the residents of Uruli Devachi and Phursungi ended on Monday after 21 days.

According to the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) officials, the civic administration sent around 350 tonnes of garbage to Uruli Devachi and Phursungi on Monday on experimental basis. On Tuesday, the quantity was increased to 400 tonnes.

Pune mayor Murulidhar Mohol said, “We had appealed to the villagers that they should allow the garbage-laden vehicles in the village in view of the coronavirus scare. The villagers accepted the request.”

The residents of Uruli Devachi and Phursungi had stopped entry of garbage-laden vehicles since February 28 as a mark of protest. Nearly 400 tonnes of garbage were processed in the plant at the depot in the two villages on Tuesday, a day after the villagers called off the agitation.

“The decision to send the garbage to Uruli Devachi and Phursungi for processing has been taken in view of the coronavirus scare. The process will continue in the days to come,” said Dnyaneshwar Molak, head of PMC’s solid waste management department.

According to PMC officials, around 2,100 tonnes of garbage are generated in the city every day. PMC claims that it has stopped open dumping at the garbage depot in Uruli Devachi-Phursungi. Only reject material like metal parts, plastic and others, which cannot be processed in the trash processing plants in the city, were being sent to the depot.

The villagers said the civic administration should take steps to meet their demands, including jobs for villagers and funds for infrastructure.

Title: Veteran actor Jairam Kulkarni dies at 87
Content:
Pune: Veteran actor Jairam Kulkarni, popularly called the ‘Police Commissioner of Marathi Cinema’, died of old age on Monday. The last rites were performed at Vaikunth.

Kulkarni was 87 and leaves behind wife Hema, two sons, daughters-in-law and grandchildren.

Noted actor Mrinal Kulkarni is married to his son Ruchir.

Kulkarni left his mark on numerous Marathi films made during 1980-90s. Prominent among them are ‘Zapatlela’, ‘Ashi Hee Banvabanavi’, ‘Tharatharat’, ‘Dhoomdhadaka’, ‘Maza Pati karodpati’, ‘De Danadan’, and ‘Navari Mile Navryala’, among others. Most of these films featured actors Ashok Saraf, Laxmikant Berde, Mahesh Kothare and Sachin Pilgaonkar.

Born on October 17, 1932, at Ambejavalge in Barshi taluka of Solapur district, Kulkarni studied at Sulakhe High School and then came to Pune, where he enrolled in S P College.

In his college days he became friends with actors Shrikant Moghe and Sharad Talwalkar.

After completing his education, he joined All India Radio’s Pune station as an assistant to noted author Vyankatesh Madgulkar.

He made his onstage debut with the play, ‘Jwalet Ubhi Mee’, produced by the Progressive Dramatic Association. Once he started getting roles in films, he quit his job at AIR and became a full-time actor.

Paying tribute to him, Mrinal Kulkarni said she recently lost her father Vijay Deo and now Jairam Kulkarni, who was a father-figure to her.

Title: 16 suspects tested, 40 quarantined, no positive case in Vidarbha
Content: Yavatmal/Chandrapur/Nagpur: No fresh positive case of the novel coronavirus (Covid-19) was reported from across Vidarbha on Tuesday.In Nagpur, 16 suspected cases were reported from GMCH and IGGMCH. Swabs of nine were sent to the lab for testing including all eight from GMCH. The results are awaited, said officials.All the 16 have been kept at the isolation wards of both the government hospitals. Total 131 suspects have been tested so far. Of this, 96 had to be kept under observation. As on date, the Mayo lab has so far conducted tests on 104 samples of which only four have turned positive.All four positive patients at Nagpur’s Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (IGGMCH) and Government Medical College and Hospital (GMCH) were doing well, doctors said.The Nagpur district administration quarantined 13 flyers at MLA hostel on Tuesday.The 16 suspected cases include a 30-yr old woman, her 6-yr-old daughter and one-year-old son who got themselves admitted to Government Medical College and Hospital GMCH on Monday night.
