Their test results are awaited.In a curious development, Sevagram’s Kasturba Hospital too sent some samples suspecting them to be coronavirus cases. The hospital sees close to 2,500 patients every day. Over the last few days, the hospital admitted some patients with pneumonia, but they lacked travel history and had no contact with corona virus-positive patients. Their samples sent to the regional diagnostic centre at Mayo hospital were returned because the lab felt that they did not fulfil the criteria required for testing them.The 50-year-old woman from Yavatmal, who tested positive on Monday, and two others kept at the isolation ward of GMCH there were reported to be stable. Two other positive patients too didn’t show any problem.Yavatmal district recorded 19 new home quarantines on Tuesday taking the tally of such persons to 56.Chandrapur district administration identified eight new foreign-returned citizens and home quarantined them on Monday evening. The administration announced the development only on Tuesday. The administration has also ordered to close down all the religious places in the district. Tadoba Andhari Tiger Reserve and Anandwan in Warora have been closed down for tourists.Chandrapur civil surgeon Dr ND Rathod said those quarantined on Monday include two who had returned from Saudi Arabia, five from Dubai and one United States. None of them have any kind of symptoms, but they have been quarantined as a preventive measure. The number of quarantined people in district has risen to 32.Offence registered against rumour mongersA fresh offence has been registered at Gobarwahi police station of Tumsar taluka in Bhandara against unknown persons for allegedly spreading an edited version of broadcast news stating that there was a corona patient at Pathri village, reports Soumitra Bose The offence was registered on the complaint of tehsilder who had lodged the complaint under the relevant sections under the Disaster management Act, 2005 and Information Technology Act. The edited news was circulated in the social media by the group members.This is the third offence registered in such rumour mongering cases in Bhandara district. A gram panchayat committee member too has been booked in the first in one of the three FIRs.

Title: Sensex sheds 811 points, Nifty closes below 9k 1st time in 3 yrs
Content:
Mumbai: The markets see-sawed on Tuesday as fears of a pandemic-led global recession kept investors jittery. Local institutions tried to support the sensex at lower levels but eventually failed. The index opened about 200 points higher, lost 800 points within the first hour, then rallied nearly 500 points but finally, due to a fag-end selloff, settled with a loss of 811 points, or 2.6%, at 30,579—a three-year closing low. On the NSE , the Nifty lost 230 points, or 2.5%, to 8,967, its first closing below the 9K mark in the last three years.

The day’s selling was again led by foreign funds with a net outflow figure of Rs 4,045 crore, BSE data showed. Banking and financial services stocks were again at the forefront of the sell-off with ICICI Bank (down 9%), IndusInd Bank (8.9%) and Bajaj Finance (6.3%) among the top sensex laggards. Of the 30 sensex stocks, nine closed higher with HUL (up 3.5%) and Hero MotoCorp (3.1%) leading. The day’s selling also left investors poorer by Rs 2.1 lakh crore with BSE’s market capitalisation now almost at Rs 119 lakh crore.

With each passing day, as the epidemic spreads across the world and market after market enters bear territory, the chances of a recession is growing. A report by global financial services major Morgan Stanley on Tuesday said the fallout was likely to trigger a global recession.

“With Covid-19 spreading in Europe and the US after hitting Asia, the disruptions and dislocations in the economy and markets will trigger a year-on-year contraction in global growth in the first half of 2020. However, the strong monetary and fiscal policy response under way will help to revive global growth from the third quarter of 2020,” the report said.

On Monday night, the Dow Jones index in the US had lost nearly 13%, its biggest rout in more than 30 years. In early trades on Tuesday, the UK and German markets were also deep in the red but recovered in late trades as the US markets rallied over 3% after opening. In India too, the VIX, a gauge of volatility, reached a current peak of 63.4, NSE data showed.

Market players feel the volatility will continue for a while. According to Pankaj Bobade, head-fundamental research, Axis Securities, “Markets are expected to be volatile in the near term given the rise in new reported cases is outside mainland China than inside, marking a new milestone in the evolution of the global pandemic. As cases blow up in Europe and North America, fear is growing in Asia of the possibility of a second wave of infections from imported cases, which is driving risk aversion in markets globally.”

Title: Met issues advisory of rise in diurnal variability of temperature in Uttarakhand
Content:
DEHRADUN: The regional meteorological center on Tuesday issued an advisory of rise in diurnal variability of temperature over the next few days in the state.

This, the Met office said, may make conditions conducive for spread of cold and flu, especially in the plains of Uttarakhand, and people have been advised to take extra precautions.

According to the regional meteorological centre, the diurnal variation (difference between maximum and minimum temperature) is likely to go above 18 degrees celsius during next the six to seven days in the plains.

Bikram Singh, director of the regional meteorological center, said, “Maximum temperatures are likely to increase gradually in the plains while the minimum temperatures are likely to remain near normal and thereby increasing the diurnal variability of temperature.”

The dry weather and high diurnal vibration in temperature is likely to make conditions favorable for spread of cold and flu, Singh said.

Incidentally, the temperatures in the Himalayan state were settling below normal level during last week due to rain, snow and thunder activity in both hills and plains.

On Tuesday, the maximum temperature in Dehradun was recorded at 27.7 degrees Celsius, while the minimum settled at 9.9 degrees Celsius, with diurnal variation of over 17 degrees Celsius. Similarly, the difference between maximum and minimum temperature in Pantnagar was over 18 degrees Celsius.

The Met office, meanwhile, has advised people and concerned state government authorities to take necessary preventive measures to ensure safety of common people.

Title: Judge takes stock of preparedness
Content: MADURAI: The administrative judge of Madras high court Madurai bench, justice P N Prakash convened a meeting with the judges and members of the bar association on the premises of the district court here on Tuesday, in order to take preventive steps to avoid the spread of Covid-19.According to sources from the court, it was advised to avoid mass gatherings inside the court premises. Canteens and tea stalls functioning inside the district court premises would be closed from Wednesday.It maybe recalled that the Madras high court Chief Justice A P Sahi had convened a meeting with judges and officials at the high court Madurai bench on Monday evening and issued several advisories to prevent mass gatherings inside the court to avoid the spread of Covid-19.TNN

Title: Plea seeks to upload local body poll candidate info in SEC site
Content:
Madras High Court

MADURAI: Madras high court has sought a response from the state government on a plea which sought to furnish all details including income, pendency of cases of candidates contesting in the local body elections in the State Election Commission (SEC) website.

In his petition, B Ramkumar Adityan , an advocate and resident of Tuticorin district, stated that all the elections for the rural and urban local bodies are conducted by the Tamil Nadu SEC . Voters have the right to know full particulars of a candidate who represents them. He stated the existing format is not sufficient for voters to know about the details of the candidates contesting in the local body elections.

Hence, the petitioner moved the high court Madurai bench to create separate columns where all the contesting candidates while filing nominations for local body elections should submit their details including the cases registered against them. He also sought to publish the details about the pendency of cases against them in two Tamil dailies.

Adityan further sought to provide income details of the candidates for the past five years and their source of income. Details of income of the candidates, their spouse and their dependents, candidates’ educational qualification should also be furnished. All these should be uploaded in the SEC website from the forthcoming local body elections When the petition was taken up for hearing on Tuesday, a division bench of justice P N Prakash and justice G Jayachandran sought a response from the state and adjourned the case to a further date for hearing. TNN

Title: Coronavirus in Pune: Many firms drag their feet on work-from-home option
Content: PUNE: Many companies operating out of Pune are still in two minds about offering work-from-home option to their employees, citing lack of clear directions from the government.This is happening in spite of Pune collector Naval Kishore Ram’s appeal to the IT companies to allow their employees to work from home.“We appeal to all IT and other private companies to allow their employees to work from home because this social distancing measure is a very important proactive measure to contain the coronavirus spread,” Ram said in a video message on Monday.Soon after the message was put out, some big companies in Kharadi and Hinjewadi allowed their employees to work from home, while others remained open.“There are about 50 listed firms operating out of Pune. Of these, only a dozen have allowed their employees to work from home,” said an IT industry insider.With several companies still not warming up to work-from-home option, those still going out to their offices to work are finding themselves and their family members vulnerable to the Covid-19 infection.“My husband is allowed to work from home, while I have to go to work. Eventually, if one looks at it, my family not protected against the infection in any way,” Pimpri Chinchwad resident Shruti Narayanan, who works in Kharadi, said.A senior executive of the firm where Narayanan works blamed the clear directions from the authorities for the situation.“They (the company) are saying some people can work from home, while others cannot and that we will be receiving more communication on it. Don’t know what is on their mind since the plan to this effect was readied around three weeks ago,” the senior executive said.Some companies have gone for split work-from-home option, under which employees interchange the option every week.At a large manufacturing firm in Pune, office staff have been told to come to work every alternate day — leaving many to wonder about the efficacy of the move.“I don’t know if it will help, but looks like they are attempting to keep distance between employees,” a senior marketing executive of the company said.In a meeting held with the divisional commissioner on Monday, small industries said they were ready to shut if there was an order.“For now, the officials have told us that we must follow sanitation measures, which we are. They have told us that only if we (the authorities) are not ready to contain (the spread), will there be a shutdown,” Sandeep Belsare, president, Pimpri Chinchwad Small Scale Industries Association, said, adding that in the manufacturing sector, there was no work-from-home option.

Title: Clueless docs, gloveless staff serve those quarantined at MLA Hostel
Content:
Nagpur: From the threshold of block number 22 of MLA Hostel, a girl in her twenties flaunts her wrist to her sister standing at a distance, almost like she is showing off a tattoo.

She has been stamped ‘Corona 17-3-2020’ on her hand after she landed at Nagpur on Tuesday morning. “I have kept the sanitizer inside the bag,” says her father, who has also come to drop her lunch. The girl cannot cross the threshold. As the conversation gets longer, a state government official asks her to get back to her room. The family refused to divulged her name.

Since March 13, passengers coming from seven countries tagged as ‘corona affected’ have been kept in the MLA hostel block. So far, three have been released after initial tests and 11 remain at MLA hostel, said sources here. A state government press release has said so far 13 have been quarantined.

A press release issued from the divisional commissioner’s office said facilities to board as many as 1,500 quarantined persons are being created at Nagpur, including at Vanamati and Nag Bhavan.

Alleged uncertainty about their fate was among the major complaints TOI got while talking on phone to two of those quarantined. Some NRIs have also complained of the lack of proper facilities.

Akashsingh Rathore, a finance professional from Germany, reached Nagpur on Qatar Airways’ flight via Doha 36 hours ago. “My colleagues in other cities have been quarantined at home after initial tests. I am perfectly healthy and ready to stay isolate myself at home. I can be stamped and let off, There is no clarity, and even doctors here do not have a clue,” he says.

Thirty-year-old Rathore, whose family is from Chandrapur , has been quarantined along with his wife. His colleague Shashank Pataudi is next door, and has to go to Chhindwara, Madhya Pradesh . “I have asked my parents not to come to Nagpur or get stressed. I am more worried about my work, which has come to a standstill,” he says.

Both Rathore and Pataudi were already working from home in Germany after the coronavirus outbreak. They decided to come to India and continue working from here. Lack of internet connectivity at MLA Hostel has affected their work, they say.

One inmate is also slated to get married in some days and still stuck here, they said.

Officials at the district collectorate managing the affairs said the decision to release a person is of the civil surgeon. However, civil surgeon Dr Devendra Paturkar passed the buck to the divisional commissioner’s office.

Even as the quarantined passengers are interacting with each other, their only view of the world outside is from the balconies. Their food comes from the MLA hostel canteen.

“There is a table outside their rooms. We just leave the food there and go away, and do not wait for them to come out,” said a canteen worker.

“Our life is at risk too, but except a mask there is hardly anything else in the name of safety gear. I don’t even have gloves so I cover my hand with a napkin to ring the door bell or even touch the door,” said a worker engaged in serving food.

The food is sent in cardboard packs. “We have not cleared the dustbins even once yet,” said one of the staffers.

The passengers arrive at MLA Hostel straight from the airport. A team of doctors is present before the immigration counter, where the countries they are coming from are ascertained. They are asked to board a bus under the protection of Disaster Relief Force personnel and taken to MLA hostel.

“They were helpful indeed but I saw that the disaster relief personnel did not even have gloves,” said a relative of one of the passengers.

Title: Temple row: HC official confirms encroachment
Content:
Hyderabad: The advocate commissioner appointed by Telangana High Court has inspected Madhavapuri Hills temple and submitted a report confirming encroachment of park by the temple authorities.

The HC has appointed the advocate commissioner following a petition filed by activist Thakur Raj Kumar Singh on alleged encroachment in Madhavpuri Hills of Ameenpur in the city.

The land parcel — earmarked as a park area as per the approved HMDA layout plan with a total area of 9,867 square yards — was inspected along with other land parcels. “A temple was constructed inside the park area. The main temple of Lord Venkateswara along with other deities was constructed within the park area in an area of 1,225 square yards. Another small temple of Anjaneya Swamy adjacent to the main temple was also constructed. There is ongoing construction activity around Anjaneya Swamy temple. The total area covered by the main temple and Anjaneya Swamy temple is 1,426 square yards. The leftover area is 8,441 square yards which is covered by boulders and rocks,” said the advocate commissioner in his report.

The high court had taken a serious view of the petition filed against the temple encroachment and summoned principal secretaries of municipal administration, panchayat raj, HMDA commissioner and senior officers concerned. The HC bench then suggested to the Madhavapuri Hills temple committee to either demolish the illegal construction or pay Rs 5 crore.

Raj Kumar of Human Rights and Consumer Protection Cell Trust had filed the petition. Though a complaint was lodged in 2017, the authorities had failed to take action due to which the petitioner approached the court in 2018. The case came up for hearing now. Police and municipal authorities have so far failed to take any action.

Title: Citizens seek Metro up to Patancheru
Content:
Hyderabad: A citizen’s group on Monday requested Metro Rail authorities to extend corridor-1 (LB Nagar-Miyar) up to Patancheru . The group, Forum to Improve Things, said the original plan of Hyderabad Metro phase-2 must be adhered to.

“It is a matter of deep concern for lakhs of residents dwelling in and around Madinaguda, Chanda Nagar, BHEL, RC Puram, Ameenpur, Beeramguda, Patancheru and other areas, that Metro line till Patancheru was not considered in the DPR submitted recently to government by HMRL,” they said in a representation to HMRL managing director NVS Reddy.

It said, “We would like to reinstate that any public transport system must originate from the starting point of traffic…The distance from BHEL to Patancheru is around 6km and Patancheru has ORR connectivity hence this can become a very good starting point for Metro commuters besides having good commercial viability.” TNN

Title: Review meeting held through videoconferencing
Content:
Pune: The city police’s Tuesday review meeting (TRM), introduced by Pune police commissioner K Venkatesham, was conducted through videoconferencing in view of emphasis on social distancing because of the Covid-19 situation.

Multi-mode real-time video conferencing facility was used to conduct the conference. Venkatesham said, “Senior officers issued guidelines to inspectors and other officers to take basic measures to keep themselves safe. We told them to maintain proper safety measures at the police stations. The crime branch and police stations were told to deal important cases urgently.”

Additional commissioner of police (crime) Ashok Morale asked to keep tabs on black-marketing of essential commodities. TNN

Title: Over 3,500 teachers working on forged docus: PIL
Content: Nainital: The Uttarakhand high court (HC) on Tuesday directed the secretary education to furnish district-wise details of teachers suspected to be working based on forged documents.This comes after a public interest litigation (PIL) filed in the HC has alleged that there are thousands of teachers working in government schools across the state based on forged documents. The petition cites a news report that has said that the number of teachers working through forged documents is around 3,500.The bench of Chief Justice Ramesh Ranganathan and Justice Ramesh Chandra Khulbe also ordered the secretary education to furnish the details as to what actions have been taken against the teachers who presented fake documents to secure the job. “The court has taken the matter very seriously and has ordered the secretary to furnish details both about the number of teachers and to inform what actions they have taken against the teachers who have been identified to furnish the fake documents to secure jobs,” said Tribhuvan Chandra Pandey, the counsel appearing for the petitioner.Though a Special Investigation Team (SIT) has also been constituted to probe the scam, the petition says that criminal cases have been registered against only 53 teachers.The PIL, while citing few cases of forgery, has highlighted that these teachers have no ability to impact knowledge or ability to impart knowledge and therefore by drawing salaries they are not only causing huge losses to the government but even the public at large is aggrieved by it. “We have examples where a person was in jail for almost six months for forging documents of 11 people, still they got a job as teachers. Though he is now out on bail but there countless such examples across the state,” Pandey said.The court has now set April 15 as the next date of hearing when the secretary will furnish the details of the teachers as well as the action taken against them.

Title: Yerawada children’s home take coronavirus precautions
Content:
Picture used for representational purpose only

PUNE: The authorities of the Jawaharlal Nehru Udyog Kendra, a children’s home in Yerawada, have decided to prevent minors who are with them, from coming into contact with coronavirus through contact with outsiders.

As a preventive measure, the authorities suspended all programmes organised for them.

“We have also obtained 50 masks and sanitizers for the minors and staff members,” superintendent G N Padghan told TOI.

Padghan said the security guards at the outer gate of the home have been told not send any person inside without applying sanitizers.

“We take efforts to reform these boys who are in conflict wit the law so that they can lead a good life after their release. We organise different programmes like meditation, yoga and motivational talks by speakers and we invite many outsiders to the home,” Pagdhan said.

They have stopped these activities for the protection of the children inside the home from Monday.

“We will continue with these activities once the situation is normal,” Padghan said.

Padghan said he has provided soaps at all barracks in the home. “We have been requesting the inmates to wash their hands regularly. “We have started lodging a limited number of boys in one barrack as a precautionary measure,” he added.

He said the home has a facility of visiting doctors. “These doctors check the inmates regularly. I have also told the staff members that if they noticed an inmate with any symptoms, they should immediately take him to the hospital,” Padghan said. Another official from the Jawaharlal Nehru Udyog Kendra told TOI, “At present there are 33 minor inmates. They have been kept in six barracks inside the home,” he added.

Title: ‘-ve turning +ve not surprising as symptoms can develop any time’
Content: Nagpur: The case of 50-year-old woman from Yavatmal who tested Covid-19 positive on Monday is being considered as a first-of-its-kind case in India as she had tested negative just 72 hours earlier. Doctors said symptoms can develop any time during the 14-day period.“Many factors influence the results. Sometimes, virus sensitivity is very low because of which the sample wrongly tests negative,” said Dr Ashwini Tayde , infectious disease specialist.According to her, that is the reason why “we insist that the 14-day standard quarantine period be completed irrespective of the test results”. “You may remain asymptomatic and your swab sample may test negative. Yet, you can develop symptoms any day during this period,” said Tayde.The Yavatmal woman was admitted in isolation facility of the GMCH on March 12 along with eight others. Their samples were collected on March 13. Four of them tested negative on March 14 while the remaining five were re-tested on March 15.Out of these, two came positive and three negative. The woman was among the three negative samples and was to be discharged when she developed fever. Her fresh samples were collected on March 15 evening.A fresh test came negative on March 16. Now, she is undergoing treatment at Yavatmal GMCH’s isolation ward.“Every test has its limitations. Even those who had tested negative at first may turn positive within this period. This standard format has been set up after worldwide analysis,” said Dr Tayde.Researchers estimate that for every 10,000 individuals quarantined for 14 days, only about 101 would develop symptoms after being released. In Kerala , this period was extended to 28 days in some sensitive cases.

Title: Health officials to accompany cops for tracing escaped patients: Pune CP
Content:
The police officers take part in Tuesday’s review meeting through videoconferencing

PUNE: Police commissioner K Venkatesham on Tuesday said his personnel would ensure that health officials, equipped with apt protective gears, accompany them for tracing and bringing back any Covid-19 patients escaping from designated quarantine facilities.

Speaking to TOI in the context of Saturday night’s incident in which a Covid-19 positive patient escaped from a designated quarantine facility in Bhosari, the Pune police chief said an isolation facility was being set up at the Police Hospital near Shivajinagar headquarters for the police personnel who might report symptoms of Covid-19 while performing duties like providing security to the quarantine facilities. The new facility would have all necessary medical equipment and medicines, he said.

Providing immunity tablets to women police personnel, allowing work from home wherever possible for pregnant staffers or offering them paid leave option, cleaning and disinfecting all police stations and police vehicles, and ensuring that basic protection was observed by all personnel were some of the measures taken for dealing with the situation, the police chief said.

The police in Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad, which have reported maximum number of Covid-19 positive cases in the state, are facing a unique challenge of not only providing security to the health establishments but also keeping a tab on patients at these facilities. Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad have a total police force of 10,000 and 4,000, respectively.

“Precaution is the best option for us as we can’t shut down police stations or establishments,” said Venkatesham, when asked about the challenges of the force in the prevailing situation. “Our primary role is to provide assistance to the health officials and we shall do that wherever called for,” he added.

Pimpri Chinchwad police chief Sandeep Bishnoi echoed Venkatesham on assistance to the state health officials.

He said, “We have placed an extensive focus on basic precautions to be taken by our personnel, including wearing masks, gloves and frequent use of hand sanitizers, besides, appealing to people to avoid visiting police establishments unless necessary and opt for e-services for lodging complaints.”

Bishnoi said, “We have provided about 4,000 masks and gloves each to our personnel and provided sanitizers. We have undertaken cleaning and disinfection work at all police establishments and police colonies.”

He said, “We have not prevented citizens from visiting our establishments, but given the current situation, we are encouraging people to opt for filing of complaint through emails. In urgent matters, people can certainly approach the police.”

Shridhar Jadhav, assistant commissioner of police (crime), said, “The use of thumb impression machines for attendance has been stopped and, instead, registers have been kept at all police establishments for marking attendance through signature.”

Another Pimpri Chinchwad police officer said the police had decided to stop using breathe analysers for taking action against drunk drivers. “Once the situation is normal, we shall resume the action,” he added.

Title: Education best tool to break poverty cycle: Collector
Content:
Representative image

MADURAI: Education is the best tool to break the vicious cycle of poverty as it can make a huge difference in life in terms of economic development and social status, said Madurai district collector T G Vinay. He was speaking at the inaugural event of free competitive exams coaching centre for inmates of Adi Dravida hostel for girls atChinna Chokkikulam on Monday.

“If students work hard for just six months, they can bring about a change for a lifetime. Uneducated people who work on daily-waged job find it hard to provide good education for their children. As their children do not get education, they again languish in poverty. Students should prepare hard to get a good job and it should start when they undergo studies at college level itself,” he said. M Uma Mageswari , member, state women’s commission, said one should not stop education because of marriage and children. Women can continue education at any time of their life. They only have to realise that education is the only powerful tool to change their life.

District welfare committee member S Malaisamy and district dalit monitoring committee member B Pandiaraja took the initiative for the free coaching class. The class will be conducted on all days between 7 pm and 8 pm. In all, 270 inmates from three college hostels and one polytechnic college hostel will benefit. The students will be issued free study materials .

Title: Administration ask suspects for home quarantine after isolation ward scare
Content: Nagpur: The episode of four suspected cases of the novel Coronavirus (Covid-19) giving the slip to the Mayo Hospital administration on Friday night has brought to the fore issues like lack of management and confusion over isolation and quarantine measures.Even as there is no clarity on the contentious issue, the administration announced that it will ask people to follow home quarantine.The four in question were asked to wait at the hospital till the results of their throat swabs were out. As per the hospital authorities, these suspects were ‘quarantined’ in the isolation ward.While briefing the press on Saturday, district collector Ravindra Thakare said, “The suspects left without permission as they feared contracting the virus from the positive patient.”The ward is on the same floor of the same building, Ward number 5 and 6 of Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital (Mayo Hospital), where Nagpur’s first positive Covid-19 patient was admitted for treatment.This is in contravention of the best medical practices which prescribe isolation of a sick person from those who are not sick. Quarantine means separating those who have come in contact with infected persons and observing them if they show any symptoms for 14 days.As per the World Health Organization ’s (WHO) interim guidance issued on February 29 to contain Covid-19 virus, “Quarantine of persons is the restriction of activities or separation of persons who are not ill, but who may been exposed to an infectious agent or disease, with the objective of monitoring symptoms and early detection of cases. Quarantine is different from isolation, which is the separation of ill or infected persons from others, so as to prevent the spread of infection or contamination.”When TOI asked Thakare why the isolation ward was being used as a quarantine facility, he said, “What is the problem? When he (the first positive patient) lived in his house for some days, only his wife tested positive. We are taking all preventive measures. There are over 20 persons quarantined in the isolation ward. Nursing staff and doctors are more exposed. 80 people have so far been inspected. They are there only for two to three hours,” he said.Mayo dean Ajay Keoliya said rooms for suspects and confirmed patients are separate. “One or two persons are kept in a room during their wait for test results. Each positive patient is kept in a separate room having separate toilets. There is a distance of an entire corridor,” he said.Yet, in the wake of the apprehension of people coming forward for getting themselves tested and being anxious to wait, the district collector announced that from Saturday “home quarantined” would be followed in all such cases.Earlier this week, home quarantine guidelines were issued by the union health ministry to contain the Covid-19 virus. In fact, on March 12, divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar, too, had said that teams would be formed to collect swab samples and people should adhere to ‘home quarantine’.Lack of coordination and management leading to non-compliance of the plan has raised a question on measures to fight the contagious diseases.

Title: 24 ID cabins with attached toilets have hosted over 50
Content: Kolkata: A woman from Beniapukur, who had returned from Saudi Arabia last Sunday, was sent to Infectious Diseases & Beliaghata General Hospital, popularly known as ID Hospital, after health officials at the airport found she had fever and cold. But she initially fled the hospital, refusing to get admitted to the government facility, fearing dirty wards, unhygienic toilets and poor services.But a visit to the hospital’s isolation wards, earmarked for treating Covid-19 patients as well as those suspected of being infected with coronavirus, presented a picture in contrast: 24 small, clean, single-bed cabins line Ward IB6, completely isolated from each other. Each cabin has an attached toilet. Though the nursing station is common, the facility has separate sets of portable equipment,like ventilators and ECG machines. This 24-bed quarantine ward at the state’s nodal hospital for infectious diseases was the first lot of isolation beds that the state health department had reserved for treating coronavirus suspected cases as well as those infected.Till Monday, the hospital had dealt with more than 50 people suspected of being infected with coronavirus but none had tested positive. However, on Tuesday Bengal recorded its first Covid-19-positive patient. “These isolation wards are designed for highly contagious diseases. While one section of the ward at the hospital was created when Nipah virus cases were reported, the other section is meant for swine flu patients. These wards are barely used as they are kept for only an outbreak like this,” said ID&BG Hospital principal Anima Haldar. The hospital has another isolation ward with 12 cabins, which was set up when Ebola cases were reported. “That section was never used. This, too, can be used for Covid-19 patients if need be,” Haldar added.Four beds in the intensive care unit have also been kept aside in case someone does test positive for the virus and needs intensive care unit support. In addition to the nursing and para-medic staff, a small team of doctors has been formed to deal with Covid-19 suspected cases. The core team comprises only three doctors—Shekhar Ranjal Paul from the department of medicine who has been trained in handling Ebola cases, microbiologist Kheya Muherjee and chest specialist Koushik Chowdhury who recently attended the WHO workshop on Covid-19 in Delhi. “As the number of patients increases, manpower shortage could be a crisis soon,” said a hospital insider.

Title: FTII stares at academic, admission delays
Content:
Film and Television Institute of India (File photo)

PUNE: The Film and Television Institute of India (FTII) on Tuesday confirmed that all of its academic activities — classes, workshops, film shootings — would remain shut till at least April 6, in the wake of the novel coronavirus spread.

“As had been advised by the Maharashtra and the Central government, we have announced that all classes and workshops and all academic activities will be postponed till April 6, to prevent the spread of the novel coronavirus infection,” Bhupendra Kainthola, the Film and Television Institute of India director, told TOI.

However, the date can also be extended, subject to instructions from the state government, he said.

It could cause delay of months with respect to the completion of the current semester as well as in the induction of the new batch, whose admission process is still underway, he said.

The admission test was conducted in February this year.

“The shootings of the diploma films will take place when the students come back after the academic activities resume. The classes for the current semester will also resume then. If there are any further postponements, the semester completion will be delayed because the courses need to be completed,” Kainthola said.

Title: West Bengal panel checks private hosps’ coronavirus preparedness
Content: KOLKATA: A team from the West Bengal Clinical Establishment Regulatory Commission (WBCERC) on Tuesday visited seven private hospitals along EM Bypass to inspect their preparedness in the wake of the coronavirus crisis.“All hospitals, including the private ones, must keep their facilities ready to receive and treat Covid-19 patients or the suspected cases, if the need arises. Our motive of visiting these hospitals is to see if they are prepared for this,” said Justice (retired) Ashim Kumar Banerjee, the chairperson of WBCERC.So far, the government hospitals — mostly Beliaghata ID Hospital — have been handling the suspected cases that has crossed 70. A few cases had earlier been referred from private hospitals in the city. Few days ago, chief minister Mamata Banerjee had asked the private hospitals to keep isolation wards ready and not to refuse admission to any Covid-19 suspect.Accompanied by members of the health panel, including doctors Makhanlal Saha and Maitreyi Banerjee, the chairperson went to seven hospitals to see they had kept the isolation wards ready and if facilities like hand sanitizers and masks were available, especially for frontline health workers. They also enquired if hospitals were playing their part in disseminating the correct information for awareness on the outbreak.“We found facilities at four hospitals satisfactory. But the rest have been suggested to revamp its preparedness immediately. We will revisit these three hospitals towards the end of this week to see if they have implemented our suggestions,” said Banerjee. The health panel will be visiting more hospitals on Wednesday.“We have a five-bed screening ward for Covid-19 suspected patients. The WBCERC delegation inspected it on Tuesday,” said a source at Rabindranath Tagore International Institute of Cardiac Sciences. While AMRI has two isolation beds in Mukundapur, its units in Dhakuria and Salt Lake have kept three and four isolation beds ready, respectively. “We have 10 isolation beds ready for Covid-19 suspected patients in addition to the isolation area in the emergency wing for screening of such patients,” said a source at Fortis Hospital.Peerless Hospital, Medica Superpecialty Hospital and Ruby General Hospital were the other hospitals the team inspected on Tuesday.

Title: MBBS students on way to Hyderabad stuck in Malaysia
Content:
HYDERABAD: More than 200 Telugu students who are studying MBBS in the Philippines are stuck in Kuala Lumpur airport in Malaysia on the way to India. The decision by the Director General of Civil Aviation ( DGCA ) restricting the travel of passengers from Philippines and Malaysia affected the students.

A parent of MBBS students, V Chittibabu, a police constable in Machilipatnam told TOI, “My daughter has been studying medicine in the Philippines for the past four years. Due to the coronavirus impact, the Philippines government closed all the colleges and declared a one-month holiday. My daughter, along with other students, boarded a flight in Manila and came to Kuala Lumpur on Tuesday afternoon. Some of the students are supposed to travel to Chennai and some students to Hyderabad. The Indian government announced a travel ban due to which all flights are cancelled. Many Indian students , most of them Telugu, are stuck there. We are worried. Indian government should interfere immediately and rescue them.”

In the circular, DGCA said, “The travel of passengers from Afghanistan, Philippines, Malaysia to India has been prohibited with immediate effect. No flight shall take off from these countries to India after 3.00 pm IST. The airline shall enforce this at the port of initial departure. The instructions shall be in force till March 31, 2020, and will be reviewed subsequently.”

Students and demanded the government make arrangements for their return in a special flight. Dr S Jaishankar, external affairs minister tweeted, “Appreciate the difficult situation of Indian students and other passengers waiting in transit in Kuala Lumpur airport. We have now approved Air Asia flights for you to Delhi and Vizag. These are tough times and you should understand the precautions. Please contact the airline."

Title: Mahe woman is Puducherry’s first coronavirus positive case
Content: PUDUCHERRY: The Union territory of Puducherry, spread in four different geographical locations, has reported its first coronavirus case on Tuesday. A 68-year-old woman from Mahe, Puducherry 's enclave in Kerala, who recently visited Gulf countries, has tested positive for Covid-19.Director of health and family welfare services S Mohankumar said the woman had returned to Mahe a week ago after visiting Gulf countries. She complained of fever and breathlessness. She was admitted to an isolation ward in Mahe government general hospital . Her swab samples were collected sent for medical tests to Kozhikode government general hospital. She tested positive on Tuesday.“We quarantined her in the Mahe Government General Hospital and kept her under observation for the past one week. The test results were out today (Tuesday). She tested positive. She is stable and responding well to the treatment,” said Mohankumar. Health directorate officials have started preparing the list of people who have come in contact with her.Meanwhile, chief minister V Narayanasam, who reviewed the preparedness of the government machinery to prevent the incidence and spread of coronavirus in the Union territory, told reporters that the government has declared a holiday for schools and colleges in the Union territory from Wednesday until March 31 to prevent an outbreak of the virus. However, public examinations for Classes 10, 11 and 12 will be conducted as per the schedule of the directorate of government examinations, Chennai or as per the schedule of the other boards. The government has directed the educational institutions not to hold any sports meets or other events inviting large gatherings.He said all the cinema theatres, malls and gyms will remain closed from Wednesday to March 31. The Sunday market will not function until further orders. He said the government will take a call on closing bars and restaurants in the next two days.Public meetings and processions by the political parties and non-political outfits have been banned. He said the government has earmarked Rs 11 crore for the department of revenue and disaster management and Rs 7.5 crore for the directorate of health and family welfare services to procure an adequate stock of life-saving drugs, masks and ensure availability of necessary equipment including ventilators at the hospitals. The government has made arrangements to screen the tourists and Indians from France reaching Puducherry, from Dubai, Abu Dhabi, Singapore and Malaysia reaching Karaikal, from Dubai reaching Mahe and from Saudi Arabia reaching Yanam for any infections.

Title: Puducherry: Centre proposes to set up residential schools for SC children
Content:
Representative image

PUDUCHERRY: The Union social justice and empowerment ministry has proposed to set up residential schools for scheduled castes (SC) children, ' Ambedkar Navodaya Vidyalaya ' from Classes VI to XII in the areas that have a larger concentration of SC population, said HRD minister Ramesh Pakriyal Nishank .

Replying to queries raised by Villupuram MP D Ravikumar in Lok Sabha, the minister said the proposed scheme aims to nurture and promote the talent of the meritorious students belonging to SC community. The scheme will provide them with the best opportunities and resources to improve their living standards. It will help them to compete with other students for higher education leading to a better choice of profession and employment opportunities, he said.

Ravikumar had earlier written to the Union social justice and empowerment minister Thaawarchand Gehlot urging him to establish Ambedkar Navodaya Vidyalaya in Villupuram. He said he came to know that the Centre has proposed to set up 150 Ambedkar Navodaya Vidyalayas for the SC students in the country in the pattern of Navodaya Vidyalaya.

He said SC community in Villupuram district, which comes under his parliamentary constituency, comprises 30% of the total population. According to the 2011 population census, Villupuram district had a population of 34,58,873 of which 10,15,716 are from SC community. "So, I request you to set up an Ambedkar Navodaya Vidyalaya in Villupuram district," he said.

He requested the minister to include skill development courses focusing on improving language and technological skills. He also urged him to introduce a comprehensive policy to deal 'discrimination in the campus' in these schools.

Title: Pune: Schools may promote students to next class
Content:
Representative image

Pune: After Kendriya Vidyalaya announced on Monday that children from Standard I to V would be promoted without taking exams, some schools in Pune have begun exploring such options while some have implemented it. Some schools have announced promotions based on average scores of two unit tests and one term exam.

City Pride School in Nigdi sent a message to parents of students studying in the school which stated: “Grade promotion decision for all students will be based on the average scores of the previous tests conducted during the academic year. Final exams shall not be conducted for this session in order to compensate for the lost time from the academic session.”

Director of the school, Ashwini Kulkarni said, “There is enough panic and fear and we do not want to add exam pressure to it. So the decision to promote students was taken so that parents are relieved.”

Many non-state board schools have just completed the exams or were in final phases while the exams of the state board schools were scheduled from March 30.

A decision on state board schools would be taken by the government. ICSE and CBSE schools have the liberty to take a call depending on the situation.

At BVP English Medium High School, Dhankawdi, two papers were to be conducted for all classes when the shut down was announced.

As per CBSE guidelines, schools have to follow a ‘no detention policy till class VIII’. “It is better that the students from classes I to VIII be promoted based on average scores. However, for classes IX and XI, balance two papers will be conducted and promotions granted as per the CBSE policy,” principal Simple Sahay said.

Rita Katawati, principal of Hutchings High School, said, “ We are giving promotions a thought.”

Varsha Kokil, principal of Mansukhbai Kothari National School, said, “Since the schools are closed till March 31, we are planning to calculate the average marks of one subject which students have missed. We are also considering online classes and teachers are working from home.”

Amruta Prabhu, principal of The HDFC School, Pune, said, “Being a CBSE affiliated school, we have finished our final exams last week as scheduled. The results are being tabulated which shall be posted on the parents’ portal on the scheduled date

Title: Covid-19: Corbett Tiger Reserve cancels 3,000 bookings
Content: Dehradun: After Uttarakhand reported its first Covid-19 positive case on Sunday, the state forest department announced on Tuesday that it would ban the entry of outsiders in forest areas. Also, the authorities at Corbett Tiger Reserve (CTR) have decided to cancel all the 3,000 bookings that they had received from March 18 to March 31, though the move would cause a cumulative loss of Rs 1 crore to the tiger reserve.CTR was opened in October 2019 for this season and since then it has already earned Rs 7 crore, with around 1.65 lakh tourists visiting different zones of the park, according to officials.While there are fewer advance booking at Rajaji Tiger Reserve (RTR) as compared to CTR , some in the former were cancelled by would-be visitors themselves in the wake of the coronavirus scare, said a source.Confirming the decision to cancel the bookings and refund the money, CTR director Rahul (who goes by his first name only), told TOI, “The move to cancel the bookings has been taken to ensure the safety of everyone. We have decided to cancel around 3,000 bookings and would refund amounts totalling to over Rs 1 crore.”Corbett is one of the most-visited tiger reserves in the country, and has the highest density of big cats (around 250, as per a 2018 estimate). Recent high-profile visitors to the park include the Swedish royal couple -- King Carl XVI Gustaf Folke Hubertus and his wife Queen Silvia Renate Sommerlath -- who came for a visit in December 2019.Director of Rajaji Tiger Reserve (RTR) PK Patro confirmed that a decision has been taken to ban the entry of outsiders into the reserve till the end of this month. According to a source, from November 2019 till date, 33,000 tourists visited RTR so far this season, and a revenue of Rs 68 lakh was generated.Meanwhile, chief wildlife warden Rajiv Bhartari said the forest department is hopeful that the coronavirus situation will be under control by March 31, after which visitors can visit the parks in the state. “The Government of India is constantly urging people to maintain social distance and avoid travel plans. Even the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI) has shut all its monuments and museums for the public. Therefore, it is time that we in Uttarakhand protect our world heritage sites, wildlife, workforce, as well as tourists, from the virus by closing these public zones,” said Bhartari.Incidentally, many states like Maharashtra and Kerala have also decided to ban the entry of outsiders in forest areas.

Title: PMC constitutes rapid response team & task force
Content:
PUNE: The civic body has formed a rapid response team (RRT) and city task force (CTF) to ensure better coordination between various departments and the district administration in dealing with the Covid-19 outbreak.

Municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad has instructed the teams to swing into action immediately.

RRT will comprise staff from the health, solid waste management and fire departments, and will work round-the-clock under the guidance of PMC’s disaster management cell. It will primarily be responsible for providing ambulance and medical services to patients.

For a few days, the team will also provide assistance to shift patients homes after the mandatory quarantine period or those who have been advised home quarantine.

“Both teams will play a vital role. The teams will alert other departments as per requirement or if there is anxiety among local citizens about shifting patients to their homes. Nine staffers each from three departments have been deployed round the clock. We expect real-time communication to avoid delays,” an official said.

The staffers have been given basic training in dealing with challenging situations and establishing communication with the departments concerned.

The city task force consists of 13 civic officials, who have been assigned various responsibilities — commissioning of quarantine and isolation wards, training staffers, maintaining data pertaining to coronavirus cases, coordinating with private hospitals and others. The role of the city task force will become important in the event of the number of positive cases going up.

Meanwhile, the district administration also has set up rapid response teams, which will work in coordination with departments at the district level and with the Pune and Pimpri Chinchwad civic bodies.

The teams will have to coordinate with tour and travel companies, police, airport authorities and the traffic department.

Title: When it comes to organ donation, Surat residents open up their hearts
Content: SURAT: A good heart, they say, is the best religion. And for Surtis, who firmly believe in the adage ‘Surat nu jaman and Kashi nu maran’ (eat/live in Suart and die in Kashi), living life kingsize and helping others live theirs too is a part of their religion called humanity.Hence, while living Surtis dole out cash and kind, and after they die, their vital organs, including the heart helps the lesser fortunate live, love, breathe and enjoy their share of life, too.No wonder then that Surat, which has carved a niche in organ donation in the country, also leads in heart donation in the state with 26 Surti hearts beating across the country today.So did 44-year-old Bipin Raghu Pradhan, who took his last breath on Saturday, but breathed fresh life in three others. The brain-dead donor’s exceptional benefaction includes his heart, kidneys, liver and eyes. With this, the native of Odisha also helped Surat donate the 26th heart since it started in 2015.According to the available data from December 2015 to March 15, 2020, altogether 32 heart donations have taken place in the state. Of these beating hearts, 26 are Surti hearts — the highest number of hearts donated by a city alone.“Ahmedabad-based CIMS hospital had received heart transplant permission in 2015 and have transplanted 32 hearts so far. Of these, 26 are from Surat, 3 from Ahmedabad and one each from Rajkot, Jamnagar and Bhavnagar ,” said Nilesh Mandlewala, president of Donate Life.“We have been actively creating awareness among people for cadaver donations for the past one decade and people have been generously donating vital organs. The biggest applause goes to the kin of these brain-dead donors, who keep their grief aside for the biggest humanitarian cause,” he added.Besides heart, Surat is also leading in eye and lungs donations. In 2019, total four lung donations were reported. Of the four lung donations, two were transplanted in Mumbai and two were transplanted in Bengaluru.

Title: Covid-19: Two IAS trainees put under isolation
Content: DEHRADUN: Two IAS trainees of Lal Bahadur Shastri National Academy of Administration (LBSNAA), one of whom had met the IFS trainee officer who was later found to be Covid-19 positive on Sunday, have been isolated by the institution. Director of LBSNAA Sanjeev Chopra told TOI that the institute is taking all precautionary measures.DEHRADUN"The two IAS trainees, who were roommates, are under self-isolation in a hostel room, which is not being used by anyone else. One of them had visited IGNFA over the weekend. They will have remote access to academic sessions within their rooms. Thus far, neither of the two has shown any symptoms of the disease," Chopra said.

Title: Kolkata: Coronavirus lockdown fear sets off panic buying of staple items
Content: KOLKATA: News of convenience stores in Covid-19 affected cities in India and abroad running out of essential staples and groceries has triggered panic buying in Kolkata with customers making bulk purchase fearing shutdown of stores.Branded standalone grocery stores in the city are seeing an unprecedented rush from the first hour itself. People are queueing up, waiting for the stores to open, so that they can pick up essential supplies before stocks are exhausted. Store employees say they are witnessing an unprecedented rush for foodgrains and essentials with people wanting to stock up for at least two months.Take the case of one hypermart on Free School Street that opens at 7am but gets reasonable footfalls only after 8 am. This one hour is spent in cleaning because of lack of footfall. “But for the past four-five days, we are seeing an unprecedented upward curve, not only in footfall but also in the quantity that people are buying. We were caught off guard initially because even when we had doubled our stocks, we were not being able to cope with the rush,” said an official.All varieties of rice, lentils, cooking oil, salt, sugar, flattened and puffed rice and biscuits are getting exhausted by the first half of the day in most stores. “We have noticed 100% rise in demand of foodgrains in some stores. This is a result of panic buying. Initially, we were not able to cope because we were following a regular replenishing pattern but we have more than doubled that as well,” said an official of a group that runs a chain of hypermarts.“In the past week, we have had to replenish store shelves more often. Even then, we have repeatedly run out of stock. This is true for not just hand sanitizers and personal hygiene products but also for staples and essential food items,” the head of a hypermarket chain that has over a dozen stores in Kolkata said.While the company had attempted to increase the inventory at the stores in Kolkata after witnessing unusual demand in Mumbai, Bengaluru, Delhi and other cities, even the new projections are failing in the wake of spiralling demand. “Customers are picking up as much groceries and staples in one visit as they usually did in four trips,” he said.At another hypermarket company, the depots are working overtime to ensure that the stores are replenished on time. “We usually do not stock up the store at night. But such is the rush during the day that we are having to run a night replenishment service too,” the operations head of the chain said.Though sales of essentials has shot up, it has not translated to higher footfalls or hike in revenue as customers are staying away from gourmet items and other personal care categories like cosmetics. However, the company has also witnessed a sharp uptake in essential groceries on its e-commerce platform and phone home delivery channels as well.

Title: Two Puducherry cops booked for extortion dismissed from job
Content:
Representative image

PUDUCHERRY: Two police constables, who were under suspension on charges of extorting money from a couple in a guesthouse, were dismissed from service on Monday.

Senior superintendent of police (law and order) Rahul Alwal said the constables - D Sathish Kumar attached to Grand Bazaar police station and K Suresh of the Indian Reserve Battalion force were 'dismissed' from service with immediate effect after a case was registered against them for their involvement in an offence amounting to 'moral turpitude in a disciplined force'. Preliminary inquiries revealed that the two constables, who were deputed to inquire into an altercation in a guesthouse in the town limits extorted money from a couple staying in the guesthouse on March 12 . The two were placed under suspension on March 14.

Grand Bazaar police registered a case under section 384 (punishment for extortion) of the Indian penal code (IPC) read with 34 (acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention) of the IPC on March 16 and launched a hunt for the absconding cops. If convicted the constables shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, or with fine, or with both.

The two were dismissed from service with immediate effect on March 17. "Since a case has been registered against the duo for their involvement in an offence amounting to moral turpitude in a disciplined force, they were dismissed from service with immediate effect," said Alwal in a release.

Title: Cinema halls, malls, gyms shut till March 31 in Nainital
Content: Nainital: As coronavirus cases continue to rise across the country, the Nainital district administration, on Tuesday, ordered closure of all the cinema halls, multiplexes, malls, clubs, discotheques, swimming pools, coaching institutes, and other such places where there are mass gatherings.This comes just two days after the state reported its first Covid-19 positive case. "The owners of all cinema halls/multiplexes, malls, clubs, discotheques, swimming pools, gyms, coaching institutes, nursing institutes, technical education institutes, and all those places where mass gatherings are expected will remain closed till March 31,” reads the order issued by district magistrate Savin Bansal.The order added that if anyone is found violating the order, they will be charged under section 188 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).Earlier, the administration had announced that all haat markets in Haldwani will remain shut. “The decision has been taken in view of rising coronavirus cases across the country. Though no positive case has yet been reported from Kumaon region, these measures have been taken so that people stay away from crowded spaces. We will review the situation in a few days and see if the order is to be extended further,” Bansal said.Meanwhile, Kumaon commissioner Rajeev Rautela directed all district magistrates of the region to distribute informative materials regarding coronavirus among locals and ensure that regional cable TV channels are informing people about tackling the fatal disease.“There is no need to create panic about the disease. We have directed all DMs of the region to create control rooms in their headquarters to closely monitor the situation. The DMs have also been ordered to distribute informative materials and to make sure that regional cable TV channels and news networks are telling people how to stay safe from the disease," Rautela added.Meanwhile, a workshop was also conducted by officials of the health department and World Health Organisation for police officers, homeguards, and personnel of SDRF and PAC regarding tackling the disease.

Title: Last meeting done for all but 1 convict
Content:
New Delhi: The family members of three Nirbhaya convicts have already had their “last meeting” , when they were allowed to meet in a closed room and touch each other . However, Akshay Thakur’s family is yet to come and his wife and parents have been asked to meet him by Thursday, a Tihar Jail source said.

The four death-row convicts in the 2012 Nirbhaya gang-rape-and-murder case are scheduled to be hanged on Friday.

An official said the family members of Pawan Gupta and Vinay Sharma met them on February 29. Both of them broke down and jail officials had to console Sharma after he started crying inconsolably, he added.

The other convict, Mukesh Singh, mostly kept quiet during his meeting on March 2 while his family members had occasional emotional outbursts, a source said. Singh apparently kept assuring them that he still had legal options left to save himself from the gallows. The high court on Wednesday rejected Singh’s plea claiming he was not in Delhi when Nirbhaya was gang-raped in a moving bus in south Delhi.

Even after the “last meeting”, the families are allowed their weekly interactions with the convicts, but no one-on-one meeting is permitted.

Thakur, meanwhile, had told the Tihar authorities that his family members would meet him on Wednesday. An official said he seemed to have lost hope that his family members would meet him after his wife decided to seek a divorce.

“We facilitated a phone call between him and his wife after this. He then claimed that his wife would come and meet him on Wednesday,” said the official. His wife, Punita Devi (29), has filed a divorce case in a court in Bihar’s Aurangabad, saying she doesn’t want to live the rest of her life as a widow.

Meanwhile, the preparations for the hanging are in full swing and dummy executions have been carried out. Officials are also keeping a tab on the health of the four men and additional staff have been deployed outside their solitary cells to avoid any untoward incident.

Another accused, Ram Singh, committed suicide inside Tihar, while a juvenile has been freed after serving his term at a Home.

Title: Covid-19: ISB stops classes
Content: HYDERABAD: Indian School of Business ( ISB ) on Tuesday said it has suspended classes at its Hyderabad and Mohali campuses as a safety measure against coronavirus.“As precautionary measure and keeping in view the safety of everyone, classes have been suspended and all the students have been advised to vacate the campuses by Wednesday, March 18,” ISB said in a statement.

Title: TS power employees cry foul over taking back Andhra Pradesh staffers
Content: HYDERABAD: The row over division of electricity employees between Telangana and Andhra Pradesh power utilities refuses to go away. Employees from Telangana are firm that the TRS government should not take back 584 employees of AP into Telangana power utilities.Claiming injustice was done to Telangana in the allocation of employees by Justice Dharmadhikari Committee, 11 employee associations began a relay hunger strike at Vidyut Soudha on Tuesday. The associations formed a Telangana state power employees’ joint action committee (TSPEJAC) in pursuit of their demands.“The allocation of employees based on supplementary report of the one-man committee is totally against the interests of Telangana. We are upset and agitated over the injustice in the allocation of employees,” JAC leader Ratnakaar said.The Supreme Court had appointed the Dharmadhikari Committee to find a lasting solution to bifurcation issues between the two states. But the committee could not resolve the issue as the AP government had refused to take 613 employees allotted to it. The Telangana employees’ unions argue that allocation of 584 additional employees to the state is against the modalities fixed by the committee.JAC leaders said allocation of 1,157 AP-native relieved employees was done as per the final report of the committee in December 2019 by following the guidelines. But, modalities were not followed by AP power utilities in allocating 584 employees to Telangana, they contended.The JAC leaders urged the CMD of Telangana State Genco and TSTransco D Prabhakar Rao to not accept joining of 655 employees (584 and 71 additional employees) relieved by AP power utilities until a final decision is arrived on allocation of 584 employees.JAC leaders also faulted the committee for not involving Telangana in identifying the 584 employees, while allowing a member from AP.

Title: Four minors burnt alive while playing in Rajasthan's Churu
Content:
Representative image

JAIPUR: Four minor children charred to death when the hut in which they were playing caught fire in Sardarshahar of Churu district on Tuesday. The cause of fire is yet to be ascertained.

According to Sardarshahar circle officer Girdhari Lal, three children (two brothers and their sister) and one cousin sister died in the incident. "The police are investigating into the matter. We did not find any source of fire. There is no electricity supply or stove in the hut,” he said.

One Lal Chand, who is the uncle of the children, told police that they were alone when the incident happened.

“Chand and his brothers have several kutcha houses. At the time of the incident, the elders of the family were not inside the hut. The villagers rushed to douse the fire, but all efforts went in vain. All the four children charred to death,” the officer said.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Bhopal police cautions people against cheats posing as ‘sanitisation’ workers
Content: BHOPAL: City police on Tuesday issued an advisory cautioning residents against miscreants, who might come to their houses or offices in the name of sanitising the place, in the wake of the coronavirus threat.“No government agency or organisation has been assigned the task of sanitising residence of offices of people,” says the advisory, adding that residents should exercise caution and warn their family and friends to not allow any person or group to enter which is offering to sanitise their home/officeAny information about such groups or persons can be reported to the nearest police station.ASP Sandesh Jain said, some people were cheated in other states using this method. As of now, no such case has been reported in Bhopal , but the police has released the advisory as a precautionary measure.BOX-DIG Irshad Wali on Tuseday took a briefing of policemen deployed in Vidhan Sabha duty at control room and asked them not to panic over fear of Coronavirus but maintain caution. He told the policemen to continue their respective duties vigilantly and take precaution. He said that awareness and precaution are necessarry to counter the problem.DIG Wali advised the policemen to maintain distance from unnecessarry people and take precautionary measures like wearing a mask and washing hands at regular intervals. He asked the policemen not to pay attention on rumours about Coronavirus being spread on social media and aware people about it.

Title: 131 passengers, close contacts advised home quarantine
Content:
Nagpur: The divisional commissioner office on Tuesday said it has advised self-isolation to 131 first-point contacts and passengers who have landed in the city since last week when the first novel coronavirus positive case was reported here.

The administration would now keep a check on these people through local police stations, beside stamping ‘home quarantine ’ on their hands.

On Monday, state health minister Rajesh Tope had said that flyers advised self-isolation would be stamped to deter them from stepping out. Over 600 people from the state have been directed to be home quarantined.

Of the 131 persons, 35 have completed 14 days in self-isolation as per the data released by the commissioner’s office.

Divisional commissioner Sanjeev Kumar told TOI, “Besides stamping, a list of such people is also being forwarded to local police stations. People can report in case they find ‘home quarantined’ persons loitering or mixing with others.”

Even as the divisional commissioner’s office came out with a detailed list of number of people being quarantined after reaching Nagpur airport from different entry points, there remains ambiguity over the home quarantine process and guidelines among officials as well as citizens.

When TOI checked with officials manning the district administration control room, they sounded unaware about the ‘home quarantine’ advisory. Despite clearing asking if international flyers were being stamped, they said first one has to go for a test only after which ‘home quarantine’ can be advised.

“Suspect has to be kept separate and the room has to be hygienic. He shouldn’t be allowed to mingle with other family members. If they have any kind of fever, cough or sickness, get them to one of the government hospitals for a test. You can also call and inform NMC helpline for further assistance,” an official said.

Kumar clarified that no one has to go to Indira Gandhi Government Medical College and Hospital or Government Medical College and Hospital. “All such persons have to stay back at home only. In case they are found to be out, police action under section 188 of the IPC can be taken,” he said.

On Tuesday, the health officials screened 22 passengers at the airport here. Of these, seven were quarantined at the MLA hostel. So far, 1,004 have been screened of which the 131 were advised self-isolation and total 13 at MLA hostel.

During the day, the commissioner held a meeting with district collector Ravindra Thakre, deputy director of health services Sanjay Jaiswal, DCP Shweta Khedkar, DCP Vikram Sali, PWD executive engineer J Bhanuse, revenue deputy commissioner Sudharkar Telang, and civil surgeon Devendra Paturkar .

The meeting was called in the wake of increase in number of incoming international passengers, especially those coming from notified nations.

In figures

People quarantined | 131

People completed 14-day quarantine | 35

Passengers screened at airport on Tuesday | 22

Total flyers screened | 1,004

Flyers quarantined at MLA Hostel on Tuesday | 7

Patients quarantined so far at MLA hostel | 13

Title: Telangana: Farmers with Rs 25,000 loan to get waiver in one instalment
Content: Hyderabad: Farmers with outstanding loans up to Rs 25,000 will get loan waiver in one go, while those having loans in excess of Rs 25,000 and up to Rs 1lakh will get the facility in four instalments.Issuing fresh guidelines for implementation of the loan waiver scheme, the government on Tuesday said that unlike the last cycle, wherein farmers having loans of Rs 25,000 got waiver in four instalments, this time they would get the benefit in one.There was, however, no change in each family getting the benefit up to a maximum of Rs 1 lakh, which was popular in the last cycle as well.A major change, as announced by chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao, is that the government would hand over account payee cheques to the farmers instead of sending the loan waiver benefit into their accounts. These cheques are different from the Rythu Bandhu cheque where farmers, by producing the cheque with identity proof could take out the amount from any bank.“The government has ensured that farmers withdraw cash from their accounts only. The measure was adopted to avoid misuse of cheques,” an official explained.The non-performing asset (NPA) accounts have been made ineligible in this cycle, as reported these columns earlier. It would mean that those who have outstanding loans before April 1, 2014, will not be eligible to get the waiver.Farmers, who have outstanding loans between April 1, 2014, and December 11, 2018, will only be able to avail the benefit. The government had earlier not mentioned the date from which outstanding loan would be considered but only mentioned a cut-off date.Many farmers who have not cleared their loans for more than a decade were also getting the waiver in the last cycle, which won’t happen this time. Banks consider accounts having loans which are not paid for three seasons or more than one-and-a-half year as an NPA.In view of several court cases pending earlier on restructured loans, the government has incorporated the new clause this time, officials pointed out. Now, all the restructured loans (loan settlement arrived between banks and farmers on outstanding loan for payment due to natural calamities) will not get the benefit.The government is creating a portal where the pattadar passbooks, Aadhaar and ration cards details of eligible farmers will be maintained.

Title: CAT upholds former AP intel chief ’s suspension
Content:
Hyderabad: The Central Administrative Tribunal , Hyderabad, on Tuesday upheld the suspension of Andhra Pradesh’s former Intelligence chief AB Venkateswara Rao .

It also said the state government has powers to place an All India Services (AIS) officer under suspension as per the amended rule of 1975.

Dismissing Rao’s contention that he was suspended by the AP government without any proof or material, CAT said the government had placed him under suspension after coming across prima facie material. “Hence, at this stage, it cannot be said that there is no material warranting his suspension,” a bench of tribunal chairman Justice L Narasimha Reddy and member BV Sudhakar said after hearing the arguments of the suspended IPS officer and the government.

Rao was suspended for his alleged role in awarding a tender pertaining to procurement of security equipment for police personnel and charged with short-listing an Israeli firm which had business links with an enterprise floated by his son.

The bench brushed aside the contention of Rao that without a charge memo, he cannot be suspended.

The bench said it was not looking at the sufficiency of the material against the petitioner which was not required here.

The bench also did not agree with the contention of the petitioner that he need not be suspended because he was sent out of police department in June 2018 and hence he was not in a position to influence the inquiry against him.

Rao’s cousel argued that the government did not intimate the Centre within 48 hours of his suspension as required under AIS rules and said there was a gap of more than 48 hours in intimation. The bench did not agree with this and said the rule is directory and not mandatory.

The bench said the Centre had to approve the suspension within 60 days as otherwise the suspension would lapse. “In this case, the Centre had already approved the suspension (on March 7,” the bench added.

Title: No fleeing isolation, Asha staff on watch
Content:
Vijayawada: Amidst the coronavirus scare, the state health department has decided to entrust the responsibility of ensuring that all foreign returnees are on home isolation to Asha (accredited social health activist) workers .

In a circular issued by the department of health and family welfare to the district medical and health officers on Monday, the Asha workers were directed to report on the status of home isolation of incoming international passengers to medical officers concerned twice-a-day.

Meanwhile, ANMs (auxiliary nursing midwifery) will be responsible for monitoring the Asha workers. The medical officers concerned, ANMs and Asha workers will be held responsible for any lapse in the home isolation process, which is said to be an effective precautionary measure to protect others from contracting COVID-19.

According to estimates, about 6,000 people returned to Andhra Pradesh from aboard in the recent times. But the huge network of ward/village volunteers, ward/village secretaries, Anganwadi workers, Asha workers and other field-level staff will prove to be an advantage for the state government to monitor and contain the spread of the disease.

The state election commission on Tuesday clarified that the model code of conduct will not be applicable for any measures taken by the state government to contain the spread of COVID-19.

Special chief secretary (medical and health and family welfare) KS Jawahar Reddy has asked people, who have returned from COVID-19 affected countries in the recent times, to self-isolate irrespective of whether they have the symptoms of the disease or not.

“We have identified 840 foreign returnees from coronavirus-hit areas. While about 560 persons have been kept on home isolation, the 28-day observation period was over for 250 persons after being overseas. Nearly 30 persons have been admitted to isolation wards and are under the supervision of the medical personnel,” said Jawahar Reddy.

The special chief secretary asked the public to be wary of rumours related to coronavirus circulating on social media platforms. “We will initiate stern action against those spreading misinformation and fake news on social media and through other means,” said Jawahar Reddy.

Even though the state government has not declared holidays for educational institutions, several schools and other organisations in Vijayawada and Visakhapatnam have declared holidays for the next few days till the situation returns to normal.

The Simachalam Devasthanam in Visakhapatnam, with the assistance of a private hospital, has conducted an awareness programme on the preventive measures of the pandamic and distributed protective masks to devotees on Tuesday. The temple also cancelled all the ‘Arjitha Sevas’ and has only been permitting devotees for ‘Laghu Darshan’.

Title: CAT takes judicial note of suspension of IPS officer
Content:
Hyderabad: The Central Administrative Tribunal at Hyderabad on Monday took judicial note of the central government’s order that confirmed the suspension of Andhra Pradesh’s former Intelligence chief AB Venkateswara Rao .

A bench comprising tribunal chairman Justice L Narasimha Reddy and member BV Sudhakar said it would pronounce its judgment in the case filed by Rao challenging his suspension ordered by the Andhra Pradesh government for alleged irregularities he committed in the past in procuring security equipment for the state police. TNN

Title: Online stores see a surge as Bhopalis stock up
